webTitle: Rot sets in with the sack race

fields.headline: Rot sets in with the sack race
fields.trailText: How is this country ever going to succeed at sport if ill-natured triumphalism, single-mindedness and necessary brutality is not given a place at school sports days?
fields.body:
Last week I attended one of the jewels in the British sporting calendar, the village first-school sports day. It was a sunny afternoon, the attendance was good and all the children got a chance to take part. As the afternoon progressed I watched kindly mums wink at six-year-olds who had just finished last in that ultimate test of poise and speed, the beanbag-on-the-head race; while grey-haired grandads exhorted nervous competitors in the year-three skipping event not to worry, "It's only a bit of fun".

To many the scene might have seemed heartwarming. To those of us forced by professional considerations to cast a coldly objective eye over things, however, it was simply another occasion to shake our heads in despair.

Bluntly, we are throwing good money after bad in coaching British children because it is plainly British parents who are the most in need of training. How is a nation of fair-minded easy-going individuals such as those I observed ever going to breed a generation of champions? Where was the ill-natured triumphalism, the single-mindedness, the I-don't-care-what-you-want-this-is-what-you- need brutality? And why was I the only father present carrying a banner reading "Eat My Daughter's Dust, Pondlife"? When will Britain learn that we cannot produce our own Mary Pierces unless we produce a few Jim Pierces to yell at them first?

The whole happy-go-lucky malaise that grips British sport was neatly summed up for me by the behaviour of one of the entrants in the parents' sack race. As he stood on the start line it was plain that the depth of the sack he had been handed meant he would have to bend double to grip the top of it, thus severely restricting his ability to bounce. I don't think we need to ask how Damir Dokic would have reacted in such a situation. Yet did the man hurl abuse at the head teacher over the unfair advantage that had been handed to his shorter competitors? Did he lie across the middle of the track and refuse to budge until a longer sack was found? Of course not. He simply did his best and finished third.

Even then he might have redeemed himself by venting his frustration on a passing dinner lady. Instead he laughed and joked with the woman who plays piano for music and movement. In similar circumstances I doubt if you would have got a wisecrack out of Stefano Capriati.

With this sort of sloppy, uncaring example being set to our youngsters, is there any wonder we are the softest touch on the international sporting scene? Or that attempts to gain that little professional edge by the surreptitious use of chewing gum during the year-four egg-and-spoon race were so conspicuous by their absence?

As it stands at the moment it is plain to me that British parents simply lack the required streak of obsessive madness (or "fully focused competitive attitude" as we sportswriters prefer to call it) necessary to power the production line of winners our nation expects and demands.

Fifteen minutes after the last event had finished my daughter emerged beaming delightedly from the school entrance, a red plastic star hanging from a ribbon around her neck. "I got this for trying so hard," she squeaked proudly.

Other British parents might have allowed themselves a fond smile, or swallowed back an emotional lump in the throat. Luckily I am made of sterner stuff.

Violently I ripped the plastic star from its ribbon and hurled it over a hedge. "You get nothing for coming second and even less for coming second last in the nursery-section 50-metre hopping race, babycakes," I yelled. "You're four years old. From now on you take care of business or change your act." And with that I turned on my heel and marched away.

My daughter has been crying intermittently ever since. But in the long term I know both she and the British public will be grateful to me.

fields.headline: Fibre-optics deal sets $41bn record
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The world's largest technology merger to date, worth $41bn (£27bn), was unveiled yesterday. JDS Uniphase, the acquisitive fibre-optics manufacturer, announced an agreed all-share takeover of an American competitor, SDL.
fields.body:
The world's largest technology merger to date, worth $41bn (£27bn), was unveiled yesterday. JDS Uniphase, the acquisitive fibre-optics manufacturer, announced an agreed all-share takeover of an American competitor, SDL.

The size of the deal in an already concentrated market is expected to lead to in-depth scrutiny by US anti-monopoly regulators. Shares in JDS fell 15% to just over $98 after the deal was announced yesterday morning, meaning the all- share offer was valued at closer to $35bn by midday in New York.

They later recovered some ground after senior executives at both companies said they were optimistic that an agreement could be reached with the US justice department.

JDS, itself formed from last year's merger of JDS FITEL and Uniphase, has bought 17 companies since 1995 - four of them in the past six months. In the process, it has transformed itself from a tiny manufacturer to an increasingly dominant supplier of fibre-optic parts to communications equipment companies such as Lucent and Nortel.

US regulators have taken more interest in the industry over recent years as high-speed data networks become increasingly important to meet the demand for internet-based services. The fibre-optics components industry is also characterised by a handful of groups acting as both customers and competitors.

Anthony Muller, chief financial officer of JDS Uniphase, said the company was "reasonably familiar" with the reg ulatory review process. "We are not sure exactly what to expect. But we do not anticipate any divestitures."

Yesterday's deal dwarfs JDS's $20bn purchase of E-Tek, another competitor, which was completed two weeks ago. In order to win regulatory approval for that deal, after concerns were raised about the fact that both companies shared several customers, JDS agreed to some restrictions.

Mike Foster, chief financial officer of SDL, said: "We believe that there are acceptable solutions, if needed, for any [regulatory] concerns." Analysts believe that regulators may want the merged group to agree guaranteed pricing or supply deals with some customers.

The components industry is notoriously wary about revealing market share statistics. Mr Foster at SDL said yesterday: "This business is extremely secretive."

Analysts have estimated that the biggest area of overlap is in the manufacturing of pump lasers, where the combined group could dominate up to 50% of the global marketplace.

Some Wall Street analysts raised concerns over the price paid for SDL, which at 3.8-for-one represented a 50% premium over the target's closing share price on Friday. SDL made a $29.9m profit on sales of $187m last year. It said yesterday that it expected 2000 sales to reach $448m.

David Wang, analyst at PaineWebber, the US investment bank, said he was relatively optimistic that the deal would gain approval. "I think it's a fair price. It's not super-cheap but it makes sense for both companies."

Jozef Straus, the black beret-wearing head of JDS, said that the merger would allow new technologies to be developed and brought to market more quickly.

Donald Scifres, SDL's chief executive who will become co-chairman of the merged entity, said his company had been in talks with another group before he started negotiating with JDS. Analysts believed the rival was Corning, the US manufacturer. As well as agreeing to the JDS merger, SDL has agreed to pay JDS $1bn if the deal falls through.

webTitle: Ebookers denies running short of cash

fields.headline: Ebookers denies running short of cash
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ebookers, the internet travel company, yesterday insisted it does not have cash difficulties.
fields.body:
Ebookers, the internet travel company, yesterday insisted it does not have cash difficulties.

The London-based company was responding to speculation that it was on the verge of running out of cash.

In a statement Ebookers insisted it was not in the midst of a cash crisis but added that it is talking to a number of parties about raising fresh funds.

Chief executive Dinesh Dhamija said: "We said when we floated in November that we would be raising new money in the second half of this year.

"That strategy has not altered and we are confident that despite uncertain market conditions we will be able to give further news of our funding when we announce our second-quarter results on July 17."

Shares in Ebookers, which are listed on Nasdaq and Frankfurt's Neuer Markt, fell 17% on Friday following newspaper articles in Germany and Britain about internet companies' burn rates.

The stories highlighted Ebookers as one likely to run out of cash by the end of the year. They also speculated that cooling of investor interest in dot.coms meant Ebookers would struggle to raise money.

Eboookers raised $60m at its flotation, had $32m left at the end of March and is burning about $3m per month.

The company's advisers at JP Morgan are said to be talking to potential partners, ranging from telecoms and hotel firms to distribution agents and internet service providers, about providing cash in return for shares.

Mr Dhamija, who founded off-line travel company Flightbookers and owns the majority of Ebookers, is prepared to put new funds into the company and is confident some concrete news can be presented at next Monday's half-year results presentation.

Ebookers is also likely to use the meeting to emphasise the underlying profitability of subsidiaries it has bought in 11 countries.

Analysts at Merrill Lynch say they are confident Ebookers will attract the capital it needs but are not advising new investors to buy in at present.

fields.headline: Tradepoint tackles Europe
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pressure mounted on the London and German stock exchanges last night to cement their planned merger after Tradepoint, the London exchange's tiny rival, linked with the Swiss stock exchange in a fresh attempt to take them on in a wider European market.
fields.body:
Pressure mounted on the London and German stock exchanges last night to cement their planned merger after Tradepoint, the London exchange's tiny rival, linked with the Swiss stock exchange in a fresh attempt to take them on in a wider European market.

Even without the Swiss link, Tradepoint, which has captured only 0.5% of trading in British shares, pressed ahead with the launch of its market in "pan-European" shares yesterday, listing 230 shares from Germany, France and Spain for instance.

In what Richard Kilsby, chief executive of Tradepoint, saw as a good omen for its attempt to trade non-British shares, the electronic exchange at one point yesterday completed almost as many trades in a German blue chip as Frankfurt.

While Tradepoint, which is backed by some of the major investment banks, has yet to make much in-road in the British market, Mr Kilsby last night set an ambitious target to capture up to 20% of all the trade in major European blue chips by the end of next year.

The link between Tradepoint and the SWX exchange of Switzerland to create Virt-X comes at a time of intensifying competition among Europe's exchanges to win business in a perceived change in investors attitudes to investing in shares. As a result of the introduction of the euro, major institutional investors cannot be deterred on currency-risk grounds alone from buying shares in Deutsche Telekom or France Telecom as both are traded in euros. The new Virt-X, which is expected to boost Tradepoint by bringing in the new Swiss trading system and the investors who trade through the Swiss exchange, is expected to be ready for trading early next year and may beat its rivals off the starting blocks.

Mr Kilsby, who said Tradepoint had a record day yesterday surpassing its previous record of £72m worth of trade in a day, said he felt sympathy for the executives trying to push through the German and London alliance, which is expected to cost its members £75m to implement.

The London stock exchange refused to comment on Virt-X yesterday. One market expert commented though that one concern inside the exchange might be that Virt-X, or even Tradepoint, will start to grab market share in the way that the German futures exchange stole business from under the nose of the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange last year.

Mr Kilsby cited figures yesterday which showed that for two hours on the first day of its "pan-European" market, 53,000 Deutsche Telekom shares had traded through Tradepoint at the same time that 59,000 had traded in Frankfurt. "That's more than reasonable," he said.

Already overcoming some of the problems faced by the London-Frankfurt alliance, Virt-X will be regulated from London by the financial services authority and integrate not only its trading systems but its settlement and clearing systems for shares too.

fields.headline: All hail the godfather
fields.standfirst:
James Brown
Brixton Academy, London
****
fields.trailText:
James Brown
Brixton Academy, London
****
fields.body:
James Brown
Brixton Academy, London
****

There are times when music is the only thing that matters, and that's no cliche, as James Brown would attest. So far, the new decade hasn't brought him much luck, but from the moment a band member roars his introduction - "He gave the world some of the greatest soul music! James Brown! JAMES BROWN!" - the grim details count for nothing.

Bounding on, perfectly coiffured, in a bright red suit with silver sequinned lapels, Brown radiates delight. He engages in dance competitions and effervescent banter with his band. You watch him dance cheek-to-cheek with one of his female backing singers during Only You, shimmy his hips with another during Sex Machine, and carry a third halfway across the stage, and all you can think is, I hope I have such stamina when I'm 67. The last thing you remember is that Brown has had to cancel a date on this tour because he's being sued for sexual harassment.

A show like this makes Brown feel like a rarity among pop's icons: he knows what his fans want to hear and he lives up to their expectations, playing songs that are 30 or 40 years old as if they were still fresh to him. The band help considerably, from the tickly riff in Papa's Got a Brand New Bag and the funk rhythms of Payback to the rich introduction to It's a Man's, Man's Man's World, the playing is impeccable. Brown relishes every note he hears and is constantly fetching musicians to his microphone to play solos, gazing appreciatively at the percussionist, or stepping back to let someone else show off their vocal skills.

Sometimes his admiration for his band goes so far that this could be a tribute act. It is a gut-wrenching disappointment to see him hand over the microphone to practically everyone else on stage rather than sing the verses to It's a Man's, Man's, Man's World. Similarly, there is something odd about the most impressive scream of the night coming from the keyboard player.

Perhaps this is the most appealing thing about him. Not only is Brown still squealing, grunting, sliding and doing the splits, but he behaves as though he is just one of many stars here, as though several thousand people aren't shouting his name alone.

James Brown plays the Essential Festival, Brighton on Sunday. Box office: 09068 230 190.

fields.headline: The manic magic man
fields.trailText:
An Evening with Jerry Sadowitz
Soho Theatre, London
****
fields.body:
An Evening with Jerry Sadowitz
Soho Theatre, London
****

Conjuring cuts two ways. Some magicians start with dexterity and graft on the skills of presentation later; some are actors and comedians who learn to do tricks. But there is a third way - what we might call the Sadowitz way. Jerry Sadowitz is a wonderfully funny comic, the foul-mouthed fount of Glaswegian ad libs. He is also a wizard with a pack of cards. Nothing up my sleeve, he tells us, mordantly, but puncture marks.

The sense of danger is constant. He looks like a mix of Marty Feldman and Bob Geldof and he stalks his audience relentlessly. Don't sit in the front row, unless you're a masochist. Don't leave halfway through for a pee, unless you want the chain pulling over your retreating head. No wonder his straighter forays into TV have mostly been short and sour. Even Channel 5 chief, David Elstein, must have bitten his nails over this one.

And yet the knowledge that Sadowitz, freewheeling away, couldn't make it in conventional television, gives the evening a special edge. The Soho Theatre is made for close-up magic, the seating so steep that you seem to hover over the tiny stage, the simple table and the manic man in black. You can see everything - the coins flying from hand to hand, the fiver that becomes a tenner, the cards he plays with a maestro's fervour.

A spotty youth volunteers to do a bit of shuffling. "You got blood all over your nose." "I know. One of my spot's burst." "That is disgusting." Find a weak spot and pick at it. Oddly, though, there is a vulnerability which saves Sadowitz time and again. Sometimes the gags are ferocious (he does a wicked David Copperfield) but sometimes they dry up and he turns unexpectedly in on himself, talking loneliness and a God (if any). He hammers at the boundaries.

The magic itself is better than fine, a constant flurry of swiftness that is worth the price of admission alone. But it is also the grounding of normality which keeps him together. There is nothing of conventional show business in his performance. "It's awful hot in here tonight," he says, and just stops. He knows that one card trick is much like another, a descant of deftness that can't be stretched. In any rational world, Sadowitz would be star. But this is an irrational world and dominating it is enough.

Further performances from July 13 to 16. Box office: 020-7478 0100.

He knows that one card trick is much like another, a descant of deftness that can't be stretched. In any rational world, Sadowitz would be star. But this is an irrational world and dominating it is enough. Further performances from July 13 to 16. Box office: 020-7478 0100.

webTitle: To share or not to job share

fields.headline: To share or not to job share
fields.trailText: 11 July: I want to work time until my son starts school but my boss says I have to come in full time or accept less money on a job share
fields.body:
The problem

I wish to extend my part-time hours for a further five months until my son starts school. My post is full time but I reduced my hours initially for 3 years. My boss now wants me to work full time or will make me job share. I would like to care for my son two days a week until he starts school in January 2001 and then I will work full time.

The solution

I have to say that I don't think your boss is being unreasonable. S/he has allowed you to reduce your hours for a three year period and now that this agreement is coming to its end, wishes to change it. Your boss probably realises that your reduced hours are not enough to allow her to employ someone else to do the work you cannot do, whereas if you went part-time, s/he would be better able to ensure that the full work-load was covered by two people. So, s/he is offering you the choice of full-time or part-time, both of which would enable her to ensure the work is done.

The only course of action then left is for you to appeal to your boss's good nature and ask for a five month extension. You will need to arrange a meeting with him/her and sit down and explain that whilst you are grateful for the opportunity to reduce your hours so far, and you appreciate their need to have you either full or part-time you are requesting a short and finite stay of execution. It would probably be in their interest to allow this since it would save them recruiting and training costs plus, if you are forced to go part-time, you are more likely to start looking for a more flexible job.

Perhaps a compromise can be reached, so that you gradually increase your hours in the run-up to January, by which time you will be full-time again. Remind your boss about your loyal years of service and how you are likely to repay the flexibility you have been offered when you needed it by increased loyalty and hard work in the future.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: A very Brazilian seduction
fields.standfirst:
Da Lata
Jazz Cafe, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Da Lata
Jazz Cafe, London
*****
fields.body:
The superb quality of Da Lata's material isn't a question of beginner's luck. The group's debut, Songs From the Tin, may be one of the most atmospheric Latin-based albums released this year, but DJ Patrick Forge and multi-instrumentalist Chris Franck's Brazilian love affair began eight years ago with Batu. Little known outside the jazz dance fraternity, Batu went on to record two memorable singles, Earth Song and Seasons on My Mind. Since then, Forge has pursued his DJ career and Franck became involved with Smoke City, who enjoyed a hit with the chill-out classic, Underwater Love.

For Da Lata, the pair are joined by Brazilian singer Lillian Chachin and the Portuguese percussionist Oli Albergaria Savill. Tonight they were augmented by Tristan Banks playing trap drums and the talented saxophonist Nathan Haines.

The band strove to be respectful to Brazil's strong musical traditions, but not slavishly so. They proved that there are new and palatable ways of bridging the hi-tech and older styles - something that other dance producers seduced by Brazil's wildly eclectic music should take heed of. Da Lata showed how it should be done, with an understated performance that stirred up genuine hysteria.

Live, their highly creative concoction of bossa nova rhythms and dance production was both rootsy and sophisticated. Chachin has a glorious voice. Sensual, shapely and beguiling, it's perfect for the smooth and lovely intonations of songs like Borbeleta and Rainsong. Rio Vida, an uptempo track, took the music deeper into jazz territory, with Haines showing off his virtuosity on alto saxophone against Franck's lilting guitar.

Every now and then, the percussionists let rip and Chachin punctuated the music with an ethereal phrase, varying the texture with new melodies. Despite the absence of Forge's flourishes, there was always a compulsive underlying dance beat, and the set's flow allowed you to see how common rhythms are subtly transformed between genres.

Their version of Pra Manha was particularly good. Released in 1998, it became a favourite among DJs around the world. Chachin took the song to another level, her melancholic poise and languidness perfectly matching the frenetic pace of the conga shuffle and Franck's flowing, tightly plucked guitar. The result was music of transcendental beauty that inspired a feeling of longing. Da Lata's calming sonority and resonant purity induces a therapeutic effect, whether it makes you swoon or dance.

fields.headline: 16 broken rules cost IFAs £125,000
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: One of Britain's largest networks of independent financial advisers has been fined £125,000 by a City regulator for a string of rule breaches.
fields.body:
One of Britain's largest networks of independent financial advisers has been fined £125,000 by a City regulator for a string of rule breaches.

The fine handed down to Coventry-based Berkeley Independent Advisers by the Personal Investment Authority is the largest imposed on an IFA firm for 18 months. It was found to have breached 16 of the PIA's rules and regulations, the most serious of which related to its "failure to adequately monitor" the conduct of its member firms.

The PIA said Berkeley Independent was found to have not carried out the necessary visits to its member firms within the correct timescales and to have not done enough to follow up reported problems or ensure that they were put right.

Other rule breaches concerned problems identified with record-keeping, the handling of complaints, the training and competence of staff and supervisors, and the administration of broker funds.

Berkeley Independent is Britain's fifth largest IFA network, with 235 so-called appointed representatives and 405 registered advisers.

Managing director Martin Banbury said the company had accepted the findings of the PIA, which related to business transacted in 1995 and 1996. "Obviously steps have already been taken to improve and we continue to develop sufficiently robust procedures to ensure that we meet the requirements of the regulator."

webTitle: Murdoch to take over Fourth Estate

fields.headline: Murdoch to take over Fourth Estate
fields.standfirst:
HarperCollins in talks with independent publisher

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Fourth Estate, a bastion of the independent publishing sector, with acclaimed authors such as Annie Proulx and Carol Shields, is poised to fall into the hands of the HarperCollins group.
fields.body:
Fourth Estate, a bastion of the independent publishing sector, with acclaimed authors such as Annie Proulx and Carol Shields, is poised to fall into the hands of the HarperCollins group.

Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian newspaper, is in advanced negotiations to sell its 42% controlling stake in Fourth Estate to the transatlantic corporation owned by Rupert Murdoch, sources say.

None of the three parties involved was willing to comment on or confirm the negotiations. But well placed sources say that a formal agreement could be signed within days.

Literary agents have already been told to make joint submissions both to HarperCollins Publishers in Britain and the small but successful Fourth Estate, which is also based in London.

There are reports that letters have already been prepared to authors explaining the impact of the pending deal.

Victoria Barnsley, the charismatic managing director of Fourth Estate, who founded the company in 1984, is expected to take the post of chief executive at HarperCollins Publishers. This position has been vacant since Eddie Bell retired last year.

Fourth Estate made its reputation as a publisher of high quality fiction and non-fiction, including the prize-winning Longitude by Dava Sobel.

But Ms Barnsley and editorial director Christopher Potter have been keen to expand the company by breaking into the American market and by moving into more popular areas, including romantic fiction.

They are also struggling to compete as a small group in a world where bigger and bigger advances are being made to best-selling authors.

Ms Barnsley and Janet Friedman, head of HarperCollins US in New York originally started talking about a joint venture in North America. But the demise of Fourth Estate as an independent publisher would leave the field to a dwindling band of British companies, led by Bloomsbury, producer of the Harry Potter books, and Faber & Faber.

There could also be some political fallout. Fourth Estate is the publisher of successful biographers such as Francis Wheen who has made clear in the past that he is no fan of Mr Murdoch.

And there could also be a question mark over a project just commissioned from another celebrated biographer, Michael Crick. He is writing a book on Mr Murdoch.

Critics of the US-based media magnate point to the row over Chris Patten's book about his time as governor of Hong Kong. HarperCollins dropped the deal amid allegations that Mr Murdoch's growing business relations with China could be harmed.

There are fears among the 35 staff at the Fourth Estate offices in Notting Hill that they would be dwarfed by HarperCollins. They are worried that the number of new titles could be cut back and that there could be redundancies.

HarperCollins employs more than 1,000 people at various locations including Hammersmith, west London. Last year Fourth Estate published 95 new titles while HarperCollins produced 1,300.

The small independent produced an operating profit of £270,000 on sales of £7.3m. HarperCollins turned in an operating profit of £6.4m on sales of £124m.

fields.headline: My media: Dominic Cork
fields.standfirst:
Dominic Cork

Cricket Unlimited
fields.trailText: I generally read most newspapers. The Daily Telegraph has good analysis of most types of cricket. Michael Henderson is very good. I have the Mail on Sunday delivered, because it's good not just on cricket but all the way through.
fields.body:
Newspapers: I generally read most newspapers. The Daily Telegraph has good analysis of most types of cricket. Michael Henderson is very good. I have the Mail on Sunday delivered, because it's good not just on cricket but all the way through.

Magazines: I like GQ, because it covers a lot of issues and has interesting interviews. I obviously read the Cricketer and Wisden.

Books: I like suspense-filled action thrillers based mainly on real-life experiences. Normally I stick to two writers. John Grisham is one: The Rainmaker is my favourite. The other is Andy McNab. I particularly liked Bravo Two Zero.

Films: My favourites are action thrillers again. I like the type of films that Wesley Snipes, Harrison Ford and Steven Seagal are in, with real-life parts. I loved The Bodyguard. And I like a bit of comedy.

Television: Channel 4's cricket coverage is very good - cricket needed a fresher, more relaxed look. Prime Minister's Question Time I like - it's controversial, a stand-up row. I like soaps, I enjoyed Bad Girls, and I loved Rowan Atkinson in Blackadder. Very dry, exactly my type of sense of humour. I like David Jason as well. I don't like the Ally McBeals and Frasiers, that sort of American humour.

Radio: For sport and news, I generally listen to 5 Live or TalkSport. I also tend to listen to the local radio stations. There's one particular pair I do like - Jo and Twiggy in the Morning on Trent FM. They're very, very funny.

Ads: I like the Super Noodles ad best. Two actors on a sofa, he's eating noodles, she's saying: "Give me some." He says no and puts the pot down. The dog licks it and he says: "All right them, here you are." I don't like the corny adverts, you know, "Buy this car and it will make your life perfect."

Multimedia: I've got a PC and I'm on the internet at home. I use a lot of email. And I use a mobile phone.

 Dominic Cork plays cricket for Derbyshire and England.

webTitle: Time to shift the ratings killers

fields.headline: Time to shift the ratings killers
fields.trailText: Who'd be a scheduler? Those marshalling the terrestrial channels are largely managing declining assets, a task for which you do not get thanked. For the satellite and digital schedulers, as little as 0.1% of the share can be the difference between happiness and misery. Then they all get the Barb statistics every morning at around 10am, a daily white-knuckle ride. On its own the job sounds appalling. Even with a generous supply of Prozac it would be daunting.
fields.body:
Who'd be a scheduler? Those marshalling the terrestrial channels are largely managing declining assets, a task for which you do not get thanked. For the satellite and digital schedulers, as little as 0.1% of the share can be the difference between happiness and misery. Then they all get the Barb statistics every morning at around 10am, a daily white-knuckle ride. On its own the job sounds appalling. Even with a generous supply of Prozac it would be daunting.

Despite this there does seem to be a queue of amateurs, backseat schedulers, determined to have a go. Messrs Blair, Smith, Kaufman and Biggam are telling ITV when to schedule its news. The arts mafia want classical music in terrestrial primetime. Then Chris Smith is "concerned" about Mark Thompson's Banff speech questioning the identity of BBC channels. In each case it is "public service", that over-used and under-defined totem, which the backseat schedulers rely on. Is this the way forward?

With a wonderfully inept sense of timing the ITC's order that ITV move the nightly news "earlier" came in the same week ITN was unveiling its 24-hour news channel. So now there are four such services available for news fans, along with BBC 1's Nine O'Clock News, Radio 4's The World Tonight and BBC2's Newsnight. The ITC's argument that ITV viewers should have "access" to news earlier is nonsense. They have automatic access to the BBC services and simple access to the news channels should they care to subscribe to a cable, satellite or digital package.

To add to the general air of farce, the company which will manufacture our TiVo boxes was also announced. Thomson will make these self-scheduling devices and BSkyB will market them, well in time for Christmas. £300 will enable us to download and schedule programmes in any order we like. This will be a fairly standard facility within five years.

As we debate how public service should be defined in future, some have completely lost the plot. Of course heavyweight current affairs and classical music should continue to be funded by and available from an intelligently organised media sector. But the idea that you can enrich people's lives by slapping such offerings in the middle of a primetime entertainment schedule is fanciful. The remote control button is already an instant bypass. TiVo and its competitors will obliterate the very idea of a schedule.

We have managed to define a public service remit for Channel 4 without resorting to a scheduling straitjacket. The News at Ten imbroglio is diverting us from what really matters - what ITV's future remit should be in return for its privileged place in the spectrum. The purpose of the forthcoming white paper is to govern media for the next decade or so. It is no longer possible to define public service responsibilities for commercial channels in terms of scheduling.

There has been much sober comment about Thompson's intelligent speech. The gist of it is that he and Greg Dyke are trying to move too fast. But it is precisely because of such conservative sentiments that the BBC needs to open a debate up now. Thompson was careful not to specify any particular programme changes, though Dyke did admit on Radio 4 that switching Panorama to BBC2 was a "possibility". What else have they in mind?

My guess is that they intend to streamline BBC1 in autumn 2001. The plan could be to shift ratings killers such as Panorama, Omnibus, Question Time, Songs of Praise and Top of the Pops to BBC2. How could anyone possibly object to that? They will be as available on BBC2 as they are on BBC1. This would still leave BBC1 with a schedule more mixed and diverse than ITV's. And the shifted shows would earn higher ratings on primetime BBC2 (witness the current success of Horizon and the History Zone).

 Peter Bazalgette is creative director of GMG Endemol Entertainment, an independent production company part-owned by the Guardian Media Group

fields.headline: The unlikely criminals
fields.standfirst: She was a respected and experienced professional devoted to helping the homeless. He was a mild-mannered charity worker. But Ruth Wyner and John Brock have just celebrated their 50th birthdays behind bars, facing long sentences for failing to stop heroin dealing in the shelter they ran. On the eve of their appeal,  Sally Weale  investigates the controversial case of the Cambridge Two
fields.trailText: She was a respected and experienced professional devoted to helping the homeless. He was a mild-mannered charity worker. But Ruth Wyner and John Brock have just celebrated their 50th birthdays behind bars, facing long sentences for failing to stop heroin dealing in the shelter they ran. On the eve of their appeal, Sally Weale investigates the controversial case of the Cambridge Two
fields.body:
When charity workers Ruth Wyner and John Brock were arrested in connection with heroin dealing at the homeless drop-in centre they ran in Cambridge, few people expected they would ever be charged. When they were, everyone told them it would never get to court. When it did, their lawyers reassured them they would not be found guilty. When they were, no one expected they would go to prison.

Wyner, director of the Wintercomfort charity, was jailed for five years for knowingly permitting heroin dealing; Brock, a manager at the charity's day centre, the Bus, was jailed for four. They have been in prison for more than six months. They spent Christmas in prison, they saw in the new millennium in prison, and they both celebrated their 50th birthdays behind bars.

Ruth is a prison gardener, planting dahlias in the unlovely grounds at Highpoint prison in Suffolk, and spends the rest of her time bashing out angry letters and articles on her uncle's old manual typewriter, which she has been allowed in her cell. There is a book in the offing. John, also at Highpoint, is deeply depressed and is on Prozac. He has done a computer course; during association time his cell is always full of fellow inmates in need of advice, but his overwhelming feeling is one of apathy.

Tomorrow, their case comes before the lord chief justice and two other judges in the court of appeal. Wyner and Brock are seeking leave to appeal against conviction. They've been told to take all their clothes with them to court, but they are not reading anything into that. They feel their world has turned into a Kafkaesque nightmare in which anything can happen.

Wyner and Brock were arrested after police mounted a surveillance operation at the shelter, which crouches next to the River Cam across the meadow from Jesus College in a smart part of Cambridge. A spy camera, which collected 300 hours of taped evidence, was trained on the courtyard belonging to the shelter from a neighbouring building. Two undercover officers posing as drop-outs, Ed and Swampy, began to drop in. They visited the Bus (it was actually once a bus) 12 times and were able to buy heroin on eight of those occasions. Eight dealers were also jailed following the operation - their sentences were, for the most part far, lighter than those dished out to Wyner and Brock.

The judge in the case, judge Jonathan Haworth, accused Wyner and Brock of creating "a haven for drug dealers". At the heart of the prosecution's case was Wintercomfort's confidentiality policy, designed to protect staff and build trust with vulnerable people. It prevented them from passing names of those suspected of drug-related activity to the police - as a result they opened themselves up to the charge that they were not doing enough to help remove dealers.

It is an extraordinary case which has sparked outrage among homelessness and drugs charities, among MPs and academics who believe there has been a gross miscarriage of justice. Even those who are critical of Wyner were horrifed by the draconian sentences - people convicted of stabbings, muggings and sexually abusing children go away for less. Wyner and Brock's fate sent shockwaves through the charity and homeless sector with reports that staff at other hostels and day centres were starting to turn away drug addicts, because they did not want to put themselves at risk of prosecution.

If these two could be convicted, they felt, anyone working with the homeless could. There is a high level of drug addiction among the homeless - up to 70% according to some estimates - and where there are addicts, there will be dealers, even if they're only trying to make enough money for their next hit.

A well-organised campaign to free "The Cambridge Two" has swung into action, with support from the great and good of the city. There have been vigils, gigs, demonstrations, marches; there's a newsletter and a website, badges, T-shirts and a CD featuring two songs written by Ruth and performed by a band called Not Guilty. A support fund has raised between £30,000 and £40,000 to help pay Wyner and Brock's mortgages - they have had to resign their posts at Wintercomfort - and the fighting fund has raised and spent a further £20,000 to highlight their plight.

Letters of support have appeared in the national press, signed by everyone from Julie Christie and Tom Stoppard to Roger Scruton and Michael Winner. Joan Baez dedicated a song to Ruth and John every night of her US tour.

The campaign has not, however, gone unchallenged. On the letters pages of national newspapers there have been angry exchanges between Wyner and Dr Don Keiller, a Cambridge resident and a vociferous and long-term critic of Wyner and Wintercomfort. He claims that drug-dealers were given "carte blanche" to peddle drugs to the extent that the shelter became a "supermarket for heroin". He says addicts came from miles around to score from dealers who turned up in BMWs to sell their wares and claims Wyner did nothing to contain the situation. Wyner denies this is what happened.

Dr Keiller also noted Wyner was "no stranger to controversy". In 1993 she was sacked from her job as manager of the St Martin's Homeless Trust in Norwich for allegedly allowing the use of drugs on the premises. The allegation, according to Wyner, was that she had allowed one resident to smoke cannabis in her room. She always denied it; there was never any police charge. She took her case to an industrial tribunal and lost. Nick Williams, who was a trustee at St Martin's at the time and is now chairman of the trustees confirmed: "She was sacked for gross misconduct. That misconduct was that she condoned the use of drugs."

And so, there it was - another drug allegation. This time cannabis, not heroin. There were no charges, but it was enough to suggest a pattern of behaviour to those who wanted to see it. "What is very clear is there is a history there," says one housing shelter manager. "There seems to be quite a lot of smoke and a good reason for fire. I manage an organisation which is presented with all the same problems as Wintercomfort and I don't see we're about to be raided by the police."

Wyner is a small, wiry, tenacious-looking woman. She has a deep, chesty laugh which reduces her to phlegmy coughing fits. We meet in the segregation unit at Highpoint prison, Suffolk. She seems self-possessed, undaunted. When she first arrived she says she scurried around, her shoulders hunched up, her hands deep in her pockets, cursing and swearing. It was defensive - she was frightened. Six months on she looks like she's handling it like a pro. Her companions are drug importers from Colombia and Jamaica - most of them inadequate, vulnerable people, just like those she worked with at Wintercomfort.

She is adamant that she and John Brock were unaware of the scale of the dealing going on at Wintercomfort. "The heroin problem in Cambridge was very, very bad. There was quite a lot of unusually pure stuff around. There were more overdoses happening, which was causing us a lot of worry.

"It was happening at the hostels as well. We were all seeing a rise in heroin use. Sometimes at the day centre we would see people keel over from overdoses and we would have to send for an ambulance."

There was one death on site; at hostels elsewhere in the city there were others. Staff at the Bus suspected one or two people were doing exchanges in the shelter, but nothing of the scale revealed by police surveillance. Wyner, bound by the charity's confidentiality policy, thought she was nevertheless liaising well with the police. Instead, she says, she found herself targeted by them. Smack dealers picked up by the police were asked specifically about Wyner's involvement; one of them was asked whether she was taking backhanders.

Conspiracy theories abound as to why Wintercomfort and Wyner, a mother of two, became the focus of Cambridge police's anti-drugs drive. Her critics maintain it was because all the police drugs intelligence led in some way to Wintercomfort. Others point to her recent success in winning a planning application and a £400,000 lottery grant to build a permanent shelter for 25 homeless people at Elizabeth Way, a road bridge facing Midsummer Common.

The plans were deeply unpopular with some local residents, who, according to Wyner, mounted a vigorous campaign to fight the planned development. "I was the driving force behind Elizabeth Way," says Wyner. "I can't help but think there's some sort of link."

On events at St Martin's, Wyner says her dismissal was about political differences over the role of the shelter. The cannabis charge, she says, was trumped up as an excuse to get rid of her. "After I got sacked I went for a job as co-ordinator of the Herring House Trust in Great Yarmouth. They went and spoke with one of the trustees of St Martin's and they still took me on with open arms in full knowledge of what had happened. I feel vindicated by that.

"I have never, ever condoned cannabis - never at all, on any project," she insists. "There was a saying in St Martin's at the time - if anybody came in with a joint, you would tell them to go feed the ducks, which meant go and have a smoke by the river. Don't bring it into the project.

"That kind of attitude fitted in with the whole of the sector. What it really meant was - keep it out of my sight, otherwise I'm going to have to ban you. You would not do that with heroin. You know it's very harmful and damaging. When it comes to heroin, we had very firm policies laid down. Anything we saw we dealt with in terms of those policies. The trouble is we didn't see everything."

Wyner and Brock say they had procedures in place and were following them; part of the prosecution case was that they did not. On one occasion they let a woman back into Wintercomfort despite banning her indefinitely on suspicion of drug dealing. "She pleaded with us to come back on the project. We were worried because we knew she was injecting in her neck, which meant she could kill herself with any injection. You are in a life-and-death situation. It's terribly, terribly difficult."

When she was appointed director of Wintercomfort in 1995, the trustees were not made aware of what had happened at St Martin's. She told them after her arrest. "We did take quite careful references at the time," says Sarah Jones, chair of the trustees. "On the one hand you think, 'Oh I wish she had told me before'. If you look at it carefully and objectively, I don't see a problem. It did not affect Ruth's judgment. The rest of the trustees agree with that."

At the Bus drop-in shelter one recent blustery Thursday afternoon, business is slow. The number of people visiting the project has almost halved since Operation Wythall, as the police called it. At one stage it looked as though the whole project might go under; there was a drop in donations and funders became very jittery. Organisers feel they've finally turned a corner; they're advertising Wyner and Brock's old jobs and they're confident there will be a lot of interest.

Things have changed a bit. There's a new closed-door policy - a camera peers down at you as you ring the bell to get in. There is careful monitoring of who is allowed entry and record keeping has been tightened up. The staff are cheery, fiercely supportive of their former bosses.

In the TV room, a small group of young men slump in front of an early episode of ER; one man weaves a friendship bracelet, another is shaving. In the cafe, fish and chips is on the menu for £1, with semolina and jam for an extra 30p. A man sits reading the paper with his face very, very close to the words; others sit listlessly - grubby, emotionless, their features shaded under baseball caps.

"I don't think it did anything to tackle drugs in Cambridge," says Val Oliver, assistant manager at the Bus. "It just moved the activity elsewhere. The clientele we see have substance misuse problems. I can't say I'm 100% sure dealing is not going on here now. But I am confident any suspicion of dealing will be dealt with by asking the person to leave and banning them."

There are those who believe the level of dealing going on at Wintercomfort was far higher than at other comparable day centres and that management procedures were lax, which put them at particular risk of being prosecuted under Section 8 of the 1971 Misuse of Drugs Act. On the other hand, a survey by the national drugs helpline, Release, of 600 workers in the sector revealed half would be guilty of some offence under this law. Many believe the act should be amended. A recent inquiry funded by the Police Foundation recommended that it should be amended, partly to acknowledge the importance of confidentiality policies.

Over the past two decades, the climate has changed radically in the homelessness sector. When Wyner, once a classmate of Harriet Harman at St Paul's School in London, first began working in the area, it was far more ad hoc. It was led by strong personalities who used their initiative to carry out work no one else was prepared to do. In recent years, however, the whole sector has had to become much more professional and co-ordinated.

Wyner's passion for working with the homeless, the outcast and dispossessed, stems from early experiences with her brother, Rickie, who was mentally ill. After 10 attempts, he finally killed himself by throwing himself out of a hostel window. Some suggest at times her passion may affect her judgment and she has made enemies along the way. "There's no doubt she's a very intelligent person," says one former colleague. "She's highly committed to working with homeless people. She does not feel the way society deals with these people is appropriate. She does not like authority. She has her own particular code."

Eamonn Burgess, a city councillor in Norwich, worked for Wyner at St Martin's. He left after a disagreement over shift patterns - she says he bears a grudge against her. "I know how hard-working Ruth is. She's a brilliant lobbyist, she's almost fanatical. There's no question she taught me good stuff.

"But she was suspended and dismissed from St Martin's following her nonsensical drugs policy. She was found to be unfit to do her job."

Wyner insists her conscience is clear. "I feel terribly angry. It feels like my life has been picked up and thrown away. I feel I've worked very hard in a difficult area of work. I've given my life to homelessness really, and to find myself incarcerated like this is very painful.

"As far as I'm concerned I've done nothing criminal. You can always improve the management of somewhere. I did my best with the resources we had. I feel I've suffered a huge injustice and John Brock has as well."

Attention has understandably focused on Wyner because of her outspoken and high-profile role in the homeless world - she trained as a journalist and has used her skills to get considerable media coverage. Brock, on the other hand, a mild-mannered family man who was employed as a printer and signwriter before working with the homeless, has remained in the background throughout.

His wife, Louise, who has two sons, says John was apprehensive about the appeal. "My main feelings are those of anger and disbelief that the police did not tell anyone about the problem. If any one of the policemen Ruth and John had been liaising with had said, 'Look here, this is getting out of hand, we need to do something', they would have done something. It's like they were trapped.

"John says he will fight till he dies to clear his name. He feels it's just such an injustice. If we fail at this appeal, we'll take it to the House of Lords and then on to Europe."

Hero or villain? Martyr or traitor? Life is rarely that clear-cut. What is clear is that even Ruth Wyner's worst enemies agree she was passionate about her work; she was devoted to the homeless cause, and she and John Brock did a great deal of good for many desperate people. The appeal judges will have to decide whether it is right that such people are charged, convicted and sentenced to serve time - such a long, long time - behind bars.

fields.headline: Israeli PM survives no-confidence vote
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: Special report
fields.trailText: Prime minister Ehud Barak of Israel today survived the no-confidence motion that sapped his political credibility on the eve of a Middle East peace summit with Palestinian president Yasser Arafat.
fields.body:
Prime minister Ehud Barak of Israel today survived the no-confidence motion that sapped his political credibility on the eve of a Middle East peace summit with Palestinian president Yasser Arafat.

The opposition failed to gain the required 61 votes needed to topple Mr Barak, after a raucous debate in the Knesset, the Israeli parliament. The Israeli prime minister held on to his position by a hair's breadth, with 54 voting for the motion, 52 against and seven abstentions.

Mr Barak said during the debate: "The moment of truth is upon us. Just a year ago the public gave us a mandate to lead, not to protect what exists, but to change the reality from its core and to assure the future of Israel."

The prime minister was constantly heckled by right-wing opponents during a debate on no-confidence motions brought by parties aimed at toppling him. "Can I even speak here?" he asked at one point, rattled by the heckling.

"I am not going alone. With me are almost 2 million voters...citizens who want peace, who want to give change a chance, and hope for a different Israel at peace with its neighbours," the embattled Mr Barak said, before leaving the summit at Camp David, near Washington, hosted by American president Bill Clinton.

Mr Barak was scheduled to leave for the US this morning but postponed his departure until after the vote. He will make a brief visit to Cairo to discuss the peace process with Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak and return home after the meeting instead of heading thereon to the US.

The opposition Likud party was in confident mood after three rightwing parties left the ruling coalition in anticipation of territorial concessions Mr Barak is expected to make to Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat. The ultra-orthodox Shas party and the Russian immigrants party Yisrael B'Aliya quit the coalition on Sunday and the head of the National Religious party, housing minister Yitzhak Levy, said he would submit his resignation today.

Likud chairman, the hawkish Ariel Sharon, said Mr Barak did not have the support of the nation and urged him not to go to Camp David. The summit is seen as an attempt by Bill Clinton to score a last foreign policy success for his presidency.

Likud leaders called on foreign minister David Levy, who is boycotting the summit because he believes it has no chance of success, to "return home" to the Likud. He had left the party when Binyamin Netanyahu was prime minister.

But Mr Barak has said that his mandate is from the nation - not from parliament - and that nothing would stop him from the search for peace with the Palestinians.

In a televised appeal yesterday, the Israeli leader shrugged off the desertions of rightwing and religious coalition allies and promised to put any peace deal to a national referendum, which he is confident will be approved by a large majority.

"If we return with an agreement, it will be an agreement that Ehud Barak will have complete faith in, and I have no doubt it will pass with an overwhelming majority," Mr Barak's chief security adviser, Danny Yatom, told Israel Radio.

Mr Barak's confidence is backed by an opinion poll for the Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper which indicates that a majority of Israelis do favour making compromises for peace with the Palestinians.

In spite of the increased strength of the opposition, political commentators did not believe it would succeed in mustering the 61 votes out of the 120 members of parliament needed to bring down the government. The government is expected to survive, but will be severely weakened.

Mr Barak is expected to hold negotiations with dovish and moderate opposition parties after his return from Camp David, in the hope of forming an alternative coalition. He is already putting out feelers to one of the splinter parties, One People - no agreement has been reached but the talks are to continue.

Israeli and Palestinian teams are trying to resolve by a September 13 deadline the thorniest issues separating them, including borders, the fate of Jewish settlers and Palestinian refugees and the status of Jerusalem. Expectations among both Israeli and Palestinian officials are next to nil that the Camp David talks, to begin tomorrow, will yield a final agreement. Mr Barak had given the summit only a 50-50 chance of success even before yesterday's political turmoil.

Just a year ago the public gave us a mandate to lead, not to protect what exists, but to change the reality from its core and to assure the future of Israel." The prime minister was constantly heckled by right-wing opponents during a debate on no-confidence motions brought by parties aimed at toppling him. "Can I even speak here?" he asked at one point, rattled by the heckling. "I am not going alone. With me are almost 2 million voters...citizens who want peace, who want to give change a chance, and hope for a different Israel at peace with its neighbours," the embattled Mr Barak said, before leaving the summit at Camp David, near Washington, hosted by American president Bill Clinton. Mr Barak was scheduled to leave for the US this morning but postponed his departure until after the vote. He will make a brief visit to Cairo to discuss the peace process with Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak and return home after the meeting instead of heading thereon to the US. The opposition Likud party was in confident mood after three rightwing parties left the ruling coalition in anticipation of territorial concessions Mr Barak is expected to make to Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat. The ultra-orthodox Shas party and the Russian immigrants party Yisrael B'Aliya quit the coalition on Sunday and the head of the National Religious party, housing minister Yitzhak Levy, said he would submit his resignation today. Likud chairman, the hawkish Ariel Sharon, said Mr Barak did not have the support of the nation and urged him not to go to Camp David. The summit is seen as an attempt by Bill Clinton to score a last foreign policy success for his presidency. Likud leaders called on foreign minister David Levy, who is boycotting the summit because he believes it has no chance of success, to "return home" to the Likud. He had left the party when Binyamin Netanyahu was prime minister. But Mr Barak has said that his mandate is from the nation - not from parliament - and that nothing would stop him from the search for peace with the Palestinians. In a televised appeal yesterday, the Israeli leader shrugged off the desertions of rightwing and religious coalition allies and promised to put any peace deal to a national referendum, which he is confident will be approved by a large majority. "If we return with an agreement, it will be an agreement that Ehud Barak will have complete faith in, and I have no doubt it will pass with an overwhelming majority," Mr Barak's chief security adviser, Danny Yatom, told Israel Radio. Mr Barak's confidence is backed by an opinion poll for the Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper which indicates that a majority of Israelis do favour making compromises for peace with the Palestinians. In spite of the increased strength of the opposition, political commentators did not believe it would succeed in mustering the 61 votes out of the 120 members of parliament needed to bring down the government. The government is expected to survive, but will be severely weakened. Mr Barak is expected to hold negotiations with dovish and moderate opposition parties after his return from Camp David, in the hope of forming an alternative coalition. He is already putting out feelers to one of the splinter parties, One People - no agreement has been reached but the talks are to continue. Israeli and Palestinian teams are trying to resolve by a September 13 deadline the thorniest issues separating them, including borders, the fate of Jewish settlers and Palestinian refugees and the status of Jerusalem. Expectations among both Israeli and Palestinian officials are next to nil that the Camp David talks, to begin tomorrow, will yield a final agreement. Mr Barak had given the summit only a 50-50 chance of success even before yesterday's political turmoil.

fields.headline: The Patriot
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Mel Gibson's latest blockbuster, and why he is  being beastly about the Brits
fields.trailText: 1. Many people think Mel Gibson is Australian, because of his dinkum accent. He isn't; he's American. And in his new epic swashbuckler, The Patriot, he couldn't be more so.
fields.body:
1. Many people think Mel Gibson is Australian, because of his dinkum accent. He isn't; he's American. And in his new epic swashbuckler, The Patriot, he couldn't be more so.

2. Gibson plays the eponymous hero, a homespun farmer with a dark past who is drawn into the Revolutionary War by the swine-like behaviour of the British.

3. To go by the highly-selective reviews on the movie's official site, you'd think it a huge smasheroo. The rather-more-objective Mr Showbiz site calls it "a long, repetitious mediocrity that is so chin-deep in stagnant clichés that you can smell the swamp gas."

4. US and British reviewers are furious about the film's depiction of King George's redcoats as devils incarnate, only taking time off from murder, rape and pillage to be defeated by Gibson's gallant guerrillas. Jonathan Foreman, the New York Post critic, goes so far as to describe the movie as fascist.

5. He takes particular exception to an entirely fictional sequence in which British soldiers lock a village of plucky patriots in their homes and set fire to them. This, argues Foreman, diminishes the memory of the similar, very real, atrocity committed by the Nazis at Oradour sur Glane in 1944.

6. Foreman and other critics are also incensed about the depiction of black American as happy-go-lucky slaves, loyal to their colonial masters. Spike Lee, the black director, has written a coruscating letter on the matter to Hollywood Reporter.

7. As a matter of historical fact, rather more blacks fought for the British in the Revolutionary War than for the colonies. And Francis Marion, the historical character on whom Mel Gibson's part is based, was apparently an out-and-out racist. And while we are on the subject, the native Americans were not all that eager to side with the revolutionaries, either.

8. In politically-correct America, alleged ethnic stereotyping is bad enough. But what really got the ratings folk in a tizz was the scene in which a British soldier is tracked and killed by a couple of young boys. Shades of Columbine High, and all that.

9. Gibson, understandably, takes a relaxed view of cinematic truth. In an interview with the movie site boxoff ice.com, he says: "Yes, I love history, and dabbling in the world of what really went down. And to make it cinematic and palatable, sure, you have to bend some of the truth a little bit. But not too much, not really."

10. None of this is likely to bother Gibson's army of fans. Much more upsetting to them, and to the movie's makers, is the fact that The Patriot is getting hammered at the US box office by a rival action epic, The Perfect Storm. It is unlikely to make up ground over here, although the film's official UK site is appropriately discreet about its less-than-flattering portrayal of King George's soldiers. Still, there's always the merchandise...

fields.headline: Children for whom school has no point (continued)
fields.standfirst:
The tower block children for whom school has no point: Nick Davies, the UK's reporter of the year, begins part three of his award-winning series on education in Britain. Today: the Tale of the Truant
Truants (part one)
fields.trailText: Disaffected
fields.body:
Disaffected

The key question for the future is: what happens if the schools miss their targets, under the cumulative strain of the profound shortage of effective therapy, the weakening of the "joined-up" strategy, the reverse incentives of league tables and performance-related pay? If the truants still walk out of the school gates and find nothing, if the excluded are still pushed out of the gates and find even less of a safety net, more and more of them will end up on the streets: more child crime, more prostitution, more street gangs, more aimless, listless, hopeless kids on tower block landings.

On paper, the DFEE has an answer to this: schools will hand over their pupil support grant to their LEA which will then make provision. In practice, however, LEA officials warn that schools are going to be very reluctant to hand over much-needed cash and, even if they do, LEAs will no longer have the PRUs to deal with the children.

And what will be happening within the schools? If the in-school units do not succeed in rapidly recycling disaffected chidren back into the classroom, they will fill up and impose a strict gate-keeping policy. Only the most disaffected children will be able to use them, making it particularly difficult for staff to succeed with them. Back in the classroom, teachers will wrestle with those who should be in the units but cannot find a place. They will hit a downward spiral.

And there is no mystery about which schools are most likely to slide down that spiral. It will not be the middle-class schools with their well-motivated intake, it will be the struggling ones, who are overburdened with difficult pupils and who are already suffering the financial penalties of Kenneth Baker's reforms.

LEAs and governing bodies are already fighting headteachers who try to exclude difficult pupils; LEAs are pressurising some schools by warning that their exclusions might be challenged in court and that the LEA would not support the school's legal costs. The future is already happening. One of the teacher unions, the NASUWT, which has been campaigning against the DFEE's strategy, compiled a list of incidents in the first four months of this year, where teachers had been ordered to teach children who would otherwise have been excluded.

A sample: "Cumbria: 13-year-old boy, last year indecently assaulted welfare assistant, excluded but returned on appeal because of 'procedural errors', now boy indecently assaults girl pupil in PE lesson Lincolnshire: 14-year-old boy, reinstated by appeal panel after permanent exclusion following repeated instances of verbal and sexual abuse of women staff Oxfordshire: 14-year-old boy, permanent exclusion following three violent incidents including assault of deputy head, parents appeal, appeal allowed on procedural grounds... Greater London: 14-year-old boy, history of violent conduct, elbowed teacher in stomach, permanently excluded, LEA overturned exclusion... Rhondda: 15 year old girl, history of substance abuse and violence to other pupils, threatened woman teacher, permanent exclusion overturned by governors advised by LEA... Hertfordshire: 10-year-old boy, history of violence and disruption, attacked another pupil and woman teacher who intervened, head reluctant to exclude fearing might be overruled by LEA... Tyneside: 15-year-old boy, excluded from previous school for violent behaviour, attacked teacher with screwdriver, head reluctant to exclude permanently."

The NASUWT is warning not just that these incidents are occurring but that they are increasing in frequency. So far, this country has seen only one headteacher killed by his students; we don't have firearms in our schools, but we do have knives; gang fights are relatively rare, but we do have assaults and exhortations; rapes are rare, but sexual harassment in the playground is not; drug syndicates are rare, but drugs are not. All this is sitting out there, waiting for us.
