fields.headline: Children for whom school has no point
fields.standfirst:
The tower block children for whom school has no point: Nick Davies, the UK's reporter of the year, begins part three of his award-winning series on education in Britain. Today: the Tale of the Truant
Truants continued
fields.trailText: The tower block children for whom school has no point: Nick Davies, the UK's reporter of the year, begins part three of his award-winning series on education in Britain. Today: the Tale of the Truant
fields.body:
One good thing about spitting is that it helps to pass the time. It's morning, about nine o'clock, and on the streets of south London the school buses have dumped their loads and the playgrounds have gone quiet. Up here, on the top floor of the tower block, the day has started, as it always does, with Karen and Philly and Annie May and the others sitting slouched on the black tile floor by the liftshaft, smoking and watching the minutes go by and practising their spitting.

In the past they've tried hanging out in the shopping malls, but the old Bill hassled them. It's the same on the streets, really.

Sometimes they go round Philly's house - his mum doesn't mind, she's in bed all day. But mostly, each morning they sit here in the block and, if it gets too cold with the wind blowing in from the open walkways, they go down on to the estate and, in among the dog crap and the flower tubs filled with fag ends, they find some litter and bring it back up here and light a fire on the landing, and then they sit and watch the smoke. A day in the life of a truant.

It's better than school and, as the morning passes, they sit and sometimes talk, but not too much. When they first started coming up here they used to play in the lift. It was not much of a game: push the button, wait for the lift to arrive, get in, go mental - jump up and down as hard as you can and batter its walls and floor with your feet and your fists - then wait for someone else on another floor to call the lift and hope it does not work.

Up here on the block, with half a dozen subdued children, it is easy to imagine that this is a small problem. At first sight, the official statistics confirm this. The audit commission says some 12,000 children a year are permanently excluded from school and a further 150,000 are excluded temporarily. It is not ideal but it is a tiny fraction of the whole pupil population. The commission also says that each year a million of the 8m children in our schools will be absent without authorisation. But many of those absences are for only one day.

The numbers conceal as much as they reveal. They say nothing about the children who are 'cleansed' - pushed out of schools by headteachers who avoid officially recording them as exclusions. They say nothing about the children who turn up at school to be registered and then walk straight out. Most of all they ignore all the children who are out of school but who do not qualify to be counted.

There is an apparently vast reservoir of students whose absence from school is authorised by parents who want them at home as carers for siblings or who just cannot be bothered to send them. And there are untold thousands who are not registered to any school at all because they have fallen through the system, usually because of their families' unstable lives: their parents are homeless and stay away from the authorities for fear of having their kids taken into care; they move and cannot cope with the bureaucracy of a new LEA; they stumble from one disastrous estate to another, and the education authorities simply lose track of them; they are among the 2,500 children of refugee families who, according to the Refugee Council, are being illegally denied an education; they are the children of travellers; they are in jail.

But this is not about numbers. You really begin to see the scale of the problem only when you first catch a glimpse of what lies beneath it. There are two central truths: first, that this has far less to do with discipline than it has to do with an epidemic of emotional damage, particularly among the 30% of British children who live in poverty; second, that these children are the most visible part of the central problems of our schools, how to teach disaffected children who see no point in learning, how to give reality to the once-vibrant idea that education is the natural escape route from poverty.

Come back to the block. By noon, a few of the faces have pushed off to play on the buses. That is not much of a game either. You get on the bus without a ticket, see how far you can travel before you get thrown off, then you walk home or maybe catch another bus, if you can be bothered.

Other faces have arrived now. They all have the same kind of faces, with the shine rubbed off, and the same kind of stories.

Listen to Karen, sitting with her back to the liftshaft wall, listless, aimless, hopeless, the kind of truant who gives David Blunkett nightmares - she has not been to school regularly since she was 11, and she is now 14. When she was seven her father started using heroin and crack cocaine and he got her mother on to it, too. Until then, life had been OK. They had a nice house, there was food in the kitchen, she was going to school. But the mother and father slid downhill fast, taking Karen and her three younger sisters with them.

Her dad used to take her out thieving. She used to knock on the door, a little girl with gaps in her teeth, and if there was someone in, she would ask for a glass of water and run along; if not, her dad would smash a window and they'd get inside and take whatever they could. She got arrested for that eventually, when she was 11, and spent 36 hours in a cell. By that time she had long lost sight of normal life. She says there was no food in the house, and to feed her sisters as well as herself she would go and borrow money off friends or eat at someone else's house or steal things from shops or scavenge in rubbish bins. They had no light or heat in the house. Her mum and dad just did drugs and watched the time go by.

She became the stand-in mother, feeding and caring for the three younger ones. At first, when she stopped going to school, she still took the others, but then it got too much and so they all stopped. From time to time the welfare officer used to come round and bang on the door, and Karen says her mum just told them to keep quiet and then the welfare officer would go away. If there were letters about it, they just ignored them. Eventually, her dad got sent to jail - four years for robbery - and her mum was left on her own with four children and a heroin habit. And that's the way it still is now.

So why does she not want to sit in school? Because she is too sure there is no point, too scared to be caught out failing, too determined to advertise her indifference, too angry and too cynical - too emotionally damaged.

When they are not up here in the block, Karen and the others spend most of their time in some old railway arches which have been converted into a kind of refuge for young people. They are run by a psychotherapist called Camila Batmanghelidjh who was taken to court by her building society because she stopped paying her mortgage and used the money to set up this day club for the kids under the arches.

Batmanghelidjh reckons that one in three children in the inner cities have some form of emotional or behavioural difficulty. Several hundred children a day find their way to her arches. Most of them are more or less out of school. They live, she says, in a state of "emotional coldness". This is the hidden core of what politicians dismiss as mere truancy and exclusion.

Last year the office for national statistics reported that 10% of Britain's children suffer from mental disorders - anxiety, depression, obsessions, clinically significant behaviour disorders and hyperactivity - but that figure masked the concentration of mental disorders among the children of the poor.

The ONS found, for example, that among the children of families where both parents are unemployed, some 20% have a mental health problem. They also found that children with this kind of illness were four times more likely to truant than others. They were also three times more likely to have specific learning difficulties, three times more likely to have special educational needs and 10 times more likely to be in trouble with the police, all of which are linked to the kind of behaviour which leads to children being excluded.

Unhappiness always has its reason. One of the 14-year-old girls who moves between the block and Batmanghelidjh's arches has started working as a street prostitute. It seems she is doing so at the behest of her mother, who needs the money. There is an 11-year-old boy who lives with his ageing gran because neither of his parents want anything to do with him; a 15-year-old girl whose mother died of cancer years ago, whose father is preoccupied with selling drugs, who has been in and out of care and who had her first abortion at 13; another 13-year-old girl who is given money for sex by an elderly man; two brothers, aged 17 and 11, both of them drug runners; a 12-year-old girl who recently found her father after he had overdosed and who has now been sent to live with her mother, who makes no secret of not wanting her.

The strategy of the education secretary, David Blunkett, is all about "inclusivity". He has introduced a complex package of sticks and carrots to persuade schools and LEAs to divert truants and the excluded back into the classroom. By 2002 he wants a reduction of 30% in both statistics; every secondary school and every LEA has been given a target. He is paying new pupil support grants so that a thousand schools can set up learning support units to help them to reach the targets. If they miss the targets, he will withdraw their grants. Some schools will also receive money to pay for learning mentors to help disaffected children. He has given LEAs new powers to join appeals against exclusion and made it their responsibility to pick up the bill for the education of those who nevertheless are excluded. Finally, the Home Office has introduced fines for parents who fail to send their children to school and powers for police to pick up truants on the streets.

Tactics

This strategy has its merits. Mr Blunkett is targeting extra resources on some of the poorest areas. Funding for learning mentors, for example, is being delivered through the excellence in cities programme focused on six metropolitan areas. Behind all the rhetoric about discipline, the reality is that many schools are now are attempting to tackle the underlying problems of the most disaffected children.

However, there are two problems. First, the tactics of the new school units and also the DFEE's particular version of mentoring are, at best, untested and, at worst, proven failures. If these schemes fail to change the way in which these children are behaving, we will have locked into our schools a group of the most delinquent and difficult children and we will start to see the kind of violence which has become part of the currency of daily life in some inner city schools in the United States.

The second problem is that Mr Blunkett has, on the one hand, made moves to persuade schools to deal with disaffected children, and then with the other hand, launched political initiatives which undermine those moves. Beyond that, the strategy suffers from the political decision to leave in place the whole package of reforms introduced by the former education secretary, Kenneth Baker, in the late 1980s.

As this series has previously shown, this structure penalises the most disaffected children: they perform badly in exams; their schools tumble down the league tables; middle-class families use their professional skills and their strength in the property market to take their motivated children away to schools with a less disaffected intake; when they do that, they take funds away with them, the struggling school is left with even fewer motivated children and even less money to educate them and so it spirals downwards. In short, the children of the poor get the schools with the poorest budgets, an imbalance that is not corrected by the available subsidies for needy children which notoriously are rationed, inefficiently distributed and inadequate in the first place.

Furthermore, these schools have had a direct financial incentive to exclude the most difficult children in order to improve their position in the league tables. As the Baker reforms took hold, exclusions rose fivefold in five years. Leaving Kenneth Baker's system in place, Mr Blunkett has introduced counter-measures to try to give schools a financial interest in not excluding children. The problem is that neither structure provides a neutral framework in which a school can decide a child's future purely on grounds of education and behaviour.

Come back to the block and to Camila Batmanghelidjh's arches. The morning is past, the afternoon is wearing on and, up in the block, where Batmanghelidjh is not in charge, finally they have found something to do. They are smoking hash. Batmanghelidjh knows they do it. She knows it is part of the daily routine, for as long as they can afford the hash. And worse. She has one 12-year-old who had rocks of crack cocaine found in his pocket. She has urged them not do it, but she is not about to hammer them for it, because she knows why it is happening: "They use cannabis to control their moods." And why do they do that? Because just about nobody else is doing anything to help them with those moods. The ONS can tell the world that 20% of poor children are mentally ill. Nobody quarrels with the finding (which has been replicated by other studies). But this country's strange and terrible reaction has been to shake its head and then to offer virtually no care at all.

The audit commission last year found that less than half the health authorities in the country even had a policy for child mental health and that, among those who did, there were all kinds of gaps and overlaps where different agencies were failing to work together. The ONS similarly, having recorded the scale of mental illness among children, found that 30% of these children had not been seen even once by a specialist, or even by a GP. At Young Minds, a national charity working to promote the mental health of children and young people, Deb Loeb told us: "The waiting lists and lack of resources are just desperate."

There is a national shortage of child psychiatrists. Four years ago the NHS executive was recording increasing concern about "the fragmentation and reduction in child and adolescent mental health services around the country". This month, the Department of Health told us it has only 180 child psychiatrists in the whole country and that most of those are in the south-east.

There is a national network of educational psychologists, 1,820 of them, but everyone who works in the field says they have become overwhelmed with assessing children for "statements" which entitle schools to extra money to help them. Brian Harrison Jennings, secretary of the Association of Educational Psychologists, said: "We are so busy seeing the next child being referred to us that we don't have time to implement the very course of action that we recognise they would benefit from. All we can do is to refer them to someone else and, for the most part, that someone else may not be able to see them either."

The "statementing" of children has itself become part of the problem, subverted by spending cuts and overwhelmed by demand. The audit commission last year found that only 48% of draft statements are prepared within the statutory timescale of 18 weeks; one in 10 trusts could not offer an appointment within six months of referral, and in five areas the average wait for an assessment was more than a year. Even if the child is assessed, its appeal for money goes to the local special needs panel, whose funds have been so rationed that frequently they will cover only a minimal number of hours support in the school.

Baroness Warnock, whose 1978 inquiry introduced statementing, now regards the system as a disaster. Last month the government withdrew plans for a new bill which was intended to re-organise the whole area of special educational needs.

The only other specialist support for disaffected children comes from educational welfare officers. Like the educational psychologists, they have become overwhelmed, each of them responsible for an average of 3,000 children, according to the National Foundation for Educational Research, who found welfare officers were frequently too busy with the paperwork of truancy even to begin to deal with its causes.

For the most part the damaged children are left with their parents, who often are part of the problem, and with their teachers, who have very little time and even less specialist training.

It is easy to imagine that there is a safety net somewhere else, that the children outside the liftshaft in the block are unusual. They are not. Elsewhere we found children out of school whose lives were grossly disfigured and who were receiving no effective help: an 11-year-old girl in Kent who was spending her evenings in a van while her mother, a prostitute, serviced punters in the back; a 14-year-old girl in Hammersmith, west London, who had been living in a car with her homeless parents; an 11-year-old boy, also in Hammersmith, who was found abandoned at Heathrow airport; a diaspora of Somalian children, some of whom have seen their parents killed. The government's strategy for truancy and exclusion rests on the effectiveness of in-school projects which will attempt to cope with these damaged children. If they fail, the whole thing collapses in disarray and disorder. The biggest scheme - and the only one which is being nationally co-ordinated - is the introduction of mentors as guides and role models for difficult children.

The idea comes from the United States where researchers have found that the Big Brothers Big Sisters movement has had real success, but the same researchers warned that "these findings do not mean that the benefits of mentoring occur automatically". Although the DFEE has quoted this research in support of its scheme, it has failed so far to introduce the kind of rigorous screening of volunteers, training, supervision and support on which the American scheme relies. When the DFEE commissioned its own research from the Centre for Social Action, the result was a loud alarm bell.

Echoing the warning from the United States, the CSA warned that the DFEE needed to invest heavily. When it looked at one project in detail, it found signs that the DFEE had failed to create effective schemes on the American model: "The mentoring relationships created are too shallow to make a difference and only have value to the young person as a means of avoiding lessons and the opportunity of a free trip." The CSA concluded: "What is regrettable is seeing the potential of this form of practice wasted through insufficient planning, lack of money, lack of communication and lack of a philosophical base that values young people's participation."

And yet the schools minister, Estelle Morris, said in May that there was already evidence that the DFEE mentoring was having "a positive impact on pupils' behaviour, attendance at school and attitudes to learning". Her department made no mention of the CSA findings but said that the minister was referring to evidence which had been produced by the National Foundation for Educational Research. In fact, the NFER report produced no statistical evidence whatsoever of any improvement in attendance or any other aspect of pupil behaviour.

Harsh

Oddly, the NFER researchers decided not to interview any of the children involved nor to use questionnaires which some of them completed. Instead, they quoted positive anecdotal comments from some of the organisers and then revealed that the average time which children spent with their mentors was only one hour a fortnight during the academic year, ie 21 hours in a calendar year. Set this beside the conclusion of the US researchers who studied schemes where children were spending 120 hours over 15 months with their mentors and concluded: "The time together does not seem sufficient to offset poor school performance, negative influences on self-esteem and 14 or more years of living in poverty. While mentors can teach responsibility and values, discuss the importance of education and trying one's best, they cannot be expected to completely neutralise the harsh conditions in which many of these adolescents live." So far as the myriad different in-school projects are concerned, there is no evidence of whether they will succeed or fail. Clearly, they are well intentioned, and although some are simply exercises in policing to catch truants and bring them back to school, others are imaginative efforts to tackle children's problems: Circles of Friends, where schools use the peer pressure of successful students; behaviour support teams, which pass behaviour-management techniques on to teachers, support staff and parents; nurture groups, which separate difficult children and attempt to teach them how to be students. Some schools are reporting encouraging signs of progress.

However, almost all of these schemes suffer from a potentially devastating weakness. They rely on the same overstretched network of specialists who are already struggling to find time to work effectively and so they attempt to delegate skills to teachers and parents and others, none of whom has any specialist training at all. As a result, they cannot be and do not claim to be therapeutic in any meaningful sense. Teachers are not therapists.

There are a few genuinely therapeutic schemes in schools. The Place To Be, for example, sends trained counsellors into 28 schools in the London area and is supported by the DFEE. And there are private schemes, such as Camila Batmanghelidjh's arches, which struggle to survive without any statutory funding from the DFEE or anyone else.

If the approach to disaffected children is frail, the approach to disaffected parents is even weaker. Jenny Price of the Association for Education Welfare Managers, said: "Fewer truant in the traditional sense, ie absenteeism without people knowing. What is more common is parents who don't care if they go to school or not, or allow them to stay at home to look after the house or after the kids. There is more of that, and it is more difficult to deal with."

In a sweep on the streets of Sheffield last month officials found 200 children who should have been in school, 75% of whom were absent with "flimsy excuses" from parents. Welfare officers say that where once any absence at all would have been investigated, now a parent who writes letters can keep their child off school without much fear of being investigated. If they do get a visit, we were told, all they need to do is hide behind the door.

To deal with this, the DFEE is relying on heavier fines and the new home-school contracts, introduced last year at a cost of £1.6m with clear political benefits but without any obvious impact on the problem parents. We met the parents of truants who had been sleeping with their children in a playground, who had fled their homes under siege from violent neighbours, who were addicted to drugs or alcohol or crushed by depression or who complained bitterly that their children were too terrified of gang bullying to go anywhere near their school. When we asked them about the effect of the new fines and the home-school contracts, they just shrugged.

This profoundly fragile structure has then been undermined by decisions which appear to be political rather than educational. The social exclusion unit and the audit commission both studied truancy and exclusion and both stressed that government strategy must be "joined up", involving all of the different local agencies who might be able to help.

In October 1998 David Blunkett adopted this view and asked LEAs to prepare three-year plans involving all their agencies, to take effect in April 1999. However, in July 1999, just as his officials had finished approving all the plans, he changed his mind and, as part of his political drive to divert power and money away from the LEAs, he announced that schools would have to take over the job; he gave them only six weeks over the summer holidays to comment on his change of direction.

This devolution not only caused short-term chaos but posed a long-term threat to the idea of a "joined-up" approach by putting all of the other agencies in a secondary position, relying on schools to come to them with money, instead of being a directly-funded part of an LEA plan. The local government association has warned education ministers that their inclusion strategy has been "seriously jeopardised by compulsory devolution".

Mr Blunkett launched a further political initiative which also threatens to dam age the chances of success for in-school units - performance-related pay for teachers. The object of these units is to work with difficult children and reintegrate them back into the classroom as soon as possible and, at the very latest, within two terms.

The new deal on performance-related pay will give experienced teachers a bonus of £2,000, but only if, among other things, their results improve. This adds a new financial incentive to reject the reintegration of a student who is likely to perform badly and to disrupt the class. The result is that at the same time as he is trying to negate the school's incentive to exclude difficult children, Mr Blunkett has introduced a new incentive for teachers to do the opposite of what he wants.

The DFEE's new investment disguises a simultaneous cut in the education of disaffected children. For years, truants and the excluded have been offered a safety net of 320 LEA pupil referral units outside schools. This network is notoriously inadequate, catering for only a fraction of the needy children with some 8,000 places for the tens of thousands who might need them. There has been nothing unusual in a child waiting a year between a permanent exclusion and a place in a PRU. When finally it comes, it often involves only a few hours of teaching each week, usually in an inadequate building and without any kind of specialist resources to tackle the child's problems. Now, this safety net is to be cut.

In Mr Blunkett's plan, LEAs no longer have a statutory responsibility for truants outside school. Pregnant schoolgirls and young mothers similarly will be dropped by the PRUS. If they chose to, LEAs are now free to make substantial savings by simply closing any out-of-school unit that was helping truants or schoolgirl mothers. They must continue to provide for any student who is excluded for more than three weeks - but many are cutting back even these units on the assumption that all of their schools will succeed in hitting their targets for retaining these pupils within school walls.

According to LEA documents, Sheffield, for example, will now provide only "the minimum necessary for compliance with statutory duties". This means: getting rid of 16% of its PRU teachers; completely closing the two units which deal with truants; closing the unit for pregnant girls; then reducing the time available in units for the excluded. The remaining out-of-school units will provide limited short-term help for excluded secondary children and nothing for excluded primary children.

Alongside these reduced PRUs, Sheffield is providing learning mentors in every secondary school, new learning support units in nine of them and a pupil inclusion team to track pupils and offer advice to schools. This is an improvement in one sense: in-school places are cheaper and they are being subsidised by the DFEE, and so the in-school units can cater for more children than the old PRUs. But the whole strategy relies on one thing - that the schools will hit their targets and succeed in keeping the children within their walls. The LEA documents admit that this will be tough: "It will be difficult to foresee exactly what remaining central needs will be, as the task of inclusion is extremely challenging."

fields.bodyText: One good thing about spitting is that it helps to pass the time. It's morning, about nine o'clock, and on the streets of south London the school buses have dumped their loads and the playgrounds have gone quiet. Up here, on the top floor of the tower block, the day has started, as it always does, with Karen and Philly and Annie May and the others sitting slouched on the black tile floor by the liftshaft, smoking and watching the minutes go by and practising their spitting. In the past they've tried hanging out in the shopping malls, but the old Bill hassled them. It's the same on the streets, really. Sometimes they go round Philly's house - his mum doesn't mind, she's in bed all day. But mostly, each morning they sit here in the block and, if it gets too cold with the wind blowing in from the open walkways, they go down on to the estate and, in among the dog crap and the flower tubs filled with fag ends, they find some litter and bring it back up here and light a fire on the landing, and then they sit and watch the smoke. A day in the life of a truant. It's better than school and, as the morning passes, they sit and sometimes talk, but not too much. When they first started coming up here they used to play in the lift. It was not much of a game: push the button, wait for the lift to arrive, get in, go mental - jump up and down as hard as you can and batter its walls and floor with your feet and your fists - then wait for someone else on another floor to call the lift and hope it does not work. Up here on the block, with half a dozen subdued children, it is easy to imagine that this is a small problem. At first sight, the official statistics confirm this. The audit commission says some 12,000 children a year are permanently excluded from school and a further 150,000 are excluded temporarily. It is not ideal but it is a tiny fraction of the whole pupil population. The commission also says that each year a million of the 8m children in our schools will be absent without authorisation. But many of those absences are for only one day. The numbers conceal as much as they reveal. They say nothing about the children who are 'cleansed' - pushed out of schools by headteachers who avoid officially recording them as exclusions. They say nothing about the children who turn up at school to be registered and then walk straight out. Most of all they ignore all the children who are out of school but who do not qualify to be counted. There is an apparently vast reservoir of students whose absence from school is authorised by parents who want them at home as carers for siblings or who just cannot be bothered to send them. And there are untold thousands who are not registered to any school at all because they have fallen through the system, usually because of their families' unstable lives: their parents are homeless and stay away from the authorities for fear of having their kids taken into care; they move and cannot cope with the bureaucracy of a new LEA; they stumble from one disastrous estate to another, and the education authorities simply lose track of them; they are among the 2,500 children of refugee families who, according to the Refugee Council, are being illegally denied an education; they are the children of travellers; they are in jail. But this is not about numbers. You really begin to see the scale of the problem only when you first catch a glimpse of what lies beneath it. There are two central truths: first, that this has far less to do with discipline than it has to do with an epidemic of emotional damage, particularly among the 30% of British children who live in poverty; second, that these children are the most visible part of the central problems of our schools, how to teach disaffected children who see no point in learning, how to give reality to the once-vibrant idea that education is the natural escape route from poverty. Come back to the block. By noon, a few of the faces have pushed off to play on the buses. That is not much of a game either. You get on the bus without a ticket, see how far you can travel before you get thrown off, then you walk home or maybe catch another bus, if you can be bothered. Other faces have arrived now. They all have the same kind of faces, with the shine rubbed off, and the same kind of stories. Listen to Karen, sitting with her back to the liftshaft wall, listless, aimless, hopeless, the kind of truant who gives David Blunkett nightmares - she has not been to school regularly since she was 11, and she is now 14. When she was seven her father started using heroin and crack cocaine and he got her mother on to it, too. Until then, life had been OK. They had a nice house, there was food in the kitchen, she was going to school. But the mother and father slid downhill fast, taking Karen and her three younger sisters with them. Her dad used to take her out thieving. She used to knock on the door, a little girl with gaps in her teeth, and if there was someone in, she would ask for a glass of water and run along; if not, her dad would smash a window and they'd get inside and take whatever they could. She got arrested for that eventually, when she was 11, and spent 36 hours in a cell. By that time she had long lost sight of normal life. She says there was no food in the house, and to feed her sisters as well as herself she would go and borrow money off friends or eat at someone else's house or steal things from shops or scavenge in rubbish bins. They had no light or heat in the house. Her mum and dad just did drugs and watched the time go by. She became the stand-in mother, feeding and caring for the three younger ones. At first, when she stopped going to school, she still took the others, but then it got too much and so they all stopped. From time to time the welfare officer used to come round and bang on the door, and Karen says her mum just told them to keep quiet and then the welfare officer would go away. If there were letters about it, they just ignored them. Eventually, her dad got sent to jail - four years for robbery - and her mum was left on her own with four children and a heroin habit. And that's the way it still is now. So why does she not want to sit in school? Because she is too sure there is no point, too scared to be caught out failing, too determined to advertise her indifference, too angry and too cynical - too emotionally damaged. When they are not up here in the block, Karen and the others spend most of their time in some old railway arches which have been converted into a kind of refuge for young people. They are run by a psychotherapist called Camila Batmanghelidjh who was taken to court by her building society because she stopped paying her mortgage and used the money to set up this day club for the kids under the arches. Batmanghelidjh reckons that one in three children in the inner cities have some form of emotional or behavioural difficulty. Several hundred children a day find their way to her arches. Most of them are more or less out of school. They live, she says, in a state of "emotional coldness". This is the hidden core of what politicians dismiss as mere truancy and exclusion. Last year the office for national statistics reported that 10% of Britain's children suffer from mental disorders - anxiety, depression, obsessions, clinically significant behaviour disorders and hyperactivity - but that figure masked the concentration of mental disorders among the children of the poor. The ONS found, for example, that among the children of families where both parents are unemployed, some 20% have a mental health problem. They also found that children with this kind of illness were four times more likely to truant than others. They were also three times more likely to have specific learning difficulties, three times more likely to have special educational needs and 10 times more likely to be in trouble with the police, all of which are linked to the kind of behaviour which leads to children being excluded. Unhappiness always has its reason. One of the 14-year-old girls who moves between the block and Batmanghelidjh's arches has started working as a street prostitute. It seems she is doing so at the behest of her mother, who needs the money. There is an 11-year-old boy who lives with his ageing gran because neither of his parents want anything to do with him; a 15-year-old girl whose mother died of cancer years ago, whose father is preoccupied with selling drugs, who has been in and out of care and who had her first abortion at 13; another 13-year-old girl who is given money for sex by an elderly man; two brothers, aged 17 and 11, both of them drug runners; a 12-year-old girl who recently found her father after he had overdosed and who has now been sent to live with her mother, who makes no secret of not wanting her. The strategy of the education secretary, David Blunkett, is all about "inclusivity". He has introduced a complex package of sticks and carrots to persuade schools and LEAs to divert truants and the excluded back into the classroom. By 2002 he wants a reduction of 30% in both statistics; every secondary school and every LEA has been given a target. He is paying new pupil support grants so that a thousand schools can set up learning support units to help them to reach the targets. If they miss the targets, he will withdraw their grants. Some schools will also receive money to pay for learning mentors to help disaffected children. He has given LEAs new powers to join appeals against exclusion and made it their responsibility to pick up the bill for the education of those who nevertheless are excluded. Finally, the Home Office has introduced fines for parents who fail to send their children to school and powers for police to pick up truants on the streets. Tactics This strategy has its merits. Mr Blunkett is targeting extra resources on some of the poorest areas. Funding for learning mentors, for example, is being delivered through the excellence in cities programme focused on six metropolitan areas. Behind all the rhetoric about discipline, the reality is that many schools are now are attempting to tackle the underlying problems of the most disaffected children. However, there are two problems. First, the tactics of the new school units and also the DFEE's particular version of mentoring are, at best, untested and, at worst, proven failures. If these schemes fail to change the way in which these children are behaving, we will have locked into our schools a group of the most delinquent and difficult children and we will start to see the kind of violence which has become part of the currency of daily life in some inner city schools in the United States. The second problem is that Mr Blunkett has, on the one hand, made moves to persuade schools to deal with disaffected children, and then with the other hand, launched political initiatives which undermine those moves. Beyond that, the strategy suffers from the political decision to leave in place the whole package of reforms introduced by the former education secretary, Kenneth Baker, in the late 1980s. As this series has previously shown, this structure penalises the most disaffected children: they perform badly in exams; their schools tumble down the league tables; middle-class families use their professional skills and their strength in the property market to take their motivated children away to schools with a less disaffected intake; when they do that, they take funds away with them, the struggling school is left with even fewer motivated children and even less money to educate them and so it spirals downwards. In short, the children of the poor get the schools with the poorest budgets, an imbalance that is not corrected by the available subsidies for needy children which notoriously are rationed, inefficiently distributed and inadequate in the first place. Furthermore, these schools have had a direct financial incentive to exclude the most difficult children in order to improve their position in the league tables. As the Baker reforms took hold, exclusions rose fivefold in five years. Leaving Kenneth Baker's system in place, Mr Blunkett has introduced counter-measures to try to give schools a financial interest in not excluding children. The problem is that neither structure provides a neutral framework in which a school can decide a child's future purely on grounds of education and behaviour. Come back to the block and to Camila Batmanghelidjh's arches. The morning is past, the afternoon is wearing on and, up in the block, where Batmanghelidjh is not in charge, finally they have found something to do. They are smoking hash. Batmanghelidjh knows they do it. She knows it is part of the daily routine, for as long as they can afford the hash. And worse. She has one 12-year-old who had rocks of crack cocaine found in his pocket. She has urged them not do it, but she is not about to hammer them for it, because she knows why it is happening: "They use cannabis to control their moods." And why do they do that? Because just about nobody else is doing anything to help them with those moods. The ONS can tell the world that 20% of poor children are mentally ill. Nobody quarrels with the finding (which has been replicated by other studies). But this country's strange and terrible reaction has been to shake its head and then to offer virtually no care at all. The audit commission last year found that less than half the health authorities in the country even had a policy for child mental health and that, among those who did, there were all kinds of gaps and overlaps where different agencies were failing to work together. The ONS similarly, having recorded the scale of mental illness among children, found that 30% of these children had not been seen even once by a specialist, or even by a GP. At Young Minds, a national charity working to promote the mental health of children and young people, Deb Loeb told us: "The waiting lists and lack of resources are just desperate." There is a national shortage of child psychiatrists. Four years ago the NHS executive was recording increasing concern about "the fragmentation and reduction in child and adolescent mental health services around the country". This month, the Department of Health told us it has only 180 child psychiatrists in the whole country and that most of those are in the south-east. There is a national network of educational psychologists, 1,820 of them, but everyone who works in the field says they have become overwhelmed with assessing children for "statements" which entitle schools to extra money to help them. Brian Harrison Jennings, secretary of the Association of Educational Psychologists, said: "We are so busy seeing the next child being referred to us that we don't have time to implement the very course of action that we recognise they would benefit from. All we can do is to refer them to someone else and, for the most part, that someone else may not be able to see them either." The "statementing" of children has itself become part of the problem, subverted by spending cuts and overwhelmed by demand. The audit commission last year found that only 48% of draft statements are prepared within the statutory timescale of 18 weeks; one in 10 trusts could not offer an appointment within six months of referral, and in five areas the average wait for an assessment was more than a year. Even if the child is assessed, its appeal for money goes to the local special needs panel, whose funds have been so rationed that frequently they will cover only a minimal number of hours support in the school. Baroness Warnock, whose 1978 inquiry introduced statementing, now regards the system as a disaster. Last month the government withdrew plans for a new bill which was intended to re-organise the whole area of special educational needs. The only other specialist support for disaffected children comes from educational welfare officers. Like the educational psychologists, they have become overwhelmed, each of them responsible for an average of 3,000 children, according to the National Foundation for Educational Research, who found welfare officers were frequently too busy with the paperwork of truancy even to begin to deal with its causes. They must continue to provide for any student who is excluded for more than three weeks - but many are cutting back even these units on the assumption that all of their schools will succeed in hitting their targets for retaining these pupils within school walls. According to LEA documents, Sheffield, for example, will now provide only "the minimum necessary for compliance with statutory duties". This means: getting rid of 16% of its PRU teachers; completely closing the two units which deal with truants; closing the unit for pregnant girls; then reducing the time available in units for the excluded. The remaining out-of-school units will provide limited short-term help for excluded secondary children and nothing for excluded primary children. Alongside these reduced PRUs, Sheffield is providing learning mentors in every secondary school, new learning support units in nine of them and a pupil inclusion team to track pupils and offer advice to schools. This is an improvement in one sense: in-school places are cheaper and they are being subsidised by the DFEE, and so the in-school units can cater for more children than the old PRUs. But the whole strategy relies on one thing - that the schools will hit their targets and succeed in keeping the children within their walls. The LEA documents admit that this will be tough: "It will be difficult to foresee exactly what remaining central needs will be, as the task of inclusion is extremely challenging." Truants continued

fields.headline: Transcript: Rupert Thomson live online
fields.standfirst: The author of The Insult, Soft and the Book of Revelation discusses pornography, desert islands, and trusting the unconscious. Read the full talk thread here.
fields.trailText: The author of The Insult, Soft and the Book of Revelation discusses pornography, desert islands, and trusting the unconscious. Read the full talk thread here
fields.body:
dfic1999
Though I've not read the novel yet (it's in the queue on my shelves), I do want to ask: Is it possible to write a psychologically convincing novel of male masochism, without the cliches of pornography? Also, why a dancer?

RupertThomson
Obviously I think so, but I had to trust in my unconscious to do it. The cliches of pornography were actually quite useful - especially in the white room when the three women are trying to think of things that might excite the dancer: I could have them think of things like red underwear, and then have it *not* work. Why a dancer? Because I needed someone who was a) physically beautiful and b) to some extent a public figure. He could then become an object of desire.

Shirleygirl
I've always wondered, the mountain near Shepherd's Bush in Soft - was that real? I always mean to look when I'm going past, but not sure where it would be if indeed it exists!

RupertThomson
shirleygirl - if you look for the mountain now, all you'll see are rows and rows of black taxis. What happens in the novel was what happened in real life. One day the mountain was there, in the waste ground behind Paddington Station ( and yes, I did climb it), the next day it was gone. An as yet unsolved mystery.

RRL30
I met you at a programme called Booked a few years ago.You had a lovely suit on with a bright blue lining and we talked about bereavment. I enjoyed Soft but loved The Insult. Have you read Corpsing by Toby Litt? I've just finshed that and it had a similar feel all the way through (although I have to say the style did not come close to The Insult) but in the end there was no mystery or confusion. The Insult is one of my favourite books of all time. Thank you.

RupertThomson
rrl30 - no, I haven't read Corpsing, so there's really nothing I can say about it (though I have the feeling I met him once). I'm so glad you liked Soft and The Insult. I'm especially glad you liked my suit.

shem32
I also loved The Insult, and - not to annoy you with endless comparisons with other writers - found it reminded me in feel of Paul Auster's New York Trilogy.
Do you like Auster? Do you see any similarity? Thanks

RupertThomson
shem32 - I like the *idea* of Auster, but I've never read anything he's written. Since I'll be meeting him on a desert island in October, I think now's probably a good time to start.

Betsy2
Hello, I've just finished The Book of Revelation and found it utterly compelling - I think I was up until 3 am the night I started reading it because I was just sucked in, couldn't put it down 'til I'd finished. I have a few questions: First, how/why did you choose a dancer for the main character? Also - this is awfully book-discussion-y but I have to ask - why did you call it the Book of Revelation? Are there any comparisons (ironic, literal, snide, whatever) to the Biblical Book of Revelation? I've never read the Bible, but the day after I finished your book I got on the web and looked up this particular chapter--wierd!!! Do you have any comments on it?

RupertThomson
betsy2 - Thanks very much for being so compelled. I arrived at the title by a very circuitous route. For a long time the novel was called The Book of Nakedness. Then I noticed that the word 'reveal' appeared pretty frequently... The Book of Revelation had a weight to it that I liked. It also lets you know that the book is a secret that has been kept for many years and is only now being told. So the book is a revelation in that very literal sense. Nothing particularly biblical, though.

Betsy2
Thanks! You might be interested to know there are some strange coincidences (but maybe you only see them if you are too excited after staying up till 3 am the night before!). Thanks for a great book, and I'll certainly read your other ones

tamara
I first noticed 'Soft' in the book shop because of its cover - it was the snazzy orange hardback edition. I went straight to it, read the blurb, and bought it. I had never heard of you... and then I read it (enjoyed it) and ironically enough, it was partly about the power (abuse) of marketing. I didn't know whether to laugh or be annoyed at my own attraction to bright colours and lush-looking book covers. Was I a victim?

RupertThomson
tamara - There was something deliciously paradoxical about the idea of actively marketing a book that was so scathing about marketing. Also the publishers decided that it was the right time to give one of my books a push (The Insult had sold well with no hype at all - amazingly). If you were a victim, at least you were a satisfied victim. A word about that orange edition - don't leave it in the sun. It turns yellow.

nsalt
Reading the extract of your new book reminded me of certain themes in The Insult, a greatly enjoyed read. How far is your writing informed by an exploration of the fallibility of perception? How close do you consider the link between reality and experience?

RupertThomson
nsalt - I think the insult derived a lot of its power by attempting to inhabit and explore the gap between what a character perceives and some kind of fixed, objective reality. In that sense, it was a schizophrenic book to write: underneath every sentence there was a second invisible sentence. I'm interested in anything that gives me a new angle on 'everyday experience.' To put it another way, I'll quote Flannery O' Connor, one of my favourite writers: "The task of a writer is to be concerned not with issues, not with problems, but with all those concrete details of life that make actual the mystery of our position on earth."

larry1000
I met a man who did the marketing for Sunny Delight - apparently the launch co-incided with publication of Soft (which I loved) and caused a massive corporate nightmare - a case of life imitating art?!

RupertThomson
larry1000 - The short answer is yes - and it's not the first time it's happened. Some time after finishing The Five Gates of Hell (a book that takes a surreal look at the death industry ) I read about two brothers in France who had recently opened a chain of death supermarkets. Perhaps I'm in the wrong business.

kudra
Really enjoyed Revelation - thank you. A couple of questions: The description of the dancer's changing emotions while he is being held hostage, and the psychological strategies he uses to help him cope with the situation, are very vivid - did you do any research to try and get into his mind? Did you read books by/talk to people who have been in hostage/kidnap situations?
Also, why did you decide to set it in Amsterdam?
Thanks

RupertThomson
kudra - When I'm writing fiction, I have to have a kind of blind faith in myself, especially when it comes to the psychology of my characters. I often have the feeling that I'm writing about something I know, even if I don't know how I know what I know. Louise Bourgeois said something interesting on this subject: "I trust the unconscious. The unconscious is my friend." So no, no research on the Stockholm syndrome, or anything like that. A lot of research on dancers and dancing, Amsterdam etc. Why Amsterdam? The book was set there from the very beginning. It could have been set in Los Angeles, I suppose, or Paris - many cities have that hidden seam of perversity, that sense of an underworld - but Amsterdam worked perfectly. Also I'd lived there once for a year.

naomi2
Dear Rupert, I'm intrigued. Why will you be on a desert island with Paul Auster in October? Can I come and rescue you both?

RupertThomson
naomi2 - I've been invited to the Brisbane literary festival, along with Paul Auster, Patrick McGrath, Peter Carey (among others). If you've flown a long way, they send you on what they call a 'retreat', supposedly so you can get over your jet lag. The retreat is this case is Fraser Island, just south of the great barrier reef. It has fresh-water lakes, petrified forests. The whales are going to be breeding (or whatever they do in october). I'm not sure I'm going to need rescuing. It sounds too idyllic.

blackbird21
I'm half way through The Book of Revelation and like everyone else find it unputdownable. Is there anything you've read recently that has had that effect?
Also can you divulge anything about your next book?

RupertThomson
blackbird 21 - I found it pretty hard to put down the last book I read - Bastard out of Carolina by Dorothy Allison. I tend not to say too much about what I'm working on. I did think of a way of describing it the other day, though: Philip K. Dick meets Voltaire.

furness
Who, or what, was the inspiration behind Loots? The image of Martin "seeing" Loots cycling home from work through deserted streets doing a variety of circus tricks is one of the most memorable and inspiring scenes I've ever read. The Insult is an absolutely wonderful book. I salute you.

RupertThomson
furness - I'm sorry but I have no idea where Loots came from. He just magically appeared (as he would, of course). I'm so glad you enjoyed the book.

derek03
Did the sexual domination and mutilation which featured in the book of revelation stem from a particular fantasy of yours?

RupertThomson
derek03 - The scenes of sexual domination and mutilation came as a complete surprise to me, and were extremely difficult to write (I often think I write either to challenge or to surprise myself), so no, not a fantasy. A nightmare? Maybe.

kudra
Revelation is a very visual book - the image of the white room, the meal and the performance of Swan Lake have really stayed with me. Have you been approached by any film-makers who are interested in adapting it? Do you think it's filmable? If so, who would be your first choice of director and leads? Thanks!

RupertThomson
kudra - Following a very enthusiastic review in the New York Times I received about twenty faxes from producers, directors, etc. from all over the world, everyone from the people who made The Matrix to the director of The Exorcist. I am now in the process of selling the film rights, but it has to remain a secret for the time being. All I can reveal at this stage is, I said a big no to hollywood.

mmreed
Did you think the Book of Revelation would be perceived as shocking - or is that, in itself, marketing?

RupertThomson
mmreed - the Book of Revelation shocked me when I first started it, but, as Truman Capote says, "writing is re-writing," so by the time I had gone through six or seven complete drafts of the book, it became quite literally everyday. Did Bloomsbury market it as a shocking book? That wasn't really my impression.

fiveonions
I agree about the Auster (do you?). Who would you cite as your literary influences? Do you read (and/or like) 'the classics'?

RupertThomson
fiveonions - My literary influences? Paul Bowles, William Faulkner, Flannery O' Connor, Jean Rhys, Patrick Modiano, Vladimir Nabokov. I know there are more, but I've gone blank. as for the classics, Dostoyevky, Conrad (does he count?), and there are certain books I often return to - Jane Eyre, for instance.

Ccole
What do you reckon to all this internet business?

RupertThomson
ccole - This is my first time. I keep my computer sealed off from the outside world. It would be too tempting otherwise.

blackbird21
Any advice for wannabe novel writers out there?

RupertThomson
blackbird21 - Three pieces of advice for people trying to write fiction (two cribbed from John Cage, the composer): experiment endlessly, work hard and stay humble.

Ccole
Another question: have you ever considered writing under a pseudonym? What would you choose? and what kind of book do you fancy writing anonymously?

RupertThomson
ccole - I don't think I'm ever going to write anonymously. I'm not sure what the point would be. You usually get found out anyway (look at Joe Klein, the 'anonymous' behind Primary Colours). Having said that, there is a book I want to write which cannot be published during my lifetime. It concerns a member of my family who I have not seen for many years. Publishing the book anonymously would not provide me with sufficient distance. It will have to wait until after I'm dead. on that somewhat sombre note, goodbye.

webTitle: The worst decisions come in threes

fields.headline: The worst decisions come in threes
fields.trailText: After last year's experience in the World Cup, you might think the England hierarchy would be wary of appointing a wicketkeeper-captain.
fields.body:
After last year's experience in the World Cup, you might think the England hierarchy would be wary of appointing a wicketkeeper-captain.

But now Alec Stewart, at 37, is back in the pair of jobs, after regaining his one-day place from Chris Read and being asked to deputise for Nasser Hussain in both Test and one-day cricket. And he's not alone.

Two other players, whose combined ages are less than Stewart's, have just been asked to perform the same juggling act. The new captain of the England Under-19 team, who play Sri Lanka in three one-day internationals this month, is Mark Wallace, Glamorgan's 2nd XI keeper. And the captain of the England Under-15 team to play in this month's junior World Cup, the Costcutter World Challenge, is also a keeper - Tom New of Nottinghamshire.

Do three wrongs make a right?

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Pleading penury, Selling sweeties and Hunting hares

fields.headline: Pleading penury, Selling sweeties and Hunting hares
fields.trailText: THE £ITTLE$T HOBO
fields.body:
THE £ITTLE$T HOBO

It's never nice to run into someone who is down on their luck. So imagine our shock when we stopped to give some loose change to a tramp who was loudly moaning about his fiscal situation... only to find we were giving our last coppers to Manchester United boss Alex Ferguson! Shocked and stunned, we stood awhile, watching him root around in bins for the odd scrap of half-eaten Figo or a nice cardboard Zidane to sleep in. Finally, he spoke.

"The only way Manchester United can improve the team is by buying the Zidanes and Figos of this world," the angry vagabond - wife and richest club in the world to support - told the Manchester Evening News today. "It is out of our financial reach," he continued. "It's all about money and it's difficult finding players who are good enough for here at our wage level." Ah, the injustices of this ruthless capitalist system!

But although beside himself with rage, the poor man still managed to remain philosophical in the face of his abject penury. "It's something that annoys you at times," he mused, wringing a flat cap in his hands, "but there is nothing you can do about it. There are some things we are exploring, but I'm very happy with the squad I have got." The Fiver couldn't stand to witness this sorry scene any longer and hurried away, but not before wishing Fergie some financial luck for once. And we're sure we spoke for fans of Ipswich, Watford, Oxford and many other clubs when we did.

A NEWSAGENT, NOT A SNOOZEAGENT

Hello folks, allow me to introduce myself. I'm WH Smyth, the newsagent. You know, I didn't envisage spending most of my life stuck behind this old wooden counter, flogging papers and cheap confectionery. No, it was always my dream to report on football. Oh for the chance to be the first to tell the nation that Tottenham Hotspur have completed a £5m deal for Wimbledon defender Ben Thatcher. But things never worked out the way I wanted them to, and here I am rearranging a rack of pornographic magazines instead.

If my life panned out in a different way, I'd be informing everyone of Nicolas Anelka's imminent £20m move from Real Madrid to the moody striker's first club Paris St Germain, the Spanish club agreeing to take a £3m loss on the player they bought from Arsenal last summer. But it wasn't to be, and I've got to accept that.

I mean, don't get me wrong, I don't hate my life. Although imagine how happy I'd be sitting at a computer, tapping out an article about Charlton, who have agreed a £2.5m fee with Everton for Don Hutchison - the ex-Hammer is also being tracked by Coventry and Sunderland, but is thought to favour a return to London. Ah, but it's all just a pipe dream... look, are you going to buy that or not? This isn't a bloody library, you know.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I want to play for Graeme Souness. It sounds corny but he was my idol at Liverpool" - Craig Hignett induces mass projectile vomiting upon joining Blackburn today for £2.25m.

HUNTING FOR A STORY

If the shrill blast of the final whistle on the last day of the season is the traditional signal for Newcastle's finest to decamp to Agia Napia and get so drunk they can't remember how many young ladies they've defiled, the opposite is true, alas, for the hardened hack. Because that last whistle blow is like a hunter's horn, sounding the start of the traditional pre-season race to find to the biggest, most astonishing world-exclusive football rumour. Ever.

Obviously, the Fiver plays its part - who can forget our "Tony Yeboah has bought a luxury pad in Docklands" or "Southgate to Southampton" scoops? But usually the hare we're all chasing is the Mirror's never-very-happy Harry Harris. Sadly, he's been slowing up this pre-season, and he'd better watch out, because which hound is leading the chasing pack? Why, none other than the Sun's Brian Bouffant. Scamper, scamper, scamper!

With Woolnough and his pals disclosing that Liverpool's Titi Camara is probably off to Bradford for £2.5m, and that Paul Merson is sure to be leaving Villa after having another pop at the hapless John Gregory, Harry the Hare needs to catch a second wind. And in the nick of time, by revealing Internazionale have made an "astonishing" £31m bid for Paul Scholes, he managed it.

His tale - the United board are apparently tempted to take the money, although Sir Alex Ferguson does not want to sell - certainly convinces us. Manchester United are lining up an £11m bid for Internazionale's Javier Zanetti - but they face competition from Barcelona and Real Madrid.

Everton are expected to move for £6m-rated Neil Lennon to counter the expected departures of Don Hutchinson, John Collins and Nick Barmby.

Cambridge's 21 year-old striker Trevor Benjamin is poised to complete a £1.5m move to Leicester.

NEWS IN BRIEF

South African officials have laid the blame for the Zimbabwe stadium tragedy on police over-reaction. Policemen fired tear gas into the 60,000 crowd at the National Stadium in Harare which caused a stampede in which at least 13 people were killed. "It was not crowd violence, but rather the response from the police forced them to try and get out from under the tear gas canisters fired into the crowd," claimed Danny Jordaan, chairman of South Africa's failed bid for the 2006 World Cup.

Bolton have been charged by the FA with failing to control their players in their Division One play-off match against Ipswich. Bolton had Robbie Elliott and Mike Whitlow sent off and eight other players booked by referee Barry Knight, who also awarded Ipswich three controversial penalties. The club have been given a suspended fine of £25,000.

Leeds are to appeal after the Department for Education and Employment rejected their application for a work permit for Mark Viduka. The DfEE claim the £6m signing from Celtic does not meet their set criteria because he has not played enough internationals for Australia in the last two years.

Birmingham have signed Fulham striker Geoff Horsfield for a club record £2.25m. The 26-year-old has agreed a five-year deal.

Leeds have been handed a major boost with the news that South Africa will not force skipper Lucas Radebe to play in the Sydney Olympics.

Luton have appointed their former England midfielder Ricky Hill as manager to succeed Lennie Lawrence, who was sacked a week ago following a change in the ownership of the club. Hill, 41, played for Luton for 14 years.

Steve Bull is to become a coach at Hereford.

BBC 1: Ground Force (8.30pm)

Charlie Dimmock, Tommy Walsh and Alan Titchmarsh give an unsuspecting neighbour a headache by erecting a pavilion close to his boundary for an expectant mother in Sandersted. Can he be placated?

A symposium: Ross Kemp debates the merits of the catenneccio over the flat-back four.

Kansas City Dodge Vipers v NY/NJ Jeep Cherokees.

fields.bodyText: THE £ITTLE$T HOBO It's never nice to run into someone who is down on their luck. So imagine our shock when we stopped to give some loose change to a tramp who was loudly moaning about his fiscal situation... only to find we were giving our last coppers to Manchester United boss Alex Ferguson! Shocked and stunned, we stood awhile, watching him root around in bins for the odd scrap of half-eaten Figo or a nice cardboard Zidane to sleep in. Finally, he spoke. "The only way Manchester United can improve the team is by buying the Zidanes and Figos of this world," the angry vagabond - wife and richest club in the world to support - told the Manchester Evening News today. "It is out of our financial reach," he continued. "It's all about money and it's difficult finding players who are good enough for here at our wage level." Ah, the injustices of this ruthless capitalist system! But although beside himself with rage, the poor man still managed to remain philosophical in the face of his abject penury. "It's something that annoys you at times," he mused, wringing a flat cap in his hands, "but there is nothing you can do about it. There are some things we are exploring, but I'm very happy with the squad I have got." The Fiver couldn't stand to witness this sorry scene any longer and hurried away, but not before wishing Fergie some financial luck for once. And we're sure we spoke for fans of Ipswich, Watford, Oxford and many other clubs when we did. A NEWSAGENT, NOT A SNOOZEAGENT Hello folks, allow me to introduce myself. I'm WH Smyth, the newsagent. You know, I didn't envisage spending most of my life stuck behind this old wooden counter, flogging papers and cheap confectionery. No, it was always my dream to report on football. Oh for the chance to be the first to tell the nation that Tottenham Hotspur have completed a £5m deal for Wimbledon defender Ben Thatcher. But things never worked out the way I wanted them to, and here I am rearranging a rack of pornographic magazines instead. If my life panned out in a different way, I'd be informing everyone of Nicolas Anelka's imminent £20m move from Real Madrid to the moody striker's first club Paris St Germain, the Spanish club agreeing to take a £3m loss on the player they bought from Arsenal last summer. But it wasn't to be, and I've got to accept that. I mean, don't get me wrong, I don't hate my life. Although imagine how happy I'd be sitting at a computer, tapping out an article about Charlton, who have agreed a £2.5m fee with Everton for Don Hutchison - the ex-Hammer is also being tracked by Coventry and Sunderland, but is thought to favour a return to London. Ah, but it's all just a pipe dream... look, are you going to buy that or not? This isn't a bloody library, you know. QUOTE OF THE DAY "I want to play for Graeme Souness. It sounds corny but he was my idol at Liverpool" - Craig Hignett induces mass projectile vomiting upon joining Blackburn today for £2.25m. Obviously, the Fiver plays its part - who can forget our "Tony Yeboah has bought a luxury pad in Docklands" or "Southgate to Southampton" scoops? Sadly, he's been slowing up this pre-season, and he'd better watch out, because which hound is leading the chasing pack? Why, none other than the Sun's Brian Bouffant. Scamper, scamper, scamper! With Woolnough and his pals disclosing that Liverpool's Titi Camara is probably off to Bradford for £2.5m, and that Paul Merson is sure to be leaving Villa after having another pop at the hapless John Gregory, Harry the Hare needs to catch a second wind. fields.headline: Protest fears prompt Ulster shutdown
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland shut down early this afternoon in anticipation of widespread protests linked to the Orange Order's controversial Drumcree march.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland shut down early this afternoon in anticipation of widespread protests linked to the Orange Order's controversial Drumcree march.

In Portadown, where the local Orange Order has called for street protests after its parade was banned from the Garvaghy Road, shops closed early and roads were filled by the cars of people trying to get home before the expected demonstrations.

Orangemen from Portadown, Co Armagh, have called on supporters throughout Ulster to turn out between 4pm and 8pm today for demonstrations over their annual parade. They were yesterday prevented from returning from Drumcree Parish Church via the predominantly Catholic Garvaghy Road for the third year in succession.

The Orange Order issued a statement from its Belfast headquarters calling for the demonstrations to remain peaceful.

"The protests called for this afternoon must be peaceful and it is the responsibility of the local organisers to ensure this is the case," the statement issued from the House of Orange said.

"It is essential that protests are not used by malcontents, who have no real interest in the Orange institution, as a cover for violence.

"To those who have or would engage in violence we can only say STOP. You are not acting on our behalf. Your actions damage an honourable cause."

Over the past eight nights Drumcree and other parts of the province have erupted in disturbances linked to the dispute. Last night missiles were hurled at police and troops behind the large steel barrier and rolls of barbed wire blocking their path at Drumcree.

Earlier Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson issued a firm warning that loyalists were "very, very mistaken" if they believed violence and bullying would overturn the ban.

His words were echoed by first minister David Trimble, himself an Orangeman, who said dialogue was the only way the Portadown Orangemen could achieve their aims.

"I hope very much that people today and on succeeding days will be calm, will be peaceful, that there will be no violence whatsoever."

"I have to say to anyone who does resort to violence that they serve no cause at all, and will only bring dishonour and disgrace on the cause they profess to support," Mr Trimble said.

Their warnings came after a hoax bomb alert at the home of a member of the government-appointed parades commission, the body which ruled against the Orangemen's march.

Army bomb disposal officers carried out a controlled explosion on the object outside Billy Martin's house in Greyabbey, Co Down.

fields.headline: Blair is not superman
fields.standfirst:
After the worst week of his premiership, Tony Blair looks knackered. Political correspondent Nicholas Watt wonders why Downing Street won't admit that the prime minister is just a normal person
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: After the worst week of his premiership, Tony Blair looks knackered. Political correspondent Nicholas Watt wonders why Downing Street won't admit that the prime minister is just a normal person.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is showing unmistakable signs of normality. After the worst week of his premiership the prime minister looks drained, prompting the Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy to advise a "knackered" Mr Blair to take a holiday.

Tories will no doubt mutter in private that the prime minister's demeanour shows he is not up to the job, unlike their heroine Margaret Thatcher. During her 11 years in Downing Street, Mrs Thatcher famously soldiered on every day after a mere three hours' sleep.

While Tories may yearn for a return to such super-human form, people who live outside the enclosed world of Westminster are likely to be relaxed that Mr Blair shows the strains of domestic and political pressures.

Mr Blair's apparent ordinariness, as a father of young children, is one of the factors which propelled him to Downing Street: today's voters appreciate political leaders who can identify with their everyday problems.

The pressures of recent weeks have meant that the prime minister has not had his usual seven to eight hours of sleep a night, which explains his haggard look. At the same time, like any new parent, Mr Blair is frequently woken during the night by his screaming baby son, Leo.

Last Thursday illustrates the pressures of combining life as a young father with running the country. The prime minister did not get into bed until well after 1.30am on Thursday morning when his drunken son was returned to Downing Street.

Next, Mr Blair was up early to chair cabinet before heading off to the House of Lords for the celebrations marking the centenary of Australia's constitution. Then it was off to Victoria station for the train ride to Brighton where he made his emotional speech about his faith at 2.15pm.

After a quick chat with black church leaders he was whisked off to Shoreham to unveil a memorial to a murdered police officer. Mr Blair then returned to Brighton to record Question Time at 8.30pm, making it home by midnight.

Downing Street insisted yesterday that it was "total nonsense" to suggest that the prime minister was tired. Perhaps Mr Blair's spinners would be better off if they came clean and admitted that the prime minister is tired, like most other people as they await the summer holidays.
