webTitle: 'I had to get out of the car to tuck the roof edges in. What was Toyota thinking of?'

fields.headline: 'I had to get out of the car to tuck the roof edges in. What was Toyota thinking of?'
fields.standfirst: In the first of his weekly reviews,  Giles Smith tests the Toyota MR2 Roadster 1.8 VVTi
fields.trailText: It's hard to think that sports cars were once a fundamentally experimental zone - something for people whose motoring pleasure was not complete unless they grazed their shins every time they changed up to third and who liked to emerge afterwards covered in oil and gravel.
fields.body:
It's hard to think that sports cars were once a fundamentally experimental zone - something for people whose motoring pleasure was not complete unless they grazed their shins every time they changed up to third and who liked to emerge afterwards covered in oil and gravel.

A new generation of sports cars, many of them Japanese, has tamed the genre, almost to the extent that one wonders whether the word "sports" really applies any more, or whether it would be better replaced by "leisure". Owners of these models, one would hazard, are not much inclined to tinker with the engine at the weekend, but they do get them valeted on a regular basis. These cars cunningly combine the thrill of the open road with the comfort of the homely sofa. They're pushy, but they're also cute. They offer sports car ownership with none of the getting down and getting dirty.

Which is fine by an awful lot of people, to judge from the number of Mazdas and Toyotas one sees on the roads. Available in one derivative only, the new Toyota MR2 pitches itself right into the thick of this relatively bullish market. It's taken an envious look at the style and speed of the Porsche Boxster. And it's taken an equally envious look at the sales figures of the Rover MGF, whose price it undercuts. (You can still buy an MGF for a couple of hundred pounds less than a Toyota, but it will have a less powerful engine.)

As a rule of thumb, the closer the back of your neck is to the tarmac, the more authentic the sports car you are driving. In the Toyota, one sits pretty much upright, as in a slightly go-ahead estate car. In fact, I reckon you could just about walk into the MR2 without breaking stride. It's also possible to get out of the car without making tell-tale geriatric noises - a handy aspect given that a sizeable portion of the market for sports cars is men whose physical peak disappeared over the horizon at least a decade ago.

Depress the accelerator and the car doesn't exactly bolt you to your seat. Toyota say their engineers thought hard about the MR2's weight and they are able to boast that the car has the best power-to-weight ratio in its class. It does indeed slip neatly around corners, but it does so quietly and politely. If you stamp down on the pedals you can get something approximating to a boisterous roar out of it, but you have the impression that the 1.8-litre engine would rather, on the whole, that you didn't. Again, some will find this a drawback - or even a sell-out - while others, who don't necessarily wish to drive in a permanent state of white-knuckled frenzy, will respond more warmly.

In the English climate, even more than engine performance, ease of opening and closing your sports car's roof is the key consideration. It's something you're going to be doing a lot of, so you don't want to end up with some laughably optimistic mechanism that leaves you looking like someone haplessly trying to crush an umbrella into a waste basket. (Incidentally, like using a hand-held mobile phone, or eating Chinese food, roof removal is not something one ought to practice while actually in motion. And especially not on motorways, or on the slip-roads leading on to motorways.)

The Mercedes SLK has a fully-automatic roof that smoothly does its stuff above your head at the touch of a button. It's impossible to top this for a Bond-style roof removal experience (and working on an appropriately aloof facial expression to hold while the Mercedes' roof mechanism was in business remains one of the most enjoyable projects I have ever got involved with in a car). But the SLK also costs about three times as much as the MR2 and beggars can't be choosers, so with the Toyota you'll have to do the heavy work yourself.

To be fair, they've gone a long way towards lightening the burden. Blessedly, there are no poppers involved at any stage of the process. (Anything involving poppers and a piece of slightly rain-shrunken canvas is route one to hell. Go to a rally of Caterham owners: none of them has a full set of fingernails.) You spring the two mildly resistant clips above the windscreen and then hoist the roof behind you. Ideally, the roof would then settle entirely into the recess created for it, but I found I had to get out of the car to tuck the edges in.

Yes, I had to get out of the car . What was Toyota thinking of? At least closing the roof can be achieved entirely from within the vehicle, though, as I reached behind me for the handles and heaved, I tended to find myself assuming the less than dignified position of someone failing to perform a bench press, and MR2 owners on first dates might like to bear that possibility in mind.

After removing the roof it would have been nice to have been able to remove a couple of things from the MR2's interior, in particular the ugly Sony hi-fi that comes as standard and the inside door handles, which are tubular and intended to have a sporty aluminium appearance, but actually look like devices from an elderly person's bathroom. Even with those out of the way, there would be, of course, no room in the car for much other than you and a friend.

Dispense with the friend, though, and the car does hint at some practical applications. As part of my commitment to testing the vehicle in a broad variety of extreme urban settings, I took it to Sainsbury's, where I learned that actually the Toyota MR2 does function as a family shopping car, as long as you don't buy anything large and unpliable, such as boxes of cereal. Better, of course, to abandon such considerations, push the roof down and find some open road. But - with the MR2 - not too open.

The lowdown

Verdict: Sedate sports car

Price on the road: £18,495

0-62 mph: 7.9 seconds

Top speed: 130mph

Fuel consumption: urban, 27.9; extra urban 47.9; combined, 38.2

Max power: 140/6,400 bhp/rpm

Max torque: 170/4,400 Nm/rpm

Weight: 975kg

Length: 12ft 8in/3.88m

Wednesday May 31

Newspapers claim the Qayyum Report revealed links between underworld figure Dawood Ibrahim and Pakistani players. Ibrahim had apparently been named by intel-ligence sources as fixing a game against England at Sharjah in 1999 - England's only win on that trip.

Thursday June 1
India's Central Bureau of Investigation reveals plans to quiz Ajit Wadekar and ex-Test opener Navjot Sidhu. Manoj Prabhakar had claimed that Sidhu witnessed an alleged bribe offered by Kapil Dev, and that Wadekar, team manager at the time, was informed.

Friday June 2
Hansie Cronje hands a confession to the King Commission: "In a moment of stupidity and weakness, I allowed Satan and the world to dictate terms to me. The moment I took my eyes off Jesus, my whole world turned dark." India's tax department says it is preparing to look at the tax returns of those whose names have cropped up in investigations.

Saturday June 3
Ex-Indian player Ajay Sharma denies allegations about his part in match-fixing. Wasim Akram leaves Channel 4's TV commentary team by mutual agreement. He goes on Pakistan's tour of Sri Lanka instead.

Sunday June 4
Bacher confirms that mobile phones have been banned from the SA dressing-room. The CBI begins examination of Prabhakar's 40 hours of video.

Monday June 5
Australia's Dean Jones says he would fear for his life were he to identify the Indian player who introduced him to a bookmaker seeking forecasts in 1992. "All the players thought it was a bit funny," he says of the $50,000 offer made to him. "It is not funny now."

Tuesday June 6
Kapil Dev's counsel says he will file a suit against IS Bindra, the ex-Indian Board president, who said Kapil offered Prabhakar money to play badly in a 1994 one-dayer.

Wednesday June 7
Play finally gets under way at the King Commission. Former SA offspinner Pat Symcox says that on the eve of a home one-dayer against Pakistan in Jan 1995, he was called to Cronje's hotel room to discuss an offer to throw the match. He told Cronje to reject it. Symcox claims he was approached by "a current international", whom he declines to name, to throw a match. He again rejected the offer. Referring to the $250,000 the South Africans were offered [to throw the Mohinder Amarnath benefit one-dayer in 1996], Symcox says the team debated the offer, but were persuaded, chiefly by Andrew Hudson, Daryll Cullinan and Derek Crookes, to turn it down.

Thursday June 8
Herschelle Gibbs admits that he accepted $15,000 from Cronje to be out for less than 20 in the 5th ODI v India at Nagpur in March. He says Henry Williams, his room-mate, agreed a similar sum to concede 50 runs in his 10 overs. In fact, Gibbs hit 74 off 53 balls and Williams did not complete his spell because of injury. Gibbs hit his first two balls for four, then "batted like a steam train", and never got the money. He said his parents were divorcing and he needed to look after his mother. He admitted to lying about it eight times. He had come clean after Mark Boucher told him he could go to jail if he didn't tell the truth.

Offspinner Derek Crookes broadly confirms Symcox's account of the $250,000 offer. He also relates his surprise at being asked to open the bowling by Cronje in an ODI in India this year.

Daryll Cullinan calls the Mumbai offer "a stroke of genius" from Cronje - a moral test for the team at the end of a hard tour.

Friday June 9
The UCB drops Gibbs from SA's imminent tour of Sri Lanka. He will be subject to a disciplinary hearing.

Saturday June 10
Ali Bacher, who has claimed that some World Cup '99 matches were fixed, and that an umpire has been on the bookies' payroll, names his sources: former Pakistan Board chief executive Majid Khan, ex-PCB president Javed Burki, and an Indian bookmaker, "Mr R" , whom he does not name for safety reasons. Bacher says Majid mentioned Pakistan's World Cup defeats by India and Bangladesh.

The 1998 Headingley Test is discussed. Bacher says ten lbw decisions were given - nine by Pakistan's Javed Akhtar, eight against SA. Bacher phoned Mr R to ask if the umpire could have been bought. Mr R's answer was "possibly", but later he confirmed "the umpire was on the payroll". Hansie Cronje is offered immunity from prosecution in South Africa - if he is "absolutely honest". The UCB says the offer does not preclude disciplinary action.

Monday June 12
Lance Klusener and Mark Boucher confirm that they, with Jacques Kallis, were approached by Cronje before the second Test against India in March. Cronje told them they could make money, but they took it as a joke. Klusener says "whoever received the [Mumbai] call should have said we would have nothing to do with it". In Colombo, Sri Lanka's newly elected Board says it is setting up an independent match-fixing panel. Majid Khan backs Ali Bacher's World Cup claims: "Whatever Bacher has stated about me is correct and I stand by his statement that those matches were fixed." Aunshuman Gaekwad, India's World Cup coach, denies that their win over Pakistan was fixed, saying: "I went to the Pakistan dressing-room and the players were very depressed by the defeat."

Tuesday June 13
Former SA wicketkeeper Dave Richardson tells the Commission that a current international player made a bribery offer to Pat Symcox in India in 1996. Fearing death threats, Richardson refuses to name the player until Symcox does. Jacques Kallis corroborates Boucher and Klusener. He says most of the team, including him, were opposed to Cronje's declaration against England at Centurion. Attorney Peter Soller alleges that Ali Bacher was involved in pay-ments to a rebel West Indian team for losing to a South African XI at Jo'burg in the '80s. The tourists had refused to resume play after a pay dispute. Bacher, it is alleged, agreed a further payment should they lose.

Wednesday June 14
Bacher denies it: "This is ... the gravest possible imputation against my character." Former PCB secretary Arif Abbasi accuses Bacher of implicating Pakistanis to "divert the world's attention".

Thursday June 15
Cronje submits a 6300-word statement to the King Commission. He admits to taking four bribes, and announces that his career "at representative level" is over. He admits to pressurising Gibbs and Williams to keep quiet, and urges the UCB not to ban them. He received $80,000 in 1996 and 1997 from Mukesh Gupta, who was introduced to him by Mohammad Azharuddin. He took $30,000 to give wickets away in a decisive Test at Kanpur, 1996-97. He says they did not do so, but lost heavily anyway. "I had effectively received money for doing nothing and I rationalised to myself that this was somehow acceptable."

Cronje says he was offered "an unspecified gift" by bookmaker Marlon Aronstam for ensuring a positive result at Centurion. Nasser Hussain agreed to Cronje's offer of a double forfeiture, although Cronje stresses that none of the England party knew of any bribes. After England won, Aronstam gave Cronje a leather jacket and 50,000 rand.

Cronje admits giving information to a man believed to be Sanjeev Chawla ("Sanjay") during the 1999-2000 one-day series involving Zimbabwe and England, in exchange for $10-15,000. Finally, Cronje says he has received death threats. In Sydney, Mark Taylor says no Australians took any form of bribe while he was captain.

Friday June 16
In Delhi, Azharuddin refutes Cronje's allegations. "They [the SA authorities] want revenge since it was the Delhi police which first caught Cronje on tape talking to bookies about match-fixing." Azhar also denies knowing Gupta.

Saturday June 17
An affidavit signed by a Cape Town businessman claims that Brian Lara was given £4500 in cash during a 1993 one-day tournament in South Africa. It is alleged that Lara was betting, not match-fixing. Lara issues a swift denial.

Scotland Yard says it is seeking to establish links between the Asian syndicate that allegedly approached Chris Lewis and the one that dealt with Cronje in India.

Sunday June 18
Mike Atherton writes: "Looking back it is easy to see that Cronje's bowling changes and field placings [at Centurion]... were designed to prevent the draw." Nasser Hussain says it "will always be remembered as a Test that was fixed for a few quid".

Monday June 19
Pakistan's Rashid Latif offers to go to India to help the police. "I have a lot to tell," he says. ECB boss Lord MacLaurin says he expects ICC to ban players found to have been involved in match-fixing, raising doubts about England's 2000-01 tour of Pakistan.

Tuesday June 20
Ajit Wadekar, quizzed by the CBI, denies that Manoj Prabhakar told him of Kapil Dev's alleged offer. Imran Khan says Bacher is "two-faced" and "vindictive to Pakistan and India". PCB chairman Lt-Gen Tauqir Zia demands "strong action" against Bacher. Rashid Latif says Cronje's statement is incomplete, and he "should have named Australians who are also involved".

Wednesday June 21
Cross-examined at last, Cronje admits to "an unfortunate love of money". He discloses a further payment of $35,000, from an unknown source in Jan 1997. Dr Ian Lewis says Cronje is suffering from clinical depression and has been on medication since May.

Thursday June 22
Azharuddin is quizzed for five hours about Cronje by investigators in Delhi. Cronje says that Azhar did not know of his transactions with Gupta. Cronje says of the Indian transcripts: "95% of the time, I was stringing Sanjay along."

Friday June 23
After 10 hours of testimony, Cronje cracks and is led, sobbing, from the witness box. He admits that the $10-15,000 paid to him by Sanjay Chawla had been a deposit for a match in the triangular series which he was to fix if SA were sure of a place in the final. Shamila Batohi, the lead advocate, confirms that Cronje may be recalled if fresh evidence emerges.

Bookmaker Marlon Aronstam testifies that Cronje offered to throw a one-day match if it was meaningless. "He said he had Pieter Strydom, Gibbs and Nicky Boje on side," says Aronstam. "I was shocked. We hadn't even known each other for an hour." Boje and Strydom deny any involvement.

Saturday June 24
Lord MacLaurin calls for toughness as ICC meets: "We must deal with this in a strong way."

Sunday June 25
The Sunday Telegraph unmasks Sir Paul Condon, ex-Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, as the ICC's first anti-corruption investigator. Ewie Cronje, Hansie's father, says his son wants to give back all the money he received from bookmakers and start a new life.

Monday June 26
The King Commission takes a break as planned. Hamid "Banjo" Cassim, the man who introduced Sanjay Chawla to Cronje, denies helping to bribe him - but admits to receiving many telephone calls from Chawla, who was keen to locate Cronje in India. Lord MacLaurin says England's tour of Pakistan will go ahead.

Wednesday June 28
Sri Lankan police deny that Nicky Boje will be arrested when he arrives with the SA tour party. WI's Board clears Brian Lara of allegations about betting in SA in '93. Mukesh Gupta emerges from a grilling by the CBI to say that although he enjoys a "special relationship" with Azharuddin, they never engaged in match-fixing. Bishan Bedi, the former Indian captain, calls for a King-style open enquiry to clean up cricket in India: "We need to be more upright. We need people of integrity." The Cape Times receives erroneous reports suggesting that Cronje has committed suicide.

Thursday June 29
Justice King, due to submit his initial findings today, gets an extension to Aug 11. He has 1143 pages of transcripts to study - and, ominously, some "new evidence".

Friday June 30
Indian Sports Minister Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa encourages players to help the CBI in their probe into match-fixing, hinting at a possible amnesty: "The government will be lenient to cricketers who will come forward to help the agencies."

Ram Jethmalani, Indian Law Minister, backs up Dhindsa's promise. He says that "if there is genuine repentance and remorse, then the fact that the cricketers are suffering public humiliation should be considered enough punishment and we should forgive and forget."

The King Commission is continuing to attempt to obtain copies of the tapes containing alleged conversations between Hansie Cronje and Sanjay Chawla. "We are pursuing the matter through diplomatic channels and hope that we would be able to receive them so that we can complete our work," says the Commission's prosecutor Sharmila Bahoti.

webTitle: Gunman guilty of shooting innocent bystanders

fields.headline: Gunman guilty of shooting innocent bystanders
fields.trailText: A gunman who cold-bloodedly shot down five innocent bystanders and took a woman hostage during a 50-mile chase has been found guilty on 21 charges including the attempted murder of a policeman, kidnap and hijacking.
fields.body:
A gunman who cold-bloodedly shot down five innocent bystanders and took a woman hostage during a 50-mile chase has been found guilty on 21 charges including the attempted murder of a policeman, kidnap and hijacking.

Olatunde Yakub Adetoro, 30, of no fixed address, has been found guilty by a jury at Manchester Crown Court after more than 24 hours of deliberation.

During a seven-week trial the jury heard that Adetoro had decided to gun down passers-by in a desperate attempt to get police to back off.

webTitle: An electronic caddie arrives on the links

fields.headline: An electronic caddie arrives on the links
fields.trailText: The game of golf has changed little over the centuries. Well, the equipment has improved a lot, but the game is much the same - as are the paper scorecards and little pencils.
fields.body:
The game of golf has changed little over the centuries. Well, the equipment has improved a lot, but the game is much the same - as are the paper scorecards and little pencils.

But wait. There's a new golf coming your way. You will soon be able to take the internet to the golf course. And what's happening to golf will happen before long to other participatory sports. Golfers are the guinea pigs for wireless sports tracking technology.

I'm a golfer, and I recently started taking my handheld computer (a Handspring Visor, similar to a Palm Pilot) with me to record my scores. At home, using a software application called IntelliGolf, I download the scorecard of the course I am going to play on to the Visor. I then record my scores as I play - including minute details of my game, such as how far I hit my drives, whether my approaches were left or right of the pin, and so on. When I get home again, I "sync" the handheld with my PC, which keeps track of all my rounds, analyses my performance and spots areas of my game that need improvement.

In a couple of years, that will seem pedestrian. Software, handheld computer and mobile phone companies are working on applications that will turn golf into even more of a high-tech sport - because golfers will be continuously connected to the internet while playing.

With a golf-scoring application on your wireless palm computer or mobile phone, you will be able to arrive at a course and download its scorecard over a wireless internet connection, then use the mobile device to record your round details. Here in the US, we're likely to see golfers mostly carrying wireless palm computers; in Asia and Europe, mobile phones will probably be more prevalent.

The phone is actually the better device for this purpose. Many golfers already take their mobile phones on to the links, and lugging a second wireless device - a palm computer - is less than ideal. Mobile phone manufacturers like Nokia and Motorola are currently working to put golf applications in their handsets, and new models of phones are getting larger screens, which make the devices suitable for on-course golf applications.

Soon, your phone or palm com puter will serve as your electronic caddie. By next year, if you're on the tee of the 17th hole at Pebble Beach, you should be able to consult your mobile phone to find out what club other golfers used. If you find yourself in a fairway bunker and forget the correct technique for such a shot, your phone caddie should be able to give you a quick tutorial.

That's the vision of Kathryn Savarese, president of Golfserv, a Chicago-based golf technology services and software company that operates a website used by 200,000 golfers to record their scores. The company, which was acquired by golf e-retailer Chipshot.com, is working on software that will bring wireless versions of its web services to mobile phone and palm computer users on the course.

Golfers who use Golfserv have their game statistics stored on a central web database. The company is working on allowing users of mobile devices to tap into this database while on the course via wireless links - to compare their performance on a particular course to all other Golfserv users, for example. (This is not possible with current systems like the one I use, where only my scoring data are stored on my PC.)

Craig Schmidt, the president of Karrier Communications in California, which makes the IntelliGolf software, says that a common request from his users is for global positioning satellite features to be built into the palm computer applications. When GPS services for golfers are incorporated into phones and handhelds, your wireless device will tell you (to within 10 or 20 feet) how far away from the pin you are. This feature is still a year away, and it will work only at those golf courses that have been mapped. (Which means it won't be cheap.)

Meanwhile, several hundred top US golf courses offer distance-estimating computers on golf carts, which measure microwave signals transmitted from devices on the course. Alas, you seldom find such wizardry on public courses.

While golf is the testbed sport for this new technology, participants in other sports should soon benefit too. Karrier, for example, has acquired numerous "Intelli-" domain names for various sports - such as IntelliSwim.com and IntelliFootball.com - and plans to create similar software to help other athletes track their performance, using the core technology that's behind IntelliGolf. (Imagine attending your kid's swimming competition and tracking results on your phone or palm computer.)

Many participatory sports are as much about statistics as they are about the athletic act, after all. Soon, amateur athletes will be up to their ears in data.

 Steve Outing is a Colorado-based columnist and analyst who covers internet trends. He is also CEO and founder of Content Exchange www.content-exchange.com email:steve@content-exchange.com

Soon, your phone or palm com puter will serve as your electronic caddie. By next year, if you're on the tee of the 17th hole at Pebble Beach, you should be able to consult your mobile phone to find out what club other golfers used. If you find yourself in a fairway bunker and forget the correct technique for such a shot, your phone caddie should be able to give you a quick tutorial. That's the vision of Kathryn Savarese, president of Golfserv, a Chicago-based golf technology services and software company that operates a website used by 200,000 golfers to record their scores. The company, which was acquired by golf e-retailer Chipshot.com, is working on software that will bring wireless versions of its web services to mobile phone and palm computer users on the course. Golfers who use Golfserv have their game statistics stored on a central web database. The company is working on allowing users of mobile devices to tap into this database while on the course via wireless links - to compare their performance on a particular course to all other Golfserv users, for example. (This is not possible with current systems like the one I use, where only my scoring data are stored on my PC.) Craig Schmidt, the president of Karrier Communications in California, which makes the IntelliGolf software, says that a common request from his users is for global positioning satellite features to be built into the palm computer applications. When GPS services for golfers are incorporated into phones and handhelds, your wireless device will tell you (to within 10 or 20 feet) how far away from the pin you are. This feature is still a year away, and it will work only at those golf courses that have been mapped. (Which means it won't be cheap.) Meanwhile, several hundred top US golf courses offer distance-estimating computers on golf carts, which measure microwave signals transmitted from devices on the course. Alas, you seldom find such wizardry on public courses. While golf is the testbed sport for this new technology, participants in other sports should soon benefit too. Karrier, for example, has acquired numerous "Intelli-" domain names for various sports - such as IntelliSwim.com and IntelliFootball.com - and plans to create similar software to help other athletes track their performance, using the core technology that's behind IntelliGolf. (Imagine attending your kid's swimming competition and tracking results on your phone or palm computer.) Many participatory sports are as much about statistics as they are about the athletic act, after all. Soon, amateur athletes will be up to their ears in data.  Steve Outing is a Colorado-based columnist and analyst who covers internet trends. He is also CEO and founder of Content Exchange www.content-exchange.com email:steve@content-exchange.com

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: No great surprises at the the European Online Journalism Awards last Thursday at City University, organised by NetMedia. BBC Online scooped four awards, including best overall journalism service (shared with video news channel TV.newsweb.com).
fields.body:
No great surprises at the the European Online Journalism Awards last Thursday at City University, organised by NetMedia nmreporter2000. BBC Online scooped four awards, including best overall journalism service (shared with video news channel TV.newsweb.com). There were two awards apiece for TimeEurope (features) and IPC's women's portal Beme for news presentation, design and navigation (its expensive redesign obviously paid off). The prestigious internet journalist of the year award went to war-hardy Miroslav Filipovic at the Institute of War and Peace Reporting www.iwpr.net whose family flew in from Croatia for the ceremony. The real odd man out was music and entertainment, which was given to an unlikely-sounding Finnish pop group, Ultra Bra, for their "webportage" of the making of their new single Villiviini. Here's a taster: "Osaka twists knobs in the studio and the Ultra Bra's rhythm section loiters in the cafeteria. Once in a while the musicians go and hear what the mixer has achieved . . ." Retribution for years of Finnish humiliation at Eurovision perhaps?

 Is she really worth £100m? That's the amount Orange has just spent on acquiring Ananova, PA's virtual broadcaster. Compared with the £4.1bn it spent on acquiring its third-generation licence, however, it's a bargain price. Orange cannot confirm whether she will be available on its mobile portal by next year but promises to reveal all at a press conference this week.

 It's all change in the editor's seat at Charlotte Street. Nicola Davenport, who has been there since the launch, has been replaced by Maria Trkulja, editor of Zoom, the shopping portal owned by Charlotte Street's parent company, Daily Mail and General Trust. Associated New Media is considering a relaunch of the ailing women's portal, targeting it at the 3m female readers of the Daily Mail.

 According to a new survey from the ARC group, the issue that is dividing the Wap industry is whether mobile content will be paid for by the end user or not. The survey, of participants in the Cannes Wap symposium last month, shows that 55% thought it would be paid-for and only 43% thought it would be available free. As with a herd of sheep on the edge of a precipice, it only takes one to jump off first . . .

 Oh dear, ft.com seems to be slipping. Staff at the London office arrived early one morning last week to find their lead story covering Aston Martin's appointment of a new chief executive illustrated with the Aston Villa football club badge. A staff member assures us it was "the handiwork of the American office" and was removed at once (after breakfast, of course).

fields.headline: Need to know: Chris Ezekiel
fields.trailText: Age? 32.
fields.body:
Age? 32.

Who is he? MD of Kiwilogic (launching this week), a software company that specialises in natural language systems using artificial intelligence. Former sales/marketing director.

What's the clever idea? "To create a programme that allows online businesses to add pop-up assistants that you can chat with. Lingubot enables individual, sophisticated, intelligent, online characters to interact with visitors, help them navigate around, enhance their online experience and keep them coming back. Kiwilogic's intelligent software requires no prior programming experience, the creator programme helps construct all the possible permutations, questions and answers, and builds a complex database that assists with that."

What's the thinking behind it? "Lingubots are the solution to making websites stickier through improved customer service and navigation. They help a site sell more by answering last-minute questions (currently 70% of shopping carts are abandoned half-empty), recommending products and cross-selling. The assistant (which can be any animated image) is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. It pops up when you click on it and you can chat with it, so saving money from unnecessary emails and customer service calls. Also, by analysing dialogue transcripts, they examine exactly how a site is being used. For the user, it's much easier to find information, more helpful, more fun and there's a personality."

How does it work? "You access one of our client websites, say Expo 2000, and want to know where a particular stand is going to be. Instead of trying to click around and find it, a little Lingubot character pops up. It says, 'chat with me', and then you click on it, and the unique thing is that you can ask it not just about the website but about other things too. So it is bringing down the barrier between machine and human, instilling personality. Our software takes the normal language sentence, puts it through our natural language processing engine, which has all the artificial intelligence bits in, and then comes back with the answer."

Any shortcomings? "Lingubot will affect the way a site interacts with visitors, the personality of the site and the messages that that company wants to convey, and so must be taken seriously."

What's next? "In the future, with the convergence of different digital technologies they will all use this natural language processing engine which we've developed."

fields.headline: The whole world is watching
fields.standfirst: Big Brother is about more than 10 people under constant public surveillance, says  Morgan Holt, editor of the show's website. It points the way forward for TV on the net
fields.trailText: Big Brother is about more than 10 people under constant public surveillance, says Morgan Holt, editor of the show's website. It points the way forward for TV on the net
fields.body:
Big Brother is a new Channel 4 series in which 10 volunteers will spend more than two months locked in a house, deprived of any contact with the outside world, in an environment where every single activity is followed by camera.

Their activities will be documented, commented upon, scrutinised. Their lives will be screened 24-hours a day and seven days a week on the web, and every weekday on Channel 4, with a finale each Friday where one participant will be ceremoniously ejected. Their lives and personal (one can no longer say "private") moments will be the property of the audience. The audience is worldwide.

But Big Brother also represents the adventure of independent television moving into interactivity and of web design into the world of television. These two fields are represented by production company GMG Endemol and web developers Victoria Real.

For an independent like GMG Endemol, which first began the Big Brother project last year in Holland, worldwide marketing via the web is a gift to be grabbed quickly, particularly as the door may not be open forever.

The set of Big Brother is at the Three Mills film studios in east London. The house where the participants will live has been built from scratch on an island, its cameras and microphones and remote controls connected via massive cables that run across a moat to the studio gallery where the video splits into two. One for the web, the other for a television audience.

The Big Brother website, like a newspaper with video, has six live video feeds, some running round the clock, that are watched by an editorial team of 18 whose job is to monitor, log, and report on the participants. The slightest change in environment, such as person X touching person Y, or person Z having a quiet time alone, is logged on the television crew's computer network.

On the cyber side, adding editorial pages to a site which is read by 5m people each day is no mean feat. The hosting of the site by Terra, the leased lines from BT and the coordination of them all with the video streams are areas that internet service providers told Victoria Real's creative director Jason George "simply couldn't be done".

Television, like the web, may just be technology in the back room, but watching these two monolithic infrastructures trying to connect with wires the size of telephone cable, when neither side supports the machinery of the other, we now wonder if maybe the ISPs were right.

Leaving the web and television teams to fight it out, we settle down to the crux of the editorial side: the law. Monitoring commercial television content is complex enough, even under the auspices of the ITC, but the web complicates the issue exponentially.

Keeping the web editorial team from a test case in court are trained monitors who sit day and night at special screens which are a buffer between the activities in the house and the video which is shown on the web. Things for us to watch out for are obscenity, nudity and, by far the most legally risky aspect of the internet today, libel. Say the wrong thing on the web and we could be paying for a long time, even if the words come from the participants. That's why we monitor.

More bizarre, though, is the present state of the music industry. Broadcasting music on the web, even if it is incidental, could land us in deep trouble. So, if a contestant hap pens to sing a particularly catchy tune, we might be forced to pay a copyright fee to the writer. While nationwide licences can be bought, securing the rights to all music in advance, without knowing which tune one of the participants might decide to whistle in the shower, is proving tricky.

All of which is sure to make for a lively editorial process when we go live on Friday. As Channel 4's own website editor Andy Gumbridge puts it: "Having a sing-song is one of the only luxuries left to those poor buggers." (Andy has just used the 23rd most obscene swear word in the English language. Spend enough time here, and you get to know such things.)

The compliance monitor's finger sits over the button as a solitary figure sits alone in the Big Brother house. A handful of trial participants have spent the past three days in captivity. Today they performed the definitive task which the real participants will have to execute each week. They voted someone out.

We are now getting our first sense that the project will be stressful as well as fun. Every week, two participants will be told by the people with whom they have been living that they are no longer wanted. Psychologists and psychiatrists are on hand. The vote is passed to the audience to decide which of the two shorlisted must leave.

On July 28, the first of nine exiles will walk the "walk of shame" that leads to presenter Davina McCall's studio audience. According to the rules, whoever doesn't make that walk is the winner. As we watch a member of the household in the throes of rejection, the gallery production team and the web development team celebrate the success of their technologies. Justice is served, and the system works.

In a world that anticipates a looming famine of content, speed of entry is vital. The door is only ajar for a short time, and creative director Peter Bazalgette of GMG Endemol (part-owned by the Guardian Media Group) finds himself in the odd position of, for the first time in 24 years, "not knowing what my business model is, or what I'm going to be making in a couple of years - or why."

What he will be making, though, is content. "Everybody says 'will TV be this or will TV be that?' " says Bazalgette. "The answer is, it will be everything." Television is coming to mean far more than transmission of images across continents. It is the themed and bundle-wrapped packaging of every medium available.

Now it is Friday and a week to go before we open to the public. We are beginning to sense what the finished website will look like. Lots of content. You may see it on a computer, or your mobile phone, or a 36-screen video wall in the local shopping precinct, but it will be hard to miss.

Big Brother incorporates live camera work, archived video, news stories and backgrounders, profiles of the participants, off-shoots to commercial ventures, chat-rooms to discuss the issues, thrice-daily updates via Wap phones or email. It is the most intensively themed live experience on the web yet. And with a little luck, on July 14, it might even work.

 Big Brother begins on Channel 4 on Tuesday July 18 at 9pm. See the website at: www.channel4.com/bigbrother

fields.headline: You cannot be serious
fields.standfirst: The most comprehensive study ever into the TV news agenda reveals that, over 25 years, bulletins have become more tabloid. Is it a move towards greater diversity or a case of dumb and dumber?  Steven Barnett  and  Emily Seymour  report on their findings
fields.trailText: The most comprehensive study ever into the TV news agenda reveals that, over 25 years, bulletins have become more tabloid. Is it a move towards greater diversity or a case of dumb and dumber? Steven Barnett and Emily Seymour report on their findings
fields.body:
Television news matters. It is not just that evening bulletins, even with the demise of News at Ten, command a combined audience of nearly 20m viewers every day; nor that more than two-thirds of viewers themselves consistently say that television is their main source of national and international news. It matters because it is one of the most vital guarantors of an informed and aware electorate.

If a healthy democracy relies on having citizens who can make informed political choices about who should represent them, and who can then contribute to the debates being conducted by their political representatives, then television remains the most powerful means of enhancing political awareness and democratic participation.

This is why the continuing controversy about moving News at Ten is more than just an arcane debate about the art of scheduling. We may be in an era of 24-hour news channels, interactive websites and news on the move via Wap phones, but for the vast majority of us it is still the mass audience evening bulletins that keep us in touch with the world.

What is happening to the content of those bulletins is therefore of more than academic interest. And the conventional view, being repeated with increasing vigour around dinner tables and in opinion columns, is that television news is dumbing down.

Some of the most prestigious names from the BBC and ITN have been adding their considerable weight to the depressing message that a growing emphasis on the sensational, the shallow and the parochial has been driving out the complex, serious and outward-looking: that British television news, once the backbone of an informed British electorate, has been heading inexorably downmarket.

In one of the most comprehensive long-term studies of British television news content, we set out to test that hypothesis. We analysed more than 700 evening news bulletins on the four mass audience television channels, taking one year in five over a period of 24 years fom 1975 to 1999. We covered all four evening bulletins on the BBC and ITV as well as Channel 4 News (which launched in 1982) and Channel 5 News (now three years old).

Each story in selected bulletins was timed and coded into one of 31 categories for domestic news, while foreign news was separately coded by country. For ease of comparison, we then grouped all categories together under three broad headings: broadsheet, tabloid and foreign. The last of these is uncontentious, but we should stress that the broadsheet and tabloid labels were descriptive terms designed to contrast political, economic or social affairs coverage with items on consumer issues, crime, sport and so on. We were not attempting to pass judgment on whether some items were "better" or "worse" than others. Our aim was simply to track changes over time.

We believe the results defy many - though not all - of the doom-merchants' worst fears. The BBC Nine O'Clock News and Channel 4 News, in particular, have sustained consistently high levels of broadsheet and foreign coverage over the whole measurement period (starting in Channel 4's case in 1985). The level of tabloid news on the Nine, from a low starting point of 16% of bulletin time in 1975, has actually declined to 13% in 1999. The highest level it reached was 23% in 1985.

The balance of coverage on the Nine has fluctuated between broadsheet domestic and foreign stories, depending on the issues of the moment: in 1975, for example, industrial relations turmoil and high political tension meant that broadsheet news dominated and foreign news was only 24% of bulletin time; by 1999, with extensive coverage of Kosovo and its ramifications, foreign coverage had nearly doubled to 43%. Channel 4 News has been even more consistent, with tabloid coverage never rising above 12% of bulletin time and foreign coverage always around 40% regardless of the nature of dominant stories.

A different pattern emerges in the early-evening bulletins, where tabloid content has increased over the past 10 years - but still represents only a third of ITV's news and less than 30% of the BBC's. In both cases, tabloid coverage fell to a low in 1990, when the news was dominated by the political machinations which culminated in Margaret Thatcher's resignation, by the Gulf war and by the continuing collapse of communism. In both cases, while the 1999 level of tabloid coverage was the highest over the measurement period, the proportion of foreign coverage was higher than in 1975.

To some extent, the changes in the 1990s can be attributed to real fluctuations in hard political news on the domestic front. It is also, we believe, attributable to a deliberate editorial policy, in the BBC's case including a fundamental news review in the early 1990s. On both channels, there has been a greater emphasis on covering issues that are more suited to a early evening bulletins while at the same time doing justice to the major domestic and foreign stories of the day.

ITN's News at Ten has also been consistent in its foreign coverage, which has never fallen below 25%. In the late 1990s, however, there does seem to have been a tangible and sudden shift in the balance of domestic news where tabloid coverage rose from 26% in 1995 to 42% in 1999. Although the 1999 figure is based on only four bulletins before the schedules changed, the trend has continued (to a slightly lesser extent) with the ITV Evening News and Nightly News: tabloid coverage for each is around a third of bulletin time.

Do we take this as evidence that, in the words of ITN's former political editor Michael Brunson, "There is a growing reluctance to confront viewers with items that are intellectually demanding"? Or do we go with Nigel Dacre, ITN's editor of ITV news, who responded that trends towards a greater diversity of issues reflect a wider societal shift rather than a dumbed down editorial agenda?

At the moment, we tend towards Dacre's view. Taken as a whole, we have today a diverse array of news programmes which contrast starkly with the dull and unstimulating uniformity of news bulletins 25 years ago, when editorial agendas on the four evening bulletins were almost indistinguishable. From the more highbrow Nine O'Clock News to the overtly more populist Channel 5 News, bulletins are more likely to be tailored to a specific audience and more consciously branded - but not a single one comprises, on average, a majority of tabloid content.

Compared to news output in some of the competitive broadcasting systems on the continent or in America, where crime, showbiz and human interest stories consistently dominate the agenda, Britain has maintained a healthy balance of serious, light and foreign coverage.

This study does not, of course, take into account some of the more subjective issues of news coverage, such as presentation, language or treatment of stories. It could not distinguish between two completely different approaches to the same story, and it is possible that a different study might find a serious decline in the real informational content of some approaches to news presentation. If, for example, the public learns nothing more about the debate over Britain's role in Europe than that Tony Blair has clashed with Lionel Jospin or that Peter Mandelson can barely speak to Gordon Brown, public understanding of this complex issue will hardly be enhanced.

The most difficult question about treatment, however, is over the vexed question of "accessibility" or how a story is framed. We saw with the floods in Mozambique that some bulletins chose understandably to focus on the human tragedy while the BBC Nine O'Clock News analysed the complex socio-economic and political context of the disaster.

This is not a question of right or wrong. But there is a fine balance between making issues accessible and relying on the controversial or sensational to maintain the interest of the audience. And despite our broadly positive conclusion about the diversity and vitality of television news, there are indications that this notion of "accessibility" may be starting to invade the editorial agenda - illustrated in particular by the decline in coverage of politics and the rise in time devoted to consumer stories and sport.

By 1999, coverage of political affairs had fallen to its lowest level in the 24-year period on all channels, a decline which is even greater if coverage of industrial disputes in the earlier years is included. By contrast, consumer news had risen significantly on the ITV bulletins and on the BBC early-evening bulletin, while sport had increased every where except the Nine O'Clock News and Channel 4 News. fields.bodyText: Television news matters. It is not just that evening bulletins, even with the demise of News at Ten, command a combined audience of nearly 20m viewers every day; nor that more than two-thirds of viewers themselves consistently say that television is their main source of national and international news. It matters because it is one of the most vital guarantors of an informed and aware electorate. If a healthy democracy relies on having citizens who can make informed political choices about who should represent them, and who can then contribute to the debates being conducted by their political representatives, then television remains the most powerful means of enhancing political awareness and democratic participation. This is why the continuing controversy about moving News at Ten is more than just an arcane debate about the art of scheduling. We may be in an era of 24-hour news channels, interactive websites and news on the move via Wap phones, but for the vast majority of us it is still the mass audience evening bulletins that keep us in touch with the world. What is happening to the content of those bulletins is therefore of more than academic interest. And the conventional view, being repeated with increasing vigour around dinner tables and in opinion columns, is that television news is dumbing down. Some of the most prestigious names from the BBC and ITN have been adding their considerable weight to the depressing message that a growing emphasis on the sensational, the shallow and the parochial has been driving out the complex, serious and outward-looking: that British television news, once the backbone of an informed British electorate, has been heading inexorably downmarket. In one of the most comprehensive long-term studies of British television news content, we set out to test that hypothesis. We analysed more than 700 evening news bulletins on the four mass audience television channels, taking one year in five over a period of 24 years fom 1975 to 1999. We covered all four evening bulletins on the BBC and ITV as well as Channel 4 News (which launched in 1982) and Channel 5 News (now three years old). Each story in selected bulletins was timed and coded into one of 31 categories for domestic news, while foreign news was separately coded by country. For ease of comparison, we then grouped all categories together under three broad headings: broadsheet, tabloid and foreign. The last of these is uncontentious, but we should stress that the broadsheet and tabloid labels were descriptive terms designed to contrast political, economic or social affairs coverage with items on consumer issues, crime, sport and so on. We were not attempting to pass judgment on whether some items were "better" or "worse" than others. Our aim was simply to track changes over time. We believe the results defy many - though not all - of the doom-merchants' worst fears. The BBC Nine O'Clock News and Channel 4 News, in particular, have sustained consistently high levels of broadsheet and foreign coverage over the whole measurement period (starting in Channel 4's case in 1985). The level of tabloid news on the Nine, from a low starting point of 16% of bulletin time in 1975, has actually declined to 13% in 1999. The highest level it reached was 23% in 1985. The balance of coverage on the Nine has fluctuated between broadsheet domestic and foreign stories, depending on the issues of the moment: in 1975, for example, industrial relations turmoil and high political tension meant that broadsheet news dominated and foreign news was only 24% of bulletin time; by 1999, with extensive coverage of Kosovo and its ramifications, foreign coverage had nearly doubled to 43%. Channel 4 News has been even more consistent, with tabloid coverage never rising above 12% of bulletin time and foreign coverage always around 40% regardless of the nature of dominant stories. A different pattern emerges in the early-evening bulletins, where tabloid content has increased over the past 10 years - but still represents only a third of ITV's news and less than 30% of the BBC's. In both cases, tabloid coverage fell to a low in 1990, when the news was dominated by the political machinations which culminated in Margaret Thatcher's resignation, by the Gulf war and by the continuing collapse of communism. In both cases, while the 1999 level of tabloid coverage was the highest over the measurement period, the proportion of foreign coverage was higher than in 1975. To some extent, the changes in the 1990s can be attributed to real fluctuations in hard political news on the domestic front. It is also, we believe, attributable to a deliberate editorial policy, in the BBC's case including a fundamental news review in the early 1990s. On both channels, there has been a greater emphasis on covering issues that are more suited to a early evening bulletins while at the same time doing justice to the major domestic and foreign stories of the day. ITN's News at Ten has also been consistent in its foreign coverage, which has never fallen below 25%. In the late 1990s, however, there does seem to have been a tangible and sudden shift in the balance of domestic news where tabloid coverage rose from 26% in 1995 to 42% in 1999. Although the 1999 figure is based on only four bulletins before the schedules changed, the trend has continued (to a slightly lesser extent) with the ITV Evening News and Nightly News: tabloid coverage for each is around a third of bulletin time. Do we take this as evidence that, in the words of ITN's former political editor Michael Brunson, "There is a growing reluctance to confront viewers with items that are intellectually demanding"? Or do we go with Nigel Dacre, ITN's editor of ITV news, who responded that trends towards a greater diversity of issues reflect a wider societal shift rather than a dumbed down editorial agenda? At the moment, we tend towards Dacre's view. Taken as a whole, we have today a diverse array of news programmes which contrast starkly with the dull and unstimulating uniformity of news bulletins 25 years ago, when editorial agendas on the four evening bulletins were almost indistinguishable. From the more highbrow Nine O'Clock News to the overtly more populist Channel 5 News, bulletins are more likely to be tailored to a specific audience and more consciously branded - but not a single one comprises, on average, a majority of tabloid content. Compared to news output in some of the competitive broadcasting systems on the continent or in America, where crime, showbiz and human interest stories consistently dominate the agenda, Britain has maintained a healthy balance of serious, light and foreign coverage. This study does not, of course, take into account some of the more subjective issues of news coverage, such as presentation, language or treatment of stories. It could not distinguish between two completely different approaches to the same story, and it is possible that a different study might find a serious decline in the real informational content of some approaches to news presentation. If, for example, the public learns nothing more about the debate over Britain's role in Europe than that Tony Blair has clashed with Lionel Jospin or that Peter Mandelson can barely speak to Gordon Brown, public understanding of this complex issue will hardly be enhanced. The most difficult question about treatment, however, is over the vexed question of "accessibility" or how a story is framed. We saw with the floods in Mozambique that some bulletins chose understandably to focus on the human tragedy while the BBC Nine O'Clock News analysed the complex socio-economic and political context of the disaster. This is not a question of right or wrong. But there is a fine balance between making issues accessible and relying on the controversial or sensational to maintain the interest of the audience. fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: No rest for Michael Cockerell, the veteran BBC political journalist, whose News from No 10, a behind-the-scenes account of Alastair Campbell's activities, airs next Saturday. The extraordinary events of the past few days mean he's shooting extra film right up to the deadline.
fields.body:
No rest for Michael Cockerell, the veteran BBC political journalist, whose News from No 10, a behind-the-scenes account of Alastair Campbell's activities, airs next Saturday. The extraordinary events of the past few days mean he's shooting extra film right up to the deadline. The programme, extended from an hour to 80 minutes, looks set to portray Campbell as a victim of his own spinning. "This is not a Campbell benefit film," says Cockerell. So, did he put that melancholy Longfellow poem into Tony's hands? "No. That's typically Blair. But we do have stuff of him talking to Campbell about how to handle it." Can we now call an end to the Campbell soap opera?

 The kindly management of the Financial Times is to launch a 24-hour "Peopleline" to offer confidential counselling to its staff and their immediate families. It will include not just the obvious areas of bereavement, divorce, financial problems and addiction, but "child care or eldercare [sic] concerns and many other issues", says a memo, promising detailed briefings in the next few weeks. Peopleline is certainly causing excitement among the troops. "Can I ask them to find me a new nanny and sort out my mortgage for a bigger house?" asks one staffer plaintively.

 Talk about making a drama out of an exit. Simon Lewis, the hotshot Granada head of drama, and Sue Hogg, his deputy, have been talking so long about leaving to make popular series for BBC1 in a semi-detached "output" capacity that their indecision has become boring. They were also noted talking intently to ITV's director of programmes David Liddiment at his celebrity-stuffed (John Thaw, Robson Green, Cilla Black, Ross Kemp) summer showbiz party last week, amid rumours that the BBC's offer wasn't generous enough.

 Remember the internal inquiry set up by Carlton's (Lord) Waheed Alli and Steve Hewlett into the News of the World's allegations of dodgy practices at the Cook Report? Whatever happened to that? When the stories broke in February, a company report was promised in weeks. Come July, and Mike Morley, the editor, is still suspended on full pay and the team is idling away in Nottingham. Meanwhile, several Cook Reports sit on the shelf, with ITV insisting it has no plans to transmit them. "I don't know what's going on," says a Carlton press officer, "except lawyers are involved." Perhaps Carlton is hoping a new editor (Rebekah Wade) at the News of the World might abandon the case (out of boredom?).

You can email Maggie Brown at maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Are you in the mood?
fields.standfirst: How do you feel? Are you ready to be sold something? Welcome to the future of advertising where if you're having a bad day you can turn the message off
fields.trailText: How do you feel? Are you ready to be sold something? Welcome to the future of advertising where if you're having a bad day you can turn the message off
fields.body:
Question: When is an advert a commercial message and when is it a distraction? Answer: It depends on the recipient's mood.

Which is why the same expensively crafted message sent to the same person at different times can have very different effects depending on how that consumer is feeling. Small wonder, then, that with all the opportunities for round-the-clock advertising that the 24-hour society and new technology provide, adland is shifting its focus - away from pigeonholing consumers into different age or social groups and towards a better understanding of its audiences' state of mind.

According to new research out next week, consumers have never been more set on individualism and self-expression. And never have they been more set against pigeonholing and rigid classification - long-standing tools integral to the adman's trade. "There is a mood of aggressive self-determination," says Caroline Chandy, director of the trends group at Publicis, the advertising agency which is behind the report. "It's a mood shaped by the growing realisation since the late 80s that 'you're on your own'."

The demise of job security and high-profile food scares are just two factors which have rocked the stability of established institutions and trust in them. The result? A nation of increasingly opinionated individuals (for proof, look no further than our increased willingness to complain) who expect the companies they deal with to have as discerning an outlook on the world as they do and to demonstrate a clearly identifiable set of values through how they behave.

"Consumers are no longer prepared to be pigeonholed - and it's becoming increasingly difficult to do so," Chandy says. "Instead, advertisers must now target attitudes and aspirations rather than lifestyle - associating their products with a viewpoint or feeling rather than identifying themselves with a particular age or social group." Where once we used brands to help define ourselves, more and more now we are using brands that fit ideas about ourselves that we already have, she adds: "Increasingly we're using brands to suit different needs at different times."

This, of course, is making the advertisers' job increasingly difficult. Which is why a growing number of ad agencies are starting to ask the previously un-askable in an attempt to understand better what we want and how we feel. Not so long ago it was enough for them simply to shout their messages at us. Now they are working hard to understand when to catch us in the right state of mind.

Obviously many different factors can affect our mood. Economic conditions and national events play their part and can sometimes have a significant effect. In 1997, studies show, the death of the Princess of Wales was followed by a nose-dive in consumer recall and awareness of many familiar ad campaigns. Less dramatic triggers, however, should also be taken into account, according to psychologist Dr Aric Sigman who has analysed how more everyday occurrences can impact on people's moods and how these can make them more or less responsive to ads.

"For obvious reasons, advertising food when people aren't hungry isn't so good an idea, and the same principle can be applied to many other situations," he says. One area under-exploited by advertisers is our desire for sensory stimulation - which is particularly acute after we've been without access to media for some time, such as after a long drive. This is why advertising in public toilets can be effective: "It's one of the few times in life when an advertiser can be guaranteed a captive audience, and [an audience] that is so used to being bombarded with messages that when it is not it actively seeks them out," he says.

Until now there has been little attention paid to how we feel and how that shapes our receptiveness to advertising. While many studies track the bigger, social trends, few have attempted to understand how moods shift according to when an audience sees an ad, what they are doing and their state of mind at the time. This is set to change, however, with ad agency McCann Erickson among the first to take the mood of its consumers very seriously indeed. In an attempt to ensure its advertising matches recipients' states of mind more closely, a rolling study is logging consumers' mood fluctuations throughout the day.

"We call it Truman Show research - where people tell us half-hourly for a week exactly what they've done when, with whom, for how long and exposed to which media," explains Jim Kite, director of global research for the agency's media and planning arm, Universal McCann. From this data you can tell the different moods that different consumers are likely to be in at different times of the day. This knowledge is primarily used for deciding which ads will run in which media and when. "If an ad contains a lot of information we can avoid scheduling it at times when consumers are feeling stressed," he says.

So, an advertiser targeting younger consumers should avoid communication between 3-4pm when this audience is likely to feel most stressed and least in the mood for receiving and responding to an ad, McCann's study suggests. Home-based mothers, meanwhile, have highest attention levels around 10am, lunchtime and after 7.30pm each night - three points in the day when they are most likely to feel positive and relaxed.

Already, one alcohol brand is targeting its advertising on Friday and Saturday nights according to its audience's mood. Increasingly, however, Kite expects such insights to be fed into the creative process to help shape the type of advertisements being devised. "I envisage a time when we have a number of different ads for one advertiser which will be used at different times of the day or week to best match consumers' particular state of mind," he says. "We are now exploring the potential for just this with a major coffee brand."

One factor increasingly guaranteed to put today's consumers into a bad mood, however, is being bombarded with commercial messages when they least want them. Historically, certain locations - such as the office - were ad-free zones. Not so now, however, with more workplaces allowing radios and even TVs to play during office hours, and with growing workplace access to the internet. All of which presents not so much a new opportunity for advertisers, but a considerable risk.

"We can't target ads at people any time, any place, anywhere just because technology allows us to or we will end up alienating everyone," says Rick Sareen, a director of new-media agency Media 21 which is exploring the potential for advertising to people on the move using the new generation of Wap mobile phones. "The right timing and the most appropriate content will be critical - far more so than when all an advertiser had to care about was running their new campaign on TV."

Adland's new Holy Grail, he adds, will be to create advertising to elicit the same type of response that MG owners have on receiving any information about their cars. "They don't see this information as advertising but content. The goal must be to create messages so in tune with the consumer at the time and point they receive them that they suck the messages from us."

Perhaps for some products, but it's hard to imagine getting so enthusiastic over the latest information about a tin of beans. But until that golden day one thing's clear: advertisers overlook how we are feeling at their peril. And while cost will inevitably limit the extent to which they can respond to our changing moods day by day, technology may soon provide one answer. When broadcasting becomes truly interactive, consumers could be asked by advertisers how they are feeling today - whether happy, sad or in a mood to indulge - and if they would prefer to be moved, informed or entertained? Assuming they have their TVs switched on, of course.

Touchy, feely: the secret of a good ad

In tune

Woolwich's current campaign includes an ad featuring a customer closing his bank account because he's not had the service he wanted. The ad's focus? A (readily identifiable) point of view rather than a picture of a Woolwich type of person, and a depiction of a consumer in control.

 QXL.com recently placed thousands of posters in service station toilets to encourage consumers to sign up with the internet site. Hardly the time or the place, one might have thought, but research suggests that because we suffer sensory deprivation in public toilets we actively seek stimuli.

 Barclaycard's ad featuring the love-lorn girl who consoles herself by splashing out on a new pair of red spangly shoes was perfectly in tune with consumers' current "I deserve it" mentality, which accepts rather than attempts to conceal our desires for indulgence.

Misjudged

 Barclays missed the mark with its recent "big is best" campaign - a good old-fashioned TV-driven mass-marketing push that demanded attention. Unfortunately it coincided with a programme of branch closures, pitching it into the role of corporate bully. Too loud, and not enough emphasis on "what's in it for me?".

 For many years Levi's has sold itself on the promise of the Levi's lifestyle. The past 18 months, however, have seen its sales and profile slip. Self-confident consumers don't passively buy into the "join our lifestyle" message, preferring, instead, a hint of how that product will help them stand out in a crowd.

 Nike, meanwhile, is also a brand perceived by some in the industry to have weakened in recent years. Its emphasis on winning - typified by its "Just do it" slogan - is now so ubiquitous amongst other firms that it's losing the edge and its advertising risks becoming faceless.

fields.headline: Man's new electronic friend
fields.trailText: The electronic programme guide, the on-screen guide that lets you select programmes by genre via a handheld device, is clearly having a big impact in digital homes. Two-thirds of viewers use it, according to Dart's survey, rather than, say, a listings magazine, to choose the next programme to watch.
fields.body:
The electronic programme guide, the on-screen guide that lets you select programmes by genre via a handheld device, is clearly having a big impact in digital homes. Two-thirds of viewers use it, according to Dart's survey, rather than, say, a listings magazine, to choose the next programme to watch.

More than two-thirds admit to surfing, but they are also able to surf with precision, and are likely to look within genres for the things they like. This boosts the audience share of adjacent channels and others with appealing programmes. One example is given of a man who only watched sport on TV, but started using the History Channel because it had profiles of great sports heroes.

Almost one in two say the EPG has become the main way they plan their viewing. Six out of ten say that since they subscribed to digital they have become more selective, leading to a higher overall level of satisfaction with TV viewing.

This suggests, says the BBC, that the EPG almost replaces printed programme guides (Radio Times please note) within digital homes. However, some people criticise the EPG for giving too little information, says Dart. This suggests that written previews, if trusted, could still guide people to things they might miss.

The BBC 's research says that men use the EPG as a fun gadget and try to exploit it to the full. While women use it as need dictates, to find what they want.

The implication is that women are less adept at using new technology and less adventurous. But it may be temporary: Dart says its latest findings for the first time show slightly more women using the EPG than men. It also finds that Sky Digital subscribers are much happier with its EPG than ONdigital's - suggesting the digital terrestrial service is not as easy to use.

Other research shows that there is a big gap between the popularity of pay-per-view movies and other services. Internet access and home banking have a fairly minor appeal at present - only 15% of viewers actually use the interactive services. But this is a fast-moving market with the lure of home shopping and pay-per-view sport also on the horizon. And while the over-55s are slower to adopt digital, there are the signs that they, too, are taking advantage of films with 15-minute staggered starts in ever greater numbers.

webTitle: Ethnic Fijians will pay the price of 'nationalism'

fields.headline: Ethnic Fijians will pay the price of 'nationalism'
fields.standfirst:
The coup in Fiji appears to have ended with total capitulation to the rebels' demands. Christopher Zinn in Sydney analyses the likely impact
Coup in Fiji: special report
fields.trailText: The coup in Fiji appears to have ended with total capitulation to the rebels' demands. Christopher Zinn in Sydney analyses the likely impact.
fields.body:
After more than 50 days the Fijian terrorists masquerading as nationalists have won the day - there's been an almost total capitulation to their demands - but at a terrible cost to their home.

International outrage at their leader George Speight means he should be wary of travelling to countries which may do what the so-called authorities in Suva failed to do - arrest him.

However, the disarmingly suave George doesn't seem to care about other nations. Under the deal with the military to release the hostages, he and his cronies could have seats in the new administration.

In what should become a classic quote from the whole sorry affair, Lieutenant Filipo Tarakinikini, the chief military spokesman, denied that the agreement means the soldiers have given in to the rebels at gunpoint.

"I wouldn't call it a failure," he said. "I would call it being realistic under the circumstances." But being realistic has yet to free the hostages - that will only happen on Thursday in another Speight deadline.

Today the small island nation is still far from stable. The illegal roadblocks are still up and there are disturbances in outlying areas.

The last time this happened, with the two 1987 coups, 67,000 Indian-Fijians left for greener pastures overseas. Speight himself estimates the financial cost of the coup at more than £150m but justifies it as "helping" future generations.

But just who? Fiji will almost certainly be slapped with sanctions from countries which buy Fijian sugar - the country's main cash crop mainly produced by Indians - at inflated prices. These include the United States, trading partners Australia and New Zealand and the European Union.

It's the ethnic Fijians, who represent 51% of the 812,000 population and the supposed beneficiaries of the coup, who stand to suffer in the long run. The former coup leader and prime minister Sitiveni Rabuka speaks of a long isolation and an even longer fight to win back recognition in the vital areas of trade and aid.

One promising young student who was due to spend the next two years at Harvard doing a business degree has already learned the hard way because the Japanese government has pulled his funding.

And countless more will feel the effects of reduced opportunities and hope as Fiji battens down the hatches for a storm of international retribution at its assault on democracy.

webTitle: Harry Potter casting row rumbles on

fields.headline: Harry Potter casting row rumbles on
fields.trailText: Following the extraordinary scenes that greeted the publication of the fourth Harry Potter book, the Goblet of Fire, this weekend, a fresh row has broken out over the casting of the trainee wizard in the movie of the first book: The Sorcerer's Stone
fields.body:
Following the extraordinary scenes that greeted the publication of the fourth Harry Potter book, the Goblet of Fire, this weekend, a fresh row has broken out over the casting of the trainee wizard in the movie of the first book: The Sorcerer's Stone.

British casting executive Susie Figgis has been scouring Britain for the right young actor to play JK Rowling's hero (see our story) and is understood to have come up with ten possibilities. Top of her list was thought to be Durham-born Jamie Bell who makes his big-screen debut in the autumn, alongside Julie Walters in Dancer.

However, according to Annanova, director Christopher Columbus is less than impressed with the choices of actor on offer. The Home Alone and Mrs Doubtfire henchman has even consulted American casting expert Janet Hirshenson over the problem, leaving Figgis exasperated

It is thought that the main area of contention is that Columbus now wants to place an American boy in the part of Potter, despite his claims in March this year that: "It's essential to find a British boy to play Harry." (see our story).

JK Rowling has specifically said that she wants a British child to play the role, and this row echoes earlier problems in the film's production when Steven Spielberg, who was originally lined up to direct the film, walked away from the project after disputes over the casting of Harry.

According to an insider: "Where does Columbus go from here? Back to America to probably cast the boy he had in mind in the first place. The whole business has become totally political... Since Renee Zellweger got the Bridget Jones part in Bridget Jones's Diary, the feeling is that Americans are much more acceptable than they used to be in very British style roles."

Top British actors such as Dame Maggie Smith, Amanda Burton and Robbie Coltrane are rumoured to be interested in supporting roles in the movie which is due to go into production in the autumn in the UK.
