fields.headline: The cause of Aids
fields.standfirst: South Africa's president has come under fire over claims that Aids is caused by poverty, not the HIV virus. Julian Glover explains why
fields.trailText: South Africa's president has come under fire over claims that Aids is caused by poverty, not the HIV virus. Julian Glover explains why
fields.body:
What's happening?
An international conference on Aids is taking place in Durban, South Africa, bringing together scientists from around the world to discuss the origins and treatment of the disease. The meeting takes place every year, but has attracted particular attention this time, partly because of its location - it's the first time the conference has been held in Africa, a continent in the grip of an Aids pandemic, where 5,500 people die from Aids-related illnesses every day. But mostly because of South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, who opened the conference by restating his belief that Aids in Africa is caused by poverty and not, as almost all doctors believe, by the HIV virus. As he spoke, hundreds of people walked out.

What does Mbeki think causes Aids?
He appears to have been inspired by the views of a handful of dissident scientists, led by Peter Duesberg, a professor of biochemistry and molecular biology at the University of California. Duesberg believes that Africans are dying from Aids-related illnesses such as tuberculosis, not because they have been infected by HIV but because their immune systems have been weakened by poverty and malnutrition. If Duesberg is right, Africa is suffering from the normal diseases of poverty, rather than a full-scale medical emergency.

Why does Mbeki back this controversial view?
Mbeki finds this idea attractive because it fits with his belief that Africa should not depend on expensive technology imported from the developed world. If Aids is a disease of poverty, it can be solved by work on issues such as third-world debt, rather than by complex - and costly - scientific innovation that might be far too expensive for most Africans to afford.

How have scientists reacted?
With horror. Almost all Aids researchers agree there is overwhelming evidence that the disease is caused by the HIV virus and fear claims to the contrary could mislead governments and individuals into delaying action against it. For instance, if people are told HIV does not cause Aids, they will continue sexual practices that encourage HIV infection - and this may kill them. Ahead of the Durban conference, five thousand Aids researchers signed a letter to the influential magazine, Nature, reiterating their belief that Aids is caused by HIV. Scientists attending the conference were particularly angry with Mbeki's heavyweight backing for the dissident view because his opinions are listened to across the continent. They had hoped that he would take the opportunity to announce a change of mind.

How does the future of Aids look?
Bleak, unfortunately. In the developed world the Aids crisis is far from over - estimates suggest 34,000 adults in the UK have been infected with HIV and 10,000 of them are unaware they've been infected. In the west, expensive treatments such as the drug AZT have enabled doctors to control Aids-related illnesses, keeping many people alive. Few people in Africa can afford such drugs, however, and even basic medical care is often unavailable. As a result, African Aids sufferers are dying in much greater numbers than in other parts of the world, causing a social and economic crisis throughout the continent. One company that manufactures an effective treatment has offered to give it free to developing countries for five years. But Mbeki's hostility to the consensus about the best way to treat Aids is hindering programmes aimed at encouraging people with the disease to seek help. Until and unless an affordable vaccine is invented to combat HIV, Africa's suffering will continue.

webTitle: Birt may hold the key to police reform

fields.headline: Birt may hold the key to police reform
fields.standfirst:
Lord Birt's appointment as a special adviser on crime may cause consternation in police canteens, but crime correspondent Nick Hopkins believes that the former BBC director could be just the man for the job
Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Birt's appointment as a special adviser on crime may cause consternation in police canteens, but crime correspondent Nick Hopkins believes that the former BBC director could be just the man for the job.
fields.body:
The appointment of John Birt as Tony Blair's 'crime-busting' adviser will not have police officers choking on their canteen-bought bacon sandwiches. This piece of news, although a shock to most, is one more likely to earn weary sighs than table-thumping condemnation.

However, the fact the prime minister has chosen Lord Birt, a friend who has no previous experience in policing or criminology, will reinforce the belief among many officers that the government does not really understand the issues - rising crime, fear of crime, rural crime - that have made law and order one of the most contentious policy areas in recent months.

Police officers remember that Ian Blair, now deputy commissioner of the Met, once advocated contracting out some policing duties. The view caused uproar. The rank and file want to protect, not diminish, their role in society. They put a question mark against Blair's name which has yet to be erased.

So imagine what they are going to make of Lord Birt. To them, he is the bespectacled bean-counter who tried to start a revolution at the BBC: he fussed at management structures, budgets and overstaffing, and was criticised for not investing enough in quality broadcasting.

Officers will ask whether he can, working one day a week and starting from scratch, offer a valuable perspective. At this point, the answer has to be a resounding 'no'.

There is a chance, however, that he will win them over. Perhaps Downing Street realises that the police and the BBC are institutions with one thing in common - both have tangled themselves up in paralysing bureaucracy.

Met commissioner Sir John Stevens says one of his major goals is to streamline Scotland Yard and free his officers from time consuming paperwork so they can go out and catch criminals.

Officers want to be unshackled. Perhaps Lord Birt has the key.

fields.headline: Blade Runner riddle revealed
fields.trailText: Nearly two decades of fierce debate among film buffs over a plot twist in the cult classic Blade Runner is finally over, thanks to a Channel 4 documentary
fields.body:
Nearly two decades of fierce debate among film buffs over a plot twist in the cult classic Blade Runner is finally over, thanks to a Channel 4 documentary.

Fans of the film have been divided over whether Harrison Ford's hard-boiled cop, Deckard, was really a genetically-created 'replicant' rather than a human being. Both the 1982 original film, and the Director's Cut from 1991, were deliberately ambiguous on the matter, but director Ridley Scott has now finally revealed that his hero was indeed a replicant.

The notion was hinted at in the Director's Cut with the biggest clue thought to be the appearance of a unicorn on screen while Deckard is lost in thought. The image of the creature appears again towards the end of the film when he picks up an origami model discarded by another character, Gaff. As the replicants have no memories of their own, fans interpreted the appearance of the model as a sign that Gaff knew what Deckard was thinking because it was an image shared by other non-humans.

In the documentary, On The Edge Of Blade Runner, to be broadcast on July 15, immediately after a showing of Blade Runner: Director's Cut, Scott discusses these scenes and confirms: "He's a replicant."

The film was considered a relative box-office flop on its release but proved to be a huge success when released on video, and its futuristic urban imagery is now considered to be highly influential.

webTitle: July 10: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: July 10: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Tomb Raider sequels planned, Oscar thief sentenced, odourama just a short sniff away, Chicken Run opening online, and Brits Christopher Eccleston and Ian Holm on the casting couch
fields.body:
 The director of the new Tomb Raider movie, Simon West, has revealed that two sequels are already planned. The first instalment, which stars Angelina Jolie (pictured) as curvaceous adventurer Lara Croft, is due to begin filming this summer. In an interview with Empire magazine, West has claimed that he, the cast and the crew, are extremely protective of the project and that everyone has signed up for a total of three pictures.

 The truck driver accused of stealing 55 Oscar statuettes before the 2000 Academy Awards has been sentenced to six months in prison by a court in Los Angeles. Lawrence E Ledent, 38,was also sentenced to five years probation, and ordered to pay £50,000 to his former employer, which sacked him after the Oscars disappeared from a warehouse near Los Angeles in March.

 Odourama in cinemas may be only a short sniff away. An idea has been hatched by Golden Harvest Pictures who want to send out blasts of scent to match the mood of their new film, Lavender. The story focuses on a fallen angel who falls for an aromatherapist, and executives on the film say they are searching for advanced scent-dispersing machines in America and Japan. This is the first time that odourama has been seriously considered since American director John Waters experimented with 'smell cards' prior to the release of his comedy Polyester almost twenty years ago.

 Fans of Chicken Run will be pleased to learn that, from today until Friday, Dreamworks will be screening the seven minute-long opening sequence of the film online for free at movie fan site Countingdown.com.

 British actor Christopher Eccleston is getting ever nearer Hollywood super-stardom, having signed up to play opposite Nicole Kidman in a film called The Others. The film is to be directed by Spanish film-maker Alejandro Amenabar and Eccleston will play Kidman's husband in a drama set in Guernsey during the second world war. The British actor is on a roll at the moment, having also just signed up to star opposite Johnny Depp in Terry Gilliam's The Man Who Killed Don Quixote.

 Ian Holm, another British actor, has just signed for the role of Napoleon in FilmFour's The Emperor's New Clothes, a historical fantasy adapted from the novel The Death of Napoleon. The story tells how Napoleon did not die in exile but returned to France in disguise to reclaim his throne. The film is due to start shooting from September on location in Italy for nine weeks.

webTitle: Mandelson warns Orangemen to stop violence

fields.headline: Mandelson warns Orangemen to stop violence
fields.trailText: Orangemen are "very, very mistaken" if they believe violence and bullying will lead to a lifting of the Drumcree Parade, Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson has warned.
fields.body:
Orangemen are "very, very mistaken" if they believe violence and bullying will lead to a lifting of the Drumcree Parade, Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson has warned.

His warning came after another night of disturbances linked to the loyalist stand-off near Portadown, County Armagh, and in response to an Orange Order call for peaceful demonstrations which he fears could lead to further violence.

Denouncing the "thuggish element", he claimed had hijacked the dispute, Mr Mandelson maintained the Orange Order would have to engage in dialogue before they could walk the predominantly Catholic Garvaghy Road in the town.

"They are the only circumstances in which it will be possible, in principle and in law, for that march to take place," he said.

"If you think that I, or the Parades Commission or anyone else, is simply gong to step back or step aside in the face of this violence, this bullying, the activities of this thuggish element, simply to allow the Portadown district to have their way, then you are very, very mistaken."

The annual parade to Drumcree Parish Church has been prevented from returning to Portadown town centre along the Garvaghy Road - the third year the ban has been enforced.

fields.headline: Police check 'sighting' of missing Sarah
fields.trailText: Detectives hunting for missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne are to examine video footage after a possible sighting of the girl with a man at a service station, police said today.
fields.body:
Detectives hunting for missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne are to examine video footage after a possible sighting of the girl with a man at a service station, police said today.

A child fitting Sarah's description and said to be "upset" was seen by a woman in the ladies' toilets at Knutsford service station on the northbound carriageway of the M6 in Cheshire, assistant chief constable Nigel Yeo told a press conference at Littlehampton police station in West Sussex.

"She was seen with a man described as white, aged 30, about six foot tall, with a solid build, crinkly sandy hair, clean shaven, and with a strong jaw and a wide nose.

"The man was wearing washed-out black jeans, a dark grey bomber jacket and a plum shirt." Mr Yeo said the child was spotted at 5am on Sunday - July 2 - the morning after the eight-year-old vanished from the secluded country lane in East Preston, West Sussex.

"It's very important that if that person with the little girl is aware that they were there and is listening to this we really need to get hold of him," said Mr Yeo.

"We really want him to come forward to eliminate him, or otherwise, from this inquiry. Until we have a reason to stop going into it we will continue to look at it."

Detective Superintendent Alan Ladley, who is leading the hunt, said the woman who saw the youngster had looked at a picture of Sarah Payne but could not say one way or the other whether it was her.

The witness first saw the girl in the toilet where she appeared to be upset before she reunited her with the sandy-haired man.

Mr Ladley said officers were due to examine CCTV security camera footage from the service station, adding: "These inquiries are still ongoing."

webTitle: Pope makes bitter attack on gay rally

fields.headline: Pope makes bitter attack on gay rally
fields.trailText: The Pope yesterday launched a blistering attack on last week's World Gay Pride festival in Rome, calling it an offence to Christian values and reiterating the Roman Catholic church's condemnation of homosexuality as a moral disorder.
fields.body:
The Pope yesterday launched a blistering attack on last week's World Gay Pride festival in Rome, calling it an offence to Christian values and reiterating the Roman Catholic church's condemnation of homosexuality as a moral disorder.

It was the first time the Pope had commented in person on the week-long event, which culminated in a colourful parade attended by around 200,000 people on Saturday.

The virulence of his speech, coming so close to the end of the festival, shocked even Vatican radio insiders.

"I cannot but express bitterness for the affront to the great jubilee of the year 2,000 and for the offence to the Christian values of a city that is so dear to the heart of the Catholics of the whole world," he told pilgrims in St Peter's Square.

The Vatican fought a seven-month battle to get the festival banned or at least postponed until the end of celebrations marking the 2000th anniversary of the birth of Christ.

Until now the Pope had left criticism of the event to senior curia officials and his unusually strong attack comes as a surprise after Saturday's parade passed off without incident and with minimal offence to Catholic sensibilities.

The Vatican had feared dramatic anti-Catholic protests against the backdrop of St Peter's Basilica. In the end, the "provocation" amounted to little more than two men dressed as priests kissing for the cameras and a fellow marcher wearing a bishop's mitre with the slogan: "God loves me too."

The irritation of the church hierarchy may have been compounded by the participation in the march of a handful of priests and by the public admission of one that he had celebrated "gay weddings". But many observers felt the Vatican's vocal opposition to the event had only magnified its media echo.

While reminding his audience that homosexuals should be treated with respect and compassion, the Pope repeated traditional teaching that homosexuality was "objectively disordered" and that homosexual acts were "contrary to natural law". The only answer for the homosexual Christian was chastity, he said.

Saturday's Gay Pride rally was attended by prominent supporters of the governing centre-left coalition, including Katia Bellillo, the minister for equal opportunities.

Centre-right politicians were quick to turn the Pope's words against their opponents. Pierferdinando Casini, leader of the Christian Democrat Centre party, described the sight of a minister in the front row of the march as a "depressing spectacle", while Francesco Storace, of the far right National Alliance, said the Pope's words vindicated his own opposition to the march.

Homosexuality has never been banned in Italy, but the gay community has not enjoyed the same visibility as its counterpart in Britain.

Imma Battaglia, a Gay Pride organiser, yesterday accused the Pope of helping to create the climate of hostility that led to a homosexual couple being attacked by rightwing youths after the Rome march.

"The responsibility belongs to the Vatican hierarchy and the intolerant and fascist right," Ms Battaglia said.

The debate over the festival has focused attention on Italy's gay community and brought unwelcome scrutiny of the church's approach to the issue, highlighting the existence of a significant number of closet homosexuals within the Vatican itself.

webTitle: Running away with myself at Southgate

fields.headline: Running away with myself at Southgate
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com goes behind the scenes to get the lowdown on one of the performances of the week. Today we talk to Tim Bloomfield, the Middlesex swing bowler, who recorded career-best one-day figures in his side's NatWest drubbing of Somerset
fields.trailText: Tim Bloomfield, 27, is a right-arm swing bowler for Middlesex. He made his debut in 1997 and has also played for Sussex 2nd XI and Berkshire. He has spent a fair part of this season on the sidelines, but in the NatWest fourth-round match against Somerset at Southgate, he took his best-ever one-day haul of 4 for 17 as Somerset were skittled for 58
fields.body:
Tim Bloomfield, 27, is a right-arm swing bowler for Middlesex. He made his debut in 1997 and has also played for Sussex 2nd XI and Berkshire. He has spent a fair part of this season on the sidelines, but in the NatWest fourth-round match against Somerset at Southgate, he took his best-ever one-day haul of 4 for 17 as Somerset were skittled for 58

"This was the first one-day game I'd played all season. I enjoy playing one-day cricket: you get more people in to watch and there is a good atmosphere, but I'm not the best batsman in the world and they tend to go for players who can bat and bowl. In fact I don't think I'd have played in this game at all but Simon Cook [the Middlesex medium-fast bowler] picked up an injury.

"I'd been bowling reasonably well in the second team and this was one of those days when it came just right. I slotted into a good rhythm and the ball was going where I wanted it to and they were nicking it - which is always a good thing.

"Southgate is a lovely ground with a nice setting but I haven't done that well there in the past. It's not wonderful for bowling because it is on a hill - at one end you are running up it and at the other end just running away with yourself.

"Justin [Langer] asked Gus [Fraser] to come up the hill which worked in my favour as I prefer the other end. It is fantastic bowling with Gus - he's done it all, hasn't he? You can always rely on him doing his job. You couldn't ask for a more consistent bowler and he certainly makes life easier for you.

"The pitch seamed about a bit, and it was a bit muggy so the ball swung when we bowled, which it hadn't done a huge amount the day before [rain meant the game was played over two days]. Funnily enough, when we'd been out practising on the first day of the match and we'd had a bowl the ball swung, but then when they went out into the middle and had a bowl it didn't.

"My first wicket was Marcus Trescothick, driving at a ball outside offstump. He was caught by [Paul] Weekes at second slip. It was a regulation catch. Trescothick is a left-hander and the ball just went across him a little bit. I didn't really think about the fact that he'd just been called up by England. There are players who you play against that you know are good, but I try not to let it worry me too much. I'm certainly not quaking in my boots.

"My next wicket was Peter Bowler - an away-swinger wide of offstump which again was caught by Weekes at second slip. That one swung late. I'm more of a swing bowler than a seamer.

"Michael Burns went to the first ball of my next over. It was another ball on offstump, he pushed forward and was caught behind. Then there was [Keith] Parsons in my second spell. He was lbw to a ball that didn't swing but seamed back into him. At this stage I was hoping for five wickets and I had nearly two overs at Nos. 10 and 11 to do it, but I couldn't get them out. Never mind - it would have been nice, but it was more important that we won the game.

"I got my first Man of the Match award at the end. You win a gold medallion with NatWest Fourth Round on it, but no champagne. You also get a cheque, which isn't too bad. It goes in the players' pool, which of course everyone made sure I did.

"Now I'd like to try to stay in the side and for us to do well for the rest of the season. In the last couple of weeks the boys have got on a bit of a roll - we've got to try to keep it going. We're playing Hampshire in the next round of the NatWest. Neither of the sides has been playing very well but we're sure to be confident of a win."

Tim Bloomfield was talking to Tanya Aldred. To read last week's My Day in the Sun, on the innings that propelled Marcus Trescothick into the England one-day team, click here.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: History is rewritten today with a record-breaking number of grand slam rumours
fields.trailText: Internazionale have made a sensational world record-equalling £31m bid for Paul Scholes reports the Mirror. Poppycock, you might think, but - wait a second! - it's from the usually reliable Harry Harris - who has probably the fattest contacts book in Fleet Street and the canny knack of finding more than his fair share of "world exclusives". Harris says the world record-equalling offer "has sparked a huge internal battle at Old Trafford" - with the board tempted to sell, but with Sir Alex Ferguson adamant he does not want one his best players to leave. We'll see
fields.body:
Internazionale have made a sensational world record-equalling £31m bid for Paul Scholes reports the Mirror. Poppycock, you might think, but - wait a second! - it's from the usually reliable Harry Harris - who has probably the fattest contacts book in Fleet Street and the canny knack of finding more than his fair share of "world exclusives". Harris says the world record-equalling offer "has sparked a huge internal battle at Old Trafford" - with the board tempted to sell, but with Sir Alex Ferguson adamant he does not want one his best players to leave. We'll see

According to Planet Football, Manchester United may have already lined up a replacement, Inter's Javier Zanetti, who they say was "one of the classiest performers in Serie A last season and is a player of undoubted quality". Apparently Sir Alex Ferguson is an admirer of the £11m-rated midfielder, but he faces competition from Barcelona and Real Madrid.

Meanwhile, French defender Laurent Blanc has insisted he will not be moving to Old Trafford. "Fabien [Barthez] and I are great friends," he said, "but I do not want to leave Inter and I will not be coming to Manchester."

Bradford manager Chris Hutchings is lining up a £2.5m move for Liverpool's Titi Camara.

The Guinean international is not the only player on the move from Anfield, according to the Mirror. Gerald Houllier is carrying out a surprise £12m clear-out of five of his first team squad. The unlucky players are: Camara, who also interests Blackburn; David Thompson, who is a potential target for Manchester City and Bradford; Erik Meijer, who could be on his way to Vitesse Arnhem for £1m and Rigobert Song, who is being targeted by "both English and continental clubs".

Everton are expected to move for £6m-rated Neil Lennon to counter the expected departures of Don Hutchinson, John Collins and Nick Barmby.

Craig Hignett is set to join Blackburn in a £2m deal. "I want to play for Graeme Souness," Hignett admitted. "It sounds corny but he was my idol at Liverpool. I feel he knows about me and my game and I'm flattered that he wants me. I also met Fulham but I wasn't so sure Jean Tigana knew what I could do."

Cambridge's 21 year-old striker Trevor Benjamin is poised to complete a £1.5m move to Leicester. "It is a very good deal for the player and the club," revealed Cambridge chairman Reg Smart. "We never want to sell our best players but it is a fact of life for clubs like United."

Benito Carbone will not be returning to Aston Villa next season and seems bound for Italy. His agent Gianni Paladini admitted: "He rang me late on Saturday to say he wouldn't be coming back to Aston Villa or any other English club." So where will he go? "The Napoli fans love him and the club has made him a very good offer," added Paladini. "Fiorentina are also interested, but he's set his heart on Napoli."

fields.headline: McQueen makes haute couture rock'n'roll
fields.trailText: The news from the Paris couture shows is that it is time to party.
fields.body:
The news from the Paris couture shows is that it is time to party.

Haute couture week is traditionally a civilised affair, where the crème de la crème of fashion designers display their most fantastical - and fantastically expensive - creations to their wealthiest clients, who spend tens of thousands of pounds from the comfort of their gilt chairs.

But the opening weekend of the autumn/winter 2000 couture shows had a rather more rock'n'roll flavour.

The British designer Alexander McQueen is famous for sharp, edgy collections with more than a hint of the dark side, but his show for the venerable Parisian house of Givenchy saw him in upbeat mood. As the show began, red brick walls painted with the Givenchy logo were lowered to reveal a party in full swing on the catwalk - complete with dancing revellers, a DJ, empty vodka bottles and even a gaggle of people gossiping in a kitchen.

The theme of the collection seemed to be how to upstage everyone at a party. Try an asymmetric yellow satin dress with a voluminous skirt of marabou feathers and a matching canary perched on your shoulder; or a floor length dragon-painted kimono in shades of orange, pink and purple.

A model in black and yellow chevron-striped beaded trousers and a sweater of knitted fox fur grabbed a Heineken from the fridge and joined the party; another threw off the floor length white and orange fur coat she was wearing over her leopard print sequinned jumpsuit and started dancing. But while there was exquisite workmanship in many of the pieces, the collection was a little too sugary to be McQueen at his best.

McQueen was not the only designer to let his hair down. Versace's show on Saturday featured Donatella's signature, indecently sexy dresses: wisps of the sheerest chiffon scattered with diamante, worn with spike heels and ermine coats - and her after show party was so star-studded that Gwyneth Paltrow went unnoticed for half an hour while other guests gawped at controversial rap star Puff Daddy and his actress girlfriend Jennifer Lopez.

webTitle: A little luck can go a long way

fields.headline: A little luck can go a long way
fields.standfirst: Starting up
fields.trailText: "You have to be lucky" were the departing words of wisdom of Scott McNealy, founder and chief executive officer of Sun Microsystems. For a man who created one of the biggest buzzes in 30 years, Mr McNealy appeared extremely unflappable.
fields.body:
"You have to be lucky" were the departing words of wisdom of Scott McNealy, founder and chief executive officer of Sun Microsystems. For a man who created one of the biggest buzzes in 30 years, Mr McNealy appeared extremely unflappable.

He is a stable, sturdy looking American, who seemed to have grown comfortably into the role of running a multibillion dollar empire. He arrived like an emperor with an entourage of at least five people, to whom he constantly doled out little tasks: "You need a systems audit? Paul, pass this gentleman your card."

Mr McNealy was handing out advice at an informal gathering last week organised by our investors. We were there to pick up any tips for our IT systems development - and if anyone knows about computers, he should.

While most of the Brits were respectful, the Americans treated Mr McNealy as if he was a minor deity. One even went to the lengths of having his photo taken with his arm around him. This brazen display of worship caused some amusement among the more reserved European delegates.

We picked up a lot from this get-together, not just from what Mr McNealy had to say but also from what we learned from the other delegates. It seems there really is more than one way to skin a cat when it comes to systems development.

One of the companies at the informal conference was a online betting company which has a system development team of 40 people. Another company - a leading pan-European online auctioneer - initially used just one person to build its entire auction system. However, what each party did have in common was a tight grip on the process of systems development.

We have outsourced our technical development to a leading British IT company. They have a strong team and the individuals involved have extensive experience in building transaction systems for banks and insurers. However, they could improve on the project and client management element of the work.

Thankfully, project management is something the Rools team knows a fair bit about as a number of people come from management consulting backgrounds. We identified this skills gap early on and quickly hired an experienced and tough project manager to add the discipline that we need to deliver the service on time.

We have the feeling that our project manager has come as a bit of a culture shock to the technical team. He has an almost religious passion for delivering the project on time.

fields.headline: Vaughan updates opening claim
fields.standfirst: Durham 314 Yorkshire 129 & 149-1
fields.trailText: Durham 314 Yorkshire 129 & 149-1
fields.body:
If Mark Ramprakash loses his England place after four uneasy tests as an opening batsman it will surely go to Yorkshire's Michael Vaughan, who once again displayed his credentials for the role here yesterday.

The main misgiving about Vaughan as an England opener is that he and Michael Atherton are too similar. Right now, though, England's top order could do with three or four Athertons when they take on West Indies in the third test at Old Trafford next month.

When play finally got under way at 2.30 yesterday afternoon, with Yorkshire resuming on nine without loss, still 176 runs behind, Vaughan was masterful against Durham's respected new-ball attack of Simon Brown and Steve Harmison.

Brown's left-arm attack was good enough to win an England cap four years ago while Harmison's pace and awkward bounce have taken him to the brink of the England side this summer.

Yorkshire went into this match as the championship leaders. But, whenever they have found themselves in this position, they look ready to abdicate, like some troubled royal.

On Saturday they had been bowled out for 129 in reply to Durham's 314 and were asked to follow on. This morning, though, thanks to Vaughan's unbeaten 94, they have a chance of saving the match. They closed on 149 for one, still 36 runs behind, but Durham's first win against these opponents looks a long way away.

Yorkshire's captain David Byas had made 18 when he plopped back a simple caught-and-bowled. Then, however, Vaughan and the wicketkeeper Richard Blakey, the latter scoring at a restrained one run every three overs, put on an unbeaten 82.

Vaughan, who scored 177 against Durham two years ago, started the season with an innings of 155 against Derbyshire before injuring his hand. But he has looked in prime form since his return and his innings at Lord's a week ago was a vital factor in England's nerve-jangling win over West Indies in the second test to level the series.

On a pitch that is holding up well by Headingley standards, his judgment was refined and his technique outstanding.

One cover drive against Neil Killeen might have been the shot of the day. He also pulled and cut anything short and played very straight in defence.

Durham's opening batsman Michael Gough, meanwhile, is unlikely to take any further part in the match after being admitted to hospital on Saturday evening.

Gough, who has been appearing in his first championship game of the summer, is believed to have picked up a chest infection during the England A tour of Bangladesh in the winter and is undergoing blood tests.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Will Kendall lifted Hampshire's spirits with a century as they finally found some form with the bat to frustrate Somerset at Taunton.
fields.body:
Will Kendall lifted Hampshire's spirits with a century as they finally found some form with the bat to frustrate Somerset at Taunton.

Hampshire, trailing by 226 after the first innings, had moved 93 runs ahead at the close as they advanced to 319 for five. Kendall, who hit 15 fours in reaching three figures off 199 balls, went on to score 161 with 23 fours while sharing a fourth-wicket stand of 160 with Derek Kenway (54), Hampshire's first century partnership in the championship this season.

The opener Michael Powell and Dominic Ostler shared an unbroken stand of 131 as Warwickshire moved from 25 for one overnight to 165 for two in their second innings against Sussex at Edgbaston.

Powell reached 70 not out and Ostler was unbeaten on 66 as the Second Division leaders extended their advantage to 259 between interruptions for rain.

Derbyshire lost two wickets, both to Glen Chapple, while adding 40 runs in the hour of play possible against Lancashire as they stretched their second-innings total to 80 for four and an overall lead of 215 at Derby.

Nottinghamshire moved from 45 for one overnight to 180 for five at Trent Bridge as they struggled to make an impression on Essex's 505 for nine declared.

The opener Darren Bicknell made 64 and fellow left-hander Usman Afzaal finished unbeaten on 65 but otherwise the bowlers were on top as Nottinghamshire entered the final day needing another 175 to avoid following on.

fields.headline: Saqlain winds up the rout
fields.standfirst: Leicestershire 143 & 184 Surrey 505 Surrey win by an innings and 178 runs
fields.trailText: Leicestershire 143 & 184 Surrey 505 Surrey win by an innings and 178 runs
fields.body:
In pre-war days the one problem for county cricket at this delightful ground was to persuade the spectators to pay rather than watch over the long low wall. It was just as well not too many were around yesterday to take even a free look at a thoroughly outplayed Leicestershire.

Surrey won by an innings and 178 runs, in the end hustled out with the minimum of fuss by Saqlain Mushtaq who took five for 35, the last three going in 11 balls. It was enough to put Surrey on top of the First Division.

The joy of the pitch was that it provided that cherished rarity, a perfect balance between bat and ball. No wonder the groundsman spends his winter Saturdays protecting the manicured cricket square from stray rugby balls. No wonder, too, that old boys like Frank Hayes, now teaching science here, and the bespectacled school professional David Steele are so proud of Oakham's cricket.

Forget the result: it may now be difficult for Leicestershire to ignore the school's claims for more first-class matches next summer. Whether or not the sums are commercially compelling, the PR exercise is formidable.

As for Leicestershire's batting, all out yesterday for 184, they leaned almost alone on Darren Stevens whose 68, with 11 brave boundaries, came off 80 balls before he was outwitted by Saqlain's slight of hand.

Leicestershire's last pair had taken their first innings total only to 143, a deficit of 362 and inevitable follow-on. The demoralising prospect was hardly helped when Darren Maddy was then out first ball, essaying an off drive of wanton beer-match abandon as if oblivious to Martin Bicknell's new-ball expertise that allows no such liberties.

Already without Alec Stewart and Graham Thorpe, Surrey were now also deficient of a bowler, Alex Tudor with a side strain. It did not appear to make a serious difference; Vince Wells chopped on in a manner which will not give him much pleasure. Aftab Habib was smartly stumped to complete for him an unproductive match.

Twenty-eight overs were lost to rain but Leicestershire's batting was no more than a fleeting gesture of restored pride. Ben Smith took advantage of Ian Salisbury's obligatory bad ball, pulling one full toss for four and similarly for six in the next over.

But, whereas Alistair Brown, so near to a triple hundred on Saturday, had threatened to penetrate the borders of slim-line Rutland - no more than 20 miles across - Leicestershire batted with a constant apprehension. Chris Lewis unfurled one sweet cover boundary, full in his case of bitter-sweet memories. Off the next ball, from Ben Hollioake, he seemed predetermined to try again and edged to the keeper. With 24 he did no more than match his previous best of the season. Though his stand with Stevens had been Leicestershire's highest of the match, it came as cold comfort to those at Oakham.

webTitle: Tufnell and Dutch turn Middlesex towards the light

fields.headline: Tufnell and Dutch turn Middlesex towards the light
fields.standfirst: Middlesex 303 Worcestershire 141 & 15-1
fields.trailText: Middlesex 303 Worcestershire 141 & 15-1
fields.body:
As Paul Pollard edged and the slip chance fell to earth, the unfortunate bowler shook the forty-winkers from their slumbers with an oath worthy of Brian Blessed at his most histrionic. That it emanated from Angus Fraser, who could have taught Job a thing or two about phlegmaticness, encapsulated Middlesex's frustrations to a T.

The ensuing deluge of 40 days' and nights' intensity handed Worcestershire what may well turn out to be more than a temporary, not to say unwarranted, reprieve. But this should not detract from the growing impression that the hosts are beginning to sense a glimmer of light at the end of what must seem like an interminable tunnel.

Not the least encouraging aspect of Middlesex's performance here has been the hints, no more, that they have finally found a spin pair fit to fill the boots of John Emburey and Phil Edmonds, the ice-and-fire combination whose complementary cunning played such an integral role in the county's era of swagger from 1976 to 1993.

It would stretch a point to describe Phil Tufnell as maturing like a fine wine; a cask of brown ale would be more apt. To see him dashing across the pitch, then swooping for a return catch off Glenn McGrath, his fourth victim of the visitors' anaemic first innings, was to appreciate both the depth of his commitment and his reluctance to endure the jibes that have accompanied his fielding exploits ever since his maiden England tour in 1990-91, when Australia's earthiest made him the butt of their caustic humour.

Tufnell has now taken 28 championship wickets at 23.64 apiece this season, inferior only to Ashley Giles among English twirlers. And, while the latter is fast emerging as a bona fide all-rounder, there can be scant doubt that West Indies, for all their left-handers, would much rather confront him or Robert Croft than Tufnell, their destroyer at the Oval in 1991, when the serious business of the summer contest resumes at Old Trafford.

Spurring on the prince of the artful dodgers is Keith Dutch, the Harrow-born off-spinner and capable bat, otherwise known as "Oik". Though twice named 2nd XI Player of the Year, only now, at 27, is he making a mark on the first-class arena: those six wickets at Chelmsford in the last round doubled his previous best haul at this level.

As Worcestershire drooped towards the follow-on, the absence of Graeme Hick and Vikram Solanki having left them as bereft as a camel shorn of its hump, Dutch completed the job by disposing of the impressive Kabir Ali, flight deceiving as much as turn. Embers would have approved.

 There are changes in the way bonus points are earned in the millennial revision of the County Championship.

As before, a win earns 12 points , a tie 6 , a normal draw 4 (see later *) and a defeat none, plus any bonus points accrued for batting and bowling in each first innings.

Bonus points are now reckoned on the score in the first 130 overs, not 120 overs as in recent seasons.

Batting: now 5 pts can be earned (4 last year)

200 -249 runs (1pt);

250-299 (2);

300-349 (3);

350-399 (4);

400 or over (5)

Bowling: now only 3 points available (4)

three-five wickets (1);

six-eight wickets (2);

nine-ten (3).

The new ball can still be taken after 100 overs.

A no ball is worth two runs to the batting side; runs scored off a no ball count in addition to the two-run penalty.

A single-innings match may be played when bad weather prevents any start until less than eight hours remain. A win earns 12 points, a tie six and a draw three but there are no bonus points.

*Note: in a draw where the scores finish level , the side batting in the fourth innings earn 6 points their opponents 4, plus bonus points.

fields.headline: Flabby Flintoff called to account
fields.trailText: England's chairman of selectors David Graveney will travel to Old Trafford later this week and is likely to inform Andy Flintoff that unless his fitness and commitment reaches the standard required of an international cricketer, his demotion from central contract to county player will be swift.
fields.body:
England's chairman of selectors David Graveney will travel to Old Trafford later this week and is likely to inform Andy Flintoff that unless his fitness and commitment reaches the standard required of an international cricketer, his demotion from central contract to county player will be swift.

It is Flintoff's weight that is causing the greatest concern. The England captain Nasser Hussain is among those who strongly believe that his history of injury - including the bad back that has plagued him since he was a teenager, and the broken foot he suffered during the fourth test in Cape Town last winter - has much to do with excess bulk.

When he has been fit, Flintoff's international career has involved massive underachievement with the bat and little with the ball. Fourteen test innings have brought just 233 runs, and those who touted him not just as the next Ian Botham but the next Wally Hammond have proved embarrassingly wide of the mark.

Ironically, a recurrence of a back injury that he suffered on Saturday following an abject piece of batting against Zimbabwe may have saved him from being publicly axed yesterday.

After his foot injury the player and his county, Lancashire, were instructed that he must lose weight, and he had made some progress before the season. However, evidence suggests that he has gained up to a stone this summer, taking him to around 17st - a result, it is suggested, of a lager and pizza lifestyle that pays scant regard to the disciplines of the job he is well paid to do.

Within the team his nickname has changed from "Enforcer" to "FS" which, rather than a tribute to any bowling likeness to Fred Trueman, stands for Fat Slogger. Now, in the words of one senior England and Wales Cricket Board figure, "enough is enough".

Among the concerns are the damage he is doing to his own career and the message he is sending out to others. So strong is the feeling in some official quarters that there may yet be an initiative to shame him into action by producing for public scrutiny his England fitness charts. It could be that, for the sake of his future, something like that must happen.

The selectors, meanwhile, are expected to replace pizza with pizzazz by calling up Dominic Cork as a reinforcement to England's one-day squad. There is every likelihood that Cork would have been called up in any event, but the strain Flintoff incurred on Saturday has settled any debate there might have been.

webTitle: England's limited efforts are cut mercifully short

fields.headline: England's limited efforts are cut mercifully short
fields.standfirst: Trescothick is a rare bright spot in a dismal batting display before rain rescues the hosts
fields.trailText: Trescothick is a rare bright spot in a dismal batting display before rain rescues the hosts
fields.body:
All this harking back to the good old days can become a bit tiresome, but do you recall only a week ago? Dominic Cork was eyeballing the world in triumph after pulling off an extraordinary test victory, English cricket was beside itself with joy, and the first NatWest triangular one-day series offered a diverting opportunity for a spot of midsummer derring-do.

That was last week, this is this week: England's one-day plans are entirely amiss, the public is shaking its head at two inadequate batting performances, and there is mounting scepticism within the England hierarchy over the commitment of Andrew Flintoff, a player who a few months ago was deemed worthy of a central contract. Life with England is anything but monotonous.

The conditions in which England had limped to 158 for eight yesterday, with 37 balls remaining, were far from straightforward, but even allowing for a modicum of swing and a mediocre surface, the likelihood was that rain spared England a second successive defeat.

After last week's test win, jubilant spectators lingered around Lord's in pale evening sunshine as if reluctant to abandon the moment. Yesterday, as the PA announcer dropped increasingly heavy hints that the match was bound to be abandoned, stopping just short of issuing a warning of a tidal wave heading down St John's Wood High Street, they ploughed homewards through the rain, heads bowed in dissatisfaction.

Marcus Trescothick had more reason than most for satisfaction. His first two one-day internationals have brought 79 and 49, and whereas Saturday's innings was compiled in a position of comfort, his confidence remained unimpaired yesterday by the failures of more experienced men around him. He should have fallen for 14 when he was dropped at short extra off Corey Collymore, but he did look like a batsman confident in his method.

Matthew Maynard, the second of England's emergency call-ups, has not been so lucky. Collymore, the most subtle of the West Indian pace quartet, had swung the ball in enough to suggest that to leave the ball was a dangerous proposition, but he did so anyway and lost his off-stump before he had scored.

Maynard's selection ahead of Vikram Solanki, who was preferred in the original squad, smacks of indecision. Solanki's recent one-day record has been dreadful, but for all that he was named in preference to Maynard in the original squad and nothing whatsoever has changed.

Duncan Fletcher, England's taciturn coach, sought justification in Maynard's "experience", and suggested that to field two young players in the top five would be overdoing it. Fletcher coached Maynard at Glamorgan and, for all his Zimbabwean credentials, he has taken refuge during stressful times in the English remedy of choosing someone old and someone you know.

Nixon McLean made the early breaches. If overloading Alec Stewart with the three roles of captain, wicketkeeper and opening batsman has been deemed as unwise in the long-term, then it is equally misguided even in an emergency. McLean had him caught at second slip and then cut one back at Graeme Hick, who was caught off the under-edge, cutting.

Craig White's entire England career has been one of selectorial inconsistency. Nothing has changed. He won a central contract on the back of a fine one-day series in South Africa, yet was omitted from the opening game at The Oval. Yesterday, Flintoff's absence allowed him to bat at No 6, a place too high, as England managed to reverse accepted practice by fielding a one-day side with less batting depth than their test XI.

White was unconvincing, re vealing the same technical deficiency as Chris Schofield earlier in the summer, although not to the same extent, in which his back foot edges towards square leg before the ball is bowled. He survived through sneaked singles before becoming the first of three victims for Franklyn Rose.

England even floundered against the off-spin of Chris Gayle. Trescothick lobbed back a return catch, Mark Ealham played inside a straight ball, and he did not concede a boundary in his 10 overs. At least Graham Thorpe, with 42 off 76 balls, might have begun to lay the foundations of an England return.

"We haven't played spin bowling well for 12 months, we don't nurdle the spinners around," said Nasser Hussain, who put that persistent frailty down to the lack of slow bowlers in a championship largely fought out by seam bowlers on duff pitches.

Hussain also reflected upon the stressful demands likely to become apparent in an extended summer of seven tests and 10 one-day internationals which, as England are roughly halfway through the programme, makes one wonder what treats are still in store.

What is needed more than anything is for the sun to come out. And who knows, it might even stop raining.

webTitle: Stewart's flops get a thick ear

fields.headline: Stewart's flops get a thick ear
fields.standfirst: From test glory to one-day disaster: how our cricketers fell from grace within a week
fields.trailText: Say what you like about England but they are as full of surprises as Paul Daniels's top hat. No sooner had the test team sniffed the rarefied atmosphere at the summit of Mount Olympus, than the one-day side dragged them down again with an inept performance against Zimbabwe here on Saturday which was stunning even by their own standards.
fields.body:
Say what you like about England but they are as full of surprises as Paul Daniels's top hat. No sooner had the test team sniffed the rarefied atmosphere at the summit of Mount Olympus, than the one-day side dragged them down again with an inept performance against Zimbabwe here on Saturday which was stunning even by their own standards.

In the aftermath of this five-wicket defeat, Alec Stewart described a batting performance that saw his side slump from 136 for one midway through the innings - when a final total of 280 was on the cards - to 207 all out, as "pretty thick". He was being generous because he might have included in that the fielding, some of the bowling, the general demeanour of his side and, not least, his own captaincy. When, shortly before the match finished with Guy Whittle drilling his only ball to the long-on boundary, he called his players into a huddle and was seen talking earnestly to them, he was not exhorting them to greater effort but asking them to try and leave the field with a measure of dignity.

It was that bad, because only twice in the match - when the debutant Marcus Trescothick was adding 106 for the second wicket with Graeme Hick, and later, when Andy Caddick and Mark Ealham reduced Zimbabwe in their reply to 35 for three, did they compete with a side that outplayed them in all departments of the game overall, from the preplanning to the execution.

Although Hick's half-century confirmed that his aptitude for the one-day game, where the fast bowlers are neutered by the rules, exceeds that for test cricket, and Ealham struck lustily later on to haul things away from total embarrass ment, Trescothick alone of the batsmen emerged from the fiasco with genuine credit.

He is a muscular uncomplicated left-hander, quick and wholehearted in latching on to anything short, overpitched or with width and hit seven boundaries in his 79 from 102 deliveries before sweeping Paul Strang's leg-spinning moon ball to deep square leg to start the slide into oblivion.

Already there is chatter of him assuming Mark Ram prakash's place with Mike Atherton at the top of the order when the tests against West Indies resume next month. It could well happen.

The selectors nevertheless will be mindful of his minimal footwork and the difference between facing Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose unencumbered by restrictions on their length and the likes of Gary Brent, Bryan Strang and even Corey Collymore and Nixon McLean.

What can be said after the weekend is that he has demonstrated a capacity to come into the international arena and perform in an unfazed manner. He could do no more than he was asked.

The rest were abysmal: Stewart hit awkwardly across the line and was lbw; Hick got a tame leading edge to Paul Strang and was caught at cover (the decision to get Strang to bowl as slowly as he could - 45 mph - so that the ball held up on the pitch was masterly); Matthew Maynard (playing in place of an original squad selection, Vikram Solanki, thus sparing an out of touch player a potential ordeal but sending out horribly negative messages) heaved at and missed a straight full toss; Graham Thorpe, anonymous on his return, chipped a gentle return catch; and Andy Flintoff drilled his third ball straight to a long-off who had just been placed there. To say that Flintoff has the cricket brain of a plant is an insult to dahlias.

Zimbabwe paced their reply to perfection with Alastair Campbell, named man of the match, shrugging off his own nightmare form to make 80 and adding 123 for the fourth wicket with Andy Flower, whose 61 included clinical use of the reverse sweep to execute a carefully planned and swift demolition of Robert Croft, the bowler who, having seen Strang, might have pulled the game round for England. Grant Flower's robust 33 from 29 balls begun with a straight six off Croft and containing three further boundaries, provided the perfect impetus at the right time.

For all his anger, Stewart was culpable, not for the overall inadequacy of the fielding (with only three, not particularly mobile, players under the age of 30, one of whom, Darren Gough, is in his 30th year, it must have been hard concealing fielders in a game where there was no hiding place) but for his own naivety - when England had to dismiss rather than contain the opposition - in failing to place, until the game was up, even a single slip for seam bowling consistently angled by left-handers off half a bat to third man for easy runs. From the most experienced player England had, that was as thick as anything.

In the aftermath of this five-wicket defeat, Alec Stewart described a batting performance that saw his side slump from 136 for one midway through the innings - when a final total of 280 was on the cards - to 207 all out, as "pretty thick". He was being generous because he might have included in that the fielding, some of the bowling, the general demeanour of his side and, not least, his own captaincy. When, shortly before the match finished with Guy Whittle drilling his only ball to the long-on boundary, he called his players into a huddle and was seen talking earnestly to them, he was not exhorting them to greater effort but asking them to try and leave the field with a measure of dignity. It was that bad, because only twice in the match - when the debutant Marcus Trescothick was adding 106 for the second wicket with Graeme Hick, and later, when Andy Caddick and Mark Ealham reduced Zimbabwe in their reply to 35 for three, did they compete with a side that outplayed them in all departments of the game overall, from the preplanning to the execution. Although Hick's half-century confirmed that his aptitude for the one-day game, where the fast bowlers are neutered by the rules, exceeds that for test cricket, and Ealham struck lustily later on to haul things away from total embarrass ment, Trescothick alone of the batsmen emerged from the fiasco with genuine credit. He is a muscular uncomplicated left-hander, quick and wholehearted in latching on to anything short, overpitched or with width and hit seven boundaries in his 79 from 102 deliveries before sweeping Paul Strang's leg-spinning moon ball to deep square leg to start the slide into oblivion. Already there is chatter of him assuming Mark Ram prakash's place with Mike Atherton at the top of the order when the tests against West Indies resume next month. It could well happen. The selectors nevertheless will be mindful of his minimal footwork and the difference between facing Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose unencumbered by restrictions on their length and the likes of Gary Brent, Bryan Strang and even Corey Collymore and Nixon McLean. What can be said after the weekend is that he has demonstrated a capacity to come into the international arena and perform in an unfazed manner. He could do no more than he was asked. The rest were abysmal: Stewart hit awkwardly across the line and was lbw; Hick got a tame leading edge to Paul Strang and was caught at cover (the decision to get Strang to bowl as slowly as he could - 45 mph - so that the ball held up on the pitch was masterly); Matthew Maynard (playing in place of an original squad selection, Vikram Solanki, thus sparing an out of touch player a potential ordeal but sending out horribly negative messages) heaved at and missed a straight full toss; Graham Thorpe, anonymous on his return, chipped a gentle return catch; and Andy Flintoff drilled his third ball straight to a long-off who had just been placed there. To say that Flintoff has the cricket brain of a plant is an insult to dahlias. Zimbabwe paced their reply to perfection with Alastair Campbell, named man of the match, shrugging off his own nightmare form to make 80 and adding 123 for the fourth wicket with Andy Flower, whose 61 included clinical use of the reverse sweep to execute a carefully planned and swift demolition of Robert Croft, the bowler who, having seen Strang, might have pulled the game round for England. Grant Flower's robust 33 from 29 balls begun with a straight six off Croft and containing three further boundaries, provided the perfect impetus at the right time. For all his anger, Stewart was culpable, not for the overall inadequacy of the fielding (with only three, not particularly mobile, players under the age of 30, one of whom, Darren Gough, is in his 30th year, it must have been hard concealing fielders in a game where there was no hiding place) but for his own naivety - when England had to dismiss rather than contain the opposition - in failing to place, until the game was up, even a single slip for seam bowling consistently angled by left-handers off half a bat to third man for easy runs. From the most experienced player England had, that was as thick as anything.

webTitle: Waqar lands ban for fiddling with ball

fields.headline: Waqar lands ban for fiddling with ball
fields.trailText: Cricket lurched into crisis mode again yesterday when Waqar Younis became the first player in international history to be found guilty of the game's second great taboo: ball-tampering.
fields.body:
Cricket lurched into crisis mode again yesterday when Waqar Younis became the first player in international history to be found guilty of the game's second great taboo: ball-tampering.

The Pakistan paceman, one of the world's most fearsome bowlers of the past decade, was suspended for one game after television replays showed him picking the seam off the ball during Saturday's one-day international against South Africa at Colombo.

His team-mate Azhar Mahmood was fined 30% of his match fee for committing a similar offence, while the Pakistan captain Moin Khan was severely reprimanded for "allowing the spirit of the game to be impaired".

In a statement released yesterday the New Zealand match referee John Reid described the offence as "clearly visible on TV" and "very serious". Waqar, who was also fined half his match fee, received a heavier penalty than Mahmood because he had already been warned by Reid after TV footage showed him scratching the ball and attempting to lift the seam during the third test against Sri Lanka at Kandy earlier this month.

But the Pakistan Cricket Board has vowed to fight the ruling. "I think John Reid has been a bit biased against Pakistan and we will certainly take up this matter with the International Cricket Council," said the board's director of operations Yawar Saeed.

It is not the first time the former New Zealand captain and Pakistan have been at loggerheads. The Pakistan board had Reid replaced as match referee against Sri Lanka earlier this year after objecting to his appointment.

Nor is it the first time that ball-tampering allegations have tainted the 28-year-old Waqar's phenomenal exploits, which include 308 wickets from only 67 tests.

Most notably, Pakistan's pacemen were accused of ball-tampering during the 1992 tour of England, and the claim was regularly repeated in the early 1990s when Waqar and Wasim Akram formed an almost unplayable partnership due to their mastery of reverse swing with the old ball.

Since then Waqar's effectiveness has declined as a string of injuries have reduced his pace, though he showed glimpses of his old self during the test series against Sri Lanka, capturing 11 wickets at 22.

This latest drama is the worst imaginable scenario for cricket officials, still reeling from the constantly unfolding match-fixing revelations.

Like match-fixing and throwing, ball-tampering has long been a source of gossip and whispering campaigns. The most famous occasion was the Mike Atherton "dirt in the pocket affair" of 1994, when the then England captain appeared to rough up one side of the ball with dirt during a Lord's test against South Africa.

Pakistan were left ruing Waqar's absence yesterday as they slipped to their third straight defeat in the triangular series, going down to Sri Lanka at Colombo by six wickets.

Hansie Cronje has been offered a job teaching ethics to future South African sports stars at a technical university in Pretoria. The university's spokeswoman Rene Uys said the position offered the disgraced former captain a "golden opportunity to redeem himself by joining the fight against corruption".

fields.headline: Touchy, feely:
fields.standfirst: Touchy, feely: the secret of a good ad.
fields.trailText: The secret of a good ad.
fields.body:
In tune

Woolwich's current campaign includes an ad featuring a customer closing his bank account because he's not had the service he wanted. The ad's focus? A (readily identifiable) point of view rather than a picture of a Woolwich type of person, and a depiction of a consumer in control.

lQXL.com recently placed thousands of posters in service station toilets to encourage consumers to sign up with the internet site. Hardly the time or the place, one might have thought, but research suggests that because we suffer sensory deprivation in public toilets we actively seek stimuli.

lBarclaycard's ad featuring the love-lorn girl (left) who consoles herself by splashing out on a new pair of red spangly shoes was perfectly in tune with consumers' current "I deserve it" mentality, which accepts rather than attempts to conceal our desires for indulgence.

Misjudged

Barclays (above, right) missed the mark with its recent "big is best" campaign - a good old-fashioned TV-driven mass-marketing push that demanded attention. Unfortunately it coincided with a programme of branch closures, pitching it into the role of corporate bully. Too loud, and not enough emphasis on "what's in it for me?".

For many years Levi's has sold itself on the promise of the Levi's lifestyle. The past 18 months, however, have seen its sales and profile slip. Self-confident consumers don't passively buy into the "join our lifestyle" message, preferring, instead, a hint of how that product will help them stand out in a crowd.

lNike, meanwhile, is also a brand perceived by some in the industry to have weakened in recent years. Its emphasis on winning - typified by its "Just do it" slogan - is now so ubiquitous amongst other firms that it's losing the edge and its advertising risks becoming faceless.

fields.headline: One speech, two speeds
fields.standfirst: How Europe's press saw Jacques Chirac's speech marking the start of France's presidency of the EU.
fields.trailText: How Europe's press saw Jacques Chirac's speech marking the start of France's presidency of the EU.
fields.body:
FRANCE

Le Monde, centre-left afternoon paper.

"The president reaffirmed that enlargement of the EU was a great, necessary and legitimate ambition, but should not be allowed to get out of hand. Neither you [the German parliament] nor [we] envisage the creation of a super-state which substitutes itself for nation states."

Traditionally pro-European, Le Monde avoided polemic and left little doubt that it saw the speech as a constructive move. It published the entire text to allow personal judgment.

Le Parisien - middle-of-the road, populist daily. "An historic speech - Chancellor Schrder was not mistaken in rushing to congratulate Chirac at the end of a pro-European plea in the framework of the prestigious Reichstag."

Le Parisien's enthusiastic report included polls showing 59% in favour of stronger European links and went further than its rivals in foreseeing the next step - an elected European president being proposed by a strong Gaullist lobby around Chirac. Paul Webster

ITALY

La Repubblica - second-biggest selling daily, based in Rome, with centre-left political slant.

"Chirac illustrated his design for the relaunch of [Franco-German] leadership of the continent. The advance guard will be concentrated around Germany and France, but it will always remain open to those who want to join."

Seen as an historic speech which should accelerate plans for a constitution, enabling power to be parcelled between nation states and EU institutions.

Il Sole 24 Ore - broadsheet daily specialising in politics, business and finance.

"A new train is leaving from the European station. We don't yet know exactly where it will stop. Some countries will climb aboard. The important ones will not remain on the platform."

Chirac's speech hailed for reviving the Franco-German engine with an ambitious vision of deeper integration and doubling EU membership: the relaunch of the new Europe.

Rory Carroll

GERMANY

Sddeutsche Zeitung - authoritative, centre-left, Munich-based daily.

"Germany and France should, in the view of Jacques Chirac, be the pioneers of European integration."

Straightforward news story summarising main points of speech and picking up on Chirac's emphasis on the role of nation states. An interpretative commentary was published under the headline "Broad lines, unclear features".

Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung - respected, centre-right, Frankfurt-based daily.

"President Chirac has in Berlin formulated solid and far-reaching goals for the further development of the EU."

News story outlining speech, but also including reaction from, among others, the Christian Democrat foreign policy guru Karl Lamers. He said it was "revolutionary" for a French president to endorse a redistribution of powers within the EU. John Hooper

UK

l The Daily Mail argued that it left Tony Blair facing "increasing isolation" by leaving Britain to face a "bleak choice" between the "surrender" of sovereignty and accepting "second division status in the EU". The speech, the paper's leader went on, had "exploded the myth peddled by British europhiles that the EU is not racing down the road to full political federation".

l The Daily Telegraph viewed the speech as a "snub" to Tony Blair, who was now "on a collision course with France and Germany" over the plans for a two-speed Europe which threatened to "leave Britain in the slow lane".

The Times also predicted a British "confrontation" with France and Germany after "the most delicate of warnings to the German government not to go out on a limb", accusing the president of adopting an "if you can't beat them, join them" attitude to Germany's calls for closer EU integration.

The Guardian saw the speech as an attempt to reassure French and German voters that "their two countries still dominate the EU's agenda". His words had, however, put "new pressure on Tony Blair to accept the idea of a two-speed Europe".

fields.headline: Why Levy was a non-story
fields.trailText: There appear to be two distinct schools of thought over the Levy affair. The prevailing Labour party view, supported by a minority of journalists, is that both the story and the manner of the investigation were invalid: the former because Levy hadn't acted illegally and the latter because the reporters - or their sources - probably had.
fields.body:
There appear to be two distinct schools of thought over the Levy affair. The prevailing Labour party view, supported by a minority of journalists, is that both the story and the manner of the investigation were invalid: the former because Levy hadn't acted illegally and the latter because the reporters - or their sources - probably had.

Then there is the Sunday Times's viewpoint, backed by most journalists, that Lord Levy's closeness to Tony Blair makes his tax affairs a matter of public interest. Therefore, the use of subterfuge, even if it did involve an illegal act, was justified.

It is an argument with a history as long as the existence of newspapers. Governments have long sought to curb a press crying freedom and, in most cases, papers have been correct to defy them. But a closer analysis of the Levy case suggests that the paper's knee-jerk press freedom defence is not as watertight as it first appears. We must follow the affair step by step to discover why. When Levy realised that the Sunday Times had discovered that he paid only £5,000 in tax last year, he was certain the paper had obtained his tax records. Levy then took some very bad advice and tried to prevent publication by going to law. The judge, rightly, refused to grant an injunction in what must rank as something of a landmark ruling. Here was a man active in public life trying to conceal information which, on the face of it, could be of public interest.

From that moment Levy was in a worse position than before he had called in his lawyers. His failed gagging bid lent credence to the notion that he had something to hide. In fact, as he cogently argued on TV and radio, there was a perfectly valid reason for his low tax bill. Indeed, the Sunday Times's story and leading article stated clearly that Levy had done nothing illegal or even improper by paying so little.

It soon emerged that Levy's anger had more to do with the way the paper obtained the information - or, at least, verified it - than with the exposure itself. He believed journalists had used subterfuge, and possibly broken the law, which the paper's Insight team denied in yesterday's paper in a second attack on Levy's tax arrangements.

Most papers were unsympathetic to Levy, concentrating their attention on his foolish legal action and delighting in the obvious embarrassment to Levy and Blair. The public interest had been served. Sometimes it is necessary for journalists to use subterfuge.

But here is where the Sunday Times's argument surely begins to weaken. I have few qualms about reporters getting up to all sorts of tricks in order to expose matters of overwhelming public interest. If Levy had been exposed as a criminal, then the ends would have justified the means. If he had been negotiating an illicit arms deal with a foreign country, breaking the law to publish the fact might also be justified.

Neither was true in this instance. Levy, by the Sunday Times's own admission, had done nothing illegal. The subterfuge used to discover that fact was reasonable (you cannot know the truth until after you have engaged in the deception) but to publish once it was realised he was 'innocent' was wrong.

In other words, the alleged crime committed by the paper was out of all proportion to what it discovered. Contrast the Levy affair with the celebrated "cod fax" sent by The Guardian's former editor, Peter Preston, to winkle out information about the hotel stay enjoyed by the Tory minister Jonathan Aitken. In that case, subterfuge was justifiable as being in the wider public interest.

The Levy exposure was entirely different. The paper wasn't uncovering a crime or even a gross error of judgment. It placed the non-story of Levy's tax shrewdness on the front page to make a political point as part of its anti-Labour agenda.

If Levy were to complain to the Press Complaints Commission, he might do well to point to a recent adjudication about a kiss-and-tell story. On that occasion, the PCC used the concept of "proportionality" to decide whether a paper had been right to intrude into a celebrity's privacy. It could measure whether subterfuge is justified in just the same way.

While we're on the subject of proportion, am I alone in thinking that the decision of every paper and TV news bulletin to lead on Euan Blair's arrest was way over the top? Some of the coverage was childish (Sun and Mirror front pages). Some was ridiculous (the Daily Telegraph leading article). And some was especially poisonous (the Daily Express leader accusing Blair of "sentimental spin").

Callers by the score to the Downing Street switchboard, and a noticeably sympathetic Radio 4 Any Questions panel and audience, illustrated how wrong papers often are. The boy is 16, for God's sake.

fields.headline: Nurses suspended over Broadmoor 'security breach'
fields.trailText: Two nurses have been suspended from Broadmoor hospital after an inmate was able to make tape recordings of confidential staff meetings.
fields.body:
Two nurses have been suspended from Broadmoor hospital after an inmate was able to make tape recordings of confidential staff meetings.

A patient with a violent history was able to tape the staff meeting and smuggle in several forbidden items into the Berkshire-based hospital which houses some of Britain's most dangerous criminals.

The BBC reports that the forbidden items included a mobile telephone, a disposable camera and audio tapes.

There were also allegations that another patient took out a contract to kill the patient who had the contraband.

The BBC said the hospital claims there were no weapons found in the searches and investigators were now probing the murder contract allegation.

Former Broadmoor nurse Ray Rowden told BBC Breakfast News he wondered what lessons had been learned from the public inquiry into Ashworth Hospital, in Maghull, Liverpool.

He added: "My second reaction is how quickly was the intelligence from this incident shared appropriately with Ashworth, the sister hospital, where as I understand it, some of the patients at the centre of this breakdown came from originally."

The inquiry was instigated into Ashworth psychiatric hospital in 1997 following allegations from a former patient about the misuse of drugs and alcohol, the free availability of pornographic material and paedophile activity.

It discovered that a young girl, being brought to the unit by a member of her family, was being groomed for paedophile purposes and was permitted, often unsupervised, to associate with men with appalling criminal records.
