webTitle: Be a hero and come out for the euro

fields.headline: Be a hero and come out for the euro
fields.standfirst:
Blair urgently needs to perform an act of reckless daring
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: On the day of the Great Common Market debate, an elderly MP called Charlie Pannel, like me, defied the party whip and voted for British membership. As we left the lobby, he thought it necessary to tell me: "He that would gain his life must first risk losing it."
fields.body:
Thirty years ago, an elderly MP called Charlie Pannell stalked the corridors of Westminster like a predator looking for easy prey. Whenever I saw him approaching, I hid behind statues of Mr Gladstone. For it was his habit to grasp young backbenchers by the elbow and subject them to homilies from which, thanks to the vice-like grip of a time-served engineer, they were unable to escape. On the day of the Great Common Market debate, like me, he defied the party whip and voted for British membership. As we left the lobby, he thought it necessary to tell me: "He that would gain his life must first risk losing it."

At the time, all that came into my head was a story which (probably incorrectly) was attributed to Cardinal Cushing. A priest, who had been called to give extreme unction to the victim of a road accident, asked him: "Do you believe in the Father, Son and Holy Ghost?" And the dying man replied: "This is not the time for riddles!" But today I feel some sympathy for Charlie Pannell's platitudes. Indeed in the unlikely event of my meeting the prime minister, I would (in the even more unlikely event of his asking my advice) repeat the biblical misquotation. The time has come for Tony Blair to improve his popularity by accepting the biggest risk of his premiership.

When discussing Tony Blair's prospects, it is always important to make clear that nobody really believes that we run the risk of a Tory government. William Hague will save us from that. What the prime minister has to decide is whether he wants to win a grudging second term, or hopes for glad confident morning again.

I constantly write and say that, far from calculating every policy according to its electoral popularity, Tony Blair really believes in what is called "the project". Unfortunately, many of those around him give quite the opposite impression. To become a national hero again he has to perform an act of reckless daring. He needs to say - or better still, have said about him - that he nailed his flag to an unpopular mast and fought for the ground over which it flew simply because he felt that was the right place to be.

For both better and worse, there is only one candidate for elevation into a test of faith and morals. It is British membership of the single European currency. It would be better if he could demonstrate his courage with an initiative which would unite the Labour party behind him. But even in my most optimistic mood, I cannot imagine him suddenly arguing for an extra penny on the standard rate of income tax in order to index link the pension. Nor would he seem credible if he did. Any socialist policy which he accepted would be a betrayal of his own beliefs. Supporting the euro would certainly offend some of his potential supporters. That would prove his integrity. There are worse initiatives with which to demonstrate that desired result for the simple reason that immediate membership is an economic necessity and eventual membership absolutely inevitable.

Siren voices - if such a female metaphor is appropriate to Philip Gould and Alastair Campbell - will tell the PM that a rush of principle to the head may make him a hero again with voters who admire thoughtless honesty, but will do nothing to make him popular with the Murdoch papers. They will be repeating the error of judgment which has already done immense damage to the government's reputation. Labour did not win because it was supported by the Sun. The Sun supported Labour because Mr Murdoch knew the party was going to win. The more people who say of Tony Blair, as they once said of Margaret Thatcher, "Agree with the prime minister or not, you have to admire his courage and determination," the more Mr Murdoch's papers are likely to say the same.

The prime minister's whole political philosophy inhibits him from taking a strong line on the euro. He despises and distrusts ideology. So he is neither passionate for the high ideal of European integration nor devoted to the sentimental notion of preserving national sovereignty. He wants to do what, in his judgment, is best for the country at any one time. It is perfectly reasonable to argue that, by the sort of calculation which would be made by the chairman of Great Britain plc, this is not the moment for membership. But he is not running Great Britain plc. When a politician talks about waiting for the terms and time to be right, it sounds like vacillation.

There is, of course, one other obstacle which bars the prime minister's way to the high ground. It is called Gordon Brown. But, despite my increasing sympathy with Mr Brown's policies, I have to admit that, for the prime minister to become a hero again, there has to be a second act of reckless daring. The chancellor has to be put in his place.

webTitle: Delegate in World Cup row quits

fields.headline: Delegate in World Cup row quits
fields.standfirst:
78-year-old New Zealander blamed for 2006 voting controversy jumps before he is pushed
Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Charles Dempsey, the Fifa delegate whose abstention in the election to decide the venue for the 2006 World Cup caused international uproar, announced his retirement yesterday as anger continued to grow over his actions.
fields.byline: Vivek Chaudhary and David Cohen in Wellington
fields.body:
Charles Dempsey, the Fifa delegate whose abstention in the election to decide the venue for the 2006 World Cup caused international uproar, announced his retirement yesterday as anger continued to grow over his actions.

Mr Dempsey, 78, said after a meeting of officials of Oceania, the football confederation which he represents, that he would step down as president in September.

He added that he had explained his reasons for not voting in last Thursday's election in Zurich to officials in New Zealand.

The executive committee of Oceania met for almost five hours in private in Auckland yesterday and expressed anger at Mr Dempsey's abstention in the election organised by Fifa, world football's governing body.

It was widely believed that had Mr Dempsey not announced his resignation he would have been forced to step down.

Germany beat South Africa by 12 votes to 11 in last week's election, with Mr Dempsey's abstention proving crucial. It caused outrage around the world among politicians, football fans and administrators.

Had Mr Dempsey voted as he was told to by Oceania, the contest would have been tied with Fifa president Sepp Blatter, who backed South Africa, holding the final casting vote.

Mr Dempsey said after yesterday's meeting of Oceania officials in Auckland: "Behind closed doors the executive met and discussed - I wasn't present - and gave approval to the explanations that I gave for what took place in Zurich.

"But after all this consideration and the [media] harassment, I will retire at the end of September because I cannot accept what has taken place over the last three days."

Mr Dempsey claimed after the vote that he had decided to abstain because of the "intolerable pressure" he had been placed under by the supporters of the competing bids.

He was due to step down as Oceania president in 2002.

Johnny Tinsley Lulu, the Oceania vice-president, said Mr Dempsey was retiring because executive members had made it clear that they were unhappy with his explanation of events in Zurich.

Shau Khan, Fiji's representative to Oceania, said: "The call definitely would have been made to step down if he had not announced his retirement. My view is that when an executive directive is given it should be compiled with."

Mr Dempsey had been mandated by Oceania at a meeting in May to vote for South Africa once England was eliminated from the competition.

England fell out of the reckoning in the second round with only two votes but Mr Dempsey then handed a lawyer's letter to Fifa officials outlining his reasons for abstaining.

Mr Dempsey, who was born in Scotland, claimed that he had been inundated with telephone calls hours before the vote urging him to back South Africa and that he had also been offered bribes.

It later emerged that letters offering cash and gifts sent to Fifa delegates prior to Thursday's vote were a hoax organised by a German satirical magazine. A special meeting of Oceania officials will be held in Sydney at the end of September to decide Mr Dempsey's replacement.

It also emerged yesterday that Mr Dempsey had sought the permission of Oceania officials hours before last week's vote for a free hand over which candidate he could back for the 2006 venue.

Fifa has said it will hold an internal investigation into the events surrounding last Thursday's vote but has ruled out a new vote on the choice of host for 2006.

Andreas Herren, Fifa's spokesman, said: "The vote itself stands. That is not part of the discussion."

webTitle: Every day gets harder, say missing Sarah's parents

fields.headline: Every day gets harder, say missing Sarah's parents
fields.trailText: The parents of missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne said they are convinced their daughter is still alive despite being missing for nine days.
fields.body:
The parents of missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne said they are convinced their daughter is still alive despite being missing for nine days.

Clutching a white teddy bear, her mother Sara was close to tears as she said: "This is for you darling. They (Sarah's brothers and sister) never stop thinking about you, darling."

The fresh plea came as it emerged that detectives working on the search are to be offered counselling because of the distressing nature of the hunt.

Sussex Police's welfare unit is arriving at Littlehampton police station, West Sussex, to assess how officers are coping and offer counselling to those who want it, senior officers said.

Sarah's family has already been offered specialist counselling to cope with their ordeal since she vanished from a secluded country lane in East Preston, West Sussex, but officers refused to say if they had accepted it.

The parents said the belief that she is still alive is driving them on.

"That's what is keeping us going, that she's out there somewhere and we are just waiting to find her," Michael Payne told GMTV.

"There is no question in my mind, it is just a matter of time and, yes, it does get harder."

His wife added: "Every day gets harder than before, in fact every hour gets harder than the one before."

The couple said a visit to the incident room had helped their other children see the efforts being made to trace Sarah, but added that it was particularly difficult time for their younger daughter, Charlotte.

fields.headline: Magic of meeting Harry's creator
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Keen Harry Potter fans Laura Tisdall, 13, and Polly Tisdall, 11, were among hundreds of children who turned out to meet JK Rowling in Didcot, Oxfordshire, on Saturday. This is their account of what happened:
fields.body:
Keen Harry Potter fans Laura Tisdall, 13, and Polly Tisdall, 11, were among hundreds of children who turned out to meet JK Rowling in Didcot, Oxfordshire, on Saturday. This is their account of what happened:

The moment the Hogwarts Express steam train finally puffed into Didcot Railway Centre on Saturday with JK Rowling on board was just totally magic. We'd been waiting for ages and ages with hundreds of other people, clutching our copies of the new Harry Potter book and our precious golden tickets.

We had sat a mock Hogwarts School Exam at Ottakar's bookshop in Chippenham, Wiltshire, and won a golden ticket each, which meant we could meet our favourite author and have our books signed by her.

A queue of excited kids and their parents stretched down the track waiting for the sound of a train whistle. To keep us entertained, and perfect for a signing of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, a man was juggling fire sticks.

Then at last the maroon Hogwarts Express chugged in with a plume of steam, drawing beautiful antique carriages. There she was: JK Rowling herself!

She climbed aboard a stationary carriage, ready to meet us. Three hundred pairs of eyes watched her. Finally we moved forward through the iron archway with Platform 9 over it, just like in the books, and on to the train, moving a few steps closer. When it was our turn, we almost ran down the corridor and entered her compartment.

JK Rowling said she liked our T-shirts; one had a dragon on it, the other a lightning bolt, like the one on Harry's forehead. She was really friendly, not rushed. She was wearing a flowery skirt. She gave the answer to one of our questions about the second book, which we'd been dying to know. Then she signed our new books.

It wasn't all over. A family we had talked to in the queue had come without golden tickets. Luckily they got in, after waiting for 3 hours. Their mum said: "It was well worth it."

We thought so, too.

webTitle: Hype at its hottest, but Rowling may survive it

fields.headline: Hype at its hottest, but Rowling may survive it
fields.standfirst: The Potter phenomenon Author's wizardry extends to getting timing of fourth book just rightBooks Unlimited
fields.trailText: In a career of only three years, JK Rowling has changed book publishing.
fields.body:
In a career of only three years, JK Rowling has changed book publishing.

She has created a world in which novels - like new cars, grouse, beaujolais nouveau and Star Wars movies - are mass-purchased on the first day of availability and in which book reviews are phoned in at half-time like a sports report. Saturday's newspapers and airwaves contained the first literary notices in which critics freely admitted that they had not had time to finish the book.

Selling literature like this is a risk. The only previous novel released to even a percentage of this hysteria, Thomas Harris's Hannibal last summer, suffered from critics taking revenge on the publicity. But while no writer could ever justify this hype, my view - backed, more importantly, by assistant critics from the target market - is that JK Rowling may survive it.

With an estimated £14m annual income and a global first print run of 5m copies for this book, Rowling is in obvious senses a lucky writer, but the fourth Harry Potter brings her another piece of author's good fortune: timing.

While the newspapers report the failure of England's bid to stage the football World Cup, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire begins with great excitement in the wizard homes of Britain over the staging in this country of the World Cup of Quidditch, Rowling's ingenious invented game.

It is such a happy coincidence that you read on half-expecting Harry to be arrested in Leicester Square after taking too many magic potions. But you should never make jokes about the commercial sorcery of Rowling: later in the story, a politician is indeed embarrassed by the actions of his teenage son.

Although the closeness to the Fifa announcement is an accident, the book feels thematically shaped to fit the summer of Euro 2000 and the Sydney Olympics. After attending a Quidditch World Cup final marred by incidents of hooliganism aimed at "muggles" (non-wizards) - a detail typical of the adult satire which makes her novels so parent-friendly - Harry's new term at his sorcery school includes an international Triwizard Tournament, a kind of magic Olympics.

In all the website speculation about what the book might contain, no one had predicted that Rowling would offer the most sporty popular fiction since the novels of Dick Francis. Those plot developments which had been floated - love interest for Harry and a climactic death - are present, though far less dramatically than anticipated. Romance is restricted to some minor blushy brushing and, with the killing, Rowling does not take the risk of thinning out the central cast list, using the old authorial trick of fattening up a character purely for the purpose of sacrifice.

Images of death and violence, however, do haunt the story, and it is here that the rising idea that the Potter books are some sort of universal literature suitable for infant school or pension queue needs to be questioned. My five-year-old assistant critic had a troubled Saturday night after hearing the first hundred pages.

Whereas Enid Blyton's characters passed decades without celebrating a birthday, part of Rowling's concept is that Harry is 12 months older each time she publishes. In this fourth novel, there are signs that this trick is taking her away from younger fans. For example, Harry and friends use the expletive "git", for which some parents and infant teachers may not feel ready.

As for the view that the Potter novels pass as adult books, any dedicated grown-up reader would need to be frightened of what real life and real writing are like. Rowling's prose is correct, but there is never a surprising sentence.

Purely as a children's author, though, the fourth Potter confirms her as an original who takes her craft seriously. Most publishers will privately tell you that huge success is often ruinous to a writer's talents: the books they write poor are usually better than the ones they write rich. But Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire suggests that Rowling still wants to write big books as well as big cheques.

 Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire by JK Rowling, Bloomsbury, £14.99 hardback

Rowling's prose is correct, but there is never a surprising sentence. Purely as a children's author, though, the fourth Potter confirms her as an original who takes her craft seriously. Most publishers will privately tell you that huge success is often ruinous to a writer's talents: the books they write poor are usually better than the ones they write rich. But Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire suggests that Rowling still wants to write big books as well as big cheques.  Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire by JK Rowling, Bloomsbury, £14.99 hardback

webTitle: Old US spy cocks a snook from Havana

fields.headline: Old US spy cocks a snook from Havana
fields.trailText: Spies have to find their way around unfamiliar surroundings. They must be ready to fly from one far-flung location to another, moving money around the world quickly and discreetly. No wonder they make perfect travel agents.
fields.body:
Spies have to find their way around unfamiliar surroundings. They must be ready to fly from one far-flung location to another, moving money around the world quickly and discreetly. No wonder they make perfect travel agents.

That is what Philip Agee has discovered. The CIA agent who turned whistleblower and fugitive in the 1970s has changed career once more, and opened up shop as a tour operator in Havana.

His newly launched company, Cubalinda.com, sells package tours offering everything you might expect from a tropical island: beach hotels, scuba-diving, car hire and fishing trips.

The website caters for Europeans but targets the US market, making it doubly unusual. Not only is it run by a former secret agent, but its principal goal is to invite potential customers to break the law. The US trade embargo, now nearly four decades old, bans Americans from spending money in Cuba, with penalties of up to 10 years in jail or tens of thousands of dollars in fines.

Cubalinda has two ways of getting around this problem. Firstly, it does business on the internet and has a parent company based in the Bahamas, so technically the customers' money does not go to Cuba. In theory, an American tourist could pay for everything up front, and arrive in Cuba with empty pockets.

The second approach on offer to customers is to follow Mr Agee's example and live dangerously.

"The whole idea is to take a chance. I mean, what fun is life if you're not taking a chance. I've been taking chances for a long, long time. I took a lot of chances when I was in the CIA," declared Mr Agee at the recent launch of a campaign to persuade American tourists to come for the summer carnival.

The biggest chance Mr Agee probably ever took was to leave the CIA in 1969 and then to write a tell-all book about his 12 years with the agency, destabilising governments and generally spreading mayhem across Latin America. The 1975 expose, Inside the Company: CIA Diary, also published a 22-page list of alleged CIA operatives. It did not go down well with his former employers, who revoked his US passport and declared him a threat to national security.

After years as a fugitive, he decided to set up home and business in Havana, home of the revolution he admired.

His flat and office - on the fourth floor of a dilapidated block in the district of Vedado - were reached by a rickety lift. Mr Agee's name was by the door but the security gate was bolted. His employees across the corridor said he was in Germany, but was in touch by email and would be pleased to respond to questions by email, as indeed he was.

He scoffed at the suggestion that his business was built around persuading people to break the law. "Come on, the law is absurd - a reflection of extremist Miami Cuban influence - and should be ignored," he wrote. "I started this business to promote contact between ordinary Americans and Cubans and to help Americans learn the truth about Cuba."

There is a demand. The website has between 30,000 and 50,000 hits a day, and reservations are coming in by the hundred. Mr Agee reckons Cubalinda.com will be breaking even before the end of the year. "Not bad for a little dot.com start up."

Each year, an estimated 80,000 Americans travel illegally to Cuba, where immigration officials oblige by not stamping their passports. Tourists rarely get caught on their way home, but the thrill of the forbidden adds to the romance, especially for would-be Hemingways keen to go deep-sea fishing and drink rum.

With the publicity generated by Mr Agee and Elian Gonzalez , the numbers are bound to rise. The old spy has come in from the cold and is drinking mojitos on the beach.

webTitle: Bradford anxious to impress their new boys

fields.headline: Bradford anxious to impress their new boys
fields.standfirst:
Bradford City 4 Mills 12 36, Blake 70 (pen), Grant 85
FK Atlantas 1 Karalius 90
Bradford win 7-2 on agg
fields.trailText: Eight days ago, for Bradford City's first competitive European game, a motley collection of juniors, reserves and the odd first-team player managed to defeat their Lithuanian opponents in the first leg of this InterToto Cup second-round tie.
fields.body:
Eight days ago, for Bradford City's first competitive European game, a motley collection of juniors, reserves and the odd first-team player managed to defeat their Lithuanian opponents in the first leg of this InterToto Cup second-round tie.

Yesterday a more familiar side took the field for the return and, after the arrival of City's £2.5m record transfer David Hopkin from Leeds, together with Ian Nolan and Peter Atherton from Sheffield Wednesday, one or two did so with a point to prove.

Even without their three new signings, ineligible until the fourth round, it was only ever a question of how many Bradford would add to their 3-1 first-leg lead.

Robbie Blake had already seen his 20-yard shot cannon back off the bar before Dean Saunders crossed low for Lee Mills to sidefoot a 12th-minute opener. For Bradford's second, Mills headed home after Saunders had found space on the left.

Blake added a third from the spot before Atlantas's goalkeeper Ivan Osipov handed Bradford a fourth by dropping a cross at the feet of the substitute Gareth Grant.

Martynus Karalius, a lone thorn in the side of the City defence, hit an injury-time consolation from a 25-yard free-kick before running the length of the pitch to celebrate with the 20 or so travelling supporters from the city of Klaipeda.

"There's a huge carrot at the end of it," said Bradford's manager Chris Hutchings, "and we're aiming for that final and a place in the Uefa Cup."

Bradford City: Clarke; Todd, Jacobs (Myers, 75min), McCall, Wetherall, O'Brien, Windass, Blake, Mills (Rankin, 84), Saunders (Grant, 71), Whalley.

Atlantas: Osipov; Puckov, Lukosevicius, Maciulevicius, Vasiljev, Zernys (Vainoras 17, Raliukonis 69), Jermakov, Vijeikis (Veseljevas 42), Petreikis, Karalius, Suika.

Referee: C Mendez (Spain).

webTitle: Celtic to break bank for Sutton

fields.headline: Celtic to break bank for Sutton
fields.trailText: Chris Sutton, once the most expensive player in England, will break Scotland's transfer record today when Celtic complete a £6m deal with Chelsea.
fields.body:
Chris Sutton, once the most expensive player in England, will break Scotland's transfer record today when Celtic complete a £6m deal with Chelsea.

The striker, who cost Chelsea £10m from Blackburn only 12 months ago - double what Rovers paid Norwich when breaking the British transfer record in 1994 - will have a medical in Glasgow today. Last week Sutton asked for time to consider a £6m move to Middlesbrough, who promptly withdrew their offer.

"I would expect Chris to fly out and join us on Tuesday," said Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill, referring to Celtic's pre-season tour to Denmark.

"I don't understand how Middlesbrough, who made the first bid, would then decide they don't want to speak somebody. I think that was because deep down Chris was keen to join us."

Arsenal and Chelsea will be asked to release their French players for a charity match three days before the start of the season. France are play ing a Fifa World XI in Marseille on August 16 and the French Football Federation is anxious that all of its Euro 2000 squad take part.

Arsenal should have four men involved, five if Sylvain Wiltord signs from Bordeaux, Chelsea are likely to have three and Manchester United would have to release their goalkeeper Fabien Barthez.

Parma's striker Hernan Crespo, who scored 21 Serie A goals last season, is 99% certain to join Lazio, the Rome club's president Sergio Cragnotti said yesterday. In return the champions are expected to hand over their Argentine midfielder Matias Almeyda plus cash.

The Spanish club Alaves have agreed in principle to sign Manchester United's Jordi Cruyff on a Bosman free transfer. Southampton, who were also hoping to land the Dutchman, will now step up their efforts to sign Aston Villa's Mark Draper for £1.5m.

Saints also expect to pay a club record £2m for Tenerife's defender Sergio Martinez Ballesteros, who will be discussing terms this week.

webTitle: Stampede kills 12 at world cup tie

fields.headline: Stampede kills 12 at world cup tie
fields.trailText: At least 12 people died here yesterday in chaos that disrupted a World Cup qualifying match between Zimbabwe and South Africa.
fields.body:
At least 12 people died here yesterday in chaos that disrupted a World Cup qualifying match between Zimbabwe and South Africa.

Police officers, in what appears to have been an over-reaction to fans throwing plastic bottles on to the field, fired tear gas into a near-capacity crowd of 60,000 at the National Sports Stadium. Thousands of spectators stampeded to get out of the stadium and many people were crushed.

Many of the players, who included Manchester United's Quinton Fortune, Birmingham City's Peter Ndlovu and two Barnsley players, Eric Tinkler and Shaun Bartlett, writhed on the turf as the tear gas hit them.

One eyewitness saw eight bodies, and officials said 12 people were killed with scores injured.

The tear gas disrupted what looked like a certain win for South Africa in the World Cup African Zone Group E match. They were 2-0 ahead with eight minutes to go when the match was abandoned.

Fleeing fans were then confronted by more tear gas outside, and some began stoning police cars.

"It was terrible. There were bottles thrown but they were only plastic bottles," said one eyewitness, Taurai Mapangavanhu. "Then the police fired tear gas and everyone panicked. "We tried to run out, but there was more tear gas outside the stadium. People became angry at the police and started rioting. It was a mess."

Riot police cordoned off the stadium and ambulances were moving in and out of the area last night.

Zimbabwean fans began throwing bottles on to the field following South Africa's second goal by Delron Buckley, scored in the 82nd minute. Buckley, who scored both of South Africa's goals, injured his ankle and was being treated by a doctor.

As Buckley was lying down, he was hit on the head by a plastic bottle and other objects rained down from the stands. It was then that the police fired tear gas.

While panic took hold among the crowd, stadium medical staff helped the players with water and, after a few minutes, escorted them from the pitch.

The referee, Falla Ndoye from Senegal, ended the match and awarded the game to South Africa.

After Fifa has received a report from the Egyptian match commissioner it is likely that Zimbabwe - who have never qualified for the World Cup -will face a heavy fine. They may also be ordered to close the National Stadium for a period, forcing them to play home matches elsewhere in Harare or in Bulawayo.

The chaos at the National Sports Stadium follows 32 violent deaths in Zimbabwe largely connected with parliamentary elections held on June 24 and 25.

It also caps a bad week for African football after the failure of South Africa to win the race to host the 2006 World Cup.

Former Wimbledon player John Fashanu, who is a sporting envoy for Nigeria, said: "Those who oppose the development of African football will use footage from Harare to maximum advantage."

Live coverage of the match was broadcast throughout Africa.

fields.headline: Internet access
fields.trailText: Once a privilege, internet access is now widespread in the workplace, and is creating demands for new skills. Recruitment consultancy Office Angels says a third of its clients are requesting internet skills as part of the secretarial package. In Cambridge, the so-called Silicon Fen, that figure rises to three-quarters.
fields.body:
Once a privilege, internet access is now widespread in the workplace, and is creating demands for new skills. Recruitment consultancy Office Angels says a third of its clients are requesting internet skills as part of the secretarial package. In Cambridge, the so-called Silicon Fen, that figure rises to three-quarters.

A few years ago, people were distinctly sniffy about secretarial internet access. Even the first secretary known to have been recruited over the internet in this country (by Reed Employment) said online recruitment was unlikely to have a future because secretaries would never be allowed internet access. As email has matured, views have changed. Indeed, email management is now the top skill demanded by Office Angels' clients. With some managers receiving 200 emails a day, the ability to prioritise and filter is much sought after.

At the same time, the world wide web is becoming an important research tool. Employers want secretaries who know their way around search engines, waking up to the fact that the web is a fast source of background information for meetings and presentations. In addition, organisations are using intranets to create departmental, and even company, diaries. And while booking travel and accommodation online is not as widespread here as in the US, many companies look for knowledge and experience of this when recruiting.

The art of information-sharing across organisations is increasingly becoming a secretarial responsibility. Some secretaries are even creating internal web pages of Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs). Now that the web is being taken seriously, the responsibility for making it work is travelling down the line.

fields.headline: Barak on the brink
fields.standfirst: Defections imperil Camp David summit
fields.trailText: For Ehud Barak, the Israeli prime minister, the moment when statesmanship must supersede mere politics has arrived. One year after creating a multi-party government, the better to pursue the cause of peace, Mr Barak looks on helplessly as defectors shatter the coalition he so hopefully built.
fields.body:
For Ehud Barak, the Israeli prime minister, the moment when statesmanship must supersede mere politics has arrived. One year after creating a multi-party government, the better to pursue the cause of peace, Mr Barak looks on helplessly as defectors shatter the coalition he so hopefully built. Yesterday's desertions by the ultra-Orthodox Shas and by Natan Sharansky will leave him with only minority support in the Knesset. Of more immediate significance, they represent a debilitating vote of no confidence in the prime minister's negotiations with the Palestinians, which will reach a sort of climax at the Camp David summit when it opens tomorrow.

This growing band of opponents wants no truck with a deal they suspect will, if it is achieved at all, require immensely difficult, perhaps vote-losing compromises. So they cut and run, on matters of supposed high principle. This is mere scrub politics; the self-serving manoeuvres of second-raters and also-rans. Of Mr Barak, as has held true since he was first elected, something more, something bigger and better is required. He extricated Israel from the Lebanon quagmire, as promised. He came very close to a Syrian deal last spring, before Hafez Assad's death left a tantalising limbo. Now, despite domestic ructions, with President Bill Clinton urging him on, he has the chance to forge a lasting, historic peace with Yasser Arafat. A slim chance, for sure. An imperfect peace, no doubt. But the peace he firmly, utterly believes the majority of the Israeli people yearns for - and will support in the national referendum he vows to hold over the head of a surly, sniping parliament.

He must seize this chance if he possibly can, for the period of bitter politicking now in prospect is preferable by far to the likely explosion of violence and instability that may be expected should the talks collapse. And yet rarely has a summit meeting been preceded by such gloomy prognostications from all sides. The Palestinians express little or no confidence in the process, in the return of land or refugees or Jerusalem, nor for that matter in their own leadership. They set a deadline for declaring an independent state, hoping to gain leverage but risking humiliation or worse. Mr Arafat tours the Arab capitals, collecting fine words and promises like alms, a mendicant seemingly doomed to wander the world and never yet find home. Their young people look wistfully to the empty triumphalism of Lebanon's Hizbullah; even their elders, like Professor Edward Said, who should know better, are reduced to casting stones.

But for the Palestinians too, given willpower and a strong stomach, a deal is reachable and far preferable to what may otherwise follow. Up to 90% control of the West Bank and Gaza; some form of limited power-sharing in east Jerusalem; the consolidation of the remaining Jewish settlements in the occupied territories into contiguous blocs; an international commission for the resettlement or rehabilitation of the estimated 3.5m Palestinian refugees: these are the rough outlines around which any second Camp David pact can be built. It is hardly heroic; not the stuff of celebration or even satisfaction. But it is the reality of the present. Like Mr Barak, Mr Arafat must find the strength to face it, manage it and then improve upon it.

"Enough of blood and tears, I say enough," cried another former Israeli general-turned-PM, Yitzhak Rabin, when, rising to the challenge of statesmanship, he offered his hand to Mr Arafat in 1993. Mr Rabin paid an awful price. But his heartfelt message still stands.

fields.headline: The Euro's not for spinning
fields.standfirst: As the popular press calls for a serious debate on the euro, Roy Greenslade remembers the years of xenophobic tub-thumping that have already undermined the possibility of a rational choice.
fields.trailText: As the popular press calls for a serious debate on the euro, Roy Greenslade remembers the years of xenophobic tub-thumping that have already undermined the possibility of a rational choice.
fields.body:
I had to rub my eyes. A Daily Mail leading article 10 days ago made an impassioned plea for a "debate" on the single currency. Soon after, the London Evening Standard - same owner, same hymn sheet, same tune, different organist - looked forward to a "prolonged debate". Both calls followed in the wake of the Sun demanding "a full, honest public debate" around the question Tony Blair intends to ask in the forthcoming, but unscheduled, referendum.

Can they be serious? The Daily Mail and the Sun, having run hysterical, xenophobic, myth-making campaigns against the euro for years, now want an informed debate! This must surely rank as one of the most perfect definitions of chutzpah.

The Sun, hostile to European integration since at least 1981, has the gall to "demand" rational discussion on the subject. Remember first its 1990 "Up Yours Delors!" article in which it called on its "patriotic family of readers to tell the feelthy French to FROG OFF!".

Recall also its 1994 story headlined "Now they've really gone bananas: Euro bosses ban 'too bendy' ones". Perhaps the paper never meant its 10m-plus readers to take this seriously, imagining that they knew that the European commission wasn't actually insisting on straight bananas. Then there was that "honest" 1997 claim that socialism was due to enter Britain by the back door through the introduction of the social chapter, encouraging trade unions to call European-wide strikes to enforce a four-day week. The following year, the Sun, under new editor David Yelland, asked whether prime minister Tony Blair was "the most dangerous man in Britain" because of his Euro sympathies.

Moreover, this is a paper owned by a company, News International, which last year refused permission for two academics, Peter J Anderson and Anthony Weymouth, to quote directly from the Sun and the Times when writing their excellent book - Insulting the Public? - on the scandalous way in which the British press has misreported events in the EU. Imagine the Wapping reaction if this bizarre act of censorship had been perpetrated by the European Commission! It is a poor advertisement for the concept of free speech by papers which squeal at the slightest encroachment on their rights to express themselves freely.

Anyway, on to that other tabloid fighter against Europe, the Daily Mail. Its anti-Euro propaganda has been less crude than the Sun's, though doubtless more effective. Note, for instance, the underlying message in its report of Blair's speech in Paris in March 1998, headlined "Blair Hands Off Warning to EU". This story, yes a "news" story, casts the EU as an alien enemy trying to gets its hands on Britain's taxes.

The paper has also helped to perpetrate many of the Euro-myths so beloved by opponents. At this point I ought to say that a number of the fears raised by the Mail about the possible effects of integration have been perfectly reasonable. It is the context in which it places them that is objectionable, narrowing the debate at every turn, using war-like language and playing to the irrational, but deep-seated, xenophobia of its audience.

Lest anyone get the idea I might be a Europhile, I speak as a 1975 referendum "no" voter and as a continuing sceptic, concerned about the loss of sovereignty and the threat to democracy caused by a supra-national tier of government far too remote from the people. (Isn't Westminster remote enough already?) My fears echo Tony Benn's in the 1970s, when he was marginalised and demonised by an almost unanimous pro-Common Market press. Then, just as now, the newspaper "debate" lacked any subtlety. It was black and white, them and us, yes or no.

The dissonance between economic unity and political unity - in which people often feel sanguine about the former and genuinely worried about the latter - certainly demands a lengthy public discussion, free from distortion. Instead, what clearly frustrates Blair and his press secretary Alastair Campbell (as it should every sensible politician) is the fact that the reporting of European affairs is so obviously infected by the prejudices of press owners and editors that there is little chance of an honest debate.

Seen from that perspective, Campbell's tirade against six papers on the No 10 website after Blair's speech in Tübingen was totally understandable. Showing how papers such as the Sun, Mail and Telegraph used the speech to push their own agenda, he accused them of "distortion and misrepresentation" which happens "on an almost daily basis".

Then again, the Campbell critique can also be seen as misguided for the simple reason that he was the messenger. His credit with the papers he seeks to influence has expired, so the substance of his argument, which certainly merits serious attention, was ignored. Campbell is now Press Enemy No 1, having replaced Peter Mandelson, who also chose last week to attack journalistic spin doctoring. "I certainly do not deny the right of the press to take positions on Europe," he wrote. "But the British people and the democratic debate are starting to lose out from the nature of the coverage."

Any impartial review of newspaper coverage - and I commend the work of the authors mentioned above and of Dominic Wring from Loughborough University - supports Mandelson's argument. Again, though, papers now ignore all his substantive criticisms. This is how the journalism of political personality works. Once the man/woman is demonised, their genuine views can be safely ignored. Yet the decision about greater European integration is surely too momentous to allow this to happen.

Incidentally, there appears also to be a huge amount of naivety in Downing Street about winning the nation around in order to secure a referendum victory. In the current atmosphere of increasingly virulent anti-Blair, anti-Campbell press hysteria, the very notion of this government being able to "ratchet up" a successful, populist pro-Euro campaign is laughable.

The editors of the Sun, Daily Mail and Daily Telegraph are not for turning. Whether their hostility to the EU is born of genuine ideological concerns or more commercial worries about "losing" their audience in an integrated Europe, they will not change their minds. Having made the concept of "government spin" into the enduring leitmotif of Blair's administration, they will scupper any moves to spin the Euro.

fields.headline: Digital gains critical mass
fields.standfirst: There are now enough homes with digital television for researchers to be able to measure its effects on viewing habits. And the emerging picture is extremely worrying for all the terrestrial channels, says Maggie Brown
fields.trailText: There are now enough homes with digital television for researchers to be able to measure its effects on viewing habits. And the emerging picture is extremely worrying for all the terrestrial channels, says Maggie Brown?.
fields.body:
At least 4m homes now take digital television, mainly through Sky but also via ONdigital. Critical mass - a sufficiently large number of subscribers to produce meaningful data - has been reached within the last year.

So the inevitable questions arise. Does the availability of scores of channels, films-on-near-demand and pay-per-view change the way people watch television? And is it right to see the electronic programme guide (EPG) leading a television revolution, tempting viewers to watch more of what they fancy on niche services, dodging both worthy BBC programmes and the adverts?

These questions go beyond narrow commercial interests and straight into issues of culture, society and human behaviour.

The achievement of critical mass is also of prime importance to the unconvinced, the 50% saying, for various reasons, that they are not interested or can't afford to switch to digital. Why? Because the rise of digital is now heavily affecting how those running the main terrestrial channels think about the future and plan programme investment ahead.

The BBC's most senior figures are openly talking about changing BBC1 and BBC2 (along with two new channels, BBC3 and BBC4) into more predictable services, like the BBC's radio networks, but also to align publicly funded television with the EPG.

The shock waves are still reverberating from the speech that the BBC's director of television Mark Thompson made in far-away Banff last month, floating the idea of making BBC1 an entertainment-driven channel - though his argument has been dismissed as futuristic by the other big threatened player, ITV. Its director of programmes David Liddiment argues that, as with digital radio, the BBC is in danger of running ahead of the majority.

Yet precisely at this juncture - when it's vital to know what's going on - the regulatory bodies let you down. The ITC plans to study the behaviour of 40 "digital virgin" families, paying for them to be linked up - but this research project has yet to start. The independent academic centres that monitor TV should get their skates on: they seem to have sleep-walked through a year which is arguably the most significant in UK television history. The BBC does possess a body of research which is informing policy-making. But only the main "bullet points" have been made available.

So in what follows I'm piecing together what is known, from a variety of sources including Zenith Media, Sky, Flextech, and, most usefully, the Dart (digital audience research tracker) survey carried out by the research company Ipsos-RSL. It's not definitive. But this represents a good stab.

The most obvious question is, what happens in digital homes? The answer seems to be that people do probably watch more. According to the Barb figures for May, digital homes watched an average of 25 hours, 33 minutes per week, compared with an average in all homes of 23 hours, 38 minutes. However, as Zenith's head of research, Simon Bolus, warns, this gap should be treated with caution. It is possible that digital homes are disproportionately occupied by the UK's heaviest viewers, telly addicts whose weekly viewing was well above average before digital arrived.

The Dart research is interesting on this point. A year ago, digital viewers were largely early adopters, from AB social groups and often single. But now, with the spread of free equipment, the audience is far more mainstream, skewed towards CDE social groups and families with young children.

But the really key finding is that in Sky digital homes, viewing of terrestrial channels slumps to just over half of all viewing. In other words, the extra choice is pushing their share down worryingly, to around 52% in May this year. In two weeks in June, digital channels netted more than 50% of viewing in digital satellite homes.

Among children under 16, the terrestrials' slump is even greater. Sky's own tracking research shows them spending 61% of their viewing with digital channels. This is a marked shift from the trend in old-fashioned analogue satellite homes, using the technology on which the 1990s multi-channel thrust was based, where the split for adults is around 35% to 65% in favour of terrestrial. The big flight has been disguised until recently, because multi-channel homes were all lumped together and digital was too small to separate out.

Most pundits, and not just Sky, think the share won by digital channels is poised to go even higher. BBC1, which has a 27% overall share in all UK homes, is down to 20% in analogue satellite/cable homes - but gets only 17% where there is digital satellite. Uncomfortable. Uncomfortable for all five terrestrial channels, actually.

Also, what the raw data doesn't show is a trend that is much discussed within Sky. There is a sharp rise in viewing to its Premier and MovieMax channels, because of their staggered start times every 15 minutes. As watching a movie involves a big commitment of time, the movie channels' audience share has almost doubled thanks to the convenience of staggered starts, by up to four percentage points to between 7% and 8% in digital homes. Around 60% are calling up extra pay-per-view movies once a month or so, says Dart, with the youngest adults the most frequent purchasers. Movies are at last displaying the same ability as sport to drive digital take-up.

The viewing data makes it clear why Sky One is investing more in its programme budget - because the EPG makes it a good investment. Zoning by genre, the EPG increases competition and creates more of a level playing field, putting Sky's entertainment offerings alongside those of BBC1, BBC2, Channel 4 and Channel 5.

So programmes that were hard to find on analogue satellite are now openly displayed. Everyone involved in starting niche channels knows how hard it is to make an impact with new programmes because they flash by unnoticed as part of the glut of multi-channel choice, watched only by tiny audiences. But for the more important and established networks this is changing.

The research does find differences between the sexes. Men are deserting BBC1 and BBC2 for digital networks faster than women. The BBC's own research suggests this may be because men and women view the EPG differently. For men it is a gadget, to be experimented with. For women it is a practical means to an end. A significant number don't really know how to use it, or how to exploit its potential to the full.

But, interestingly, there are sound reasons for the BBC and ITV not to panic. For example, although audience share plummets with the arrival of digital, the effect on reach - how many access terrestrial networks each week - is not so drastic. 87% still watch BBC1, 80.6% ITV (ITV has unwisely kept its service off digital satellite).

This suggests that people still value traditional programming. This is borne out by BBC research and other studies. Dave Brennan, formerly Flextech's vice president overseeing research and channel development, says: "It is going to be a long time before the main terrestrial channels lose their reach."

As he observes, the schedules of BBC1, ITV and to some extent Channel 4 and BBC2 are very well known: the start-times of Coronation Street, EastEnders and Neighbours are ingrained on people's minds. So large numbers switch on without prompting for soaps or drama premieres in prime evening viewing time.

But where they start straying is at all other times, outside peak hours and when, as happens too often, BBC1 is offering nothing special - lifestyle programmes, cheap docu-soaps or films that have already been screened several times on Sky.

So the BBC's conclusion that it needs more landmark programming on BBC1, where it is eyeball-to-eyeball with other entertainment networks, and less indifferent stuff, is absolutely correct. The problem it has is that even when it premieres top drama with stars (Fish, starring Paul McGann, is a good recent example) it is not hitting the popular button. Either the wrong series are commissioned, or there is not enough attention to script quality and production values. BBC1 will really be in danger if Sky One manages to forge fruitful links with the likes of Harry Enfield and top writing and production talent.

But the viewing trends in digital homes underscore the big dilemma faced by all established networks. If you fail to respond, the erosion of share will continue relentlessly. But change too fast and you run the risk of alienating viewers - both those content with what they've got, and those who, spoilt for choice, still plump for tried-and-tested favourites.

fields.headline: Mrs Clinton needs a flaw
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: Candidates in the American system spend most of their lives raising money for television commercials. Hillary needs every cent she can get for her bid for the Senate seat for New York, which is being vacated by the scholarly and tetchy Senator Daniel Moynihan. This is the first anniversary of her candidacy and she is still unable to break 50% in the polls, despite the commotions in the Republican party.
fields.body:
As a rule, the only buzz in the quiet little seaside village in the Hamptons, Long Island, where I spend weekends, is from the subfamily Apinae: bees to you. (They are slim, social bees, not to be confused with the obese, hairy Anthophorus crowd). This weekend the Apinae were buzzed out by the rising excitement concerning the slim queen bee of the Clinton family. Hadn't I heard she was coming in a couple of weeks and we could all have a summer lunch with Hillary for $1,000 a plate? Candidates in the American system spend most of their lives raising money for television commercials and $1,000 is small change: $5,000 a seat is commonplace for the rubbernecking you get with the rubber chicken.

Hillary needs every cent she can get for her bid for the Senate seat for New York, which is being vacated by the scholarly and tetchy Senator Daniel Moynihan. This is the first anniversary of her candidacy and she is still unable to break 50% in the polls, despite the commotions in the Republican party. The melodramatic contest I described between Hillary, as the schoolmarm, and Rudy Giuliani, as the law'n'order sheriff of New York City, has been pulled from local theatres. Mayor Giuliani has retired from the race, having announced that he was suffering from prostate cancer and had finally decided to leave his wife for his mistress. He had barely made his exit when last week a book suggested his father, Harold, spent a year and half in Sing Sing for taking a baseball bat to slow payers in loan-shark and gambling operations run by La Cosa Nostra, and his cousin, Leo d'Avanzo, was a car-thieving goodfella who was gunned down by FBI agents in Brooklyn in 1977.

The mafia smear sooner or later gets attached to anyone with a vowel at the end of his name running for office in New York, but for Giuliani, a very effective prosecutor, it's akin to someone suggesting that when Joe McCarthy was doing his witch-hunts, his dad was heading up a Soviet spy ring. Rudy came to fame getting 100 years jail apiece for the heads of five mafia families and I think he would have got a huge sympathy vote if he had stayed the course.

Rudy's place, alas, has been taken by another vowel, a handsome young New York congressman, Rick Lazio, with a thin skin and an erratic left-right-left voting record. But Lazio has lots of Republican cash. He has spent some of it giving the press a special bus fitted out for them with a fax machine, captain's swivel chairs, couches, a microwave oven, coffeemaker, well-stocked fridge, satellite phones and colour television. A cunning move, that TV set. From their captain's chairs, reporters have been watching Wimbledon all week, which is a safer use of their time than trying to disentangle where Lazio stands on abortion. His position has been that he is pro-choice provided nobody chooses. Now the supreme court has removed his wriggle room in a judgment weighted in favour of women's rights, which is Hillary's position. But her press crowd have been no help: they've been too busy grumbling about her plain old press bus and the nanny notice that the campaign "Cannot be responsible for any electrical items plugged into this socket. (Use at your own risk.)"

This weekend the enemy forces were already gathering. Outside the Village Cafe there was parked a racy blue convertible with a fancy plaque welded to the boot: "Go Back Home Hillary", which was rich, because the vehicle's licence plate was from the Sunshine State, suggesting someone had the nerve to drive all the way from Florida to protest carpet-bagging in our politics up here. I did a double take when a slim blonde emerged from the cafe, a Hillary lookalike, but it's symptomatic of what is going on. Hillary has a problem with women, just the kind of women you would think she would attract. She has slipped from a 50% approval rate among women in 1998, during the Monica affair, to 44%. The trouble is the suburbs where the vowel is ahead 54% to 32%. Suburban women could give Rick the Senate seat. It is puzzling. So many of them look and talk like Hillary and think more like her than Lazio on abortion and guns and education.

The polls afford little clue to the contradiction, but she may be resented for being too poised, too perfect, too self-righteous, too forgiving, even - the wife who has fixed her hair and manicure and is in the hammock reading Foreign Affairs while you're still wrestling with the kids' breakfast. Call it the queen bee syndrome. My conclusion is she needs the sympathy vote again. Maybe she could borrow a skeleton or two from Giuliani's cupboard.

 Harold Evans is the author of The American Century.
comment@theguardian.com

Hillary needs every cent she can get for her bid for the Senate seat for New York, which is being vacated by the scholarly and tetchy Senator Daniel Moynihan. This is the first anniversary of her candidacy and she is still unable to break 50% in the polls, despite the commotions in the Republican party. The melodramatic contest I described between Hillary, as the schoolmarm, and Rudy Giuliani, as the law'n'order sheriff of New York City, has been pulled from local theatres. Mayor Giuliani has retired from the race, having announced that he was suffering from prostate cancer and had finally decided to leave his wife for his mistress. He had barely made his exit when last week a book suggested his father, Harold, spent a year and half in Sing Sing for taking a baseball bat to slow payers in loan-shark and gambling operations run by La Cosa Nostra, and his cousin, Leo d'Avanzo, was a car-thieving goodfella who was gunned down by FBI agents in Brooklyn in 1977. The mafia smear sooner or later gets attached to anyone with a vowel at the end of his name running for office in New York, but for Giuliani, a very effective prosecutor, it's akin to someone suggesting that when Joe McCarthy was doing his witch-hunts, his dad was heading up a Soviet spy ring. Rudy came to fame getting 100 years jail apiece for the heads of five mafia families and I think he would have got a huge sympathy vote if he had stayed the course. Rudy's place, alas, has been taken by another vowel, a handsome young New York congressman, Rick Lazio, with a thin skin and an erratic left-right-left voting record. But Lazio has lots of Republican cash. He has spent some of it giving the press a special bus fitted out for them with a fax machine, captain's swivel chairs, couches, a microwave oven, coffeemaker, well-stocked fridge, satellite phones and colour television. A cunning move, that TV set. From their captain's chairs, reporters have been watching Wimbledon all week, which is a safer use of their time than trying to disentangle where Lazio stands on abortion. His position has been that he is pro-choice provided nobody chooses. Now the supreme court has removed his wriggle room in a judgment weighted in favour of women's rights, which is Hillary's position. But her press crowd have been no help: they've been too busy grumbling about her plain old press bus and the nanny notice that the campaign "Cannot be responsible for any electrical items plugged into this socket. (Use at your own risk.)" This weekend the enemy forces were already gathering. Outside the Village Cafe there was parked a racy blue convertible with a fancy plaque welded to the boot: "Go Back Home Hillary", which was rich, because the vehicle's licence plate was from the Sunshine State, suggesting someone had the nerve to drive all the way from Florida to protest carpet-bagging in our politics up here. I did a double take when a slim blonde emerged from the cafe, a Hillary lookalike, but it's symptomatic of what is going on. Hillary has a problem with women, just the kind of women you would think she would attract. She has slipped from a 50% approval rate among women in 1998, during the Monica affair, to 44%. The trouble is the suburbs where the vowel is ahead 54% to 32%. Suburban women could give Rick the Senate seat. It is puzzling. So many of them look and talk like Hillary and think more like her than Lazio on abortion and guns and education. The polls afford little clue to the contradiction, but she may be resented for being too poised, too perfect, too self-righteous, too forgiving, even - the wife who has fixed her hair and manicure and is in the hammock reading Foreign Affairs while you're still wrestling with the kids' breakfast. Call it the queen bee syndrome. My conclusion is she needs the sympathy vote again. Maybe she could borrow a skeleton or two from Giuliani's cupboard.  Harold Evans is the author of The American Century. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Testing times
fields.standfirst: Not everyone would relish a job involving more than a million exams, but Dawn Sargent loves it. She tells  Dolly Dhingra  why
fields.trailText: Not everyone would relish a job involving more than a million exams, but Dawn Sargent loves it. She tells Dolly Dhingra why
fields.body:
Up and down the country, more than 15,000 examiners for the Oxford and Cambridge and RSA Examinations board (OCR) are busily marking exam papers taken by students earlier this summer. August 17 is the day of reckoning for the 220,000 awaiting A-level results; a further 1.1m GCSE results will be issued a week later. Whatever a student's grades, exams - and the long wait for the results - can be traumatic.

It was curiosity that made Dawn Sargent, 27, apply for her job as PA to the general assessment director of OCR, David Barrett. She was keen to take a peek behind the doors of an institution that most of us would rather forget.

"I thought, 'Wouldn't it be interesting to see what goes on behind the scenes of the exam process?' As a student, all you know is that an exam paper arrives on your desk, and then some time later you get the results," she says. Sargent sat her A-levels more than nine years ago and decided to take time out to dabble in the world of work before taking a degree. "I worked as a receptionist for a year - I hadn't had any formal secretarial training - and everything I've learnt, I've done myself. I've been keen to develop my organisational skills."

A degree in English from Anglia Polytechnic University gave her the space to be flexible in her career - the rigidity of a profession, she says, is not for her. She spent several years working in the telecommunications industry until one day she spotted a particularly interesting job advert. "I enjoyed the blue-chip companies because they were moving onwards and upwards, but I wanted to get my teeth into something, to specialise, rather than just work in a huge call centre," she explains.

Originally from Reading, Sargent lives in and loves Cambridge. "I like the character and the academia here. Cambridge has a slower pace of life than Reading, which is very cosmopolitan, and I enjoy the sense of tradition," she says. Fortunately for her, she is based in an open-plan office with 70 other colleagues in the heart of Cambridge, next to the famous expanse of green known as Parker's Piece. A year and a half into the job, she is beginning to find a rhythm. "It is an immense job, so for the first year it was all a learning curve. No two weeks were ever the same, but now things are beginning to settle down," she says.

The assessment department is responsible for setting exam questions and papers, and is currently experiencing its busiest period. OCR must conform to the standards set by the Qualification and Curriculum Authority, which means that all sorts of issues have to be looked into - confidentiality in the marking process being a hugely important one. "Examiners are currently marking papers at home. As soon as the exams have been taken, the papers are put into special envelopes that are sealed and can only be opened with a pair of scissors," explains Sargent. "All deliveries are carefully monitored and have to be signed for - if there is any sign of tampering, or any kind of breach of confidentiality, it would be investigated immediately."

And what if an examiner finds that they happen to be marking the papers of a friend's child? "That would not happen - examiners have to inform us if they know of anyone sitting our exams. The same applies to staff. If I had children who were doing the exams, I would have to disclose that," she insists.

So does all hell break loose once the results are published? "We do get schools and individuals ringing up to say that they didn't get the results they expected and we have a team that investigates the post-exams process. So far, any difficulties have been resolved, or procedures have been put in place to deal with the complaint," she says.

With more than a month before the results are published, you might think Sargent would suggest students take some time to relax before they're plunged into the world of clearing and career choices, but no. "I think students should be busy looking into every eventuality," she says. "They shouldn't panic, but there's no point in doing everything at the last minute. We are doing our utmost, but a person will only get the grades for how they performed on the day."

webTitle: Poverty at the heart of a nation

fields.headline: Poverty at the heart of a nation
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: There is a war memorial on the outskirts of Moscow, made up of three red crosses designed to look like anti-tank defences. Next to it is a new branch of IKEA. The former is there to show how close the Nazis got to defeating the Soviet Union in 1941, the latter is a symbol of the more successful invasion from the West half a century later.
fields.body:
There is a war memorial on the outskirts of Moscow, made up of three red crosses designed to look like anti-tank defences. Next to it is a new branch of IKEA. The former is there to show how close the Nazis got to defeating the Soviet Union in 1941, the latter is a symbol of the more successful invasion from the West half a century later.

Gum, the store that used to be reserved for the party's leading lights and foreign tourists, is now a shopping mall, complete with atrium, fountains and shots of Elizabeth Hurley advertising cosmetics. But it still has very few people in it actually buying anything, which is hardly surprising given that a fetching little something from Dior will cost more than the average monthly wage.

Some Russians do, of course, shop in the arcade and in many cases they are the same KGB officers who used to shop here before and have now turned up in a new guise. The top 20% of Russians now account for almost 50% of the country's income, and they have become rich beyond imagination. Certainly beyond the imagination of ordinary Russians, who are poorer now than they were a decade ago. Pensioners have to get by on the equivalent of £15 a month. Beyond Moscow itself, the skin-deep nature of the new Russia quickly becomes apparent. Mytishchi is a one-industry town, just outside the capital, which makes cars for the metro. Out here, there are fewer Mercs, only Ladas. The housing, poorly constructed in the first place, is decrepit. From one end of the town to the other, there is nothing that looks modern except for a new power station and a branch of the state-owned savings bank, Sberbank. The public spaces are unkempt, with waist-high grass in the parks and empty flower-beds.

By the roadside, there are people with their goods displayed on tarpaulins. One is selling T-shirts, with Versace emblazoned on the front. An old lady has three punnets of strawberries on sale for 50 roubles a throw. A group of six or seven men in late middle age, with all the familiar signs of long-term unemployment and poverty, are trying to make a few roubles by selling their last pathetic possessions, books without covers, a length of flex with a plug on the end, a hacksaw without a blade.

Further along, the road peters out and muddy tracks lead off from a supermarket across the waste ground between six blocks of flats. Given its location, the supermarket is well-stocked with sausage, crab, turkey, french wines, scotch , designer water. But there seems little demand for 12-year-old Chivas Regal at £45.

In the centre of the city, there is an administration building complete with a hammer and sickle embedded in the masonry and a statue of Lenin in commanding pose. But for those seeking signs that globalisation is working there is one encouraging sign, at least. A boy of eight, looking for something to eat or sell, climbs a tree with two friends to pick unripe apples. He is wearing a Manchester United football shirt with Beckham emblazoned on the back.

webTitle: Crime rise adds to Blair woes

fields.headline: Crime rise adds to Blair woes
fields.standfirst: Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will attempt to bury details of an alarming rise in violent crime across the country by publishing a series of embarrassing Home Office statistics on the same day as Gordon Brown unveils his headline-grabbing spending review.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will attempt to bury details of an alarming rise in violent crime across the country by publishing a series of embarrassing Home Office statistics on the same day as Gordon Brown unveils his headline-grabbing spending review.

In a sign of the growing panic in Downing Street that ministers are losing the initiative on law and order, the annual crime figures will be slipped out on July 18 at virtually the same moment as the chancellor announces a massive hike in government spending on health and education.

Ministers are said to be deeply alarmed at the Home Office figures which are expected to show that recorded crime in England and Wales has risen by about 3% in the past year and is accelerating, with violent crime rising by more than 10%.

Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, last night accused the government of a cynical attempt to manipulate the news. "Ministers are so transparent," Ms Widdecombe said. "This is yet another pathetic attempt at spin, but the difference now is that people are wised up to the ways of this government."

Her criticism came as the government underlined its concerns over crime by appointing the former BBC director general Lord Birt as a special unpaid adviser on crime.

At the personal invitation of the prime minister, Lord Birt will work unpaid for the government one day a week to tackle "deep-seated issues". Downing Street said that Lord Birt, who will continue to sit in the Lords as a crossbencher, had been chosen because he could bring an outsiders' view to crime.

His appointment was criticised yesterday by the Tories and Liberal Democrats as a poor response to rising crime. Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, said: "After 18 years in opposition and three years in government and the huge amount of facts, figures and research already available, what has Labour been doing? Soundbites and supremos are not enough."

John Prescott defended the appointment, saying that Lord Birt would help the government to continue to be tough on crime.

However, the appointment, which comes hard on the heels of the prime minister's ill-fated "cashpoint initiative" to tackle drunken yobs, indicates a growing worry among ministers that they are losing the initiative on crime.

Ministers will attempt to play down the crime increases by focusing on the continuing fall in domestic burglaries which have dropped by 28% over the past five years to their lowest level for a decade.

The prime minister, who believes that Labour's "tough on crime tough on the causes of crime" message was a crucial factor in his landslide election victory, attempted to regain the initiative at the end of last month by floating the idea of marching drunken yobs to cashpoints to pay on-the-spot fines. Within days this was shot down as unworkable by police.

Whitehall sources were surprised when Mr Blair continued to talk about law and order initiatives after his embarrassing climbdown. The sources expected that the prime minister would move on to other issues in the immediate aftermath of his son's arrest and reprimand last week for being drunk and incapable.

The panic over law and order comes amid signs that senior ministers fear that the government is failing to communicate effectively with voters. It was confirmed yesterday that the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, has been instructed to report to Mr Prescott once a week on how he is succeeding in selling the government's achievements.

In a defensive letter to the deputy prime minister Mr Campbell insisted that he did have "a reasonable success rate in getting our agenda up".

fields.headline: Jargon works if jail doesn't
fields.standfirst:
An open letter of advice to John Birt, the government's new special adviser on crime
Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: Dear John, I was amazed to hear of your appointment as adviser to the PM on crime. Although we have known each other somewhat for three decades, I had no idea of your interest or knowledge in this field. Perhaps you are coming to it fresh.
fields.body:
Dear John,

I was amazed to hear of your appointment as adviser to the PM on crime. Although we have known each other somewhat for three decades, I had no idea of your interest or knowledge in this field. Perhaps you are coming to it fresh.

Many would regard that as a liability. On the other hand, the current inspector of prisons, David Ramsbotham (a distinguished soldier), was appointed for his lack of knowledge. So too was his predecessor, Stephen Tumim, a civil court judge, and Lord Woolf, the current lord chief justice, author of the Woolf report on prisons, another civil judge. All were so outraged by what they saw when they visited prisons, they became radical reformers. Perhaps that will happen to you.

By coming fresh to this field, you will also bring with you the expensively learnt lessons of management consultants during your time at the BBC. Having spent two years filming McKinsey's and others, I know how comfortable they are at reviewing their client's business and recommending changes without prior knowledge. They argue that this apparent weakness is in fact a strength, as they are not trapped in the blinkered culture that resists change.

Of course one problem you will face at once is the question: who is the client? Is it the government - currently under fire? Is it the community - such as the frustrated residents of estates where crime really is high? Or is it the media and politicians, who wrongly imagine that the crude language, numbers and solutions they toss around have a bearing on the complex and often intractable problems that make up the causes and patterns of crime? There is no magic bullet, though there are things which can work.

I hope you will be able to bring to bear the McKinsey techniques of talking extensively to people at all levels of the system - most particularly victims and offenders. You will hear how being a victim increases your chance of victimisation. And that most persistent offenders already think that sentences are longer than they are - and yet still offend. To them the courts and prison are just a game, or occupational hazard. Your goal must be to increase victim satisfaction while reducing offender criminal productivity. This may involve organisational reform around new principles - indeed your biggest shock may be learning that there are no guiding principles in the justice system, and the customers are seen as the judges and lawyers.

Having looked at the evidence, and braindumped what you found with colleagues, you come up with a view of what works and what needs to be abandoned or changed. In policing, this is known as problem-oriented policing (Pop) and has worked wonders both here and in America. Instead of just pouring more officers on to the streets, they are targeted at known offenders, and hotspots - areas and times of day when offending is occurring - such as Friday night outside certain pubs at closing time. It leads to imaginative partnerships and civil actions, such as making the landlord liable for violence outside his pub.

But Pop (I know you like acronyms) soon leads you to the bit which politicians find hardest to accept: that the causes and predictors of persistent offending have nothing to do with the justice system. They involve poor housing and frequent moves, domestic violence and child abuse, drug and alcohol problems, unemployment, poor physical and mental health, learning problems, school failure and exclusion, and harsh and erratic parenting.

To speak to those factors, you need a radical reorganisation of their job description that consultants are famous for - such as combining radio and television news.

When you look at the market research, like all good consultants you will find a meta-analysis by Mark Lipsey of Vanderbilt of 40,000 young offenders. He found that much the most effective form of rehabilitation was a job. The next most effective were high quality "multi-modal" programmes (I know you don't mind jargon) tailored for the offender's specific problems.

Then comes the hard part, assessing personnel for what McKinsey calls a skill/will rating. You must decide who has the skill to take the venture forward in its new form, and who also has the will to do this. By putting both together, you can see who to keep and promote as change agents - champions in consultant-speak - and who will be excess to requirements.

Meanwhile the old, largely redundant, part of the justice business - the prison complex - still lumbers on, vacuuming up resources and hindered from following best practice in a lean and efficient way by outdated sentencing practices that overload the system. You know the sort of thing: too much throughput lowers the quality of the final product, and demoralises the staff.

Of course firms call in outside consultants for a few obvious reasons: often they are in deep trouble and need to change dramatically, but don't know how to achieve it or how to tell their workforce. This government knows the answer. They just need to trust it, and get the credit for it.

Yours, Roger.

cc Tony Blair, Jack Straw

 Roger Graef is a criminologist and filmaker
