They involve poor housing and frequent moves, domestic violence and child abuse, drug and alcohol problems, unemployment, poor physical and mental health, learning problems, school failure and exclusion, and harsh and erratic parenting. To speak to those factors, you need a radical reorganisation of their job description that consultants are famous for - such as combining radio and television news. When you look at the market research, like all good consultants you will find a meta-analysis by Mark Lipsey of Vanderbilt of 40,000 young offenders. He found that much the most effective form of rehabilitation was a job. The next most effective were high quality "multi-modal" programmes (I know you don't mind jargon) tailored for the offender's specific problems. Then comes the hard part, assessing personnel for what McKinsey calls a skill/will rating. You must decide who has the skill to take the venture forward in its new form, and who also has the will to do this. By putting both together, you can see who to keep and promote as change agents - champions in consultant-speak - and who will be excess to requirements. Meanwhile the old, largely redundant, part of the justice business - the prison complex - still lumbers on, vacuuming up resources and hindered from following best practice in a lean and efficient way by outdated sentencing practices that overload the system. You know the sort of thing: too much throughput lowers the quality of the final product, and demoralises the staff. Of course firms call in outside consultants for a few obvious reasons: often they are in deep trouble and need to change dramatically, but don't know how to achieve it or how to tell their workforce. This government knows the answer. They just need to trust it, and get the credit for it. Yours, Roger. cc Tony Blair, Jack Straw  Roger Graef is a criminologist and filmaker comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: G7 will link debt relief to peace

fields.headline: G7 will link debt relief to peace
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has won the backing of other major western countries for his plan to reward poor countries which abandon wars and other conflicts with speedier debt relief.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny  and Jonathan Watts  in Fukuoka
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has won the backing of other major western countries for his plan to reward poor countries which abandon wars and other conflicts with speedier debt relief.

Finance ministers from the Group of Seven leading industrialised nations have endorsed Britain's proposal that debt relief should be "swift and effective" for post-conflict countries. Their recommendation, in a confidential document seen by the Guardian, is certain to be rubber-stamped when G7 leaders meet in Okinawa in two weeks.

Debt campaigners welcomed the commitment to fast-track post-conflict countries through the international debt relief process which has been criticised for being far too slow in delivering results.

"Conflict is one of the greatest causes of poverty and suffering in the world and it is tragic that conflict stalks many of the poorest countries," said Ian Bray from Oxfam. "While this offer will not lead to an immediate laying down of arms it will be one more incentive for peace." However the present debt deal was still too little, too late. "The important issue is urgently ridding the debt burden of poor countries already at peace."

Progress towards the G7's initial target of getting 25 countries through the international debt relief programme by the end of the year has been painfully slow. By the time G7 leaders meet in Okinawa only nine countries will be receiving interim debt relief. Only two - Uganda and Bolivia - are expected to receive debt cancellation by the end of the year.

Mr Brown and Clare Short, the secretary of state for international development, are worried that conflict has become a major barrier towards efforts to reduce third world debts. Of the 11 countries scheduled to receive relief by the end of the year, four are engaged in internal or external wars and one has had a coup d'état.

As part of the drive to tackle the conflicts which scar the world's poorest and most indebted continent, finance ministers have also agreed to a review of their countries' policies of subsidising arms exports to poor countries. The G7 will ask the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development to examine the activities of western export credit guarantee departments which underwrite exports to politically risky countries and will call for a ban on insuring arms exports.

"It is vital for donors to reaffirm their commitment to discourage unproductive expenditure," the ministers' statement to G7 leaders said. Britain announced a ban on the use of export credits for arms sales to 63 of the world's poorest countries in January.

The ministers agreed that prospects for the world economy were the brightest for some time. Laurent Fabius, the French finance minister, said: "The only worry I voiced was about the high price of oil, which could undermine all our good work."

fields.headline: Home truths
fields.standfirst: The Queen Mother has been considered untouchable by TV executives. Until now.  Mark Lawson applauds a robust profile by Channel 4 - and detects a refreshing change in journalistic coverage of the royals
fields.trailText: here's a splendid moment in The Real Queen Mother when journalist Graham Turner offers an insight into the political views of the imminent centenarian. fields.body:
There's a splendid moment in The Real Queen Mother when journalist Graham Turner offers an insight into the political views of the imminent centenarian. The trick, apparently, is to watch her drinking port: "She'll raise her glass if she's speaking of a politician of whom she approves but lower it when speaking about one of whom she disapproves." Analyse this anecdote and it begins to haunt you. For the code to be clearly understood, the Queen Mother would need to (a) only discuss politics while drinking port, or (b) drink port most of the time. But if it's the latter, then her parliamentary insight would inevitably be limited to a few slurred starts at remembering the prime minister's name.

Also, to avoid misunderstanding, her glass of port would need to be held steadily at about chest level throughout the meal. And there must be a risk that, beginning a refreshing sip just as a diner mentions William Hague, she misleads the gathering about her political affiliation. In such circumstances, does she then clarify "that was thirst, darlings, not Conservatism"? But this revelation about the politics of snifters perfectly illustrates the difficulties of the royal documentary. Because those who really know the royals don't talk, such films are forced to give absurd weight to anecdotes gathered from hangers-on and downstairs gossip.

Even so, The Real Queen Mother is to be welcomed for its relative irreverence. Most genres of television differ according to the broadcaster - ITV sitcoms are often written and even lit differently from BBC ones; an ITN news running order may reverse the emphasis given to stories by the BBC - but, until the 1990s, all royal broadcasting was the same: a televisual bending of the knee.

This particularly applied to the Queen Mother, who was viewed even by the tougher executives as untouchable. There are still disturbing rumours from the BBC that, when the Queen Mum has no more birthdays left to come, comedy and entertainment shows will be removed from the schedules until the state funeral, thereby giving record ratings to the channels run by the republican Rupert Murdoch.

When at the BBC, Michael Jackson, now chief executive of Channel 4, was bravest in questioning this Ruritanian belief that obsequies need to be obsequious. And The Real Queen Mother is by some way the toughest programme ever made about this touchy subject. If I were to resort to the glass-of-port method of television reviewing, I would have raised my arm several times during the documentary.

Because the third-hand reminiscences are so flimsy, David Batty's film is most impressive in the sequences of free comment. Whereas the average Queen Mum doc has merely simpered about the ceaseless millinery of her widowed years, this one makes the clever point that the hat became a pseudo-crown, a surrogate for the regal head-gear she had had to concede to her daughter. It also shows how Hartnell's outfits and Beaton's photos (retouched to make her look slimmer) remade her image. This proto-Diana even once claimed for herself the title Queen Of Hearts.

You can tell how far we are from the conventional monarcho-doc because when a single contributor strikes the old Alistair Burnet tone - a royal chaplain describes her at prayer as "beatific she has one foot in heaven" - it seems gigglingly anachronistic. There's rather too much insistence on the Queen Mum as a ruthless driving force - you sometimes think you're hearing about a matriarch in The Sopranos - but this is a rare example of a British film about the royals which is reflective rather than genuflecting.

Even the BBC, traditionally cringing in these matters, has recently risked throwing a few stones at the glass coach, sensibly refusing to transmit a charity pageant for the Queen Mum's birthday which even the Queen was not attending.

And now we have Counterblast: Dear William, in which another 18-year-old, Barry Hale from a Liverpool comprehensive, harangues the second heir to the throne for being out of touch with modern Britain. And so the funding available to Prince William's Eton is contrasted with the cash crisis at Barry's alma mater. The problem is that it's never made clear why similarity with Barry should be the qualification for the monarchy's survival. None of the cabinet or shadow cabinet have lifestyles resembling Barry's - nor has any executive at the BBC - but this doesn't make the case for the ending of democracy and the closure of broadcasting. And in giving vast symbolic weight to an individual, aren't the Barryists in broadcasting duplicating what they see as the illogic of monarchy? Sadly, in finding a backbone as regards the monarchy, the BBC seems to have lost some of the messages to the brain.

Anyone nostalgic for the old hagiographic approach has A Service Of Celebration And Thanksgiving, in which Sue Lawley and Jennie Bond preside over the C of E's birthday gift to the Queen Mum, and during which I fear my glass of port may be permanently close to the floor.

 The Real Queen Mother, tonight, 9pm, C4 Counterblast: Dear William, tonight, 7.30pm, BBC2 A Service Of Celebration And Thanksgiving, tomorrow, 11am, BBC1

webTitle: Rain and more rain wash out summer

fields.headline: Rain and more rain wash out summer
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Torrential rain and icy winds cut a swath across Britain yesterday leaving thousands of sports and music fans damp, cold and shivering.
fields.body:
Torrential rain and icy winds cut a swath across Britain yesterday leaving thousands of sports and music fans damp, cold and shivering.

While parts of the Mediterranean and Eastern Europe basked in sunshine and temperatures soared above 38C (100F), the English summer looked washed out.

Persistent downpours and arctic winds delayed the start of play in the Wimbledon men's tennis final for more than an hour.

The action on Centre Court was punctuated with rain throughout the afternoon as Pete Sampras and Pat Rafter battled it out.

Meanwhile 100,000 revellers at the Party in the Park music concert in Hyde Park, London, were drenched as rain fell almost incessantly.

Travis opened the festivities with the band's single Why Does it Always Rain on Me? - only to be answered by rainfall 20 minutes later.

Forecasters warned of worse to come as freezing winds affected much of the country and temperatures fell to 13C (56F) as rain and cloud swept in.

There is hope of respite later in the week. Average temperatures in south and east England should settle at around 22C (72F), 20C (69F) across the rest of the country and slightly cooler at 15C (59F) in north west Scotland.

But yesterday's temperatures were much lower, with the southern and eastern parts of England at 15C (59F), falling as low as 10C (50F) further north.

As Britain shivered, temperatures in the Bulgarian capital Sofia, hit 40C (104F), the highest since records began 112 years ago, while in Bucharest, temperatures reached 42C (108F).

webTitle: Israeli coalition collapses on eve of peace summit

fields.headline: Israeli coalition collapses on eve of peace summit
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's ruling coalition fell apart at sickening speed yesterday, weakening the prime minister, Ehud Barak, as he sets off for a high-stake peace summit with the Palestinians.
fields.body:
Israel's ruling coalition fell apart at sickening speed yesterday, weakening the prime minister, Ehud Barak, as he sets off for a high-stake peace summit with the Palestinians.

After months spent pandering to rightwing and religious members of his fractious coalition, Mr Barak's government collapsed within hours when three parties announced their escape, robbing him of his parliamentary majority on the eve of his departure to tomorrow's Camp David summit with Yasser Arafat.

And in a further humiliation, Mr Barak was abandoned by his foreign minister, David Levy, who is boycotting the summit because he believes it is destined to fail.

Despite the disaster unfolding around him, Mr Barak tried to brazen it out yesterday, declaring he would march on to the summit, and that he still enjoyed a popular mandate to make peace. "None of these rejectionists will teach me how to defend Israel and its future," he said in a televised address. "No one will teach me what security is. I must distance myself from all the political controversies and party considerations to find the way to peace that will end the conflict of blood between ourselves and our neighbours."

But it was clear that he has been seriously bled by the defections, and can no longer take the bold steps needed to produce an agreement that will be palatable with the Palestinians.

In his address, he pledged to "sign only an agreement that will ensure security for the people of Israel and maintain the red lines of the governments of Israel which are known to all".

For Israelis, the implication is clear: Mr Barak is determined to hang on to a sizeable portion of the West Bank - regarded by hawkish Israelis as a biblical birthright and a vital security buffer - despite accusations from the departing rightwing and religious members of his coalition that he is contemplating surrender.

The message is equally clear for Mr Arafat: Mr Barak is too weak to deliver the minimum the Palestinians have demanded: return of all lands occupied by Israel since 1967, and Arab east Jerusalem as the capital of an independent state.

That increases the chances that this summit, billed as a make-or-break affair by the Palestinians, Israelis and Americans alike, will fail. If that happens, there are widespread predictions of bloodshed.

"The alternative is so horrible that a failure of Camp David is inconceivable," Efraim Sneh, Israel's deputy defence minister, told CNN.

The potential for violence was underscored yesterday when Israeli soldiers opened fire on a Palestinian car in Gaza, killing a woman and wounding five people.

Mr Levy's walkout, partly the result of pique that Mr Barak has not kept him informed of secret negotiations, comes after the Shas party, which merges ethnic pride with ultra-orthodox theology, bolted from the coalition, also accusing Mr Barak of unilaterally deciding to make dangerous concessions to the Palestinians.

The firestorm in the Israeli right, with settlers' groups announcing a series of mass rallies, has been fuelled by press reports that Mr Barak is ready to hand over 90% of the West Bank to the Palestinians, evacuating 50,000 Jewish settlers, and to grant Mr Arafat a toehold in Arab east Jerusalem. He is also reportedly considering the return of the Jordan valley, and a formula to allow thousands of Palestinian refugees to return to Israel proper.

Shas had demanded that the prime minister outline the limits of his willingness to compromise. "The process is very important to us and we expect to be genuine partners on the way," said Eli Yishai, Shas leader. "But we don't know the way."

The resignations do not take effect for 48 hours, leaving time for the haggling that has become a feature of Israeli politics. But with Mr Barak preoccupied at Camp David, his options appeared to be narrowing, and the defections could leave him with only 42 loyalists in the 120-seat Knesset.

fields.headline: Mbeki insists poverty causes Aids
fields.trailText: An unrepentant Thabo Mbeki, president of South Africa, yesterday refused to bow to pressure from international scientists and used his speech at the opening of the international Aids conference in Durban, South Africa, to blame the Aids epidemic devastating the continent on poverty rather than the HIV virus.
fields.body:
An unrepentant Thabo Mbeki, president of South Africa, yesterday refused to bow to pressure from international scientists and used his speech at the opening of the international Aids conference in Durban, South Africa, to blame the Aids epidemic devastating the continent on poverty rather than the HIV virus.

The speech was a blow to the scientific establishment which hoped the president would use his authority to change attitudes towards a disease that killed 2m in 1998 alone.

They hoped for unambiguous backing for stronger measures to prevent HIV infection, including drugs to prevent mothers passing the virus to their babies.

But it was clear yesterday that the president was angered by attempts to steamroller him. Last week, more than 5,000 scientists signed the Durban Declaration - a proclamation to the world of their conviction that HIV causes Aids.

Yesterday Mr Mbeki delivered a firm rebuke. "As an African, speaking at a conference such as this, convened to discuss a grave human problem such as the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, I believe that we should speak to one another honestly and frankly, with sufficient tolerance to respect everybody's point of view, with sufficient tolerance to allow all voices to be heard."

The speech will leave many of those who are fighting Aids tearing their hair at what they will see as a missed opportunity to raise awareness of the dangers of HIV in Africa where two thirds of today's 15- to 29-year-olds will die of Aids if treatment does not become available.

fields.headline: Lurking fears behind estate walls
fields.standfirst:
The resident
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Just before midday yesterday Josephine Corrigan made her way down the hill for mass at St John's Catholic church. She follows the same routine every Sunday, and as usual after the service she returned home to her small terraced house on the Garvaghy Road to cook lunch for her elderly brother.
fields.body:
Just before midday yesterday Josephine Corrigan made her way down the hill for mass at St John's Catholic church. She follows the same routine every Sunday, and as usual after the service she returned home to her small terraced house on the Garvaghy Road to cook lunch for her elderly brother.

But this Sunday the scene outside the chapel was very different to the other 51 Sundays of the year. A line of concrete blocks strung with razor wire separated the chapel from the road, while the arriving congregation was greeted by the sound of an accordian band and massed ranks of Orangemen tramping past.

But Mrs Corrigan tries not to let it bother her. "Whatever happens and whatever is going on, I still have the house to run," she said, pointing at a pile of washing.

She has lived on the Garvaghy Road for 23 years, and every July for the last six she and her elderly brother have been under the shadow of the standoff at Drumcree.

Despite her attempts to continue with her normal routine, the strain of living in a community that feels under siege has begun to take its toll. "I'm tired of it," she said with a weary sigh.

"You can feel the tension in the air. Every year you are hyped up wondering what is going on," she said, nodding her head in the direction of the church at Drumcree.

"I'm not scared, mind, I'm too old for that; it annoys me more than it frightens me."

But for her brother, Robert, who was sitting in the front garden watching the world go by, it is a different matter. "He is afraid. He's 68 and he gets nervous about what is going to happen," she said, referring to the events of three years ago when the residents of the nationalist estates that line the Garvaghy Road were woken by a siren in the middle of the night as the security forces moved in to push the parade down.

fields.headline: Barak on brink of disaster
fields.standfirst:
Israeli prime minister heads for US talks as his coalition founders
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, is fond of insisting that he is no politician, and that was never more apparent than yesterday when, as his government fell apart around him, he prepared to depart for Camp David.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, is fond of insisting that he is no politician, and that was never more apparent than yesterday when, as his government fell apart around him, he prepared to depart for Camp David.

With three parties having announced they are to exit his coalition, Israeli commentators say Mr Barak is heading for disaster, no matter what the outcome of talks that begin tomorrow.

The analysts may disagree on whether his predicament is due to political inexperience, his uncompromising and secretive style of governance, or the political system. But they concur on a few things: Israel is heading towards early elections, and may also be heading for a violent confrontation with the Palestinians.

If the summit produces a deal, Mr Barak may gamble on elections, combined with a referendum on the peace agreement, calculating that voters will once again reward him with a generous mandate.

If the talks fail, Mr Barak may be forced into a national unity government with the rightwing Likud party. While that may buy peace at home, he may then face a violent conflict with the Palestinians.

Within the territories ruled by the Palestinian Authority, frustration is spreading. On Friday, a Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erakat, told Israeli television he was exhausted by seven years of talks, and called Israel a society of "fascists and racists". He went on: "I am sick and tired of you in your uniforms. I am sick and tired of Israelis with their guns."

The fear is that that sentiment would translate into large-scale violence if a Palestinian state were declared later this year, and Israel responded, as Mr Barak has threatened, by annexing large chunks of the West Bank.

The scale of Mr Barak's crisis must be seen against the enormous expectations that accompanied his rise to power. One year on, and the sense of impending doom is so strong that Israelis are becoming nostalgic about their disgraced former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu. Written off following last year's election defeat and his investigation on charges of squirrelling away state gifts, Mr Netanyahu is now moving ahead of Mr Barak in opinion polls. With officials admitting that the case against him may collapse because of thin evidence, he is poised for a political return.

As during previous crises, Mr Barak never lets on that he is troubled by the prospect of political meltdown - and that may be part of the problem. During the past year, he has plodded on, neglecting his coalition partners, the economy, and deepening social divisions to pursue peace.

His singlemindedness served him well when he pulled Israeli forces out of south Lebanon in May. But his failure to build consensus among his coalition partners has proved fatal - to the viability of his government, and perhaps to the peace process.

For 11 months he ignored the wrangling between his second largest coalition partner, Shas, which fuses ethnic pride with ultra-orthodox theology, and the secular Meretz party. Then, with Shas poised to walk out and torpedo his parliamentary majority, he made such desperate attempts at appease ment that he sacrificed his credibility, and his natural allies in the peace camp.

And in the end, it was to no avail. Only days after returning to the stable, Shas threatened to leave the coalition again yesterday, because Mr Barak would not give them veto power over his ground positions in the summit.

As before, Mr Barak went into last-minute overdrive, pleading for the survival of his government. Shas notables were unmoved by the display.

fields.headline: Industrialists reject Austrian slave fund
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austria's efforts to right past wrongs by establishing a fund to compensate former Nazi slave labourers have suffered a blow after a leading industrialist reportedly attacked the demands for money with an anti-semitic statement.
fields.body:
Austria's efforts to right past wrongs by establishing a fund to compensate former Nazi slave labourers have suffered a blow after a leading industrialist reportedly attacked the demands for money with an anti-semitic statement.

All four parliamentary parties voted on Friday in favour of a 6bn Schilling (about £275m) fund to be shared among the 150,000 Jewish and other slave labourers still alive. The government has pledged to provide at least half of the money and industry is expected to come up with the rest.

But business people close to Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel's Austrian People's party have criticised the fund. In today's issue of the news magazine Profil, a leading industrialist said the demands were an "absolute injustice".

"Hitler killed 20 million people, Stalin 100 million. But nobody demands anything from Russia. Not only that but those who did the real forced labour are no longer alive," said Johannes Asamer, a gravel producer from the province of Upper Austria. He added: "The Jews are exerting so much pressure, that soon they'll get it in the neck again.

"The six billion will have to be paid, because America puts pressure on us. That's pure blackmail."

He said he would refuse to pay. Another well-known industrialist and aristocrat, Carl Anton Goess-Sarau, chair of the supervisory board of a carton-producing conglomerate, Mary Meinhof, is also quoted as saying he would not contribute to what he called an unfair supplementary business tax.

"I was a prisoner of war in Russia myself, but I would never have considered the idea of demanding something from the Russians," he said. "The fact is there was a war going on then and because of that you can't make demands today."

Their views will do little to improve Austria's image, coming after the EU imposed sanctions and announced a team to monitor the country after the far right Freedom Party of Jörg Haider joined the government.

The government has ordered a referendum in the autumn on the sanctions. Members of the FPO have now said they also want a referendum on the compensation fund. Andrea Mölzer, the FPO's cultural adviser, told Profil: "Morally we're certainly not obliged to pay anything, but in the real world of politics that argument won't wash and we'll simply have to pay up."

In February Mr Schüssel asked Maria Schaumayer, former president of the Austrian national bank, to form a compensation plan. The move was interpreted as an attempt to limit concerns that Austria had lurched to the right with the entry into government a few days previously of the FPO.

Unlike Germany, which has paid the equivalent of about £36bn to the Nazis' victims since 1951, Austria avoided paying for decades, claiming it was a victim of Nazism rather than a willing collaborator.

fields.headline: Keeping step with forefathers
fields.standfirst:
The marcher
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Yesterday morning Reggie Tedford got up, washed and shaved, put on his best suit, bowler hat, Orange sash and white gloves, picked up his black umbrella and made his way down to the Orange hall on Carleton street in the centre of Portadown in good time for the start of the parade to the Church of Ascension on Drumcree hill.
fields.body:
Yesterday morning Reggie Tedford got up, washed and shaved, put on his best suit, bowler hat, Orange sash and white gloves, picked up his black umbrella and made his way down to the Orange hall on Carleton street in the centre of Portadown in good time for the start of the parade to the Church of Ascension on Drumcree hill.

Mr Tedford, 74, has been going through the same routine on the Sunday before July 12 for the past 50 years, and for 47 of those he has walked home from church along the same route his forebears in the Orange Order have been taking for more than two centuries. But since 1998 the members of Portadown LOL No 1, of which Mr Tedford is a member, have been stopped in their tracks by a steel and barbed wire barricade blocking their way back to the Orange hall for their traditional lunch of beer and sandwiches.

Being stopped from making a 10-minute walk might seem inconsequential to many people, but not Mr Tedford; he believes it threatens the very existence of his religion. "This is our tradition, our Protestant heritage. It has been handed down from father to son and we can't give it up now," he said.

For Mr Tedford the barricades have only added insult to injury. "I think it's ridiculous. They never put up anything like this in 30 years of the Troubles and all for a 10-minute walk. It is the Queen's highway and nobody has the right to block the road. There is no provocation; it is a religious service that we are going home from.

"When I first paraded back from Drumcree it was all green fields, there were hardly any of the houses that you see there now. It used to be friendly affair. The Catholics didn't care. They used to watch it coming up to the Garvaghy road and come out and see it. The older ones would shout out at you: 'You're looking well this morning' and the like. There was no animosity or anything like that."

Mr Tedford, who worked in the bacon factory in Portadown before he retired, is in no doubt about who is to blame for what has happened at Drumcree over the past six years.

"Sinn Fein/IRA have come in and turned the place into a ghetto," he said. "These younger ones have seen it on TV, they have seen Sinn Fein/IRA orchestrating it and they've got behind it."

During the early years of the standoff he would sleep in his car in the field in front of the pretty little parish church. He does not stay overnight anymore, the protest has gone on for too long. But he was at Drumcree every day last week and he will be back again every day this week. He promises to keep going back until he is allowed to walk home from church along the route his forefathers took: "This is the future of the Protestant faith right here. We can't walk away from it."

fields.headline: Fears grow as bombers return
fields.standfirst:
Loyalists defiant after RUC warns of tit-for-tat violence
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: In the early hours of yesterday came the explosive development that security forces in Northern Ireland had been fearing.
fields.body:
In the early hours of yesterday came the explosive development that security forces in Northern Ireland had been fearing.

The Real IRA, supposedly on ceasefire, ratcheted up the crisis surrounding the Orange Order's banned march in Portadown, its 300lb car bomb devastating the mixed village of Stewartstown, Co Tyrone, and reverberating on Drumcree Hill, 15 miles away.

Loyalist law-breaking last week had been terrible enough, said the RUC assistant chief constable Tom Craig, standing next to the engine block of the red Rover, 100 yards from the seat of the blast, outside the RUC barracks. But the intervention of dissident republicans was to spray petrol on an already blazing dispute, and police sources feared it threatened a new tit-fot-tat dimension to the fearsome violence. He looked a worried man.

The car bomb, the first to explode since the Omagh tragedy claimed 29 lives in the single worst atrocity of the Troubles almost two years ago, was on the route of an Orange march due to take place yesterday. It left Tracey McAliskey, 32, a Catholic mother of two, angry. She thought that all this nonsense was over.

Ms McAliskey, surveying smashed windows and a ruined roof, said: "Children had been playing as the driver, wearing an industrial mask, dumped the car, its lights on and driver's door open, just before midnight. The police had problems clearing the place. We thought it was a hoax, and no one would get off the streets or our of their beds."

The Orangemen in Stewartstown went ahead with their parade yesterday, willingly re-routed away from the devastation that ripped through nationalist estates. It was, as ever, a peaceful occasion, as were all but nine of 3,300 Orange marches during last year's marching season.

Patricia Robinson, 25, also a Catholic mother of two, said: "A young Protestant lad, Gareth Faulkner, was killed in a car crash recently. His funeral was last Sunday, and the whole town turned out to show their respects. There have never been religious differences here."

Drumcree might as well have been a million miles away, rather than a short hop down the M1. In Stewartstown there was universal regret yesterday, but both sides of the community were pulling together. At Portadown, they would have been at each other's throats yesterday, if the RUC had given them the remotest opportunity.

Close to 2,000 Orangemen and 1,000 supporters braved driving rain to take part in the parade. The weather was enough to persuade all but a couple of hundred to go home after the march from Portadown town centre, past the Garvaghy Road, to Drumcree Hill where a church service and speeches took place.

The Portadown Orange Order's annual service is to commemorate 300 of its members fallen on the first day of the Battle of the Somme in July 1916, most from a single machine gun. It is also to celebrate King William of Orange's victory over the Catholic forces of James II at the Battle of the Boyne in 1690 and they first marched down what is now the Garvaghy Road in 1807.

Drumcree Six, the latest episode in a saga dating back to 1995, was different from its predecessors. The Portadown district, in calling another march last week, achieved its aim of stretching the RUC and army in province-wide protests. Trouble had previously only followed the parade, rerouted away from the Garvaghy Road yesterday for the third successive year.

The Orangemen called for four hours of protests today. They said they wanted them to be peaceful, but the RUC is in little doubt that its officers will again be facing petrol bombs and burning barricades as disaffected loyalists, as much using Drumcree as a vent for hooliganism as to support the civil liberties of Portadown Orangemen, lay waste to their own deprived areas.

Yesterday they marched from Carleton Orange Hall past the loyalist Corcrain estate, where Ulster Freedom Fighter Johnny Adair had applauded masked Loyalist Volunteer Force gunman firing a volley of shots last week. A sign there read: "It is better to die on your feet than live on your knees."

But there was humiliation for the Orangemen after the Rev John Pickering's hour-long service at the once picturesque Church of Ascension.

For the first time in the 104 weeks since the 1998 ban, no RUC officer came forward at the steel barricade to accept the Orangemen's letter of complaint. It was because of shame, suggested Nigel Dawson, district secretary.

The main attraction at the barrier was Harold Gracey, blamed for fostering last week's violence with his demands for loyalists to take to the streets. He said he felt like a pop star, and, although he was singing the same old tune again yesterday, his 4,000-strong audience roared its approval.

He denied that he was to blame for last week's violence, which left 37 police officers injured, and tourism and inward investment wrecked. Others were at fault, he claimed, and he listed the BBC, the Northern Ireland Office, the SDLP member Brid Rodgers, her leader, John Hume, and even the ecumenicals in the Church of Ireland.

Mr Gracey said: "I asked last last week for people to get off their bellies. I think they are back on their knees now, and very soon, they will be back on their feet."

He refused to condemn violence, again pointing out that the Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, never did. But he did ask protesters to respect the Sabbath, if only for the rector's sake.

But a stark indication of how far Orangemen feel the balance in Northern Ireland has swung against them came from Robert Shaw, 40, who railed against the RUC.

Mr Shaw said: "They are a republican force. They are the military wing of Sinn Fein. After 30 years, they have deserted us. I don't agree with violence, but violence put the RUC in power."

The main attraction at the barrier was Harold Gracey, blamed for fostering last week's violence with his demands for loyalists to take to the streets. He said he felt like a pop star, and, although he was singing the same old tune again yesterday, his 4,000-strong audience roared its approval. He denied that he was to blame for last week's violence, which left 37 police officers injured, and tourism and inward investment wrecked. Others were at fault, he claimed, and he listed the BBC, the Northern Ireland Office, the SDLP member Brid Rodgers, her leader, John Hume, and even the ecumenicals in the Church of Ireland. Mr Gracey said: "I asked last last week for people to get off their bellies. I think they are back on their knees now, and very soon, they will be back on their feet." He refused to condemn violence, again pointing out that the Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, never did. But he did ask protesters to respect the Sabbath, if only for the rector's sake. But a stark indication of how far Orangemen feel the balance in Northern Ireland has swung against them came from Robert Shaw, 40, who railed against the RUC. Mr Shaw said: "They are a republican force. They are the military wing of Sinn Fein. After 30 years, they have deserted us. I don't agree with violence, but violence put the RUC in power." www.orangenet.org Orange Order site links www.garvaghyroad.org Garvaghy Road Residents' Coalition www.paradescommission.org Parades Commission

webTitle: Anglicans take first step towards women bishops

fields.headline: Anglicans take first step towards women bishops
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Church of England last night took the next step in its tortuous 25-year-old debate over the ordination of women by agreeing to set in motion moves which could eventually - probably in another 10 years - see them being appointed as bishops.
fields.body:
The Church of England last night took the next step in its tortuous 25-year-old debate over the ordination of women by agreeing to set in motion moves which could eventually - probably in another 10 years - see them being appointed as bishops.

The General Synod meeting in York passed a motion to begin a theological study on the implications of promoting women to the Church of England's highest offices - but only after a formal vote was demanded by opponents of the move in order to gauge the strength of opinion among bishops, clergy and lay members.

The motion was designed to maximise support, and succeeded as the bishops voted 36 to 1 in favour of the study, clergy members by 154 to 39 and laity by 165 to 49. More radical moves to speed up the appointment of women bishops were thrown out.

Women were first ordained into the priesthood six years ago, but any further moves will require not only the eventual approval of the synod but also parliamentary legislation.

Afterwards the proposer, the Venerable Judith Rose, Archdeacon of Tonbridge, Kent, one of the most senior ordained women in the church, said: "The debate needs to continue and I hope this will give a positive incentive to push forward."

Mrs Rose, herself one of the first women to be ordained, will be long retired before female bishops are appointed. "Because of my age I am never going to be a potential candidate, although the colour purple suits me quite well," she said.

Even though yesterday's proposal was limited, it caused opponents of women priests to claim that promoting women further would split the church and further complicate ecumenical discussions with the Catholic Church, which does not recognise the ability of women to be priests in any form.

One opponent, the Rev Angus MacLeay of Houghton in Carlisle diocese told the Synod: "The important fact is that Jesus did not allow female oversight. The witness of the New Testament is clear."

There are fears that the 1,000 Anglican churches in England which at the moment still do not accept the authority of women priests may harden their opposition by refusing to recognise even male clergy if they are ordained by women bishops.

More than 450 clergy left the ministry following women's ordination - some of them to become Roman Catholics - a move which has so far cost the Church of England £15.6m in compensation payouts to them for the cost to their consciences.

Sister churches in the United States, New Zealand and Canada already have women bishops and the Scottish Episcopal Church is likely to appoint them soon.

The Methodists, with whom the Church of England holds periodic discussions on unity, has many women ministers and is currently considering introducing bishops.

webTitle: BBC faces up to new regulation

fields.headline: BBC faces up to new regulation
fields.standfirst:
Pressure mounts for reform of board of governors
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is preparing to accept plans to reform its board of governors, as pressure mounts on the government to abolish the body charged with protecting the interests of licence fee payers.
fields.body:
The BBC is preparing to accept plans to reform its board of governors, as pressure mounts on the government to abolish the body charged with protecting the interests of licence fee payers.

Virtually every broadcasting and consumer organisation has called for the BBC to be brought under a fully independent system of broadcasting regulation. Many feel the governors are "in the pocket" of BBC managers.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, is considering proposals for a communications bill, likely to be introduced early in the next parliament. While the BBC will fight hard against moves to sweep away the governors, reform is regarded as inevitable. Reports yesterday indicated that Mr Smith is leaning towards bringing the governors under an independent regulator, although suggestions that he favours abolition are regarded as exaggerated.

Critics of the governors say they are too quick to side with the BBC, instead of standing up for viewers and listeners. Although they are supposed to be independent of executives, they are supported by BBC administrative staff. The BBC, however, says the governors provide an important buffer against political interference and are in a position to keep a close eye on how the £2.3bn generated by the licence fee every year is spent.

Mr Smith is concerned at plans to switch current affairs and arts programmes, such as Panorama and Omnibus, from BBC1 to other channels.

Shortly after the proposals were mooted last month, Mr Smith unveiled a tough set of tests which the BBC will have to satisfy before making significant changes to its services. Although these have not been widely reported, they are among the most significant constraints ever placed on its long-term ambitions.

Mr Smith is also worried about increasing evidence of "tacky TV" - such as the recent Channel 5 nude game show featuring Keith Chegwin - and wants regulators to ensure the mainstream broadcasters do not plunge further downmarket.

In the longer term, the governors are unlikely to be abolished. It is thought likely that commercial broadcasters' demands for the BBC to be brought under an umbrella body of communications regulation will be met. But the BBC will almost certainly need a layer of regulation, based on the governors, to watch how it spends licence fee cash.

Executives are paving the way for change. Phil Harding, head of editorial policy, said at the Radio Festival in Glasgow last week that the BBC was not opposed to reform, so long as close scrutiny of its managers was maintained.

The BBC will have to argue its case hard, however, against voices such as the former controller of BBC1, Michael Jackson, now Channel 4 chief executive, who said recently that the board of governors "is not an adequate or sustainable form of independent regulation".

In its submission to the government's communications review, the BBC said it was difficult to see how a single regulatory body would not compromise its independence. But some within the BBC believe that change is inevitable, and that it should be arguing the case for a strong layer of independent regulation within the new structure.

fields.headline: No credit to the creditors
fields.standfirst:
The G8 nations' failure to deliver debt relief throws doubt on their ability to control global capitalism
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: When it fell to Japan to host the G8 annual jamboree a few years ago, Tokyo hit on a brilliant wheeze. Pour millions of yen into a purpose-built conference centre for the G8 summit on one of Okinawa's prettiest bays, and you kill two birds with one stone: you compensate the Okinawans for their Yankee occupiers and you avoid the nasty fracas that these tedious demonstrators cook up when you put the G8 leaders in a major city.
fields.body:
Know where Okinawa is? Neither did I until last week when I managed to find it, a tiny island which is nearer to Taipei or Shanghai than it is to Tokyo. My knowledge of Okinawa consists of second world war horrors, when the civilian population retreated to caves to plot suicide bombing missions against the invading US army. The legacy of this is that a fifth of the island is taken up by US bases and scandals periodically erupt (as they did last week) about servicemen preying on local women. So when it fell to Japan to host the G8 annual jamboree a few years ago, Tokyo hit on a brilliant wheeze. Pour millions of yen into a purpose-built conference centre for the G8 summit on one of Okinawa's prettiest bays, and you kill two birds with one stone: you compensate the Okinawans for their Yankee occupiers and you avoid the nasty fracas that these tedious demonstrators cook up when you put the G8 leaders in a major city.

The fact that Okinawa is in the middle of nowhere has become its prime virtue for a global political elite who are finding it increasingly difficult to deal with that voluble circus which now happily set up camp outside their get-togethers. Birmingham in 1998 and Cologne in 1999 were bad enough - cities clogged up with all those debt campaigners and every NGO in town - but things looked seriously out of hand in Seattle last November and in Washington in April. The Japanese decided not to take any risks, and they have spent more than any previous G8 government doing exactly that. When, the weekend after next, Tony Blair relaxes on the sun-lounger with old chum Bill Clinton, watching the sun set over the Pacific, chilled Japanese beer in hand, they need have no fear that demonstrators will brave the shark-infested waters to wave placards.

This is making Jubilee 2000, the debt relief campaign, very angry. They are running out of time; they close up shop in December, and already some staff are moving on to big, glamorous jobs in other NGOs. The fact that they have engineered what is regarded as the most successful global activist campaign since apartheid plays well on the CV. But their dedication was to the issue not their careers, and they are acutely aware that the campaign may have failed.

Their publication last week, Island Mentality, makes for painful reading for all Jubilee 2000's fellow travellers. First, because it details how little has been delivered: Uganda, the "star pupil" of western creditors, will not have had one dollar of debt cancelled by the end of the year; Tanzania has had its debt servicing reduced by the princely amount of 7%. And these are the lucky ones who are scheduled to receive debt relief; other countries such as Haiti and Nigeria, burdened with huge debt, are not even in the queue. Second, because a tone of panic has crept in; knowing there are only a few months left, Jubilee 2000 has made emotive (and unsubstantiated) statements such as: "by stopping the collection of debt payments now, the G8... would start making a difference - and saving lives - immediately". The frustration is understandable. If you can't achieve debt relief in the millennium year with millions of campaigners, when can you?

To say that Jubilee 2000 has failed is a bit of a volte face for this newspaper which did more than most (with the arguable exception of the Financial Times) to cover the campaign and to record its triumph in a) mobilising an army of activists contrary to all the doom-mongering of compassion fatigue; and b) getting results such as the G8's promises in Cologne a year ago and Gordon Brown and Bill Clinton's competing offers to cancel bilateral debt. But these achievements have never looked so fragile; Cafod (the Christian charity) published a survey last week reporting that more than half the population believe the debt problem has been solved.

The fear is that the momentum to resolve the issue will simply ebb away. Mr Brown is aware of these anxieties; his initiative yesterday to hold out debt relief as a carrot to entice countries at war, such as Ethiopia, to make peace is a bid for campaigners to keep faith that he will deliver. There are two critical issues: why is debt relief happening so slowly? And why does it matter so much? The first question has got buried in two conflicting views: either the creditors don't really want to give debt relief, so they pile up criteria which ensure that nobody qualifies for it. Or the villains are held to be the debtor countries themselves: they get involved in wars, or jack up the pay of their teachers and nurses and fail to balance their budgets. The truth lies somewhere between them. It also draws in wider, linked questions of the reasons for Africa's political instability, to which Clare Short sensibly proposed this weekend some "joined-up government" between the Foreign Office, the Ministry of Defence and her own department for international development.

But before Mr Blair, who often talks of globalisation, tucks into his sushi, perhaps he should consider this: debt relief is critical to ensuring that a whole swath of the world isn't permanently trapped in a cycle of poverty, interest payments and underdevelopment. This is not just leftie rhetoric, it is widely accepted. What is at stake here is whether globalisation really means the continuing enrichment of a small proportion of the world's population at the expense of the deepening poverty and instability of large tranches of the rest. Is globalisation for the few or for the many, prime minister?

But there is another answer to the question of why it matters. The debt relief campaign throws into stark relief the central contradiction of globalisation: it is to do with time. Money, information and trade are moving faster around the world than ever before, but as they are speeding up, so the political system to manage and regulate them is slowing, getting bogged down in international negotiations and the turf wars of multilateral institutions. The economic and the political are out of kilter; to use a homely metaphor, it is like bike gears crunching. And it frustrates even some politicians, wearing down the reserves of perseverance of the genuinely committed such as Gordon Brown, as the process moves at the speed of the lowest common denominator. Debt relief is developing into a major test of the global political elite and its institutions - the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank - to manage globalisation. Can they? Do they want to? The questions are about both their capacity and their political will. Disturbingly, it looks as if they put most effort into managing (through manipulation, bureaucratic inertia or indifference) the challenges to global capitalism, rather than the beast itself.

As, for example, the retreat to Okinawa where they will escape from the possibility of demos, tear gas and awkward questions, to contemplate the soothing rhythm of the Pacific's waves breaking on the shore.

 Island Mentality is available from Jubilee 2000 Coalition, 1 Rivington Street, London EC2A 3DT.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

The head of Centrica, Roy Gardner, wants to strike deals with a further two companies in North America following the acquisition last week of Canada-based Direct Energy. The Direct Energy agreement means that 820,000 gas customers in Ontario and 450,000 in six US states are now Centrica customers.

Time Computers, Britain's biggest computer seller, is to sue IBM in the high court. The company is claiming £13m compensation saying IBM supplied it with fault components.

Sunday Telegraph

The satellite television group BSkyB is understood to be in talks with the digital internet and service and set-top-box supplier OnDigital with a view to a takeover. BSkyB already owns a 32.5% stake in the business and is seeking to lift the holding to 75%. The satellite broadcaster will also inject further funds in the business to subsidise the distribution of set top boxes for digital television.

The Credit Suisse life insurance subsidiary, Winterthur Life, is to stop selling endowment mortgages following a slump in sales. The move is seen as further evidence that life insurers are no longer prepared to sell the products after allegations of mis-selling and public outrage at high charges.

Sunday Times

Peter Harrison the internet entrepreneur is to give up his remaining stake in his firm Chernikeef. Mr Harrison will net £200m from the deal. Chernikeef, which offers consultancy design and supply and maintenance, is selling to Dimension Data of South Africa, who bought 49.9% of the company last year for £100m. Mr Harrison bought Chernikeef from Crest Nicholson in 1979 for 133,000.

Former Mirror boss David Montgomery has teamed up with two other former national newspaper editors to launch an online tabloid that will be screened in pubs. Yava is already screening in a trial group of pubs owned by Punch Taverns, whose chairman, Hugo Osmond, is backing the scheme.

The Offshore Kazakhstan International Operating Company - made up of Agip, BG, BP Amoco, Exxon-Mobil, RoyalDutch/Shell, Statoil and TotalFina - is to announce a find in the Caspian Sea thought to be up to 50bn barrels.

Mail on Sunday

The inland revenue has admitted that because of problems with the software for processing self-assessment forms, the department is facing an enormous backlog, the newspaper said. The new software was scheduled to have been up and running in April. The revenue insisted this weekend that the problem had been solved but the backlog had still to be tackled.

The accountancy firm PriceWaterhouseCoopers could face heavy fines for its alleged failure to detect the activities of rogue trader Nick Leeson when it was auditor of Barings bank. A professional tribunal convened by the Institute of Chartered Accountants is scheduled to publish its findings this week after hearing the serious charges against Coopers, now part of the merged practice.

Sunday Business

Halifax's new internet and telephone bank, IF, is offering unique rewards to financial advisers of £25 for every new customer they introduce. The payments could spark a commissions war in Britain's banking industry.

IoS

The European commission will on Wednesday publish a draft directive forcing BT to open the last part of its network to competition by the end of 2000 - six months earlier than that agreed by BT and the British telecoms industry watchdog Oftel. The so-called local loop was to have been opened to competitors in July next year.

Reports out this week
Today

Interims Low & Bonar. Finals Ashtead, British Bloodstock Agency, Bulmer, Inter Link Foods, Pace Micro Technology, Rex Online. AGMs Manx & Overseas, Tardis . EGMs None scheduled.

Tuesday

Interims None scheduled. Finals Batleys, Cammell Laird Holdings, Ellis & Everard, Jurys Doyle Hotel Group, Oriental Restaurant, Osmetech. AGMs British Airways, Land Securities, Liontrust, Safeway, SSL International. EGMs Peel Holdings.

Wednesday

Interims None scheduled. Finals None scheduled.

AGMs Albany Investments, Cadcentre Group, RPC Group. EGMs Internetaction.com.

Thursday

Interims Skillsgroup. Finals Samuel Heath & Sons, Hyder, International Greetings, JWE Telecom, Stanley Leisure. AGMs Advent 2 VCT, Advent VCT, Christian Salvesen, Gartmore Shared Equity, Hiscox, Railtrack, Victoria.

EGMs Channelfly.com.

Friday

Interims None scheduled. Finals None scheduled. AGMs British Land, Express Dairies, Knutsford, Latchways, Matalan. EGMs None scheduled.

Indicators this week
Today

UK PPI (June). UK M0, Final (June). UK CBI financial services survey (Q2). Japan Bank lending (June).

Tuesday

UK BRC Retail sales monitor (June). UK EEF pay settlements report. UK CPI (June). UK MPs Primarolo, Johnson to give evidence to House of Commons Treasury Select Committee on economic and monetary union. UK BoE's King, Nickell, Allsopp to give evidence to House of Lords Treasury select committee. Euro zone Unemployment (May).

webTitle: Diageo faces tough task as Burger King loses ground

fields.headline: Diageo faces tough task as Burger King loses ground
fields.trailText: Diageo will reveal this week that US sales at its Burger King fast-food chain remain worryingly sluggish, due to a poor performance from restaurants operated by franchisees.
fields.body:
Diageo will reveal this week that US sales at its Burger King fast-food chain remain worryingly sluggish, due to a poor performance from restaurants operated by franchisees.

The news will leave the food and drinks corporation with a tough task ahead in convincing investors to sign up for a planned £2bn flotation of Burger King on the New York stock exchange.

Burger King has lost ground in a price and promotions war with its biggest rival, McDonald's, over the past couple of years. Burger King's US sales slipped significantly last summer.

In a bid to snatch back the initiative, Diageo has unveiled a new brand image and changed some key products - most notably the company claims, by improving its chips.

However, a trading update tomorrow will reveal that comparable store sales have been broadly flat for the entire year - against a rise of 0.4% at the half-year.

But there are signs of hope. Company-owned stores, where the new brand has already been introduced, have picked up. However, about three-quarters of Burger King outlets in the US are operated by franchisees, many of whom have been reluctant to make an immediate investment in changing their restaurants.

The poor performance of Burger Kings in the US has been masked by rapid expansion overseas. The chain has performed better in Europe and Asia than in its homeland.

Diageo is under pressure to reduce its exposure to the food industry, in order to concentrate on its global beer and spirits brands, which include Guinness, Smirnoff, Gordon's and Johnnie Walker.

The company is widely expected to seek a buyer for its Pillsbury food manufacturing business in the United States, which includes Häagen-Dazs ice cream and Green Giant sweetcorn.

Pillsbury is worth about £6bn and Diageo admits that its board is "exploring options" for the business. However, the company insists no decision on a sale has yet been taken - the board is keeping open the option of strengthening Pillsbury through acquisitions.

The US food industry is consolidating rapidly. Unilever's £13bn takeover of Bestfoods has heightened speculation of further deals. Diageo believes that Pillsbury needs greater scale in order to compete with the marketing muscle of rivals such as Unilever, Nestle and Philip Morris.

fields.headline: Eads slashes float price
fields.trailText: Europe's largest defence and aerospace company, Eads, was forced to slash its flotation price yesterday after institutional investors raised fears that it would suffer from internal divisions and struggle to grow in the face of stiff competition from the US.
fields.body:
Europe's largest defence and aerospace company, Eads, was forced to slash its flotation price yesterday after institutional investors raised fears that it would suffer from internal divisions and struggle to grow in the face of stiff competition from the US.

Trading in European Aeronautics, Defence and Space company, formed by the merger of Germany's DaimlerChrysler Aerospace, France's Aerospatiale Matra and Spain's Casa will start in Frankfurt, Paris and Madrid today at 19 euro (£11.90), well below earlier forecasts.

The company has been forced to reduce its price, despite the fact that the offer has been twice oversubscribed. It had initially hoped its 144.8m share offering would be priced at around €24 raising as much 3.5bn euro.

However, poor timing, image problems and slack institutional demand led to lower price expectations. At 19 euro, the offering would be worth only 2.75bn euro.

Eads, the third largest global aerospace and defence group in the world behind Boeing Co and Lockheed Martin, owns 80% of aircraft maker Airbus and also makes helicopters, missile systems and military aircraft. Britain's BAE Systems owns the remaining 20%.

Worries about development costs of Airbus Industrie's A3XX jumbo jet, which is to be built in three different countries, and a sense that, with many European countries slashing defence budgets, the aerospace industry was at the top of its business cycle have scared some investors away. Analysts said the investors were sceptical about whether the merged company would achieve the costs savings it promised.

Investors are also concerned that Eads has failed to override internal divisions following its decision to retain two co-chairmen and major offices in all three countries. With a sprawling, complicated or ganisation, investors fear the company will find it hard to react swiftly to competition from its two major American rivals.

The US has also threatened to investigate whether German and British government loans to the Airbus project comply with international trading rules. Sources close to the company were putting a brave face on the disappointing price yesterday. "The level of oversubscription is greater than we might have expected during the week," the source said. "A lot of the institutional demand came in on Thursday and Friday. Not a huge amount from the States, but we always thought that this might be a little bit difficult in the States."

Retail investors accounted for just over 50% of the demand, the source said.

The company had earmarked as much as 60% for the retail side, but the late spate of institutional demand cut into that amount. Executives at Eads are believed to be hopeful that a low price will help spur interest in the offering, which has been hampered by concerns about the company's prospects and an IPO market that prefers technology, media and telecommunications stocks.

fields.headline: Adopting best policy
fields.trailText: The government's proposed "national adoption register" is not going to make much difference to the number of families coming forward to adopt the vulnerable and challenging children who make up the bulk of today's potential adoptees (Ministers plan 50% increase in adoptions, July 8).
fields.body:
The government's proposed "national adoption register" is not going to make much difference to the number of families coming forward to adopt the vulnerable and challenging children who make up the bulk of today's potential adoptees (Ministers plan 50% increase in adoptions, July 8).

Think of the day-to-day life in a family whose adopted child came to them at the age of six after a dozen short-term placements, or had been sexually abused, or had not so far bonded with any adult. The adopters probably need to negotiate remedial teaching, or specialised medical or psychiatric help. Currently, most of them have to do battle for this provision.

Adopters are - usually - rational beings, and if they can be confident that reliable support systems are in place in case the relationship runs into heavy weather, then they will be much more likely to come forward.

The most effective contribution central government could now make would be to define clear entitlements to specialised medical, educational, even legal support, to define the conditions under which this will be forthcoming and to supply the resources to ensure delivery against entitlement in every part of the country.

Providing credible post-adoption support is the key to recruiting families for the actual children now in need of adoptive homes.

Prof David Chambers Chair, Adoption UK dchambers@mcmail.com

webTitle: Living without Marxism, but with the bubbly at hand

fields.headline: Living without Marxism, but with the bubbly at hand
fields.trailText: Thank you for illuminating the sad virtual world inhabited by the Last Magazine and the intellectually impoverished engines that produce it (Life after Living Marxism, July 8).
fields.body:
Thank you for illuminating the sad virtual world inhabited by the Last Magazine and the intellectually impoverished engines that produce it (Life after Living Marxism, July 8).

I can't believe that they are so out of touch. Rather than tackle the complexity of life, they have chosen to redefine it as simple and proscribe from there. The posturing of this intellectual "cream" panders to the agenda of the multinationals. It is the perfect relationship between people who think simply and corporations who benefit from simplifying the marketplace. And it smacks of the desire for power. Bankrupt intellectuals and scientists similarly pandered to large powerblocks in Germany in the 1930s and 40s.

Their denial of environmental agendas is similarly stark, and suggests they have never been near, or heard of, a pollution disaster in their lives.

These people only consider what touches them. As this is limited to a keyboard and a fluted glass of bubbly, they should stick to commenting on just that.

Simon Katz London

I would like to make clear that I agreed to speak at the Institute of Ideas on behalf of PEN, of which I am a committee member.

PEN is a strictly non- political association of writers opposing political censorship. It also campaigns for writers harassed or held in prison, wherever this occurs. PEN's involvement and my participation in the debate, Freedom and its Limits, imply no formal affiliation with the Institute of Ideas.

Timberlake Wertenbaker London

It ill behoves the Guardian to vilify one of the last bastions of free speech and thinking this country has. Statements such as "Holocaust denial is acceptable" are scurrilously distorted. In fact, LM stated back in 1997 that: "Labour's plans to ban Holocaust denial will do nothing to combat racism in society, since the discrimination which minorities face today has nothing to do with Nazis and death camps... Holocaust denial is a minor problem compared to the consequences of making it into a crime."

The Revolutionary Communist party's weekly newspaper was The Next Step; Living Marxism did not appear until the late 80s. At no time was I ever, as a supporter, expected to toe "the party line" or "donate a percentage of [my salary] to the party and its publications".

Said Khan Birmingham said_khan@hotmail.com

I think I have sussed them out. A background of fanatical adherence to communism. A current credo that boils down to worship of capitalism, violence and speed and the importance of offending as many people as possible. Dependence on witless hip media types (and the Guardian) to propagate their views. It is time the Institute of Ideas was unmasked for what it surely is - the political wing of Julie Burchill.

William Redgrave London

fields.headline: Lessons in logic over fees
fields.trailText: Contrary to your leader (July 8), the Greenaway report's logic is not "shaky" but is entirely consistent with the direction of government policy. Those universities which accept the report's recommendations to opt for market freedom would, of course, have no claim to public funds.
fields.body:
Contrary to your leader (July 8), the Greenaway report's logic is not "shaky" but is entirely consistent with the direction of government policy. Those universities which accept the report's recommendations to opt for market freedom would, of course, have no claim to public funds.

The report is no doubt a reaction to a central problem of the present education system: being funded by government and run by government through quangos and appointees. Serving the ambitions of a political party is becoming the primary purpose. Should public money be used for this?

Alternatively, the government could distance itself by restoring the progressive element in taxation, abolishing fees and restoring the grant. It could further distance itself by encouraging widespread democracy, and thus greater accountability, throughout the sector.

The fair share of the tax burden would be returned to the wealthy. Access to and the purpose of higher education would be open to all, and the need to fund it evident.

London Your leader exposes the Greenaway report's strange logic that full cost university education need not exclude poorer students. They are already being excluded by tuition fees and even more by the abolition of grants. A more questionable idea is the report's view that, while the benefits of higher education are social, cultural and economic, the costs should be borne by individual students. Although the report was commissioned by the Russell group it must be remembered Prof Greenaway works at Nottingham University whose vice-chancellor, Sir Colin Campbell, is a strong believer in the market. Perhaps Sir Colin could demonstrate the benefits of the market by cutting Nottingham University off from state support . Geraldine Thorpe Chislehurst, Kent

webTitle: Our guilt in the land of the dying

fields.headline: Our guilt in the land of the dying
fields.trailText: I am glad Maggie O'Kane has highlighted the unimaginable human and economic cost of the sub-Saharan Aids epidemic (Welcome to the land of the dying, July 8). She rightly blames African cultural practices as one factor in the spread of Aids. But economic factors are also driving the epidemic and sustaining the cultural problems she mentions.
fields.body:
I am glad Maggie O'Kane has highlighted the unimaginable human and economic cost of the sub-Saharan Aids epidemic (Welcome to the land of the dying, July 8). She rightly blames African cultural practices as one factor in the spread of Aids. But economic factors are also driving the epidemic and sustaining the cultural problems she mentions.

Is it a coincidence that at the same time as Aids appeared on the continent (20 years ago) the World Bank and IMF began to enforce its structural adjustment programmes on indebted countries? These programmes slashed health and education budgets, introduced charges for both these services, raised the price of food by abolishing subsidies and thereby increased malnutrition. Cuts in rural health clinics, reductions in health sector pay, cuts in tuberculosis and sexually transmitted disease coordination, and reductions in drug availability have all fanned the epidemic.

Increasing unemployment has meant men seek work far from home while their women sell sex to survive and feed their families. Perhaps more importantly these neo-liberal policies have weakened the function of the state and have inhibited the ability of local governments to set priorities, implement health and educational policies and direct resources appropriately.

With intensifying poverty, and loss of hope, physical and sexual abuse of women has increased. Many young girls now appreciate that in order to escape from sexual oppression and dangerous traditional customs they need education. But one-third of Zambian school-age children, the majority of whom are girls, are not enrolled in school. One of the commonest reasons for young girls becoming infected is by selling sex to older men to pay for their school fees.

Two decades of crushing debt and adjustment programmes have had a significant hand in perpetuating this tragedy. As we squeeze the economic lifeblood out of Africa, the spread of Aids on the continent says as much about our beliefs and our cultural values as it does about Africa's.

Dr Dorothy Logie Melrose, Roxburghshire

Thank God for Maggie O'Kane and the Guardian for giving Aids in Malawi and southern Africa front page status. Glaxo Wellcomes' dismal corporate ethics parallels that of Shell, RTZ, Nestlés and many other multinationals operating in Africa and the south.

When is the north going to act? Botswana's case is a singular irony. It is the worst affected by Aids (or is it that its data is more accurate and honest?) but in all other respects the most rapidly developing of the smaller African states. It is also one of the least corrupt nations globally. Unless we can learn to build concepts of social and environmental equity into market economies there is little hope for Africa's survival - or our own.

Jeremy Beare Wacton, Norfolk

Is the Durban Aids conference too polite to name and shame the Roman Catholic church? From early in the pandemic the Pope and Blessed Mother Theresa reminded their African flocks that the use of condoms is a sin.

Caroline Woodroffe London carolinewoodroffe@compuserve.com

People do not die from Aids alone but from an infection to which Aids makes them uniquely susceptible. Of these tuberculosis is the most important because it is the commonest cause of death in HIV positives and it can easily be transmitted to HIV negatives by coughing.

It is out of the question for developing countries to afford the $10 weekly for the antivirals needed to keep Aids patients alive. What is practical is the (once-off) $20 cost of drugs to cure the tuberculosis which will lead to an early death. London has experienced an 80% increase in TB cases in a decade, mainly due to migration from Africa where TB/Aids has risen nearly tenfold over the same period. Inaction is affecting (infecting) us now.

Peter Davies Secretary, TB Alert pdd3044@liverpool.ac.uk

Maggie O'Kane's article brings out the real horror of HIV and Aids - not just the diseases themselves but the abject and heart-wrenching suffering of those without money or power.

Other august newspapers run campaigns on such essential issues as the price of CDs. Now is the time to lobby for something real: ways to alleviate the poverty which is the real enemy in all natural disasters. People want to do something. In the face of the grim statistics, we feel so powerless.

Barbara Jones London

As Sarah Boseley reports (The disease 10 times as deadly as war, July 8), the popular UK perception is that HIV is no longer a problem - although recent health reports show an increase in UK cases, most dramatically in the heterosexual population. Why is the British government not increasing public awareness through advertising and other means? I know this is being addressed in schools, but what about the high risk groups, especially the 18-30-year-olds who have become very complacent concerning safe sexual practices. HIV isn't only a problem for Africa.

Ewan Watson Dundee ewanw@madasafish.com
