Glaxo Wellcomes' dismal corporate ethics parallels that of Shell, RTZ, Nestlés and many other multinationals operating in Africa and the south. When is the north going to act? Botswana's case is a singular irony. It is the worst affected by Aids (or is it that its data is more accurate and honest?) but in all other respects the most rapidly developing of the smaller African states. It is also one of the least corrupt nations globally. Unless we can learn to build concepts of social and environmental equity into market economies there is little hope for Africa's survival - or our own. Jeremy Beare Wacton, Norfolk Is the Durban Aids conference too polite to name and shame the Roman Catholic church? From early in the pandemic the Pope and Blessed Mother Theresa reminded their African flocks that the use of condoms is a sin. Caroline Woodroffe London carolinewoodroffe@compuserve.com People do not die from Aids alone but from an infection to which Aids makes them uniquely susceptible. Of these tuberculosis is the most important because it is the commonest cause of death in HIV positives and it can easily be transmitted to HIV negatives by coughing. It is out of the question for developing countries to afford the $10 weekly for the antivirals needed to keep Aids patients alive. What is practical is the (once-off) $20 cost of drugs to cure the tuberculosis which will lead to an early death. London has experienced an 80% increase in TB cases in a decade, mainly due to migration from Africa where TB/Aids has risen nearly tenfold over the same period. Inaction is affecting (infecting) us now. Peter Davies Secretary, TB Alert pdd3044@liverpool.ac.uk Maggie O'Kane's article brings out the real horror of HIV and Aids - not just the diseases themselves but the abject and heart-wrenching suffering of those without money or power. Other august newspapers run campaigns on such essential issues as the price of CDs. Now is the time to lobby for something real: ways to alleviate the poverty which is the real enemy in all natural disasters. People want to do something. In the face of the grim statistics, we feel so powerless. Barbara Jones London As Sarah Boseley reports (The disease 10 times as deadly as war, July 8), the popular UK perception is that HIV is no longer a problem - although recent health reports show an increase in UK cases, most dramatically in the heterosexual population. Why is the British government not increasing public awareness through advertising and other means? I know this is being addressed in schools, but what about the high risk groups, especially the 18-30-year-olds who have become very complacent concerning safe sexual practices. HIV isn't only a problem for Africa. Ewan Watson Dundee ewanw@madasafish.com

fields.headline: Coming down to earth
fields.standfirst: Gore should oppose US missile plan
fields.trailText: America's national missile defence system is a bad idea whose time has passed. That would seem to be a logical conclusion to draw after the weekend, when a "hit-to-kill" interceptor rocket fired from Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific failed to get anywhere near a dummy intercontinental ballistic missile launched 20 minutes earlier and 4,300 miles away at Vandenberg air base in California.
fields.body:
America's national missile defence system is a bad idea whose time has passed. That would seem to be a logical conclusion to draw after the weekend, when a "hit-to-kill" interceptor rocket fired from Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific failed to get anywhere near a dummy intercontinental ballistic missile launched 20 minutes earlier and 4,300 miles away at Vandenberg air base in California. According to a chastened Pentagon, the interceptor did not separate from the second-stage of its lift-off rocket. But other, independent reports said the kill vehicle also began to swerve off track as it approached its target. If true, this would seem to contradict the official spin that the cause of this spectacular flop was merely an ageing booster rocket which will, in any case, be replaced by zappier models once the proposed $60bn NMD budget kicks in.

The scale of this fiasco is indeed truly epic, even by US defence department standards. Everything was done to assure the success of this test, after the failure of a preceding trial. US controllers had advance warning of the exact time and location of the "enemy" launch and the speed and direction of the dummy warhead - information they would certainly be denied in real life. The attack missile is said to have been equipped with fewer, and less effective decoys than would be the case in an actual war situation. And, of course, there was only one ICBM to intercept. In the nightmare conditions nuclear war planners must accurately simulate if such new toys are to have any credibility at all, the US could face many hostile "incomings" fired simultaneously by a "rogue" state. Conscious of the almost universal condemnation of NMD, and aware of President Clinton's ambivalence, the generals pulled out all the stops to show that the system works. They failed: theoretically they are all dead, vapourised by their own thermo-nuclear tomfoolery.

But will this latest embarrassment kill off NMD? When this question is raised, logic and America's political-military-industrial establishment appear to part company. Even if Mr Clinton ducks a deployment decision, the men most likely to follow him - Republican George W Bush and Democrat Al Gore - are both currently in favour. Mr Bush's position is no surprise; his strategic thinking appears stuck in the Reagan era from whence hail many of his top advisers. But Mr Gore has a duty to think again, fast.

fields.headline: Tapping the profits
fields.standfirst: Yorkshire water deal raises hard questions
fields.trailText: It is becoming a fishy business, water. A plc called Kelda wants to sell its Yorkshire pipes, reservoirs and sewage treatment plants - acquired at privatisation at a knockdown price - to a shell company which is to be run by its executives on a management services contract, the terms of which Kelda will draw up.
fields.body:
It is becoming a fishy business, water. A plc called Kelda wants to sell its Yorkshire pipes, reservoirs and sewage treatment plants - acquired at privatisation at a knockdown price - to a shell company which is to be run by its executives on a management services contract, the terms of which Kelda will draw up. This shell will borrow £2bn or so to pay Kelda, which will promptly give its shareholders a handsome return on their equity. The debt and the sweetheart managers will be taken on by the residents of Leeds and so on - who will not, however, be asked to vote on their new-found status.

Don't worry, say the City commentators. Everyone benefits. None of the Kelda managers who have found it so hard to deliver drinkable water and make a profit are to lose their jobs. Kelda's stockholders enjoy a bonus. As for Yorkshire residents, they will not feel a thing. But what kind of "mutualisation" is this? A mutual must involve assent. Members should come together of their own free will in a project of common benefit. The assurance mutuals and building societies had, too often, fallen into bad ways. They squirrelled away surpluses and lost any special connection with members. The succession of votes in favour of demutualisation - until Scottish Amicable - showed how ordinary the relationship had become. But mutuality still has a role. Mutuals serve to benchmark the performance of plcs while offering lessons in corporate governance. But not in this Yorkshire plot.

If Kelda finds the water business too difficult it should ask the regulator for permission to surrender its licence and sell its assets. It is open to Kelda to switch between equity and debt finance. The company must not, however, be allowed to play fast and loose with the people who depend upon it for this basic service. Sir Ian Byatt and his successor as regulator must keep a close eye on Kelda's proposals. There is a rather unpleasant smell about them.

webTitle: We need to keep in step

fields.headline: We need to keep in step
fields.trailText: I like David Hanson's idea for a virtual reality march down the Garvaghy Road (Letters, July 8). My own suggestion to solve the Drumcree problem is for the government to lay on a fleet of coaches to take every Catholic family on the route of the march to the seaside for the day
fields.body:
I like David Hanson's idea for a virtual reality march down the Garvaghy Road (Letters, July 8). My own suggestion to solve the Drumcree problem is for the government to lay on a fleet of coaches to take every Catholic family on the route of the march to the seaside for the day, and to give them each £100 as "compensation for social disruption". The Orangemen would quickly get fed up with their actions putting money in Catholic pockets and call the whole thing off.

John D Nixon Horley, Surrey John.Nixon@nationwideisp. net

I play in a band which presides over the thin line between organised chaos and bedlam that is a barn dance, and fully concur with Simon Hoggart's account (Diary, July 8). I was therefore somewhat mystified as to why you chose to illustrate the item with a photograph of line dancing, that strange solitary pastime in which dancing with a partner, or even having contact with any one else, is frowned upon, but strange costume is mandatory.

Mike Tavener York mike@mtavener.freeserve.co.uk

It's a trifle disingenuous for Simon Hoggart to say of 10 Downing Street: "If we approached our work in the same careless, slapdash, headless-chicken manner, we'd be out on our ears". Come off it!

Chris Stephenson Hebden Bridge, West York chris@step9.freeserve.co.uk

Tories oppose detention of assumed troublemakers en route to overseas football matches (Straw dismisses loophole fear in hooligan law, July 6). Have they forgotten that, during the Thatcher era, Kent miners were physically restricted by the police from travelling (within their own country!) to join fellow workers during the Yorkshire miners' strike?

John Sheeran Cheltenham

fields.headline: 'Tabloid shift' in TV news
fields.trailText: Television news in the time of Reggie Bosanquet and Angela Rippon was far more high-minded than now, according to research commissioned by the BBC and the Independent Television Commission.
fields.body:
Television news in the time of Reggie Bosanquet and Angela Rippon was far more high-minded than now, according to research commissioned by the BBC and the Independent Television Commission.

Broadcasts today - with the exceptions of BBC's 9pm news and Channel 4 news - have shifted away from political stories and foreign affairs towards a tabloid diet dominated by consumer affairs and crime.

Westminster University researchers warned that serious news could be marginalised if the present trends continued. "There has undoubtedly been a shift towards a more tabloid domestic agenda," the researchers said.

News chiefs gave a guarded welcome to the report, but criticised the use of "tabloid" and "broadsheet" labels to classify the stories covered in the survey. Roger Mosey, the head of BBC television news, said to describe the Paddington rail disaster or the Shipman murder inquiry stories as tabloid was misleading.

The researchers stressed the terms were descriptive, not judgmental.

The survey of more than 700 evening news programmes between 1975 and 1999 showed that while the "dire warnings" of dumbing down have not been borne out, the early evening news programmes on BBC and ITV were pursuing a more tabloid agenda.

By contrast, the BBC's 9pm news and Channel 4's news programmes have maintained a broadsheet approach. In the BBC's 6pm news, tabloid content - such as crime, consumer and showbusiness stories - rose from 18% to 30%. Foreign coverage also rose, but numbers of broadsheet stories, such as politics, wars and social affairs, fell.

On ITV, the trend towards tabloid stories in the early evening news was even more marked, more than doubling from 15% in 1975 to 33% in 1999. Content in the relaunched ITV evening news was broadly the same.

Tabloid stories in the BBC's news at 9pm fell from 16% in 1975 to 13% last year. The proportion of foreign stories increased from 24% to 43%.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: A French prosecutor ordered an investigation yesterday into the possible mass murder of between 25 and 40 elderly and seriously ill patients at a private care centre 15 miles south of Paris.
fields.body:
French examine 'mass murder'

A French prosecutor ordered an investigation yesterday into the possible mass murder of between 25 and 40 elderly and seriously ill patients at a private care centre 15 miles south of Paris.

The state prosecutor for Evry, Laurent Davenas, said medical examinations will determine the causes of death of some patients at the La Martiniere clinic near Saclay. Police are said to suspect that the patients were killed with a powerful cocktail of sedatives, administered by the clinic's personnel. AP, Paris

Blasts kill seven in south Russia

Seven people died in two separate bomb blasts in southern Russia yesterday, raising fears that Chechen separatists were extending their guerrilla war beyond the rebel province.

Five people were killed and 17 wounded in a blast at the central market in Vladikavkaz, in North Ossetia, the scene of an explosion in March 1999 that killed more than 50 people. Two others were killed in a blast outside a shop in Rostov-on-Don, further north, near the Sea of Azov. Reuters Moscow

Bus crashes in China kill 80

More than 80 people were killed in China at the weekend when two buses plunged into rivers swollen by heavy rains, according to the country's state news agency.

At Liuzhou, in southern province of Guangxi, 65 died on Friday night after their bus plunged 30 metres into the Liujiang river. Seventeen others were reported killed when a bus crashed into the Yellow river in the northern province of Shanxi. Reuters, Beijing

Jolo rebels grab French TV team

Three members of French television crew were reported missing yesterday on Jolo island in the southern Philippines where Islamic rebels have been holding 20 mostly foreign hostages for 10 weeks.

A provincial police chief said the reporters, from the France 2 television network, had been working close to rebel-held areas in Mindanao province and had not returned by late evening. Reuters, Jolo

Injuries mount in Pamplona

Forty people were injured yesterday, one seriously, on the third day of Pamplona's running of the bulls, the Spanish festival in which men run alongside a stampeding herd through the town's narrow streets. Seven of the injured required hospital treatment. Reuters, Pamplona

Haitians to vote for Aristide

Haitians appeared set to grant former president Jean-Bertrand Aristide's party control of parliament yesterday in second-round elections despite a poll indicating that 43% of respondents felt there was "massive fraud" in the first round. Most voters said there was no viable alternative to Mr Aristide's rule. AP, St Marc, Haiti

fields.headline: Radical return
fields.standfirst: Tom Paine remembered in home town
fields.trailText: Tom Paine is briefly back in Lewes, the Sussex town he quit in 1774 with a head full of radical ideas that became his famous Rights of Man.
fields.body:
Tom Paine is briefly back in Lewes, the Sussex town he quit in 1774 with a head full of radical ideas that became his famous Rights of Man.

He left nothing in the town, where he lived for six years, except a pile of unpaid bills and a discarded wife. All the items in the town's Paine festival, which takes place all this month and features lectures, concerts and a special exhibition celebrating his life and work, have been borrowed. On show are first editions of the Rights of Man, Common Sense and other writings, and a portrait and a death mask of the man who became a hero of the left and a bogeyman of the right. The death mask, borrowed from the museum at Paine's birthplace, Thetford in Norfolk, is one of two made when he died on his small farm in New York state in 1809. It is all that remains of him.

There are at least three claimed genuine skulls, but a proposal for DNA testing foundered on the fact that he left no known descendants, and there is nothing else to test except one dubious lock of hair.

Paine left Lewes under a cloud of suspicion provoked by his writing - in this case a fiery pamphlet on the grievances of excise men, which he had intimate knowledge of, having worked as one for six years. The uproar over the Rights of Man forced him out of England to revolutionary France, and then to America where he is credited with at least influencing, if not partly writing, the Declaration of Independence.

The exhibition in Lewes's Barbican House Museum is the centrepiece of the festival. David Powell, who has revived the Lewes radical debating society, The Headstrong Club, where Paine was the star turn, says the revival of interest in him in the town is remarkable.

"Fifteen years ago if you'd stopped somebody in the street they'd hardly have heard of Paine," Mr Powell said. "When Tony Benn came to speak at the opening of our exhibition, we thought we might get 100. We had to close the door with 250 inside. Church and state conspired to write Paine out of English history, but they failed."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Adapted by Alistair MacLean from his second world war novel, this has Richard Burton leading a band of craggy British character actors into a night-time swoop on the Germans' impregnable mountain castle, Schloss Adler.
fields.body:
Where Eagles Dare

(Brian G Hutton, 1969)

9pm, TCM

Adapted by Alistair MacLean from his second world war novel, this has Richard Burton leading a band of craggy British character actors into a night-time swoop on the Germans' impregnable mountain castle, Schloss Adler. The plan is to rescue a British general before he reveals all, but there's a spy in their midst. There's also Clint Eastwood as their American friend, who wipes out half the Wehrmacht during the escape. Burton is great, cliff-hanging atop the cable car and acting Patrick Wymark out of the plane.

The Last Broadcast

(Stefan Avalos, Lance Weiler, 1998)

10.40pm, FilmFour

A $900 movie about people meeting gruesome ends in the woods - sound familiar? Released months before The Blair Witch Project, there was much debate about whether any copycatting had occurred. Whatever, this is a gripping and creepy tale, making the most of shaky, shifting hand-held camerawork. A film-maker (David Beard) is filming a documentary about the bloody murders of a pair of cable show hosts (played by the directors) and their soundman (Rein Clabbers) in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey, while searching for the mythic Jersey Devil. The fourth of the party was convicted of the killings - but a more horrifying truth is revealed.

Amistad

(Steven Spielberg, 1997)

2am, Sky Premier

This is the story of the slave ship Amistad, and the incident in 1839 when the slaves overpowered the crew and headed for Africa and freedom, only to end up in a US court in 1839. There are powerful performances from Anthony Hopkins as John Quincy Adams, speaking up for the rights of all men, and Djimon Hounsou as the charismatic slave leader, Cinque. But much of the passion and horror of the ship is dissipated in grinding legal debate.

fields.headline: Up to speed
fields.trailText: New technology has noticeably increased the speed of journalistic reaction. Newspaper websites mean that the publications need never wait a whole day to break a story; 24-hour news channels mean that the "news flash" interrupting mainstream programmes will become more rare. But the artier end of the craft still risks the tortoise moment.
fields.body:
New technology has noticeably increased the speed of journalistic reaction. Newspaper websites mean that the publications need never wait a whole day to break a story; 24-hour news channels mean that the "news flash" interrupting mainstream programmes will become more rare. But the artier end of the craft still risks the tortoise moment.

Glossy magazine lead-times recently left more than one title with pieces on Meg Ryan's enduring marriage even as papers reported her divorce. There's the same problem in documentary television, with the commissioning process slowing down due to the intensifying pressure on executives to deliver hits.

Certainly The E-Millionaire Show (Monday-Sunday, 8pm, Channel 4) would have seemed a more enticing prospect a few months ago. The series - in which people compete for £1m for an online project - clearly owes its inspiration to that dizzy spell when Ms Lane Fox became the most famous Martha since Mrs Washington.

At the time of the commission, the main worry must have been why people would bother to enter a television competition when the City was hurling greenbacks at any spotty kid with a computer. Now, with most venture capitalists cursing the fact that they ever saw three w's in a row, Channel 4's largesse may be the only outlet for web hopefuls.

The main interest is just how realistic the programme's panel of venture capitalists will be and whether, in the section where the public votes, the numerous small investors who have lost money in dot.com projects may take revenge by selecting a contestant they dislike.

In television terms, though, the series does offer one definite hint of the future - Jon Snow (pictured) has vacated his Channel 4 news desk for a week to host it. For decades, American TV has used its news anchors elsewhere in the schedule presenting entertainment shows.

In a week which also sees the chatshow Trevor McDonald Meets The Newsmakers (Sunday, 1.10pm, ITV), this is clearly the headline development for newsreaders.

fields.headline: Doctors despair at Mbeki
fields.standfirst: Statement fuels fears that efforts to combat HIV virus will suffer
fields.trailText: The scientific establishment was stunned yesterday by President Thabo Mbeki's public rejection of the conventional wisdom that Aids, which is the leading cause of death in Africa, is caused by the virus HIV.
fields.body:
The scientific establishment was stunned yesterday by President Thabo Mbeki's public rejection of the conventional wisdom that Aids, which is the leading cause of death in Africa, is caused by the virus HIV.

Scientists gathered in Durban for the 13th international Aids conference, held for the first time in a developing country at the heart of the pandemic, had hoped the president would drop his flirtation with the dissident ideas of Peter Duesberg, professor of biochemistry and molecular biology at Berkeley, California, and back the efforts of doctors, scientists and Aids organisations to prevent and treat infection by HIV, the human immunodeficiency virus.

The scientists who have come to present research papers at the conference want the South African president to back the war on HIV, including efforts to reduce promiscuity and to end the stigma of Aids, which makes women, especially, hide their infection from their partners. They had hoped he would embrace the new drugs that can prevent the transmission of HIV from mother to child - especially since Boehringer Ingelheim, the company which makes the most effective drug for this purpose, nevirapine - offered on Friday to give it free for five years to developing countries.

But they were sorely disappointed. Mr Mbeki berated them for stifling free speech by denying him the right to question the received wisdom, and made it clear he believes that the true cause of his country's health crisis is poverty.

The president's doubts over what the west was telling him first surfaced in his criticism of the AZT drug, used against HIV infection, which he suggested was unacceptably toxic. Then last autumn it became clear that he was influenced by the ideas of Prof Duesberg, the leading dissident in the US, whose ideas lost currency there 10 years ago when anti-retroviral drugs were developed which kept HIV levels down.

But Prof Duesberg says Africa is a different story. The epidemic is sweeping through the heterosexual community. The hospitals are full of young women and babies - not gay men. He and fellow dissidents say people are dying en masse in Africa from tuberculosis and other infections they contract because their bodies are weakened by poverty and malnutrition - but not by HIV.

The argument is attractive to Mr Mbeki, who talks of Africa needing her own solutions, not imported answers from the west. If Prof Duesberg is right, then he does not have a full-scale medical epidemic on his hands, ready to kill a third of his young people, unpick all the gains of development and bankrupt the economy. Instead, he has the normal diseases of poverty, which major investment from the west could help to solve.

The number one killer in Africa, he said yesterday, is extreme poverty. He cited a World Health Organisation report in 1995 which said poverty was the reason why children were not vaccinated, clean water, sanitation and medical treatment are not available and why mothers die in childbirth. It named countless diseases, from malaria to cholera, to guinea worm which were all blamed on poverty.

"In the end," he said, "I came to the conclusion that as Africans we are confronted by a health crisis of enormous proportions. One of the consequences of this crisis is the deeply disturbing phenomenon of the collapse of immune systems among millions of our people, such that their bodies have no natural defence against attack by many viruses and bacteria.

"As I listened and heard the whole story told about our own country, it seemed to me that we could not blame every thing on a single virus. It seemed to me also that every living African, whether in good or ill health, is prey to many enemies of health that would interact one upon the other in many ways, within one human body."

The president set up an international panel of 30 scientists to look again at the question of Aids causation, which comprised both dissidents, including Prof Duesberg, and believers. They met twice this year, but have not reached any agreement. Mr Mbeki said they have agreed to look again at the reliability of the HIV test and report back by the end of the year, prolonging the debate still further.

Mr Mbeki's determined stand destroys the hopes of the conference organisers that the meeting could put an end to the uncertainties. It also raises the temperature of the conference - a biennial event that was in the past a purely scientific talking shop has become a political cauldron.

In the months running up to Durban, the Aids establishment saw all its old certainties unpicked as South Africa's president continued to say the unsayable.

The attempt, with the Durban Declaration, published in the respected Nature magazine, to put a line under the controversy and get on with the business of saving lives, as scientists see it, seems to have gone badly wrong.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: It's one of life's cherishable moments to hear art critic Brian Sewell recall cleaning a urinal with a razor blade. It happened during his national service, when the consequences of refusal would have been far worse than the chore.
fields.body:
It's one of life's cherishable moments to hear art critic Brian Sewell recall cleaning a urinal with a razor blade. It happened during his national service, when the consequences of refusal would have been far worse than the chore. In the first of six programmes about The Peacetime Conscripts (9.0am, Radio 4), Charles Wheeler reminds us why the Attlee government retained conscription - it had continuing imperial responsibilities in Palestine, Aden, Suez, Cyprus, Hong Kong, Singapore and India. Not to mention the 100,000 troops occupying Germany.

The cataclysmic effect of the Aids epidemic in Africa is portrayed by Robin Lustig in a special 60-minute report on The Orphaned Continent (8.0pm, Radio 4). With 6,000 sufferers dying each day across the continent, the curiously obstructive attitude of South Africa (with one of the world's highest infection rates) has brought serious problems. But so have western pharmaceutical companies, pricing their life-saving drugs beyond the reach of most victims.

fields.headline: Losing the plot
fields.trailText: When the tirelessly uncritical Radio Times is reduced to pleading that Border Café (BBC1) "should be given the benefit of the doubt", there's trouble ahead. Border Café has been consigned to the shapeless category of "comedy drama", yet there was no evidence of either quality in episode one.
fields.body:
When the tirelessly uncritical Radio Times is reduced to pleading that Border Café (BBC1) "should be given the benefit of the doubt", there's trouble ahead. Border Café has been consigned to the shapeless category of "comedy drama", yet there was no evidence of either quality in episode one.

It might have helped if writer Tim Firth had incorporated some slender connection to recognisable human behaviour. Retired rock star Charlotte has bought a café in the wilds of the Lancashire/Cheshire borders for her childhood sweetheart David, so he can give up being a builder and fulfil his songwriting ambitions instead. Elizabeth Carling plays Charlotte as a caring, maternal sort of person, more like a nurse or a librarian than Mariah Carey. David hires tedious halfwit Kidder to be the chef (why has the off-the-peg moron become a prerequisite of TV comedy?), while Charlotte's neurotic fan Ronnie turns up pretending to be a journalist, then tries to commit suicide with a starting pistol.

Ronnie is obviously unhinged, so Charlotte offers her a job. Then Kidder tries to commit suicide by jumping off the roof, but is prevented by Ronnie threatening to commit suicide again with her starting pistol. You do sometimes wonder if anybody in commissioning land actually bothers to read scripts before they start filming them. The final straw is the soundtrack, comprising twee pop songs which sound like a feeble imitation of Wet Wet Wet.

It's enough to make you grateful for the return of Badger (BBC1), where Jerome Flynn reprises his role as tough and uncompromising Wildlife Liaison Officer Tom McCabe. It's called Badger because, er...

Anyway, in Badger's favour are its desirable Northumbrian scenery, tearduct-tweaking scenes of animals in peril, and stoical conviction that viewers would like a coherent plot that proceeds logically from A to Z. Although, in this case, not a particularly believable plot. It was like an attempt to remake Michael Mann's epic whistle-blower flick The Insider, without Russell Crowe, Al Pacino or 99 per cent of the budget.

Now, the evil Zelenka Corporation had been polluting the water-table and poisoning the local wildlife, then tried to deter whistle-blower Aidan Fletcher with arson and thuggery. Imagine the police's chagrin when they discovered that Crown Prosecutor Annabel Staunton was a mole on the Zelenka payroll, but then what did they expect from a toffee-nosed southerner in designer suits? Tom McCabe is so one-dimensionally righteous that you'd like to dice him up with a chainsaw, but isn't it nice to know there's at least one policeman who won't be taking bungs and running a vice ring on the side? No, you're right, it isn't.

Close Up's film about Amy Jenkins, This Life, That Girl (BBC2), said more about the workings of the media establishment than it did about its putative subject. Jenkins went dutifully through the motions of talking revealingly - but not too much - to the camera, describing her bemusement at her rocketing media profile after the huge success of This Life, and at the staggering news that Hodder & Stoughton wanted to pay her the sum of £600,000 for two novels.

But the whole exercise was rendered pointless by the fact that the film had been made to plug - sorry, coincide with - the publication of Jenkins' novel Honeymoon (already out and trampled over by critics), but had been lamely held back until the tail end of the BBC's reruns of This Life. Thus, in a sequence where Hodder's Sue Fletcher excitedly described how she "jumped up and down in front of my colleagues until they'd read it, and we all agreed that it was just extraordinary", the phrase "promotional opportunity" metaphorically flashing in neon across her forehead could hardly fail to trigger a wry smirk. A quote from the book ("women weren't in fact liberated by Germaine Greer, they were liberated by the chicken korma") offered an excellent reason for not buying a copy.

Meanwhile, the Jenkins bandwagon rolls on. This Life director Sam Miller laid on the luvvieish rent-a-quotes - "there's a compassion in her writing which is a really rare and wondrous thing" - while the auteuse herself revealed that "I've always wanted to be a film director." Oh, please .

fields.headline: Royal flush
fields.trailText: Last Wednesday, at 4am, I was woken by my mother's emergency hooter. She had an ominous pain in her chest and arm. What could it be? Pulled muscle? Heart attack? Indigestion? "Take my rings!" she cried in the usual way. "I'm fading fast!" It is difficult, when one is nearly 94, not to suspect that you are about to drop dead, especially with a nasty surprise pain in the small hours.
fields.body:
Last Wednesday, at 4am, I was woken by my mother's emergency hooter. She had an ominous pain in her chest and arm. What could it be? Pulled muscle? Heart attack? Indigestion? "Take my rings!" she cried in the usual way. "I'm fading fast!" It is difficult, when one is nearly 94, not to suspect that you are about to drop dead, especially with a nasty surprise pain in the small hours. But just as we were about to call the ambulance, the pain subsided. Good. No need to sit for several hours in A&E, only to find it was trapped wind or some other lightweight complaint.

Next morning my mother called Jenny the acupuncturist who wrenched her around rather cleverly and improved things enormously. But just as she was recovering from this complaint, another one kicked in. Then another. First a frightful cough, then another excruciating pain which seemed to be coming from her liver. "One bloody thing after another," moaned my mother. "I want someone to come and shoot me!" She was fed up to the teeth with it all.

We blame Camilla Parker-Bowles. Apparently bad temper affects your liver and every time That Woman is in the news, my mother is thrown into a steaming, festering rage. Only one other person enrages her as much and that is Prince Charles, and what with all the recent news of her beloved Princess Diana's memorial playground and Camilla's grisly pink dress, my mother almost blew a gasket. Her liver went wild, she saw spots and went right off her dinners. And all this when she has barely got over Wallis Simpson.

My mother was 94 at the weekend. Would she make her birthday party in the favourite Chinese restaurant? Yes, she did. Fortunately, the Chinese admire the elderly. My mother was showered with praise, kisses and congratulations, given a toffee-banana cake and treated like a reigning monarch. It perked her up tremendously, but who knows what will happen next? My mother insists that I learn to make her fishcakes. I may put it off no longer. Otherwise, once she is gone, this heavenly tradition will be no more. I spend two hours in the stinky hot kitchen, frying fish. What an odious task. Tonight I am giving my mother her rings back. Let's hope she hangs on to them for several more years.

fields.headline: One man and his wallet
fields.standfirst: Want to marry a millionaire?  Polly Vernon takes a course
fields.trailText: At 2.30 in the afternoon, in the lobby of a trashy hotel with a good address and vulgar postcards of London in spiny racks by reception, a mismatched collection of women gathers. They shuffle around self-consciously, reapply their lipstick, wonder where the loo is, eye each other guardedly. Some of them are beautiful, some aren't, one is 70 if she's a day.
fields.body:
At 2.30 in the afternoon, in the lobby of a trashy hotel with a good address and vulgar postcards of London in spiny racks by reception, a mismatched collection of women gathers. They shuffle around self-consciously, reapply their lipstick, wonder where the loo is, eye each other guardedly. Some of them are beautiful, some aren't, one is 70 if she's a day. But they are all palpably nervy for within moments they will meet Ginie Sayles, professional Texan, self-styled relationship fairy godmother, Best Selling Author, Popular Speaker and Consultant - even to Celebrities. And Ginie Sayles will teach them How To Marry Rich.

Sayles' press release reads: "Financial independence? Screw that. Who needs to earn their own living when you can freeload off a passing aged billionaire? He'll buy you diamonds, take you to the upmarket equivalent of Sandals Resorts and pay for your Botox injections! Fun, fun, fun!"

That's a lie, of course. It actually invites you to hear how Ginie married rich (and bonus! you get to meet the billionaire chump who married her) and get an in on her tried and tested 12-point plan. The promise of this, her first UK seminar, had the phones ringing off the hook and ladies hitching up their skirts and beating back the opposition in their eagerness to secure a place. A mere 35 made it.

There is something simultaneously appalling and yet unsurprising about the Ginie Sayles phenomenon. About the mega book sales and the sell-out seminars, the fan mail and the iconic status; 21st century spiritual and yoga literate though we are, have we ever been so materially aspiring, so covetous? So Sayles is merely flogging us another way to get us some. Or maybe there's a political agenda bubbling under the surface: is she in fact peddling a twisted form of feminism, reclaiming the idea of the gold-digger?

Back in the hotel lobby, the tension erupts. "Oh!" gasps a late thirtyish type with a rigid French pleat. "We're not going to have to role-play, are we?"

Too late. Resplendent in a red logo T-shirt, belted tightly into her beige tapered chinos, Ginie Sayle (Southern belle petite, Krystle Carrington blonde, snub nose-pretty) flings open the door. "Hello, hello, thank you so much for coming, oh, we're going to have fun, I can tell it!" Behind her, the leaden figure of Reid, her sixty- something, millionaire husband of 15 years, looms ineffectually. He is also wearing the belted-in T-shirt and chinos combo, but somehow it doesn't work so well on his large, slope-shouldered, inherently grey person.

"I would like to congratulate you all," Ginie begins, "on knowing you deserve the best. That is why you are here and why I am going to teach you it is A-OK to marry money."

Ginie's seminar manner is pure evangelical preacher. She paces, she thrusts a finger skyward, she punches her fist into her hand. Sometimes she cries, mostly she smiles the wide smile of the converted. "The value of a human being cannot be measured in money. Lifestyle, however, can. I want you to love a rich man, and win."

On the flip chart behind her, in not particularly pretty handwriting, is her legendary 12-point plan. It's a curious combination of pop psychology and practical advice on hijacking rich men. Highlights include: 3) Four Types, as in identifying rich mates (RM) who are most likely to marry out of their financial class. They are: your Novelty Seeking RM junior (Donald Trump type), your Guilty RM junior (who doesn't think he deserves his wealth but can't bring himself to hand it all to the drought- ridden, so looks for a struggling woman to rescue - a single mother, say), your Outcast RM junior (never accepted by the family, so marries to shock) and your self-made RM.

Also 4) Changes To Make. Move to an expensive postcode, even if you wind up starving in an attic. Your mind is like boiling water, the rich neighbourhood is like expensive tea. Get a professional make-over every two years. "Bipperty Bopperty Boo! See, I am your fairy godmother." Then there's 8) Sex. Make it safe, hold out till the fifth date, "don't be too exotica erotica". Plus 9) Money. "If someone says they love you, but they won't spend money on you, they're lying."

Each pointer is illustrated with extravagant anecdotes, in which all the women are Lucky Santangelo beautiful and feisty, all the men are loaded and independent legal advice is sought on prenups. The audience takes notes, nods, laughs. There is a scary consistency in the skewed logic of these ramblings. Sometimes Ginie ambles happily into the offensive ("You let an RM know an ex beat you and you are inviting your RM to do the same") but sometimes, weirdly, she makes sense: "It's not about matching like Ken and Barbie, it's about knowing your flaws are compatible."

The impossibly vain, beautiful, seventyish Maria is spellbound. "I have read all Ginie's books. I have plenty of men wanting to marry me, but none can share my lifestyle. fields.headline: Blinded by science
fields.standfirst: The Science Museum's two new galleries bring out the kid in Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: "Once or twice I have asked the company how many of them could describe the Second Law of Thermodymamics. The response was negative. Yet I was asking something which is the scientific equivalent of, 'Have you read a work of Shakespeare's?' "
fields.body:
"Once or twice I have asked the company how many of them could describe the Second Law of Thermodymamics. The response was negative. Yet I was asking something which is the scientific equivalent of, 'Have you read a work of Shakespeare's?' "

That was CP Snow, the scientist turned novelist, speaking in his famous lecture The Two Cultures, delivered in 1959. Snow's two cultures were, of course, those of science and art. Today the gap has been reduced in some measure. What, for example, would this controversialist from the age of Blue Streak missiles, Vulcan H-bombers and the pioneering jump jet (British Boy's Own-style achievements all) have made of the two inspired new galleries that opened last week at the Science Museum in London?

For in both - the Making of the Modern World and the Wellcome Wing - art and science are woven together. The Science Museum has always been a magical place, even if that magic has sometimes been as wobbly as Tommy Cooper's. This is where generations of children and their charges have come not so much to gawp at Puffing Billy (Bessamer's epoch-changing iron-to-steel converter) or early mass-production tool-making machinery by Marc Brunel, but to pull levers, press buttons, turn handles, and put their sticky fingers into anything that looks like a Van de Graaff generator.

The museum's two latest galleries, one a conversion from a penny-plain wing dating from 1961, the other a Lottery and charitable trust-fuelled phantasmagoria, follow in this populist tradition. Yet neither for a moment talks down to its audience. Both make science as enjoyable and fascinating as it wasn't in the days when anyone who wanted to do art at school was denied science, even if they loved the Science Museum. There should never have been "two cultures" in British education and intellectual capital. Yet where, outside genuinely child-friendly institutions like the Science Museum, could children enjoy the laws of thermodynamics, motion and what have you?

The latest design and architecture at the Science Museum are striking and enjoyable, if ultimately quite simple behind the theatrical lighting, dramatic colour schemes and bravura displays of the Wellcome Wing. What the museum has done over the past few years is rejig the main processional walkway from its Exhibition Road entrance through to the immense blue glass rear wall of the Wellcome Wing. Now the visitor moves past an introductory display of mighty old machines, through the revamped Space gallery, into the Making of the Modern World and then the £50m Wellcome Wing.

The new wing - designed by MacCormac Jamieson Prichard, architects of such refined and imaginative new buildings as Southwark station on the London Underground and the Ruskin Library at the University of Lancaster - is signed clearly in mesmerising blue and orange light seen from the far end of the much cooler and more stately Making of the Modern World. Children seem to make a crocodile rush into this enticing realm, while adults are just as likely to linger in a well thought-out gallery designed by the architects Wilkinson Eyre, which brings together 250 years of scientific invention in what Andrew Nahum, its creator and curator, describes as "100 steps".

Here's Puffing Billy, a model of the Forth Railway Bridge and a catalogue of marvels and wonders that leads up to a curatorial climax with a beautiful, polished-aluminium Lockheed Electra plane hanging at a jaunty angle from the high ceiling. This was the type of aircraft that featured in the last reel of Casablanca, and flew Neville Chamberlain back to Croydon airport from Berlin with his worthless piece of paper in 1938.

Here the addition of films and newsreels on small monitors would be a help. It is all too easy for children - and adults - to wander past such important monuments to modern design and technology without giving them a second glance: a bit of Bogart and Bergman, or Chamberlain announcing "peace in our time" would bring this silent precursor to modern flight to vibrant life. There are, in fact, several such small films and animations in the gallery, including remarkable colour footage of Werner Von Braun's V2 missiles being launched from their pads on the Baltic coast. And a black and white still of a street in Hornsey, London, blown apart by one of Braun's rockets, brings home the salutary, if obvious, truth that science brings tragedy as well as the promise of brave new worlds.

Beyond the Electra is the Wellcome Wing with its blue lighting and latest whizz-bang interactive technology carried off with style, wit and even grace. Essentially nothing more than a giant shoebox, the Wellcome Wing is kitted out with four can tilevered steel galleries hanging from massive concrete columns. The clarity of the building makes it a delight when it could so easily have been a madhouse, given the flow of people through its cavernous interior.

From the lobby of the Imax cinema, you can look down and across to the goings-on in the four hanging galleries. Each of these has been given a distinct theme: the impact of digital technology (Digitopolis); the question of human identity (Who Am I?); what's next (In Future); and the latest news (Antenna, which boasts a clever display on the 33m-letter human genome, rushed up in about 48 hours). The exhibition design is by Casson Mann and is both imaginative and enjoyable. Exhibition lighting throughout, by DHA, is playful and, for a museum, remarkably restful despite the sheer volume of activity contained here.

The effect is like some giant, ultra-modern film set, more Total Recall than Casablanca, but never overbearing and with more content in a few square feet than some famous £1bn exhibitions have in hundreds. There's a funny, Star Wars-like cafe on the ground floor with visitors looking filmically ghoulish courtesy of illuminated table tops. There are views up and through the various displays and no sense of claustrophobia despite the (delightfully) dim lighting.

These two new galleries deserve their instant popularity: they are a complementary pair and do much to inject new blood into this august institution. The Science Museum plans to keep changing over the coming years. Julian Powell-Tuck has been commissioned to design a new Energy gallery, while the 50-strong Wellcome team aim to keep their special contribution up to the minute.

All this is timely, given Gordon Brown's promise last week: the government is to spend £1bn on scientific research in a partnership with the Wellcome Trust, without which the Wellcome Wing would, of course, have been impossible. Science, we will no doubt soon be told, is the new rock'n'roll. Now, how does that Second Law of Thermodynamics go again?

fields.headline: Mind the gap
fields.standfirst: Is Dennis a dunce? Is Meg a dumb blonde?  William Leith investigates
fields.trailText: Last week, we found ourselves following a good Hollywood story. It contained adultery, international travel, two competing male suitors and a glossy blonde. The cast was familiar. Meg Ryan was the blonde. Gladiator star Russell Crowe, who played a questing, soul-searching cop in LA Confidential and a questing, soul-searching tobacco executive in The Insider, was the smart leading man.
fields.body:
Last week, we found ourselves following a good Hollywood story. It contained adultery, international travel, two competing male suitors and a glossy blonde. The cast was familiar. Meg Ryan was the blonde. Gladiator star Russell Crowe, who played a questing, soul-searching cop in LA Confidential and a questing, soul-searching tobacco executive in The Insider, was the smart leading man. The other suitor, an old-fashioned, conventionally masculine good ol' boy from Texas, was Dennis Quaid. We last saw him as a tough, leathery quarterback in Oliver Stone's Any Given Sunday

The story, of course, was true. Ryan, familiar to us as Billy Crystal's pert, wistful girlfriend in When Harry Met Sally and Tom Hanks' pert, wistful girlfriend in Sleepless in Seattle and You've Got Mail, is said to be leaving Quaid because he is not her intellectual superior, or even her equal. A friend of Ryan's told People Magazine that, during their relationship, he had "failed to grow", that he "plays golf and watches football" and, furthermore, Ryan "has always wanted to play Sylvia Plath", Ted Hughes' pert, wistful girlfriend.

Like Ryan's screen boyfriends, Crowe is said to be cerebral, a lover of books. Intellectually, he is on Ryan's level. Perhaps, I have heard it said, he is even her superior.

The story, of course, seems to make perfect sense - like a mainstream Hollywood film, it plays to our prejudices and endorses our deep-seated beliefs. Namely: a woman likes a man she can look up to. A woman likes a chance to play the dumb blonde once in a while. What a woman likes about a man is depth. On the other hand, what a man likes about a woman is the chance to impress her.

Why are we so eager to believe a story about a pretty blonde woman wanting a clever man to show her the way? Because the myth of the dumb blonde is rooted in our culture. Women grow up believing in the attractions of clever, powerful men; many men are secretly afraid of the posssibility of their girlfriends being brighter than they are, wielding more power and earning more. The coupling of Marilyn Monroe and Arthur Miller still seems a more natural, mutually beneficial one than its converse - say, David Beckham and Germaine Greer - could ever be.

As if it were needed, research demonstrates that men are attracted to young, childlike women. In a study by psychologist Michael Cunningham, men, asked to rate photographs of women in terms of attractiveness, chose the ones whose faces most resembled those of babies - the ones with small noses and large, widely-spaced eyes. But the dumb blonde is not somebody we feel sorry for. Far from being pitied, the dumb blonde is resented because she is powerful. She is the one who pulls the clever men.

Of course, another reason why the story of Ryan and Quaid and Crowe is so easy to believe is that we've seen it all before, in their films. We, the film-going public, did not buy into Ryan and Quaid as a couple. The three films they made together - Innerspace, DOA and Flesh and Bone - were not hits. We do not want to see Quaid, who is great at playing craggy, flawed alpha male types of average intelligence, get the pretty girl. That honour goes to questing, soul-searching types such as Tom Hanks, Billy Crystal and Russell Crowe.

We know that Dennis Quaid is not stupid; we know that watching televised sport is not a sure sign of an idiot, that intellectuals play golf, that reading books is not a key to intelligence, that Meg Ryan is anything but kooky and dumb. But we believe what we want to believe. Dumb blonde falls for clever man. It's the story we have been telling ourselves for generations; it's the story Ryan and Quaid have been telling us, in the combined efforts of their work, for a decade. Perhaps, frighteningly, they have come to believe it themselves.

fields.headline: Jack plays the blame game
fields.trailText: I know that the government's daily idea to solve the country's law and order problem is not meant to be taken too seriously, but every now and again I am moved to raise an eyebrow at the quotidian suggestion. Jack Straw's contribution the other day was to suggest that, when a defendant commits any crime while on bail, the magistrate who granted that bail should be named and shamed. I wonder, in passing, how the recruitment of new JPs will be affected when word gets round that any magistrate who makes what proves to be a wrong bail decision is likely to have his name and mugshot plastered all over the newspapers and, I dare say, on billboards and the sides of buses.
fields.body:
I know that the government's daily idea to solve the country's law and order problem is not meant to be taken too seriously, but every now and again I am moved to raise an eyebrow at the quotidian suggestion. Jack Straw's contribution the other day was to suggest that, when a defendant commits any crime while on bail, the magistrate who granted that bail should be named and shamed. I wonder, in passing, how the recruitment of new JPs will be affected when word gets round that any magistrate who makes what proves to be a wrong bail decision is likely to have his name and mugshot plastered all over the newspapers and, I dare say, on billboards and the sides of buses.

The serious point is that this surely amounts to an attempted interference with the independence of the magistracy, contrary not just to our new human rights laws but to every tenet of English justice. In effect, the home secretary is saying, "The government thinks that too many people are being freed on bail. You, the magistrates, are responsible. So if you don't start keeping more of these as yet untried - and presumed innocent - people in custody, we will make sure the nation knows who you are." I may be using exaggerated language, but I do not think I am misrepresenting the principle. It's an unpleasant, unworthy threat, which I hope will be quickly abandoned.

Yet another so-called legal drama on television; yet another chance to watch something totally divorced from legal reality. In Defence (ITV, Monday) stars the former East-Enders actor Ross Kemp as a disgraced crown prosecutor turned miscarriage-of-justice- solving lawyer. Kemp is a good actor and the dramas are watchable. But the setting and the language bear as much resemblance to real law as Frasier is an accurate portrayal of a psychiatrist. Yes, I know, sometimes you have to take liberties for dramatic reasons; but that doesn't mean you have to jettison all semblance of veracity. The TV series Kavanagh QC, for instance, was more or less accurate professionally, without sacrificing good storylines. As usual, there is a point to my moaning. Most people in England and Wales get their knowledge of lawyers and judges, and about how the legal and trial systems work, from film and television. Most of what they see is American; hence some huge misconceptions, even among some English film-makers, who import Hollywood procedures into what are supposed to be English courtrooms. But even where there aren't visible howlers, few home-grown dramas portray the ambience of legal practice with accuracy. And so the English television viewer remains alarmingly ignorant about his or her own system. The law plays a large part in everyone's life; to know so little about its workings is societally unhealthy. Mind you, a whole generation of viewers, on both sides of the Atlantic, now believes that the frightening loony Ally McBeal and her egregious colleagues are what American lawyers are like.

I 've been shown the new letter-head of the libel firm Peter Carter-Ruck and Partners, and there was something strange about it, something missing. A name, or rather, the name. As of last week, the best-known, most feared and most controversial libel lawyer of our times, not always known for the modest level of his bills, is no longer associated with the firm he founded. Carter-Ruck (the man) is now 86 and has been doing libel for nearly 60 years; but far from retiring, he's carrying on practice, on his own. Prospective clients will now have an embarrassment of choice between Carter-Ruck the firm and Carter-Ruck the chap.

You may have been puzzled, in last week's column, to see the picture of the high court judge in his Arsenal shirt, without any explanation of his surprising costumery. Why was he thus clothed? I'm afraid, though, that Sir Robin may have to wear his red shirt under his judicial robes.

fields.headline: Thick as thieves
fields.standfirst: A new book says today's criminals are somewhat intellectually challenged.  Nick Hopkins on how the average crook takes his inspiration from Crimewatch and thinks he's invincible - even when he has been caught
fields.trailText: A new book says today's criminals are somewhat intellectually challenged.  Nick Hopkins on how the average crook takes his inspiration from Crimewatch and thinks he's invincible - even when he has been caught
fields.body:
The underworld has changed a great deal since the moonlit night in 1963 when Bruce Reynolds, the most erudite of the great train robbers, lit a Montecristo No 2 cigar and waited to spring one of the most audacious and carefully planned heists in history.

Reynolds, nicknamed "Napoleon", undoubtedly earned his place in the higher echelons of the criminal premier league, and his escapades in the 50s and 60s helped enhance robbery's perversely romantic image.

It's an image that has taken a hammering over the years, and a new book, Commercial Robbery, by Martin Gill, director of the Scarman Centre at the University of Leicester, will probably consign it to history once and for all.

Today's robber is unlikely to have been inspired by Reynolds and his ilk, but may well have been encouraged by the TV show Crimewatch. Over the years, the programme has shown grainy footage of numerous successful raids, and thus convinced a generation of villains that robbery is really very easy.

Planning a "job" on a building society, bank or post office can involve, DR Gill found, no more than a few minutes' preparation, and CCTV cameras, sophisticated alarms and quick-closing screens at the counter are unlikely to act as a deterrent.

Money is obviously a key motive, but one of the 341 robbers who was interviewed for the book explained that excitement was an important factor too. "When you do coke you get a rush out of it, but when you've got a gun in your hands, people are listening to you, they're doing as they're told, you're in full control. It's just brilliant, you're just there, you are the man, you're like God."

Sixty-one per cent of the bank robbers who contributed to the book thought it was very unlikely they would be caught, and most were entirely dismissive, not to say scornful, of detectives, who were regarded as hopelessly incompetent. These beliefs seemed particularly bizarre considering every one of the robbers interviewed had been convicted and was already in jail.

Most of the offenders admitted they hadn't give a second thought to the tough prison terms judges can hand down for robbery - the maximum is life - because "they view the threat of prison as, at best, a remote one".

With each fresh insight, Dr Gill paints an ever more baffling picture of the thought processes driving a typical robber, leaving the reader feeling that most villains who pull on a balaclava and pull out a gun are far from criminal masterminds. The author highlights the contradiction. "It is slightly ironic that these robbers were being interviewed in prison and yet claimed to have found their offence relatively easy to carry out."

The book does, however, elicit interesting crime-prevention tips, especially to floor designers hoping to make buildings raid-proof. To most robbers, both amateurs and professionals, ease of escape, rather than the potential reward, is the most pressing concern. If a bank is on a street corner, it is likely to be a favoured target. "I had five directions to go. It was perfect," explained one villain.

Revolving doors, queueing rails and an L-shaped layout - meaning the robber cannot see what's creeping up behind - are just as likely to deter a robber as hi-tech security measures. Piped music is also off-putting because it affects concentration.

CCTV cameras might help detection, but they don't frighten villains. This response was typical. "I don't care if there's cameras. You can always change your appearance."

Robbers are sometimes trapped on the wrong side of rising screens (on the staff side of the counter), increasing the likelihood of violence. One prisoner recalled: "I was filling the bag with money all of a sudden, there's this terrible noise, bang, and I thought a weapon went off.

"I shouted to one of the girls, 'Look, you silly cow, get me out of here, otherwise there will be trouble.'"

This sample of robbers thought Thursdays and Fridays were the best days to strike. And almost a fifth admitted they had robbed the same place twice. "It was easy, so I went back 10 days later." Another added: "If you get a good result, you go back a second time."

The weapon of choice was a gun, but the robbers admitted using a whole range of other arms, including golf clubs, hammers, screwdrivers and baseball bats. Some simply cocked their fingers inside a jacket. Most insisted they didn't like being violent and even showed remorse and sympathy for bank staff, particularly women. "I feel hurt inside, [I worry that they might think] I'm going to come and get them or I'm going to blow them away or something."

"Have-a-go heroes", meanwhile, deserve everything they get, crooks believe. Dr Gill found that robbers viewed them "with resentment and even disbelief".

One of the most startling findings was that offenders did not seem to be discouraged by the prospect of a long prison sentence. The way prisoners deluded themselves about whether they could "go straight" when they were released was also disturbing. A mere 11.7% of the sample thought they would rob again, yet two-thirds of them had been in prison before.

The reality is that most villains regard robbery as such an easy crime, and the likelihood of being caught so low, that reoffending is worth the risk, especially when serial offenders have little prospect of getting a job once they are back in the community.

Somehow, awareness of the likelihood of capture and the inevitability of stiff sentencing needs to be raised. Some of the more professional armed robbers have cottoned on, but the vast majority have not. "Robbers are no longer the cream of the underworld and they are much more likely to be desperate people who risk long terms in prison for relatively low rewards," concludes Dr Gill. He suggests the advantages of Crimewatch must be weighed carefully. "There is no doubt that the programme has helped solve crimes, but at the same time it gives people ideas."

As one of the robbers put it: "They actually show people robbing banks and building societies and it just goes to show how easy it is if you've got a bit of nerve. I used to watch them programmes all the time, thinking, 'Well, if they can do it, I can do it.'"

Tom

Tom is a 36-year-old career robber, married with three children, serving a 14-year sentence after committing three armed robberies while on the run.

The eldest of three children, he felt his mother took her problems out on him. "She had a malicious, vicious streak through her." His father was a "gentle alcoholic". He stole from the age of five and became involved in gangs, graduating from theft, vehicle offences and burglary to commit his first robbery at 22.

He had joined the army but was drawn into burglary by a friend. His first burglary was a major turning point because it netted the two men nearly £1,000. "I lost interest in any kind of work at all. This was easy money for me. All of a sudden I could get all the things I want and I could get them now."

After six months during which he committed a burglary every night, he was caught, and served his first sentence of six months. He was thrown out of the army but managed to rejoin. He carried out a large number of commercial robberies while still in the army but eventually left.

Many robberies later, he was arrested, convicted and sentenced to seven years in prison. After he came out he went straight for nearly three years and had established a successful career in the tyre business when he was arrested for a robbery he says he hadn't committed. He escaped while in custody awaiting trial and committed three robberies. He was caught and sentenced to 14 years. He has severed all links with his family, and says: "I've got no goals any more. I've lost my way."

John

John, 28, is serving eight years for robbery. He grew up in a two-room bedsit with his mother and five brothers after his father left the family, and later with a stepfather.

John's mother told him he began stealing at two. He was first convicted at the age of 10 and taken into care. He was expelled from school at the same age and never went back, living in a series of local authority homes and detention centres. He started to commit more and more burglaries, up to eight houses a day.

At 17, in prison for burglary, he decided to move into armed robbery. "The only way we can get to the top is through crime, so we do armed robberies because we know that's where the money is for us guys, and not the white-collar guys." He became the leader of a gang of armed robbers, using the money from one job to finance a cannabis deal which doubled his money. When he was charged after a police raid, he "grassed" his ex-associates because he felt they had let him down.

He feels the system has failed to help him. "Some people say you could have got a job here or there but that's bollocks. My mind doesn't come up with the request to get a job. My mind comes up with 'let's do a job'. I've been in this for 20 years and they don't think that I need reprogramming. They don't know what to do with me. I know I need help but I'm just not getting it."

 Commercial Robbery, by Martin Gill, is published by Blackstone Press Ltd, priced £19.95.

webTitle: Levy to name names in tax feud

fields.headline: Levy to name names in tax feud
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Levy, the millionaire Labour party fundraiser, is to hand to police the names of two men who allegedly tracked down details of his tax affairs.
fields.body:
Lord Levy, the millionaire Labour party fundraiser, is to hand to police the names of two men who allegedly tracked down details of his tax affairs.

A spokesman for the music impresario, who raised millions of pounds to fund Tony Blair's office before the last general election, said that the names of the two men would be passed to Lord Levy's solicitors today. The names, which have not been released, will then be passed to the police.

Lord Levy's spokesman said yesterday that one of the men uncovered secret details about his tax affairs. These were then passed to the second man who tricked the inland revenue into confirming the details by pretending to be Lord Levy in a telephone call on June 23.

Two days later the Sunday Times sparked public debate about Lord Levy's tax affairs by reporting that he paid only £5,000 in tax last year. Lord Levy accepts that neither man was employed by the Sunday Times, but he believes that they supplied the information to the newspaper.

In an interview with BBC1's Breakfast with Frost yesterday, Lord Levy underlined his anger with the way his tax affairs had been exposed. "If someone in public life used those methods, impersonated people to get information, went out of their way to get information obtained illegally - how would those figures in public life be treated?" he asked.

However, Lord Levy faced renewed pressure yesterday over an offshore trust he set up for his children in Guernsey in the late 1980s. The millionaire denied that he had avoided paying British taxes and said that he paid full taxes when the trust was wound up and returned to Britain.

In his television interview, Lord Levy admitted that he had considered abandoning his public support for Labour. "Over the last few weeks there have been moments when I have thought, what is this all about," he said. "It's been a total invasion of my privacy, my family's privacy. But at the end of the day I do what I believe in and I support Labour."

fields.headline: Labour appeases grassroot activists
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair headed off a grassroots revolt yesterday by granting concessions to trade union leaders and Labour activists at a weekend conference called to help draw up the party's manifesto for the next election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair headed off a grassroots revolt yesterday by granting concessions to trade union leaders and Labour activists at a weekend conference called to help draw up the party's manifesto for the next election.

In a clear sign that Downing Street is heeding calls from heartland supporters, the party leadership offered concessions on workers' rights and a debate on pensions at the party conference in the autumn.

The leadership also threw its weight behind a compromise on electoral reform which kicks the issue into the long grass for up to five years.

Trade union leaders last night welcomed the outcome of the national policy forum in Exeter, saying that it allowed Labour to turn its fire on the Tories. Sir Ken Jackson, the engineering union (AEEU) leader, said: "From now on we can focus our attention on the alternative - William Hague and his extremist policies that would ruin Britain."

His upbeat remarks came after a weekend of intense bargaining between senior ministers, trade union leaders and constituency activists on a raft of policy areas.

The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, will unveil proposals to help pensioners at the Labour conference in October. Trade union leaders and activists had been spoiling for a fight with the government over the 75p increase in pensions which ministers now admit was a public relations blunder.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who chaired the weekend meeting, lowered the temperature by agreeing to the special conference debate. Mr Darling is expected to use the debate to spell out details of the government's Pensions Credit, which is designed to help pensioners with modest savings who feel they have lost out.

Government sources admitted yesterday that this group has not benefited as much as the poorest pensioners who had been targeted by the chancellor, Gordon Brown. One trade union source said: "We are now prepared to wait and see what the government comes up with. If there are genuine and significant increases, we will be happy. If not, there will be hell to pay."

The prime minister intervened to reassure trade union leaders over workers' rights. In a meeting with the general workers' union (GMB) leader, John Edmonds, Mr Blair agreed to set up a review of the procedures over company mergers and closures to ensure that workers are consulted more effectively on redundancies.

Union leaders, who have been alarmed by the lack of consultation over closures at Dagenham and Longbridge, want the government to introduce an EU directive on workers' rights which would compel companies to consult workers over redundancies. This was resisted by the prime minister, but he did agree that the review should look at which elements of the directive could be implemented in Britain.

In the final concession, the leadership accepted an amendment on electoral reform which said that no referendum would be held on changing Westminster's voting system until the new voting systems in Scotland and Wales had bedded down. This compromise was enough to appease diehard supporters of the existing first-past-the-post system, such as the AEEU's Sir Ken. He has accepted the principle of a referendum on electoral reform because he believes a poll is unlikely.

Supporters of change appear to be happy because they have won a referendum commitment. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said he was happy to wait for a referendum because the yes camp would lose at present.

There was a minor revolt at the weekend meeting when delegates managed to win enough support - more than 25% but less than 50% - for reports in seven areas. But these were areas which will not trouble the leadership, such as lowering the voting age, House of Lords reforms, rail safety, pollution, and extending the New Deal to cover schools.
