Mr Darling is expected to use the debate to spell out details of the government's Pensions Credit, which is designed to help pensioners with modest savings who feel they have lost out. Government sources admitted yesterday that this group has not benefited as much as the poorest pensioners who had been targeted by the chancellor, Gordon Brown. One trade union source said: "We are now prepared to wait and see what the government comes up with. If there are genuine and significant increases, we will be happy. If not, there will be hell to pay." The prime minister intervened to reassure trade union leaders over workers' rights. In a meeting with the general workers' union (GMB) leader, John Edmonds, Mr Blair agreed to set up a review of the procedures over company mergers and closures to ensure that workers are consulted more effectively on redundancies. Union leaders, who have been alarmed by the lack of consultation over closures at Dagenham and Longbridge, want the government to introduce an EU directive on workers' rights which would compel companies to consult workers over redundancies. This was resisted by the prime minister, but he did agree that the review should look at which elements of the directive could be implemented in Britain. In the final concession, the leadership accepted an amendment on electoral reform which said that no referendum would be held on changing Westminster's voting system until the new voting systems in Scotland and Wales had bedded down. This compromise was enough to appease diehard supporters of the existing first-past-the-post system, such as the AEEU's Sir Ken. He has accepted the principle of a referendum on electoral reform because he believes a poll is unlikely. Supporters of change appear to be happy because they have won a referendum commitment. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said he was happy to wait for a referendum because the yes camp would lose at present. There was a minor revolt at the weekend meeting when delegates managed to win enough support - more than 25% but less than 50% - for reports in seven areas. But these were areas which will not trouble the leadership, such as lowering the voting age, House of Lords reforms, rail safety, pollution, and extending the New Deal to cover schools.

webTitle: Have we taken political irony too far?

fields.headline: Have we taken political irony too far?
fields.standfirst: Robert McCrum thinks so.  He says an overdose of irony is turning us into  an infantile nation of spoiled cynics
fields.trailText: Robert McCrum thinks so.  He says an overdose of irony is turning us into  an infantile nation of spoiled cynics
fields.body:
The first thing you should know is that, married to an American, I might be presumed to live in an irony-free zone. Irony is seen as a peculiarly British trait, like tea and crumpets or the stiff upper lip. A penchant for irony seems to be one of those defining characteristics, in which the rapier thrust of the nimble-minded ironist is contrasted favourably with the lumbering blunderbuss broadsides of, for instance, the German intellectual tradition that has so influenced American public discourse.

According to the OED, irony is "a figure of speech in which the intended meaning is the opposite of that expressed by the words used". In its first recorded appearance, in Plato's Republic, it has the meaning of "a glib and underhand way of taking people in". In Plato, it's usually Socrates who takes the role of the eiron or "dissembler". He asks the naive questions that trap his interlocutor into an apprehension of the truth about things. Hence Socratic irony.

The first mention of irony in English comes in 1502: "yronye'of grammare, by whiche a man sayth one & gyveth to understande the contrarye". Situational irony flourishes in the works of all great English writers: Austen, Gibbon, Byron, Dickens, Hardy, James, Shaw, Waugh, Murdoch, Amis. Such a strong literary tradition of irony may be one reason why the English deploy it so effortlessly. Joseph Conrad makes one of his characters say in Under Western Eyes: "Remember that women, children, and revolutionists hate irony, which is the negation of faith, of all devotion, of all action."

Which is where I come in. The ironic tone that now envelops the British media - what Umberto Eco called self-expression in inverted commas - is part of a sustained assault on seriousness for the purpose of populist entertainment. There is nothing wrong with a culture of ridicule in the face of overwheening power, but when irony becomes the first, and sometimes the only mode of discourse, it clogs up the arteries of grown-up discussion.

Irony and ignorance have formed an unholy alliance. Socrates affected ignorance; the British commentariat employs an ironic knowingness to disguise a real lack of knowledge. And in parts of academia, this ramshackle instrument is all the more lethal when referred to, approvingly, as "postmodern".

I know I am describing something about which many people feel uneasy. I suspect that much of this riot of irony can be attributed to Britain's historical and cultural predicament between the years 1950 and 2000. For 200 years British cultural dominance was a recognised, and rather astounding, international phenomenon. The longshoremen who greeted arriving British transatlantic steamers with shouts of "How is Little Nell?" were not simply honouring the power of Dickens the storyteller.

The Victorian heyday of British power was, you might say, innately pompous; there was no real appetite for irony. Take away English cultural supremacy and replace it with - horrors - the dominance of a former colony and you have not just an Athens v Rome, but a David v Goliath drama in which we, the British, become the small boy hurling stones with catapults, but probably in the hope of breaking windows, not heads.

It's the misuse of irony, the debasement of the everyday currency of irony and satire that has become so troubling. There is a political dimension to this. The young satirists of the 1980s and 1990s - Spitting Image, alternative comedy, Weekending and so on - poured oceans of vitriol over the Tory party. Now that the Tories have gone this oppositional energy has given way to sarcastic indifference or plain facetiousness. I think this is of consequence because it contributes to a feeling that nothing matters, that nothing should be taken seriously, that everything is about "spin," that nothing can be changed, and that no one can be trusted. The ironic mode becomes a sort of Private Eye/Have I Got News for You meta-attitude which knows that everyone is on the make and on the take and that all politicians are bastards - it is not open to evidence or argument. This leads to an infantilisation of public discourse, exemplified by the sneering combination of irony, populism and kitsch which was the unlamented Modern Review.

But perhaps most important of all it belittles freedom, a precious thing secured in Britain after centuries of sacrifice and heroism. Irony, in its political form, is the characteristic response of writers and intellectuals to tyranny and authoritarianism - most famously in Russia, before and after 1917. We do not live in a tyranny; we live in an anti-authoritarian democracy in an age when authority has never been so constrained. We can speak to power directly, ask it questions, contradict it, present it with facts it may not like, and then kick it out at the next election. Yet judging by the ironic tone of some parts of the media (particularly, alas, the liberal media) we might be living in the high days of the Austro-Hungarian empire. We are drowning in political irony when we need it least, and it makes us seem spoiled, oblivious of how lucky we are to live in a stable, liberal democracy, during one of the most extraordinary economic booms in memory. This may have something to do with the end of ideology. Now that the big slogans have given way to a host of micro-problems it takes intellectual effort to follow politics. How much easier to give an ironic shrug.

There is an apposite cartoon in this week's New Yorker. A man in a suit is lying on the couch, telling his shrink: "Look, call it denial if you like, but I think what goes on in my personal life is, frankly, none of my business." Which brings me back to the difference between the British and the American humorous sensibility. Irony, you might say, comes with personal flippancy and emotional evasiveness, a refusal to face things squarely and an unwillingness to admit that serious concerns should be treated seriously. Yes, it's partly post-imperial; it's also connected with other trends such as dumbing down, the crisis of authority, the end of (left-wing) idealism. Above all it's a national characteristic.

The ironists point out that politicians do as much to lower our respect for them as much as any "postmodern" clever-clogs, and there's something in that. But isn't it possible that by tearing down our essentially harmless political leaders we are contributing to an alienation from political life? The ironic blast of the mass media is hard to gainsay. Perhaps John Major never acquired gravitas precisely because of the Adrian Mole spoof and Steve Bell's caricatures. The jokers claim they are simply painting a true picture of the idiocies of power but that is often not so.

Just now, history is closer to farce than tragedy but it was not always thus. Was it irreverence or the stiff upper lip that got us through two world wars and a depression? Is irony the luxury we enjoy during good times that transforms itself into an essential survival mechanism we deploy during the worst?

In our "Republic of Entertainment," in which politics (and history) merge with the 24-hour media it's inevitable that the earnestness I still want from a good part of public discourse will be contaminated by frivolity. But I will just have to live with that. This is Britain after all, with a long and distinguished tradition of irony and satire. The jokesters will always have the last laugh.

 Robert McCrum is literary editor of the Observer. This piece was edited from an exchange between Robert McCrum and Craig Brown in the current issue of Prospect magazine, www.prospect-magazine.co.uk

webTitle: Moscow gold would be better spent at home

fields.headline: Moscow gold would be better spent at home
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: It seemed, just two years ago, that Big Mac Russia had managed to do what Iron-Curtain Russia never could - bring capitalism to the point of collapse. When Moscow stuck two fingers up to the global financial markets and defaulted on its debt, the tremors were felt around the world. Stock markets collapsed, hedge funds teetered on the brink.
fields.body:
It seemed, just two years ago, that Big Mac Russia had managed to do what Iron-Curtain Russia never could - bring capitalism to the point of collapse. When Moscow stuck two fingers up to the global financial markets and defaulted on its debt, the tremors were felt around the world. Stock markets collapsed, hedge funds teetered on the brink.

In the end, full meltdown never came about, largely because America proved willing to spend the global economy out of recession. After its 15 minutes of fame, Russia ceased to be of any great interest. Everybody knew what Russia was like - backward, corrupt, crime-ridden, bristling with nuclear missiles - and there was nothing more to say.

But actually there is more to be said on the subject. Beyond the bright lights of Moscow, male life expectancy has fallen by a staggering 10 years since the break-up of the Soviet Union, opiates are arriving from Afghanistan to satisfy Russia's growing drugs habit, HIV/Aids and tuberculosis are on the increase.

For Russia's new rich, life is sweet. They have their fast cars and their fast women, they have their money safely stashed away in Switzerland and Cyprus. But Russia has no middle class, because the scientists, university lecturers and doctors who did reasonably well under the old regime have suffered from cuts in public spending, from the loss of their savings and from inflation. For the poor, life is more miserable than ever.

Russia has seen larceny on a grand scale, with valuable assets pocketed by the so-called oligarchs, and scant evidence that 10 years of hardship have succeeded in turning the country into anything approaching a market economy.

The west is in part to blame. The idea that Russia could be the test bed for every crackpot idea dreamt up by free-market economists, and that 200 years of development could be telescoped into a supercharged dash to advanced capitalism was always utterly fatuous and so it has proved. From the outset, the plan was to ensure - even if it meant handing the country over to a handful of robber barons - that all traces of communism were expunged. This has not really happened. Large chunks of the population, especially pensioners, still hanker for the "bad old days".

The new president, Vladimir Putin, is part economic liberal, part traditional Russian hard man. Some see him as the Kremlin's General Pinochet, offering a mixture of market economics and authoritarianism. Certainly, the gist of his state-of-the-nation address at the weekend suggested that he advocates an aggressive form of economic nationalism, under which the country will go it alone and win back self-esteem without recourse to "simplistic" models.

The geo-political implications of this are serious. Russia has an ageing population, and on current trends this will become a serious problem over the next three or four decades. On some estimates, the population could shrink to 90m in 40 years, with a rapidly declining number of people of working age. Evgeny Gavrilenkov, one of seven advisers appointed by Putin to chart a way forward, says that Russia could become a "buffer zone between the developed countries of the west, where the population will also be shrinking, and the poor countries of Asia and the near and middle east, where the population will be growing at rapid rates. One should not rule out the possibility that the country may also be faced with the threat of territorial claims on the part of forces with fundamentalist views, and supported by a number of orthodox regimes."

Russia now has three options. It can try to rebuild its strength by returning to a form of central planning of the economy, it can seek to make the full transition to a market economy, or hope to finesse a combination of the two.

Given that the relative decline of the Soviet economy in the 1970s and 1980s meant that it could not compete with the US even as a military-industrial complex, an attempt to turn the clock back does not seem remotely feasible, nor would it be desirable. Russia still has more restrictions on freedom than would be acceptable in the west, but the country is freer politically and the better for it.

Who can blame them?

However, establishing a fully functioning western-style economy, complete with social safety net to protect the poor from the consequences of industrial restructuring, is not going to be easy either. The Russian people feel let down by their own leaders and by those in the west who led them up the garden path in the 1990s, and who can blame them?

On the plus side, the macro-economic climate in Russia is much better now than it was two years ago. Breaking free from the deflationary policies supported by the International Monetary Fund was the best thing that could have happened to the country, since it resulted in a more competitive exchange rate that made imports dearer and encouraged growth in domestic manufacturing.

Industrial production rose by 8% last year, a rate not seen since the early 1970s, and there was growth on a broad front. Russia's problem has been that it has been good at getting things out of the ground and good at getting things out of its citizens' brains but not very good at the bit in-between. It needs to diversify out of oil and gas.

The effects of the devaluation are now petering out. The crisis left Russia with debt mountain on top of the $43bn in foreign loans that Russia inherited when the Soviet Union collapsed. Russian finance minister Alexei Kudrin got a dusty answer when he asked western finance ministers to forgive the country's Soviet era debts at the G7 summit this weekend.

Inflation is running at around 2% a month, factories are still over-manned, and large chunks of the capital stock date back to the days of the Soviet Union. The need is for investment on the scale that allowed countries in east Asia to industrialise rapidly, and this could come either from abroad or by recycling Russia's domestic savings. But foreign investors are put off by Russia's micro-economic deficiencies - the lack of a system of property rights, bankruptcy and contract laws that work, a banking system that actually provides credit. For domestic investors, it has been more profitable to send money abroad than to invest it at home, which is one reason why domestic savings are running at around 25% of gross domestic product and investment at around 15%.

It is too late to crack down on the oligarchs or to try to seize their ill-gotten gains. The best that can be hoped for is a sustained period of investment-led growth before widening income inequality and declining living standards tear the country apart. That means keeping demand strong so there is an incentive for the new rich to keep their money in the country, and a concerted attack on Russia's supply-side problems.

The west should not give up on Russia. It is a land of immense potential, but it could easily fall to pieces. Debt forgiveness would be a start. Condemning a little less and understanding a little more would be even better.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Livingstone to quit as MP
fields.body:
Livingstone to quit as MP

London mayor Ken Livingstone says he will stand down as MP for Brent East at the next election. He told ITV's Trevor McDonald Meets The Newsmakers yesterday: "Being an MP is not really a job for grown-ups - you are wandering around looking for and making trouble."

Spy questioned on killings

A former member of an undercover army intelligence unit has been arrested in connection with the murder of Catholics in Northern Ireland.

He was questioned last week about statements he made on the recent BBC TV series Brits relating to Brian Nelson, an informant in the Ulster Defence Association who was jailed for conspiracy to commit murder. The man was released without charge.

Prince's new coat of arms

A coat of arms to mark Prince William's coming of age was unveiled yesterday. It draws on the royal arms of the Queen and Prince Charles, and contains a tribute to Princess Diana in the shape of a small red escallop shell. The shell has been incorporated at the prince's insistence.

Road to the manifesto

Today's Road to the manifesto, the Guardian's unique experiment in which specialist writers draw sketches of what should form Labour's programme for a second term, will appear instead in next Monday's edition. The subject: local democracy.

Lottery rollover

The National Lottery jackpot of £8.3 million will roll over to Wednesday after no one matched the drawn numbers of 21, 30, 35, 38, 41 and 46. The bonus ball was 26. The Thunderball numbers were 9, 18, 25, 28 and 10. The Thunderball was 4.

fields.headline: Bookshops cash in on spellbinding launch
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Like one of the young sorcerer's own spells, Pottermania is producing some unexpected results in bookshops across the globe.
fields.body:
Like one of the young sorcerer's own spells, Pottermania is producing some unexpected results in bookshops across the globe.

While many stores agree that JK Rowling's Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire - the teenage wizard's fourth adventure - is the fastest selling book they have seen, the hype and hysteria surrounding the launch is driving some children to distraction.

"It's been crazy, I've been in the trade 15 years and I have never known anything like it," said Rebecca MacAlister, a Waterstone's branch manager who, like many, had extended opening hours at her store in New Street, Birmingham, over the weekend to appease demand for the book.

"We sold 600 copies on the first day, which is unbelievable. One mother rang in to say her daughter was so excited about the book coming out that she made herself sick. She was too ill to come down to the store so we are going to deliver a copy to her."

More than 1,200 copies of the 636-page hardback were sold in two days at another branch in Plymouth after six-year-old Gregory White sat in its display window to draw in passing trade.

"He absolutely loved it," said a staff member. "We gave him a chair and a copy of the book and photographers took pictures of him reading away."

In some shops copies of the book - priced £14.99 - were reported to be selling at more than 100 an hour.

Meanwhile Ms Rowling cheerfully described the start of her promotional tour in London on Saturday as "complete madess". As she boarded the Hogwarts Express - a red steam engine named after the train that takes Harry to school - squabbling broke out among press, parents and children, all jostling with police for a glimpse of the author. One mother is reported to have dangled her son from a railway bridge before being stopped by police.

A spokeswoman for Goblet's publishers, Bloomsbury, which has seen its share price increase five-fold since 1998, said: "It has been brilliant. I've never seen so many children with eyes like saucers and such huge smiles."

The Potter series has sold 21m copies in America and at one point held the top three spots on the New York Times bestseller list.

Such is the confidence in Goblet that it has been given a record-breaking first print run of 3.8m in the US alone - about twice the number for a John Grisham novel. A record 1m copies were printed in Britain in the initial run.

The Hogwarts Express is expected to bring pandemonium today to Waterstone's in Emerson Chambers, Newcastle, and to the Assembly Rooms in Edinburgh where Ms Rowling will be signing copies of her new book.

webTitle: Missing girl's family visit police nerve centre

fields.headline: Missing girl's family visit police nerve centre
fields.trailText: The brothers and sister of Sarah Payne yesterday visited the nerve centre of the police investigation into the eight-year-old's disappearance.
fields.body:
The brothers and sister of Sarah Payne yesterday visited the nerve centre of the police investigation into the eight-year-old's disappearance.

Lee, 13, Luke, 11, and Charlotte, four, barely uttered a word as they met overall-clad search officers involved in the nine-day hunt for their sister.

Their parents, Sara and Michael Payne, gave constant reassurance as the family toured Littlehampton police station. The children, who had requested the visit, were the last to have seen Sarah before she vanished from a country lane on July 1 in Kingston, West Sussex.

Detectives heading the investigation fear the girl was abducted as she made the short walk to her grandparents' house from a field in which she and her siblings had been playing.

Assistant Chief Constable Nigel Yeo said the boys had asked for the meeting as they wanted to understand the investigation better. He said: "It helps my officers to understand it is a family tragedy, a living tragedy."

As the search entered its second week and police continued to insist Operation Maple remained a "missing persons investigation", the Payne family refused to give up hope of their "little princess" being found.

A Sussex police spokesman, David Edwards, said: "There is a distinct lack of developments here. We are still getting a good response from the public but we are just missing that vital bit of information that will help us find Sarah. There may well be a nugget of information on one of the thousands of calls we are getting."

Mrs Payne, 31, praised officers and said the family was overwhelmed by the size of the operation: "You're doing everything we would do, that's the best compliment I can give you."

She later added: "We've got every confidence that it is just a matter of time. There's somebody out there, please just pick up the phone."

Sarah's grandfather, Terry Payne, made a similar appeal at a press conference on Saturday. He said: "It's tearing our family apart. Somebody's got Sarah and we want her back."

As cards and letters of hope flooded in from around the world, villagers gathered at the church in East Preston to pray for the Payne family and the safe return of their missing child.

Meanwhile police were deluged by calls after a reconstruction of the crime on Friday and road checks over the weekend. DNA test results were also arriving on a daily basis.

Police confirmed there had been more than 4,500 calls, including leads on two new witnesses, and more than 600 separate tasks had been given to officers.

New posters and leaflets about Sarah's case were distributed to revellers at the Littlehampton carnival on Saturday and police reiterated an appeal for help in tracing the drivers of a white van and a grey Ford Mondeo car, both seen close to where the youngster went missing.

A family photo taken by Sarah's brother, Luke, showing Sarah and her sister Charlotte hugging, was also released.

Mrs Payne was expected to return to Littlehampton police station today for a news conference at which she plans to read from the thousands of letters of support.

fields.headline: Missile system flop boosts protesters
fields.trailText: Looking at first like a spectacular shooting star with its own vapour trail hurtling through the night sky off the Californian coast, it was the world's most expensive fireworks display and it has ignited an international political and scientific furore.
fields.body:
Looking at first like a spectacular shooting star with its own vapour trail hurtling through the night sky off the Californian coast, it was the world's most expensive fireworks display and it has ignited an international political and scientific furore.

The Minuteman II missile that was launched from Vandenberg air force base near Santa Barbara in southern California at the weekend was part of a £66m missile defence test. The dummy warhead was meant to have been destroyed in a 16,000 mile-an-hour collision by an interceptor rocket fired from the Pacific atoll of Kwajelien 4,500 miles away. But the interception failed because the "kill vehicle" did not separate from the rocket.

The failure has provided useful ammunition for opponents of the scheme who see it as an unnecessary escalation of nuclear capabilities promoted for bogus reasons by the military-industrial complex. It has also been hinted that President Bill Clinton is far from displeased with the flop because it allows him room to defer support for a missile defence system about which he has always been lukewarm.

Pentagon officials, who had watched the flight in silence from a basement in Washington, were trying to put a brave face on it yesterday. Lieutenant-General Ronald Kadish, the director of the Ballistic Missile Defence Organisation, said: "We're disappointed."

He added frankly that the failure of the kill vehicle to separate was "not even on my list" of things that might have gone wrong. "It did not receive a necessary electronic signal."

A White House spokesman said after the test that "a hit doesn't automatically suggest success. Nor does a failure automatically come with a miss".

Presidential candidate George W Bush, a big supporter of "Star Wars", said that the test had been "a disappointment". Al Gore said that he did not want to pre-empt analysis of what had gone wrong.

Leading members of the scientific community in the US have also attacked the tests.

And there was wide condemnation internationally.

Officials in Moscow said Saturday's failure showed it was impossible to create an impenetrable anti-missile shield.

A US official in China for arms control talks said after the test failure that Beijing reiterated its opposition to NMD. "They were clear, as they have been publicly, on their position on National Missile Defence. They don't like the idea," senior US arms control adviser John Holum said.

webTitle: Gene screening 'could cut cystic fibrosis by half'

fields.headline: Gene screening 'could cut cystic fibrosis by half'
fields.trailText: A leading health researcher has attacked as a "scandal" the government's failure to launch a genetic screening programme which he said could cut the number of children born with the painful, life-shortening disease cystic fibrosis by half.
fields.body:
A leading health researcher has attacked as a "scandal" the government's failure to launch a genetic screening programme which he said could cut the number of children born with the painful, life-shortening disease cystic fibrosis by half.

Howard Cuckle, professor of reproductive epidemiology at Leeds University, said he was angered that last month's excitement at the deciphering of the human genome glossed over existing, medically important knowledge of our genes which the NHS was refusing to use.

"It's quite scandalous that there's been all this hype about the genome project and enormous expectations of how it's going to change things, and yet we've known for more than 10 years the gene responsible for cystic fibrosis and we're not screening for it," he said.

Prof Cuckle's support for screening is controversial because abortion is used to reduce the number of cystic fibrosis cases.

"We should be offering all expectant couples pre-birth screening so they can prevent the birth of a child with cystic fibrosis," he said. "There have been 11 studies of this and they've all shown a high up take... We can't prevent the disease as such, but we can prevent people being born with this disease."

Sufferers from cystic fibrosis, which causes a thick build-up of easily infected mucus in the lungs and prevents the digestion of food, have an average life expectancy of around 30 years. They require constant medication and violent physical therapy, experience frequent infections, and, without a life-extending lung transplant, usually die from respiratory failure.

There are around 7,500 sufferers in Britain, with 250 more born each year. Mutations in the gene involved are relatively common - one in 24 people have them - and if two carriers have a child, the chance of it having cystic fibrosis is one in four.

In Edinburgh, the only city in the UK where screening is offered to all expectant couples, the number of children born with the disease has fallen sharply, from an average of 4.6 a year to 1.6.

Not all the fall can be accounted for by terminations - the implication is that couples with affected genes but a healthy baby chose not to have more children together.

Last year the government-appointed national screening committee rejected a report commissioned by the NHS from Prof Cuckle and colleagues which recommended screening.

But the committee will discuss the issue again this year. Its director, Muir Gray, said it supported offering parents an informed choice over abortion, but feared being seen as promoting eugenics - the now discredited pseudo-science of breeding "better" human populations.

Screening for Down's syndrome is routine, and mass screening for spina bifida, introduced in the 1970s, cut the incidence of the disabling disease by 95% through abortion.

Dr Gray questioned whether it would be so easy to introduce spina bifida screening in today's social climate. "The eugenic dimension of screening has become more of an issue. Is it right to give people the choice to abort those who are deemed less valuable by society?"

The Cystic Fibrosis Trust, the main charity involved in work on the disease, is a passive supporter of screening but is reluctant to lobby for it because of the link to abortion.

Prof Cuckle said: "In the war against congenital abnormalities, screening is a kind of holding operation. It's temporary and we hope in the end to have cures, but meanwhile thousands of affected individuals are being born every year."

fields.headline: Siege boosts Sharif's wife
fields.standfirst: Pakistan: special report
fields.trailText: The wife of Pakistan's deposed prime minister Nawaz Sharif was penned in her Lahore home last night, surrounded by armed police desperate to stop her leading an anti-government rally.
fields.body:
The wife of Pakistan's deposed prime minister Nawaz Sharif was penned in her Lahore home last night, surrounded by armed police desperate to stop her leading an anti-government rally.

Police detained Kulsoom Sharif for 10 hours, at one point using a crane to tow away her Toyota car while she sat inside it with colleagues. Officers arrested at least 200 members of her husband's Pakistan Muslim League to stop the rally going ahead.

Riot police raided a Muslim League meeting in Rawalpindi and detained another 30 people. Party workers say up to 1,000 people have been detained nationwide since Friday.

What would have been a small-scale protest quickly turned into an ugly demonstration of the tough arm of the military, which seized power in a coup in October.

The operation comes just days after the British government lifted the arms embargo on Pakistan and agreed to resume supplies of naval and other equipment.

Last night Mrs Sharif insisted she would try again to stage the rally, in which a motorcade would have driven 300 miles from Lahore to Peshawar, in north-west Pakistan.

"I want to say to the military government that their days are numbered. They have to go back to the barracks and allow the political process to continue," she said.

Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, suspended parliament immediately after the coup and this year banned political rallies. Nawaz Sharif has been jailed for life on charges of hijacking and terrorism, and now faces a string of corruption charges.

Party support for his wife has been limited and she has not appeared a serious threat to the regime. But the police crackdown may have improved her credibility.

"Kulsoom Nawaz, who only two days ago was flailing in a destructive intra-party storm, is wearing the badge of a lady-leader who can make iron men run for extra security measures," the newspaper the News said.

Police began their operation with dawn raids on Friday, arresting dozens of party workers across Lahore, the Sharif stronghold. Armed officers surrounded one of the family's houses, in the city's smart Model Town suburb, and disconnected the telephone lines.

But on Saturday Mrs Sharif slipped through the cordon and led police on a 10-mile car chase across the city before the road was blocked. She refused to leave her car and so police attached a crane to the front bumper and hauled it to a police compound.

After a 10-hour standoff she was allowed to drive home. "Hundreds of police are still surrounding our home. We are under house arrest," Mrs Sharif's 26-year-old daughter Mariam Safdar said last night.

"But my mother has now become a greater leader. She has more determination, more courage and I think more popularity."

fields.headline: 'Lord Woodbine'
fields.trailText: Harold Phillips, 'Lord Woodbine', entrepreneur, born 1928; died July 5 2000
fields.body:
A walk-on part in the Beatles' rise to fame brought "Lord Woodbine", who has died in a house fire aged 72, to a wider public than his talents might ordinarily have warranted. There were fleeting mentions of him in biographies of the group, and, in 1995, Paul McCartney spoke of him with affection in the Anthology television series. The previous year, Woodbine had been represented in Backbeat, a biopic of the Beatles' Hamburg period, by actor Charlie Caine, resplendent in sharkskin suit and snap-brim hat.

As plain Harold Phillips, he arrived in Liverpool from Trinidad in 1948. Ennobling himself as "Lord Woodbine" - after the cheap cigarettes he chain-smoked - he quickly established himself as one of the city's characters. As a builder and decorator, and a calypso singer and barman in Toxteth's rougher shebeens (where he defused unrest by brandishing a cutlass), he formed the All-Steel Caribbean Band, who were resident in his own New Colony Club. He also booked the Beatles, then a scruffy bunch who often turned up with only half their equipment or a member short.

The All-Steel band also played evening sessions in the basement of the Jaca-randa, a coffee-bar venture run by Allan Williams. After Woodbine left, it remained there, as the Royal Caribbean Steel Band, until 1960, when they were noticed by a German sailor and poached by a Hamburg club agent.

The band reported the recreational delights of their new-found home to Woodbine back in Liverpool. Sniffing a business opportunity, he and Williams decamped to the Reeperbahn, where they were soon negotiating with local promoters to bring over more accomplished Liverpool groups. This new enterprise began with a season by Derry Wilkie and the Seniors at Bruno Koschmider's Kaiserkeller.

Back on Merseyside, the Beatles were, twice nightly, accompanying a Mancunian stripper at Williams's and Woodbine's New Cabaret Artists Club. Because they had so gamely gone through this tasteless assignment, their employers were convinced that the group was no longer, as George Harrison would say, "hopefully messing about."

When Koschmider requested a group for another of his Hamberg clubs, Woodbine drove the then five Beatles - drummer Pete Best, bass player Stuart Sutcliffe and guitarists Harrison, McCartney and John Lennon - to Germany in an overloaded minibus. Conditions were dire; the musicians' accommodation was in pokey rooms adjoining a cinema toilet, and, initially, there was an onstage mutiny by the band. But the necessity of keeping up the equivalent of an all-night party atmosphere for their audience began the transformation of the Beatles from clumsy provincials to a peerless live act and a potential chart proposition.

Woodbine, however, was all but lost to the archives of oblivion, though his daughter, Barbara, was to surface as a playwright whose work includes episodes for Brookside. Well placed to grow fat on Beatlemania, her father instead chose to continue living on his wits around Toxteth. He never guested at any of the Beatles conventions, and, unlike others less qualified, resisted the chance to cash in on the group's fame.

His wife, Helen, died with him in the fire.

 Harold Phillips, 'Lord Woodbine', entrepreneur, born 1928; died July 5 2000

Woodbine, however, was all but lost to the archives of oblivion, though his daughter, Barbara, was to surface as a playwright whose work includes episodes for Brookside. Well placed to grow fat on Beatlemania, her father instead chose to continue living on his wits around Toxteth. He never guested at any of the Beatles conventions, and, unlike others less qualified, resisted the chance to cash in on the group's fame. His wife, Helen, died with him in the fire.  Harold Phillips, 'Lord Woodbine', entrepreneur, born 1928; died July 5 2000

fields.headline: Michael Ripper
fields.standfirst: Actor with a flair for horror and humour
fields.trailText: Michael Ripper, actor, born January 27 1913; died June 28 2000
fields.body:
Hammer horror fans are familiar with the aptly-named supporting actor Michael Ripper, who has died aged 87, one of the stalwarts of that most commercially successful of all British film companies. In fact, he appeared - rather than featured or starred - in more Hammer pictures than any other performer.

Short and stocky, with a big head and bulging eyes, Ripper was often the victim of Draculas, mummies, Frankenstein monsters and werewolves. In The Mummy's Shroud (1967), he was dropped from a window by the mummy, while in The Curse Of The Werewolf (1961), as a drunk, he was thrown into the same prison cell as the powerfully snarling werewolf (Oliver Reed).

In the early 1950s, Ripper, once a heavy smoker, developed a thyroid condition for which he had to have an operation. "When I came out of it, I could only talk in a whisper," he recalled. "It got a little better, of course, but I didn't really sound like a human being - so all I could do was horror."

Apart from the period Hammer movies, he popped up in a plethora of British pictures, as all sorts of servants, pub landlords, petty crooks and coppers. Mainly, however, his blunt looks, cast him as a low-ranking army officer, notably as the nervous soldier guarding the pulsating radioactive blob in X The Unknown (1956), and the sergeant in Quatermass II (1957), one of three feature film spin-offs from the Nigel Kneale BBC television series, Quatermass, in which Ripper was a regular.

Ripper was born in Portsmouth, where his father worked in the Admiralty. By the age of 14, he had already decided to leave school and become an actor. His understanding parents allowed him to study at the Central School of Speech and Drama, from which he graduated at 16 and joined Folkestone rep.

While working in the theatre, Ripper made his screen debut in a "quota quickie" called Twice Branded (1935), starring James Mason in his second film. Shortly before the war, after a dozen or more of such justifiably forgotten films, many of them directed by P Maclean Rogers, he was invited to the Gate theatre, Dublin, where Rogers had become a producer. It was there that the 27-year-old played Hamlet. After the war, he returned to England, where he appeared regularly in films, especially those by the producer-director team of Frank Launder and Sidney Gilliat.

Among them was The Story Of Gilbert And Sullivan (1953), in which Ripper played Sullivan's manservant, and Albert, the cheeky stable lad, in The Belles Of St Trinians (1954).

In Laurence Olivier's Richard III (1955), Ripper was Forrest, the second murderer, who stuffs the corpse of the Duke of Clarence (John Gielgud) in a barrel of malmsey, and one of the "bloody dogs" who kills the young princes in the Tower of London. A few years later, in The Anatomist (1961), he was the grave-robbing Hare, supplying corpses to Dr Alastair Sim. Among his other films of the 60s was The Secret Of Blood Island, as an evil Japanese soldier, The Reptile, The Plague Of The Zombies, and Dracula Has Risen From The Grave.

On television, Ripper impressed as the patient chauffeur-confidante of married Wendy Craig's admirer in Butterflies (1978) and, more recently, he was the seen-it-all porter of the Drones club in the Jeeves and Wooster series. One of his last roles was as oldtimer Tony Bonaparte, in No Surrender (1985), an effective parable of the Northern Ireland conflict.

Ripper is survived by his third wife and a daughter by his first marriage.

fields.headline: Richard Levin
fields.standfirst: Designer who gave the BBC its visual identity and revolutionised programme presentation
fields.trailText: Richard Levin, designer and photographer, born December 31 1910; died July 2 2000
fields.body:
Richard Levin, who has died at the age of 89, was head of design for BBC Television from 1953 to 1971, and thus the individual who set the visual stamp on the service throughout its great period of expansion and innovation, including the switch from black-and-white to colour in 1967-69.

Television "design" in those days meant everything from the scenery for a grand opera to the seating plan for a panel game or the graphics illustrating a plain man's guide to the economy. It could be sinister Martian creatures in a Quatermass serial or a new set for the teenage pop show, Six-Five Special, to help young viewers feel a part of the proceedings rather than merely spectators.

Levin, always "Dick" to his friends and colleagues, drove it all along by sheer enthusiasm, energy and a disregard for red tape. "He was a nightmare to the administrators," according to his widow, the former BBC producer Patricia Foy, but a steadfast supporter of such gifted des- igners as Clifford Hatts, Natasha Kroll, Eileen Diss, Stephen Taylor, Richard Greenough and the special-effects wizard Jack Kine.

He was also a good talent spotter, often finding future designers among the ranks of scene-painters and carpenters. George Wisner, then a 16-year-old apprentice carpenter, and later head of design at the BBC's Open University unit, worked on the 1955 Miss World Contest, which Levin always liked to handle in person, however politically incorrect the occasion was beginning to be seen.

That year, his white felt carpeting on the elaborate staging in the Albert Hall was found to be irretrievably soiled by the end of rehearsals and had to be replaced in time for the show next day. Wisner and the other lads worked through the night, "scared stiff", he remembers, because the hall was rumoured to be haunted and they kept hearing mysterious sounds from beneath the auditorium.

From the age of seven, when he was given a box camera, the young Levin was devoted to photography. He left Clayesmore public school at 17 to become a trainee with Gaumont-British Films. There he was attracted to the design side, rose to be an assistant art director and, after studying at the Slade and in Paris, entered the world of industrial and exhibition design, including, prophetically, a stint with the prewar television service at Alexandra Palace.

During the war, he worked for the Air Ministry as a camouflage officer and for the Ministry of Information as an exhibition designer. For the 1951 Festival of Britain he designed the travelling exhibition The Land, which earned him an OBE.

Two years later, just as television was taking off, he got the opportunity to rejoin the BBC at the top. Though "design" embraced every aspect of television output, it was in drama, variety and big spectacles that it was most noticed. Levin found that painted scenery flats were still the norm. In the cramped little studios of Alexandra Palace, there had been no alternative, but now Lime Grove and Riverside were available there was no need for such two-dimensional illusion. He set about giving plays, especially, three- dimensional sets, in which the camera could move about as a privileged observer.

In 1960, he published a book, Television By Design, in which he pointed out that the designer's talents existed to serve the needs of the writer and director. For the majority of these clients, and certainly most viewers, that meant absolute realism.

Anticipating the agitation for more expressive forms of storytelling which would arise a few years later, however, Levin looked forward to a time when the designer might contribute to the initial concept of a programme. He set up specialist photographic and graphics units, personally designed the BBC logo and conducted experiments with a widescreen format. Michael Barry, then head of drama, was enthusiastic but, with colour on the horizon, there was no money to pursue the project.

Another of Levin's sidelines, rather unusual in a BBC department head, was to always carry his camera with him and take portraits of all the great and famous who came to the studios. When he finally retired from broadcasting, he turned this lifelong hobby into his profession, specialising in portraiture. He was elected a Royal Designer for Industry (RDI) in 1971, and awarded the Royal Television Society's Silver Medal the following year.

Away from the studios, of whatever sort, his passion was fishing, though he had many other enthusiasms and played a variety of musical instruments. "That man," Huw Wheldon once said of him, "invented the word 'hobbies'."

Levin was married twice, first to Evelyn Alexander, with whom he had two daughters, and later, in 1960, to Patricia Foy.

fields.headline: Terry Coppock
fields.standfirst: Geographer driven by concern for man's abuse of the landscape
fields.trailText: John Terence 'Terry' Coppock, geographer, born June 2 1921; died June 28 2000
fields.body:
The geographer, John Terence "Terry" Coppock, who has died aged 79, had a consuming passion with agriculture. In 1964, he produced the Agricultural Atlas Of England And Wales, and went on to develop some of the earliest forms of computer-based mapping in the world.

The examiners for his DSc - awarded by London University in 1999 on the basis of a lifetime's work - quoted from an American publication: "Coppock first came to appreciate the need for electronic aids to analysis after making attempts to analyse results in map form from his land-use survey of the Chiltern hills in 1954. At the end of the 1950s, he analysed about half a million records from the agricultural census using an early computer in London University. His work may be the earliest substantive geographical information system (GIS) based research."

Today, GIS - including computer mapping - is a $10bn turnover branch of the information and communication technologies industry, growing annually at a rate of 20%. In later years, Coppock's involvement led to the first GIS master's degree programme in the world, at Edinburgh university, and he became founding editor of the first journal in the field, the international Journal Of Geographical Information Science.

Known as "Terry" to everyone who knew him, Coppock was born and went to school in Penarth, south Wales. He became a civil servant in the Lord Chancellor's Department, the Ministry of Works and the Customs and Excise. Commissioned in 1941 in the Welsh Regiment, he counted himself immensely fortunate to go to Queens' College, Cambridge in 1947, at the age of 26. This opened his eyes to the challenge and excitement of scholarship and he pursued his new vocation as a junior member of staff at University College, London, in 1950. Soon after the production of the agricultural atlas, he was made Ogilvie professor of geography at the University of Edinburgh, where he remained from 1965 to 1986.

His life's work was essentially concerned with man's use and abuse of the landscape. In all his academic work, he demonstrated an impressive ability to operate either at the micro scale, delving into great detail, or at the broad synoptic scale. Much of the latter stemmed from his recognition, during the 1960s, of the increasing potential conflict between maintaining a viable agricultural economy and providing space for rural recreation to meet the demands of the fast-growing numbers of car-owning families. His foundation of the tourism and recreation research unit at Edinburgh produced important research results and trained many staff who have gone on to illustrious careers.

Coppock was always clear that there was much to be learned and discussed with fellow geographers around the world, a belief that occasionally led to difficulties. One of his colleagues was once asked to confirm whether he had held a tutorial at Edinburgh airport between two flights. In fact, the answer was in the negative; the tutorial took place at Edinburgh Waverley station.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, given his pragmatic, yet research-based, approach, and his understanding of government, Coppock served on many official inquiries, including being special adviser to the select committee on Scottish affairs, a member of the Ordnance Survey review committee and the Sports Council. He also represented the British Academy and Royal Society. When he retired in 1986, he became secretary and treasurer of the Carnegie Trust for the Universities of Scotland.

Coppock received many honours for his distinguished service, notably the CBE in 1987. Both Edinburgh and Glasgow universities awarded him honorary doctorates in 1999. He was one of the first geographers elected as a fellow of the British Academy.

My memories of him are as much about comradeship as business. He was a man wholly without malice and deviousness, someone who helped many others to fulfil their potential. In his chosen area he made major contributions to scholarship, policy and practice at national and international level. He was also good company - my abiding memory of him remains, as a septuagenarian, joyously flying kites with my two young daughters.

Coppock's wife, Sheila Mary Burnett, died in 1990. He is survived by a son and a daughter.

webTitle: Fiji coup leader signs peace deal

fields.headline: Fiji coup leader signs peace deal
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: The man who held Fiji's government hostage for 52 days was unable to hold back a smile yesterday as he signed a deal in which he pledged to release his captives in return for the destruction of the country's multi-racial democracy.
fields.body:
The man who held Fiji's government hostage for 52 days was unable to hold back a smile yesterday as he signed a deal in which he pledged to release his captives in return for the destruction of the country's multi-racial democracy.

Commodore Frank Bainimarama, the military head of state, looked morose as he bowed to George Speight's demands to disenfranchise Fiji's ethnic Indian minority.

Mr Speight acknowledged that Fiji would be shunned abroad, but was unrepentant.

"It is a path that has begun in a manner which to the world at large ... they do not condone or accept," Mr Speight said. "I totally understand that."

The military, which took control of Fiji 10 days after Mr Speight and six other gunmen stormed parliament, agreed to scrap the country's multiracial constitution, depose its first prime minister of ethnic Indian descent and grant Mr Speight and his men immunity from prosecution.

Mr Speight said he would release his 27 hostages - including the deposed prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry - and turn in his rebels' arms.

The hostages will be freed on Thursday, before tribal chiefs meet to choose a new president and to name an interim government to guide Fiji to elections under a new constitution curtailing ethnic Indian political rights.

Fiji will almost certainly be hit with sanctions from countries including the US as well as the European Union, which buys Fijian sugar, the country's cash crop, at inflated prices.

The fate of 28 other hostages, snatched on Saturday, was unclear, but Mr Speight is likely to order their release too.

webTitle: Just wait and see, says Sir Clive

fields.headline: Just wait and see, says Sir Clive
fields.standfirst: After two years at the CBI, the outspoken chairman of Rentokil Initial is returning to rescue his company
fields.trailText: To his detractors who have gleefully watched the company's share price plummet in the two years since he became president of the Confederation of British Industry, Rentokil Initial chairman Sir Clive Thompson has a typically pugnacious reply: just look at the upside at 12.45pm on July 18.
fields.body:
To his detractors who have gleefully watched the company's share price plummet in the two years since he became president of the Confederation of British Industry, Rentokil Initial chairman Sir Clive Thompson has a typically pugnacious reply: just look at the upside at 12.45pm on July 18.

At that precise moment, Sir Clive, who denies his company's disappointing performance has anything to do with his spending too much time hobnobbing with world leaders, will hand over the reins of the organisation to Sir Iain Vallance, chairman of BT.

Then, he pledges in an end-of-term interview, he will devote all his energy to repairing his and his company's reputation after the battering it took from the abandonment last year of its long standing target of 20% annual earnings growth.

He has no shortage of plans to inject some vigour back into the flagging share price, including beefing up the business services group's acquisition team, which has up to £1bn to spend, and the launch of a series of e-commerce activities at the half-year stage in August. "I can see an exciting time ahead for Rentokil Initial shareholders," said Sir Clive.

In the meantime he is still wearing his other hat as the leader of Britain's captains of industry and clearly delighting in cementing his reputation as an aggressive, if charming, individualist - and a thorn in the government's side.

A devout free-marketeer, Sir Clive, unlike his emollient predecessor, Lord Marshall, chairman of British Airways, has not been afraid to say uncomfortable things in public, surprising Tony Blair and John Monks, general secretary of the TUC, at the CBI's annual dinner two years ago by comparing unions to the pests his company chases.

He said this was meant as a joke but it was a remark which confirmed the view that some in government have of him as an unreconstructed Thatcherite. Certainly, he is no fan of trade unions.

"I have got many friends in the trade union movement. I think they are warm, fun people with good leadership skills... but I see the trade union movement as being a declining activity in the way a number of businesses are in decline," says Sir Clive.

"I think it's wrong for them to be propped up in the same way that it's wrong to prop up lame ducks in business. If the market has a declining need for them, they should be allowed to decline in the same way," he says. "At the same time, employees have a right, and I do mean a right, to be consulted on those issues which directly affect their employment."

Having consistently criticised new union legislation and a range of other labour market regulation brought in by Labour, including the minimum wage, Sir Clive keeps up the attack to the end of his presidency.

The government is considering including in its next manifesto pledges to introduce paid parental leave and the automatic right to part-time work for returning mothers.

But Sir Clive says this would be a mistake, harming not only the people the laws are meant to protect, but also the economy as a whole by slowing the development of the new hi-tech industries and their capacity to generate wealth.

"It's safer to get the economy to grow and then to improve people's working conditions rather than improve people's living standards and then expect the economy to grow within that," says Sir Clive.

"If you protect jobs in old industries people won't leave to join the new economy. You get stuck with the decline and you don't get the upside. If one has to apply a generalisation it would be: don't cut back on the opportunity by wishing to be over-concerned about the status quo."

Even when he broadly agrees with government policy, on the principle of joining the euro, Sir Clive is critical.

While sympathising with the government's dilemma - keep quiet for fear of upsetting sceptical voters or take on the eurosceptics to prepare public opinion for entry soon after the next election - he expresses disappointment at the way the warm body language of Tony Blair's national changeover plan announcement in February 1999 has cooled since the heavy defeat suffered by Labour in the European elections.

With reputable bodies such as the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development suggesting the British economy is moving into line with euroland, Sir Clive thinks the time is ripe for ministers to set a firm target date for entering the euro.

At the same time, they could begin discussing in public an appropriate entry rate as a way of persuading the markets to deliver it.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: New firms unfazed by euro
fields.body:
New firms unfazed by euro

New-economy companies considering whether to invest in Britain are unconcerned about whether the country joins the euro, according to computer industry consultant Richard Holway who has found that the single currency "barely merits a mention" among chief executives of a range of software and computer companies.

Workers' skills and flexibilities are much more important to the firms.

Flotations hit four-year high

The number of companies floating on the London stock exchange has reached its highest level for four years, according to figures from KPMG. The accountancy firm reports that 36 companies joined the market in the second quarter, raising £2.86bn.

Forever to launch on Aim

Forever Broadcasting, a radio company linked to the former Sun editor Kelvin MacKenzie, is to float on AIM with a market capitalisation of between £20m and £30m. Forever runs two stations: Liverpool-based Juice 107.6FM and Tower, serving Bolton and Bury.

fields.headline: Mainstream Iran joins student protests
fields.trailText: A new challenge to President Mohammed Khatami's government has emerged in the wake of demonstrations at the weekend in central Tehran, where thousands of Iran's poor joined university students in a bloody battle with Islamic extremists.
fields.body:
A new challenge to President Mohammed Khatami's government has emerged in the wake of demonstrations at the weekend in central Tehran, where thousands of Iran's poor joined university students in a bloody battle with Islamic extremists.

The spontaneous coalition on Saturday night of students and ordinary Iranians demanding improved social conditions marked a turning point in the struggle to redefine the Islamic Republic.

A year ago, it was primarily students who demanded more freedom and political reform, as they spilled their blood on the nation's campuses and city streets. Now, the cries for profound change are coming from mainstream society.

Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, summoned President Khatami and senior government officials to his residence yesterday to discuss the crisis. State radio said the ayatollah blamed the demonstration on foreign "enemies" and called on the nation and the government to remain on high alert.

President Khatami flies to Berlin today, where he is expected to face more protests from as many as 25,000 members of emigre groups who have been exiled from Iran.

The visit will be the first to Germany by an Iranian leader since 1967 and, to stem the possibility of public unrest, one official said 6,000 dissidents had already been stopped from travelling to Berlin, where security will be even tighter than during President Clinton's visit last month.

Even before Saturday's protest in Tehran, which left dozens seriously injured after Islamic vigilantes used clubs to beat back the protesters, sporadic demonstrations against electricity shortages and sub-standard drinking water had erupted in a number of Iranian cities, including in the oil centre, Abadan, near the Iraqi border.

The demonstrations were planned to mark the first anniversary of pro-democracy rallies on July 8 last year, which sparked six days of the worst unrest since the 1979 Islamic Revolution.

The leading student group, the Office to Consolidate Unity, had organised the rally to honour the hundreds of students injured when the police, aided by Islamic vigilantes, broke into dormitories at Tehran University and beat the residents, some as they slept.

President Khatami and his allies had tried to head off public protest, predicting that the peaceful rallies could turn bloody. In a prophetic speech last week, Mr Khatami warned his conservative rivals that Iranians were dissatisfied and this discontent could no longer be contained by force.

"We must not expect the people to behave as we would like, and [threaten] to suppress them if they don't," he said.

"People must be allowed to speak freely and criticise their government. If people are left unsatisfied, this will one day lead to an explosion."

The explosion on Saturday was directed not only at the hardline clerical establishment but also at President Khatami, who was criticised for failing to make profound changes to the system.

"The clerics live like kings, while the people are reduced to poverty," shouted the crowd. Other chants followed: "Khatami, Khatami, show your power or resign," and "Khatami, Khatami, this is the final notice".

The president's weakness was on public display, as hundreds of Islamic vigilantes from the Ansar-e Hizbullah and the basij, an Islamic militia, took over Revolution Square, where the demonstrators had gathered. They beat the protesters with clubs and threatened them with lengths of electrical cable and wooden staves, weapons delivered to the scene in state-owned vehicles, including ambulances.

Once again, it was evident that President Khatami's policy of "rule of law" had taken a back seat to the hardliners' brute force. The president does not control the armed forces; that power lies with Ayatollah Khamenei, who is closely aligned with the conservatives.

Masoud Dehnamaki, a leader in the Ansar-e Hizbullah, said last week that the extremists have not even begun to confront the reformist movement, despite numerous violent acts for which they have claimed responsibility.

"The leader of the Islamic revolution has invited all to respect the bounds of morality," he said, justifying the extremists' activities.

fields.headline: Killer algae hit California
fields.trailText: Scientists in the US are battling to contain a virulent and noxious species of algae that has already destroyed tens of thousands of acres of seabed in the Mediterranean and has suddenly surfaced in California.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in Santa Barbara, California
fields.body:
Scientists in the US are battling to contain a virulent and noxious species of algae that has already destroyed tens of thousands of acres of seabed in the Mediterranean and has suddenly surfaced in California.

It is believed that the outbreak in California may have been caused by someone dumping the water from their private aquarium into a storm drain. The algae, which are attractive to look at, were originally developed by biologists in Germany at the Stuttgart Zoo aquarium because they made a luxurious green bed for display tanks.

"It is a very serious potential problem," said Bob Hoffman of the National Marine Fisheries Service in San Diego yesterday. "It could have a dramatic impact. There is not yet an established method of controlling it."

At risk are marine plant life and creatures on the seabed as the algae kill seaweed, coral, clams and shrimps.

The rich, dark-green algae, caulerpa taxifolia, were discovered in the Agua Hedionda lagoon 35 miles north of San Diego. They were first identified by a marine biologist working for an environmental consultancy which had been employed by a power company in Carlsbad to organise a project to restore the lagoon with transplanted eelgrass.

Although the algae have been banned for sale in the US by an executive order from President Bill Clinton, they can be bought through the internet and is popular with aquarium owners.

"It could have come from someone clearing out their aquarium and putting it in the gutter," said Mr Hoffman, who believes the alga could have been carried into the lagoon in a storm drain. He said that they were attempting to contain the spread of the algae by covering them with tarpaulins and injecting a powerful herbicide under the cover.

There had been only two other outbreaks, one in the Mediterranean and one in Australia. The Mediterranean outbreak took place in the 1980s and followed an accidental discharge from the Oceanographic Museum in Monaco. That outbreak damaged around 4,050 hectares (10,000 acres) of seabed off the coasts of Spain, France, Monaco and Italy.

The algae - or "killer algae" as they are known in California - consume oxygen and kill sea life that fish eat. They spread much faster than other species and are able to exist in colder waters, making them much more dangerous. One theory is that the species has mutated because of exposure to the ultraviolet lighting used in many aquariums.

It is not harmful to people.

Although the growth of the species has been caught early in the US, Mr Hoffman said he would not know for at least two weeks whether efforts to kill it off have been successful. He said it was difficult to predict that they would be "100% successful" in their attempts.
